description:
So happy this place opened up in Stonestown!

Although there were super long lines when it first opened, I find that the hype has died down a little. Wait times are usually no more than fifteen to twenty minutes on a week day. 

Ordering is through an assembly line style where you pick your noodle base then pick up various tempura choices before reaching the cashier. It is a large restaurant with ample seating.

My favorites are the kake udon and niku udon. Prices are super reasonable and the noodles are freshly made and great quality. The chicken tempura and potato croquettes are so good.
author: Christina G.

description:
Although I am really into ramen, I was not really a udon person until I tried this place!

Since its soft opening, I seem to come to this place at least 3-4 times a month. Although the wait could be long at times (especially on Friday and weekend nights - 40-1hr wait), if you come right at the time when they open or at 5-5:30PM in other weekdays, there seems to be only 5-10 minutes or barely any wait. 

The first thing you would hear as you open the door would be "FRESH UDON!" It is in a food-court style in which you come in a line to first order your udon, choose your tempura/musubi, and pay at the cashier. Then, there is a little bar with toppings and sauces, including green onions, tempura flakes, tempura sauce...etc. 

Every time I come here, this is what I always get:
1) Nikutama udon, hot, regular (you can just say "#8 regular") 
- It comes w/ sweet beef, caramelized onions, and soft-boiled egg in Bukkake sauce and kake soup that is not too sweet. It is VERY flavorful! Since they make their own noodles, it is very FRESH and CHEWY! You can actually see them rinsing the noodles w/ cold water a lot to give that chewy texture. They also give you enough beef, which is a big plus for me:)
2) Squid tempura (my favorite!!!)
- In many restaurants, I see that the batter is too thick with not much filling inside. Here, the squid fills up the whole space and the batter is not too thick! Complements greatly to its sweet tempura sauce that you can get from the bar.
3) Mentaiko musubi
- I recommend this to anyone who loves mentaiko (pollock roe) like I do:)

From the bar, I put A LOT OF green onions, because it adds that spicy flavor to my udon and some tempura flakes as well. If you want more spice, I recommend adding some spicy chili powder as well!

In a cold, windy day (which is almost always in SF), Marugame Udon would definitely be a great choice to melt your stomach :)
author: Justyn P.

description:
I like the concept here-choose your soup in assembly line fashion; grab tempuras and other sides as you snake your way to the register to pay. Staff is youthful and somewhat friendly. Three of us split a large spicy udon and a normal sized udon whose name I don't recall. Also got onion tempura and chicken tempura. Both were flabby and mostly batter. They have a little condiments bar that lacks vinegar or lemon-kinda need one or the other to oomph up the flavor of the soups.

In the end I'd say the udon was good quality but, alas, I can't stand the texture or flavor of udon noodles and much prefer ramen which they don't seem to have here. 

Do come here if you're an udon fan-and split a large, but avoid the tempura.
author: Trish W.

description:
After trying the one in Waikiki, I was super excited to see this place in San Francisco! But I was sad to be disappointed because udons were lukewarm :( We got the curry udon, tonkotsu udon, musubi, and a side of fried squid, shrimp, and fried chicken. 

The broth and udon would have been good if they weren't lukewarm! The fried tempura sides were good but also cold. The musubi was decent.
author: Joey W.

description:
I was on an Udon fix again and found this sister restaurant in Daly City! This place was more modern than the one in Oahu. I did not care for modern look here but as I stated I liked the feel of the other place better. This restaurant or fast food chain was located in the outside part of Stonestown mall. We came here on a Tuesday and it was packed in the parking lot and restaurant!

I was glad we didn't have a huge line in front of us when we went but once we got our food, the line was long outside! I would feel bad if it was raining and cold as Daly City tends to be! Same set-up as the other where you pick your broth. My family had the curry and tantan soup. Noodles were fresh as can be! Their choice of tempuras were different from their other place but still good. 

Prices are a little cheaper here which was good. Still a clean place and fast service. New since beginning of 2018. The condiments were for our taking which was better. I will definitely be back when craving udon soup. [132/100]
author: Edna G.

description:
I love this place! I tried it for the first time in SoCal and could understand why there's always a long line for it. Their udon is amazingly delicious and the broth is so good too! I usually get the Nikutama udon which has a nice sweet beef both with an egg. I noticed that the one at this location had a wider selection of add-ons at the end like spam musubi that I hadn't noticed when I went to the one in SoCal (though I could've just overlooked it) but I thoroughly enjoyed picking way too much add-on items since the udon bowl (even a regular size) was more than enough to fill my tummy. 

Luckily they had to go boxes for all my extras that I had enjoyed at a later time. 

All in all, I would definitely recommend this place! The line may seem long and daunting but it goes by fast and is worth the wait.
author: Nenette T.

description:
Being sick that day... I was in the mood for feel good soup noodles. I had heard that Marugame Udon and Marukame Udon (in Hawaii) were of the same company. I had been eyeing this place for awhile given the amount of reviews, and I honestly prefer udon more than ramen (the noodles are more fun to eat!). Having not gone to the Hawaii location, this place sold me on their udon.

FOOD

I believe in the hype (I haven't gone to the Hawaii location). Got the regular Nikutama Hot Udon, which was the perfect cure for my runny nose. Everything was so tasty. I loved the udon - soft but chewy, not at all soggy. The soup also went really well with the mellow flavor of udon. The poached egg was awesome... the creaminess made it go well with savory flavor of the thin meat. It definitely tasted like comfort food.

Some udon items are soupless, like the Mentai Kamatama Udon. I got to try some of my sister's, and it had a nice flavor to it. Very savory, if you're familiar with the burst of salt you get from eating fish eggs. Reminds me of mentaiko pasta without the cream. Overall, I liked it, though my sister was a little sad there was no warm broth.

Honestly I'm glad I got the regular, because it gave me more room in my stomach to finish my sides! You get tempted to grab everything you see that looks delicious, but I opted for the vegetable kakiage tempura, fried fish, and fried shrimp tempura. I even got a mentaiko mayo rice ball. The tempura was perfectly crispy, and could be dipped in the designated sauce or dunked in your udon soup.

Sadly the rice ball... I never got to eat. I tried to take it with me, only for it to get smashed in my bag. Lesson learned... gotta restrain yourself on the sides.

PRICE

Worth it - and the best bang for your buck. My regular nikutama was only $8.50... and I was already quite full from just the udon. The sides are under $2, but it stacks up if you get too much... so seriously restrain yourself. The vegetable kakiage at $1.70 was a good deal for the side, and you get a variety of flavors from it. 

My set of food was under $15 (before tax and tip), and I couldn't even finish my rice ball!

LOGISTICS

I'm fairly familiar with the concept of cafeteria style - in Seattle, there's popular chain called U:Don that does the same thing. Seating is first come, first serve... you aren't assigned a table, but you pick/pay for your food first.  You take a tray, choose your style of udon, they'll hand you the assembled bowl then you get the option of picking whatever pre-made fried sides you want.  There are also stations to add ginger, sauce, tempura bits, and green onions. Getting to control how much green onions was a nice touch - I love green onions!

There may be a line to get into the place, as a worker usually controls the flow of people that go in, which was the case for us. However because of the "assembly line", it went pretty fast for 1 pm on a Saturday (we waited about 20 min). And while it may look crowded and you may be tempted to "save" a table... people cycle through here pretty quickly, so I wouldn't worry about finding a table once you get your tray.

Parking is super easy because the store is located in the mall (though the entrance is outside of the mall). More of a reason to come here while in SF - easy parking!

Now I can't wait to try the one in Hawaii...
author: Alyanna C.

description: Can't wait to go to Marukame in Waikiki? This sister restaurant will hold you over till then. Same menu, same food, same lines, still good and satisfying for a reasonable price. Don't be scared of the long lines, it does move pretty fast. Cafeteria style, chose your noodles , then select from the array of side dishes to complement your meal.
author: Gary W.

description:
A bit underwhelming as I had expectations it would be similar to the Hawaiian location. Don't get me wrong, it was good but lacked that wow factor upon first bite. 

Chicken karaage is bigger here but isn't juicy like Hawaii because it's made with chicken breast rather than dark meat. 

The tempura batter was really thick and about 1/5 of the end of my chicken was batter so I didn't eat it. 

I think the musubi, particularly mentai is better than the Hawaiian location though.
author: Jackie O.

description:
Friend: "Let's go to this Marugame Udon near Stonestown"
Me: "Naw, there's no way, that's too far, I'm about to leave to Michigan for work, I need to rest up for my company's conference." 
Friend: "You need to chill and relax and it'll help and I'll drive and you can relax" 
Me: "Fine, I do miss having a car"

AND DANG Marugame is worth taking Muni or something to get all the way out to the SF State area, it's so good. 

Things to note: I went around 9pm on a Tuesday night. There was a small line but it was all inside and I saw the setup outside that showed there was a much longer line before. 

First, you line up and watch the noodles being made. It's really fun watching masters at work through the glass. You take a tray, bowl, and a plate and slide it along while you pick your noodles and hand them your bowl when it's your turn and then get back gold. 

I tried the Curry Udon and my friend got the Nikutama Udon. Both were insanely good and extremely reasonably-priced. $6.50-8.50 for regular, both +$1 to size up. Then you continue along down the line can add tempura to your plate. There's vegetables, sweet potato, chicken, and other options, as well as various types of musubi. I was insanely tempted by them all but only selected sweet potato and green bean tempura (both roughly $1.50 each.)

Lastly, you pay and you're off to add toppings. There's a sign that suggests what to add to different dishes. There wasn't a suggestion for Curry Udon so I added chives and green onion. They also had some sesame seeds and a type of ginger. 

Honestly the Curry Udon was heavenly. The noodles were thick but not overly chewy and oozed with flavor. The broth was savory, rich, and warm and great for a cold day at Stonestown. 

Service: 
Amazing service. Quick, knowledgeable, friendly, and helpful. Love the guy at the end at the cash register who made small talk with us about our mutual love of Trader Joe's and different Trader Joe's stores in the city. 

Design: 
Clean and light and open. Lots of windows. 

Overall? I will definitely be back and will definitely tell others to come here too. I've been known for my love of ramen but I think there's now a new type of noodle competing with said ramen!
author: Lizzie S.

description:
Not a fan of the ridiculous lines that I've seen, but definitely a fan of the food when a craving for udon & tempura hits. (The line moves fast, so don't be TOO intimidated if you really want to try it and the line is long.)

Conveniently located at the Stonestown Galleria, Marugame is a welcome addition to SF. I'd already been familiar with this spot because there's a location back in LA. You walk in, grab a tray, order off of the udon menu, and they serve you your food right then and there! Then you can pick your tempura pieces and onigiri a la carte. Pretty fun!

The quality of food here is great for the price! Definitely recommend stopping in. :)
author: Emily K.

description:
Five stars for the incredible udon and assortment of tempura/snacks, plus the nice tables and self service condiments station. Also, staff is friendly.

But three stars for the slow line. It's frustrating to see how it bottlenecks at the udon station. Maybe they do that to create anticipation, because the longer I waited the more food I decided to get...

My 4 year old nephew loves their udon here, so we'll be back (hopefully during less busy times)!
author: Ellen H.

description:
Definitely one of the best spots to score some udon!  Line starts 30 minutes prior to opening on weekends.  Per item, things are fairly cheap at Marugame.  But that mentality gets your wallet emptied when you start piling the tempuras on your plate. When compared to the sister stores in Asia, the SF location pales when it comes to the quality of the assorted tempura items.  Why?  Too greasy...  The vegetable kakiage was drenched in oil and chicken tempera had sogg outer coat.

Udon on the other hand was decent in quality.  Nice and firm in texture and you get to try it cold or hot.  To be honest, you can enjoy that bowl of udon without anything on the side.  It is the star of the show!  If you like something a little extra on your udon, head to the condiments station where you can add tenkasu (fried batter), green onions, and other seasonings to give it the flavor boost of your choosing!
author: Ken L.

description:
Don't let those lines fool you! You actually move through pretty quickly. This place is like a chipotle style udon. You choose which udon you want and they prepare it for you then and there you can also see them cut fresh udon behind them too. After that, you can grab whatever fried tempura you want and pay at the end of the line. Hardest part is finding a seat. 
There's a concession stand in the middle to grab toppings. Perfect cause I love me some green onions. They also got a variety of sauces for you to choose from. 
The soup was pretty good, not as thick as ramen broth but still flavorful enough. The noodles were cooked enough so that it's chewy, just the way I like it. 
Check in for a free drink! I was a bit thirsty after finishing my meal so that was a life saver. I will be back for more tho!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Honestly, I think udon might be my favorite type of noodle. I'm a huge fan of the bouncy texture and consistency and it goes well with soup or sauces. That being said, Marugame is a solid spot if you appreciate udon as much as I do. 

Unlike other reviewers, I haven't been to any other location so the one here at Stonestown would be my first experience. The ordering process is pretty simple, you pretty much go down the row cafeteria style with your tray. Pick which type of udon you want and then pick the toppings you want to accompany your dish. Based on the amount of things you add, it could get pretty pricey but at least you know that the udon is good here.

After you pay and find a table, don't forget to go grab your sauces for your add-ons. Mix n match, make something that you like or stick with the OG choices.

Note, I would not suggest getting any of their onigiris. I bought 2 salmon onigiris and I swear that there was less than a teaspoon of protein in it so I was basically eating a ball of rice...
author: Wiseley F.

description:
Long line that was worth the wait!

So I was a bit shocked when I noticed a huge line extending from the front of the restaurant. I was actually in the 3rd section & ended up waiting approximately 30 minutes to get into the restaurant. Note to self (and you all of course!), don't come at dinner time- go at an off hour to avoid the wait. 

As a first timer here, it was really cool seeing the workers make the noodles and prepare them right in front of you. The process is relatively quick so there's a steady flow of people in and out of this place. The menu isn't overwhelming in any way, just google some of the menu names to get an idea of what the broth will be like and you'll be fine! You'll get to pick your tempura options after you order so don't worry too much about that while waiting in line. You also get to add toppings (scallions, cilantro, etc.) after you order. 

I ended up getting the large and hot... bukkake. It's a shame that this word has turned into such an "interesting" meaning (don't google this option if you want to save yourself). The broth is soy-based and has a solid amount of depth due to the dashi. The noodles were cooked beautifully and had the perfect bite to compliment the broth. Moreover, for the price point of only $5.50, this is a steal. 

For the tempura, I got the chicken and shrimp. These were just alright, nothing too spectacular, but were cooked right. The dipping sauce didn't really do much for me, but that's just my opinion. I'd recommend sprinkling some chili powder over these.

All in all, this was a pretty good experience. I'll definitely be back!
author: Nick Y.

description:
I have been here three times already and I always order number 8 which is the nikutama udon. Broth is amazing and the sweet marinated beef is great. They usually skimp on the broth for number 8 so I usually ask for extra broth. 
The tempura is alright.. its not as crispy or flavorful as I want them to be and the tempura sauce seemed water down yesterday when I went. 
The restaurant is located in stonestown mall so theres plenty of free parking. Theres always a wait when I went but its usually pretty fast and you order your food and find open seating yourself.
author: David Y.

description:
I thought all udon tastes the same, until I had Marugame Udon. Structured differently than your typical Japanese restaurant, you're taken on a journey to your meal. Its really cool and interesting to see the process of how they make their udon, witnessing the workers roll out the dough, boil the noodles, and section it out, making its way into your bowl. Everything is udon based, you get to watch the servers pour in the soup base and add protein. they crack the soft boiled egg right in front of you, I've seen a serve throw some eggs away when its not perfectly soft boiled.

I tried the regular sized beef udon and curry udon, with 2 shrimp tempura and a vegetable kakiage. I love that you are able to pick how every many sides you want, and its all made fresh. 

For pricing, this place is pretty cheap! A regular size bowl of curry udon was $6.90 and a beef udon was $7.90. The shrimp tempera was $1.90 and the vegetable kakiage was $1.70.

I came at 8 on a weekday and the wait was less than 30 minutes. I have heard of people waiting way longer. Let me tell you know, this place is good, but its not worth waiting hours for.
author: Yennhu N.

description:
An overhyped udon stop. 

First time I came here, I ordered the Tonkatsu Udon.  I thought this dish was alright, but to be honest, don't eat Tonkatsu broth with udon, eat it with ramen. 

The second time I came here, I ordered the Beef Udon and let's just say that the udon was soggy. The last thing you want to do at an udon restaurant is get the udon wrong. The soup was good but if you have bad udon, it will just kill the entire dish. 

The tempera sides are all really good and cooked well. The onigiri were pretty dry and I would not recommend them. 

Overall, I would not recommend this place.
author: Eric Q.

description:
Party of 4 at 5:10pm Tuesday night 
Stonestown parking lot busy as usual. 6 people ahead of us outside the front door. Total time in line before ordering about 10-15 mins. Process is efficient and limited menu helps process. 
Two regular and 2 large udon bowls ordered. I would definitely go with a regular next time. Added the tempura tamago  and an inari. All very filling and reasonably priced.
author: Elaine S.

description:
I've always wondered why this places was always super busy so I figured I would give a try. I'm not much of a Udon kind of girl but this places I highly recommend. This has to be the best udon place I've been to so far. 

You start off by placing your udon order you choose. Than comes the tempura side with various selections. Than after comes the register to pay. After paying there is a self serve so you can dress your udon with unlimited cilantro,greens onions, tempura flakes etc. including all other tempura dips and sauces found at a common station. 

Our order as follows : 
#5 Beef Udon Regular size $7.90 Served with sweet flavored beef and the signature kake soup. 
#1 Tonkotsu Udon size regular $9.90 Pork broth with chashu pork,miso ground pork,garlic,soft boiled egg and chili oil. Also added shrimp , asparagus, & fried fish tempura. Udon was perfect savory and sweet. As far as tempura everything was very much outstanding except for the asparagus. It was cold and very soggy. 

The best time to to go is when right when it opens because this places gets super packed and youll be waiting in line for quiet sometime.Numerous parking so thats no biggie. Customer service was amazing. Very attentive at all times. For the price and speed of food I will highly recommend to family members and fellow colleagues. I will definitely come back again!!
author: Len A.

description: I may be biased since I'm a huge udon person. I first tried Marugame Udon when I was in Oahu but I actually think this joint performs better, especially the fried items(tempura). My husband and I arrived on a Sunday around 7:30pm and we waited almost 50 minutes. Beware that you have to start at the line that is located furtherest away from the restaurant...... I had the nikutama udon (beef udon with egg) and my husband had the curry udon with a bunch of add-ons. I love the consistency of the udon - slightly chewy. The beef was also thinly sliced and packed with flavor. We also picked up some tempura: shrimps, zucchini, asparagus and squid. All fresh and crispy! The food in general is of great quality and the pricing is low. If you have time to wait around, I'd recommend it.
author: Phoebe T.

description:
This udon is out of this world! The nikutama udon comes with freshly made udon, homemade beef broth, and a soft boil egg. I thought I'm not fan of udon, but it's because I haven't had real udon until today!! 

The line can be long but generally moves pretty fast. I went at 11:15 on a Sunday and waited 20 minutes. Worth it!
author: Angela T.

description:
Favorite udon place in the Bay Area. I was so excited that this location opened up after having been to the la location. It's at a mall so there's many parking spots but you may have to circle around when it gets busy. 

We went to have an early dinner and waited ~20 minutes. I love watching them make the noodles while you're waiting and there's plenty of time to change your mind and decide on a type. It's also fun to pick the tempura. Tried the mentai kamatama and nikutama. Both are delicious. The noodles as so perfectly chewy and great flavor
author: Sophia L.

description:
I LOVE MARUGAME. I am a huge fan of noodle soup, and Marugame is no exception! I never knew how much I loved udon until I ate here.

It's such a fun experience here where you can watch the noodles made before your very eyes. They're very chewy and delicious. My favorite hands down is the tonkatsu udon! I like that you can customize how spicy it is with the amount of chili added. Then, you get to pick your sides from a huge assortment of deep fried goods. My absolute favorite is the chicken. It's extremely flavorful and more tender than I expected- perfect side to my soupy goodness! There's also rice balls as if you want more carbs :P 

After you pay, there's an all you can get topping station with green onion, cilantro, tempura flakes, etc. There's also tempura dipping sauce here. I love that it's DIY toppings so I can add way too much tempura flakes!! 

The line here can definitely be pretty intimidating. But the promise of a hot bowl of udon is so worth the wait in the cold!
author: Sandy Y.

description: I recently came here last Thursday when finally I tried something different than I had my first time. I came here late evening when the line was short. It definitely was a 15 minute wait outside but worth the meal inside! I was very pleased with my meal and the cost of the udon & tempura was around $13. I just wish they added more broth to my noodles. It's amazing how they make their noodles from scratch and you get to watch the noodles boil while standing in line. Make sure to grab your tray and a tempura tray if you plan to get udon/tempura! I would definitely come out here again... all the way from Fairfield. Also, make sure you find a seat right away and if you're with somebody let them put their toppings first and then switch off. Seating is very hard to find!
author: Sheryl H.

description:
TL;DR: You wont find a better place for udon at this price point.

The inside is very clean and simplistic. They have workers monitoring every table to make sure they are available for the next customer almost immediately. Upon choosing your noodle, you are happily greeted by a small row of tempura battered appetizers (extra charge of course) which go perfectly with your broth and udon. Or you can get a mini onigiri as a post meal snack for later.They even have a condiment bar which has cilantro, green onion, and *wait for it* TEMPURA BATTER BITS!! I have to resist the inner asian in me to take a hefty zip loc bag and filling it up to go. Also, there's very little wait between you ordering and you eating your meal--the only reason the lines are long are because people are trying to savor their heaven in a bowl before they devour it. Overall, an enjoyable fooding experience with very little hassle l.

Tonkatsu Udon:
My new favorite over the nikutama.
The broth is rich and creamy with just enough savoryness. The chashu is okay, but of course, the main star of this dish is the udon. It has the absolute perfect texture. Make sure when you get the tempura bits that you dont add them to your udon, but put them on the side and only add them when you eat them. You get the super nice crunch from the batter and the chewiness of the noodles and the umami from the broth--it all comes together in perfect harmony. "5 ALL DAY SON!!!" 

Nikutama:
The niku is savory, but a bit too sweet for my liking, but still very delicious nevertheless. The broth is light and the udon does most of the talking for this dish. Make sure you ask for some hot chili oil to give it that extra oomph. Still, a very satisfying dish. 5/5.

If you are looking for amazing udon with great portions and a sub $10 price, then this is your place. You will be knocked off your feet.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
Do you want some poppin Udon? THIS is where you can get it. 

A few notes:
There is a long wait at night, bring a jacket while you wait outside. 

While you wait in line outside, look at the menu and think about what you want.

This is not a good place for groups larger than 4 because it's so packed all the time. This is a great stop for a date or something cute like that! 

The food is good quality. The udon is fresh and made right in front of you. All of the fried options are also freshly fried and set out for you to grab. I highly recommend getting the pork tonkotsu and get it extra spicy!
author: Gladys M.

description:
I describe this place to my friends and family as a "Chipotle" of Udon. Grab a freshly made bowl of noodles with your choice of soup base and pair that with a whole variety of tempura ranging from chicken karage, shrimp, and sweet potatoes. It reminds me of a high school cafeteria assembly line, but with exquisite delicacies. 

I ordered the Nikutama udon, which tasted like a sweet beef broth home made by your dearest grandma. I picked out a few pieces of chicken karages and a shrimp tempura that had me salivating waiting in line to pay. The chicken karage was crispy on the outside, but tender when you bite into it. Next to the register, there is a topping bar that lets you add tempura crumbs and finely cut green onions to pile on to your bowl. 

The lines are long sometimes extending outside to prevent overcrowding, but there is good movement. Decent price point and ideal for a casual outing when you crave a hot bowl of noodle soup in the cold weather.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Lunch review. Udon.

Ordered:
Tonkotsu udon (Best)
Nikutama udon
Curry udon
Shrimp tempura
Chicken tempura

Almost certainly the best udon in the city.

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Honestly, for a "fast food" noodle place, I love it so much. Did I understand the hype for the first six months as I drove by and saw a line 50 people deep each time? Of course not. But do I love it when I go on weekday evenings around 8 pm and there's five people in line? I sure do.

I love the simplicity and the convenience of the restaurant. You tell them the number of the noodle and the size. They put it on your tray. Done. Oh and add whichever (aka all) tempura you want and pay with the cashier. Skip those onigiri... not worth the price and weirdly salty.

I love the toppings station where I can pile up on the crunchy tempura bits. And don't make the same mistake that I did... that's GINGER, not garlic. I did that to my first bowl and I'll never forget it.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
As my friends can attest, this place makes me soooo happy. Food is fresh and delicious, service is welcoming and accommodating, and there's a plethora of choices to satisfy every palate. 

When we came here at 9:45 on a Saturday night, the dining area was still half full and the girl working the tempura station cheerfully offered to fry more things for us if what we wanted was already out even though it was so close to closing time. 

My personal favorite was the egg drop chicken udon which doesn't seem to be on their menu anymore, but the curry udon is also an excellent choice. The soup is thick, but just right and so, so flavorful. Noodles are cooked well every time and the tempura shrimp never disappoints. Easily one of my favorite places to visit when I'm in the area.
author: Emily L.

description:
Yes, Marugame did pioneer the fast casual udon concept - they're the Chipotle of udon - but I want to argue that Kagawa-ya in SoMa is overall a better fast casual udon experience. Their noodles are more toothsome, and their broths more savory, and there's rarely a wait. Support a local boutique business! 

As for this branch of Marugame: it's decent but not worth the immense stress of lining up for 20-50min only to battle for a greasy seat in the food court. The noodles aren't much better than the frozen sanuki udon you get at Japanese markets, and the broths are... fine. The main plus is that the portions are big and cheap.
author: Ken H.

description:
This is a great place for anyone craving udon. Whether you go alone or with a group, it is still a good experience. I usually go here around 6pm and it's usually about a 30 minute wait. This restaurant is a cafeteria style setting where you go down the line for each step. After you pay, there is a second section that you can go too. This section is the toppings bar with items such as, green onions, tempura flakes, sauces, and others (you can add as much as you'd like without being charged).

I got their beef udon. The meat slices are tender and well marinated. I also grabbed some sides to go with my main dish. The sides I got was a crab musubi, chicken tempura, and a potato croquette. All of these sides were good, but the crab musubi didn't have much crab.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Great bang for buck. One of the best in the SF area. Curry udon was great and generous in amount. Line can get long so make sure to plan ahead for that.

The croquette, spam musubi or the other items can be a bit pricy.
author: John L.

description:
Not bad for a quick, affordable, and filling meal! My friend and I came at a pretty busy hour on a Sunday night, and the wait was out the door and around 35 minutes. 

The restaurant is cafeteria style, where you can pick which type of udon you want at the front, and add condiments and tempura items (with additional charges) to your choosing. I went for the mentai spicy fish roe and soft boiled egg dry noodle, and it was simple but pretty good! The udon texture was perfect, and the meal was overall pretty light with a ponzu sauce. 

For the price and the speed of the food, I would recommend it if you're in the area.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Went to the Hawaii location and was excited to know that there was one in San Francisco too. Knowing that the lines were crazy in Oahu, I expected it to be the same here. There were 3 lines with an employee outside managing it so no one cuts. The wait was about 20-30 minutes on a Saturday night and was worth the wait. 

Once you get inside the door, you get to see them cook the udon in front of you. You make it to the worker and let them know what dish and size you want. The worker might forget what dish you want so you have to repeat it. After that, you get to the tempura line with many options - shrimp, fish cake, zucchini, mixed veggies and more. I recommend the shrimp one! Don't get the mixed veggies. Then you'll make it the rice triangles and the cashier! Definitely love how it's an assembly line and how organized it is. 

The one thing I appreciate about this place is you get to choose the amount of cilantro, green onion, and fried bits of tempura to put inside your bowl. There's also a self serve water area which is super convenient. 

I ordered the beef udon dish (#5). Total came out to be $10 for this + shrimp tempura. The udon was chewy, soup was savory and sweet. May be a little too salty for some people (including me, -1 star) but overall enjoyed this place and will be coming back when I crave udon.
author: Sherluna V.

description: I wasn't really impressed by this place as many others are. The food was decent but not amazing. The broth was really oily and just not very tasty. The egg looked kinda gross and I avoided it. I got the #1 and overall I wouldn't get that again (rubbery and bland). Perhaps something on the veggie menu would work but it's not a place I would make a point to go to again.
author: Bella B.

description:
Came here on a Saturday during peak hour lunch time (~12:30pm). The line was out the door, and it had to split (to the walkway area). The wait wasn't too long, surprisingly. It was only about ~15 minutes wait. It went by pretty quickly. 

Their menu is not too large but it has a variety to choose from. We got the beef udon, mentai udon (mine), and tonkotsu udon. It was really cheap, and the portion matches what you're paying for. There's also a wide selection of tempura at the end of the line. 

The seating style is like a cafeteria. You get your food on the tray, then you find a place to sit. Not a very good place for large parties. You'll definitely get split up during a busy day. Some people also tend to overstay & hang out for too long so that can be annoying. 

Food wise, I think it's okay. The flavors were good. Noodles were cooked to perfection and broth is so flavorful. Id go again to try different flavors. It's definitely an interesting concept. I just hope the crowd dies down a little, haha. 

Also, My mentai udon + one sweet potato tempura + Canned green tea was about $11 total with tip.
author: Elle T.

description:
One word: overhyped. I've been hearing about marugame non-stop from friends both in the bay as well as LA. We decided to try it out for lunch on a Saturday. Line was pretty long, but not insane. We waited about 20 minutes. 

We ordered the tonkotsu and the nikutama udons along with karaage, shrimp tempura, ebi fry, mixed vegetable tempura on the side. The udon itself was decent but would have liked more chew to it as it was slightly overcooked. The tonkotsu broth was surprsingly really good and flavorful. Niku was alright. The worst part was all the tempura sides. The quality and authenticity were really lacking -- all of them were soggy and coated with a very thick layer of batter! We've been to Japan and have had the real deal. Sadly, Marugame doesn't even come close. Not sure why this place is super popular. The prices aren't cheap either... The ebi fry (or whatever they called it) was $4 for one piece.
author: Jasmin C.

description:
THIS PLACE WAS ABSOLUTELY AMAZING TO ME! I love noodles so much. The udon noodles were soooo good. I forgot what I ordered but it was udon noodles mixed with a sweet savory sauce and some meat as well. I expected my order to be a type of soup but the woman serving me said that the liquid was more of a sweet sauce instead of a broth and offered to give me more for free if I wanted more. My meal was perfect as is! Next time I'm going to try the soup! I'll be coming back for more.

Expect a wait, but line goes by super fast!
author: Leanne N.

description:
Our 3rd time here for amazing fresh made udon noodles- I have always ordered the Tonkotsu Udon - creamy pork broth - & pick your toppings
Place is clean , udon noodles are just made to perfection .  Will surely be back!
author: Ruth M.

description:
I have been wanting to come here since they opened and I finally got to visit a few days ago. I missed out on the Hawaii version and was ecstatic to finally make the trek to the foggy city for a girls day out. I didn't have too many expectations going in but just excited for some fresh udon. I've only had the pre-packaged kind from the grocery stores previously. 

We could see the line out the door and it was also lunch time so we expected to be in line for awhile. Much to our surprise, the line was only about 10 min? It's cafeteria style and and the udon is constantly being made so the line really moves as quickly as customers make their selections. The dining area is fairly large with both communal tables as well as smaller tables. Bus your own table after you eat and you are on your way! There is a big sign that says no outside food and holding tables - not sure how strictly this is enforced but it is posted. 

There are many add ons to choose from after you make your udon selection - there is signage but still can be somewhat confusing. Don't be afraid to ask the workers as they will gladly explain the item. I chose 3 add ons - potato croquette, tamago tempura, and fried chicken. Potatoes are always my jam so it was definitely my fave. The tamago tempura was interesting to try but I don't know if I would get it again. The fried chicken was really tasty and very juicy inside. 

What my friends and I enjoyed the most was the condiment bar - they both said it was better than Hawaii or LA. We loaded up with sauces, green onions, tempura bits and flakes - YUM! 

It was definitely a satisfying and somewhat inexpensive meal for you are getting but do be aware the add ons can add up quickly! The SFSU students are lucky to have this spot so close to campus! 

PROTIP: If you have leftovers, load up on more condiments - it's almost like new bowl of udon! :D Yelp check in for a free drink - was so distracted by everything I forgot to check in till much later haha! 

Two things I will note about my visit - The first one is they have gender neutral restrooms here which is completely fine but dang - CHILL OUT to the dude in the bathroom who gave me dagger eyes like I was stupid for entering the men's room (you clearly didn't look at the sign SIR). Just be aware if this somehow makes you uncomfortable! The second one was I failed to check my receipt until I got home and realized I got charged DOUBLE for my udon. I'm still wondering where's the beef because that's basically what I got charged for (a #8 with beef instead of #4 plain with bukkake). What's ironic is that I didn't want beef and my friends did that's why they ordered #8 and I got the latter. I guess the cashier assumed we all got the same. I know it's my own fault for not checking the receipt thoroughly at the time but the line was hectic. UGH it honestly still irks me a little - check your receipts people - I know I will next time!
author: Johanna L.

description:
Those extra 7-8 minutes waiting for the register really made a difference.

I've come here two more times since my first visit with the 2-stars rating and might I say that I am happy to conclude that I am now more satisfied.

I've tried the Nikutama Udon and Beef Udon on separate occasions and I genuinely enjoyed both options. Both options use sukiyaki beef - I do, however, prefer the Beef Udon over the Nikutama Udon purely based on the heaviness of the taste in the base. The Beef Udon option uses a kake broth as opposed to the kake sauce that's used in the Nikutama Udon, making the flavor much lighter and much more suitable for my personal palate.

My opinions on the tempura and onigiri still stands but the fried fish tempura appears to be a new favorite of mine. Will be returning occasionally, for sure.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
The restaurant is well thought out, and the assembly-style makes the line pass by quickly! I came when it was fairly long, but the line kept moving and we were inside within 10 minutes. There's also a lot of seating so you don't have to worry too much about waiting around.
 
In San Francisco standards, this place was good, fast, and cheap. I ordered the Curry Udon and it was super filling even though I only ordered the Regular. The broth was heavy, the meat was flavorful, and the udon had the perfect amount of texture. You could also order sides which consisted of various tempura and spam masubi. Definitely use the sauces provided at the side bar for your tempura, and add the crispy things (not sure what they're called) into your udon.
 
One thing I didn't like was the bathrooms. It's poorly designed because it looks like there's only two bathrooms - each having the vacant/occupied lock capability. However, inside each vacant/occupied bathroom, there's actually two stalls inside (totaling 4 stalls for customers to use). I'm glad there's more bathrooms and it's gender neutral, but it's not obvious for people who come here for the first time. Bad design.
 
When comparing this to Hawaii's, this restaurant location was not as good. Hawaii's was cheaper (~$5 vs ~$7), had some different udon options, and gave more per bowl. However, the theme was the same and at least SF has more seating.
 
Overall, this restaurant can't beat Hawaii's but I still enjoyed my meal. It's cheaper than many other restaurants in SF, but you feel just as satisfied. I'd definitely come back to try their other menu options as well.
author: Aileen J.

description:
I have been there 3 times.  The line is definitely more manageable compare to when it first opened.  
They have a new menu now. Honestly, I like the old menu better. I have been there twice when they had the old menu. The egg drop noodles and the beef noodles were amazing.  I got the Thai noodles from the new menu. It was good too! I will definitely go back again and try different items.

Oh! I loved the fish cake. =) 

The photos attached are the old items.
author: Rachael C.

description:
There was much anticipation when the billboard went up during the construction period.  Having eaten at the one in Waikiki I looked forward to giving this location a try.

It wasn't until last Thursday that hubby & I finally had a chance.  We dropped in around 3:30pm.  No lines!!!  We would have given it a try prior but the long lines were a deterrent.

Unlike the one in Waikiki where we ordered not only our udon noodles but many of the sides where your food bill can skyrocket; we were very conservative here.  Same concept.  It's like a cafeteria line.  Take a look at the menu posted; then place your order with one of the cooks behind the counter.  Doesn't take long.  It's a good assembly line method of preparation.

Hubby got a large size #1 tonkatsu udon, and I got the #8 regular size beef udon with the egg.

He got his with the chili oil drizzle.  Unless you like sweet I'd skip #8.  I thoroughly enjoyed it as I've got a sweet tooth.  

Take your tray with your noodles;  move down the line;  grab any enticing sides.  We got one veggie tempura and one inari sushi side.  You place your sides in a provided carton.  Seems wasteful but I guess it keeps dishwashing to a minimum.

You can dress up your udon soup noodles with cilantro; green onions, etc. found at a common station.

When you're done eating, be courteous & bus your own tray.

Total bill was $23.00.  Not bad for early supper.

We'd come again.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Wow! $26 and you got yourself a meal for two!! We opted for a large udon bowl to share. It only made sense to us, because we wanted to try out the tempura and rice balls! Here's the drill.

1. Wait in line outside (35 minutes+)
2. Enter the doors and be amazed by the production they got going here! It was interesting to watch the chefs at work. This made the extra 10 minutes in line go by really quick
3. Get a tray and plate
3. Order your udon 
4. Place your tray close to the chef so he or she can serve your bowl of soup
5. Shimmy over to the fried tempura section
6. Contain yourself as you pick and choose from an array of shrimp, chicken, and vegetables
7. Then, care for some rice balls? 
8. Order your drinks and call it a meal
9. Pay 
10. Customize it with some toppings and sauces 
11. Last, but not least, devour the meal. Don't forget to slow down and savor each bite! 

Fresh ingredients at an affordable price! I definitely recommend coming here.
author: Briana H.

description:
This place was AMAZING! Don't let the long lines scare you away. It went all the way out to the parking lot, but it only took us maybe 20 minutes to wait in line for lunch on a Sunday. 

We both ordered the large tonkotsu udon and picked up a couple of sides. The sides are what gets you!!!! Each side (tempura, onigiri, croquette) are over $1 each. EACH. Choose wisely. I got the zucchini, shrimp and croquette. Boyfriend just got the shrimp and croquette. My eyes were bigger than my stomach. Then we got to choose any toppings at the topping bar. I put almost everything in my ramen. Green onions, cilantro, ginger, tempura flakes... I wish I saw the croquette sauce before I added the tempura sauce all over the fried things. 

The verdict: very tasty udon. I would recommend getting the regular size unless you are STARVING. I liked all of the tempura, but we didn't care for the croquette too much because it was all potato. We were hoping for it to have some other type of veggie mixed in there too. 

Will definitely recommend to anyone who is wanting noodles in the city and hopefully we will come back soon. :)
author: Heather I.

description:
I'm gonna drop 5-stars on this spot for shaking up the noodle (maru)GAME and doing something else that is not ramen. Don't get me wrong, I love ramen as much as the next noodle fiend, 'but SF needs a good noodle villain...and marugame is going to give it to them' -- Joker, probably.  

As some reviewers mentioned already, the noodles are prepared cafeteria-style. Pick a base menu order (i.e. the Sweet Beef Udon), then move through the line to add your fixings. There are an assortment of tempura goodies like mixed veggies or fried chicken. The fixings range from roughly $1-5 so in the end your order may come out to $10-12. Grab a seat anywhere, they've got ample seating inside. 

Some udons come with broth while others come with sauces. My sweet beef udon came with the latter. I did not know that so I went up to the register to ask them for more 'broth'. A worker passing by me overheard and warned me of the salt content I would be consuming if I decide to add more sauce than suggested. I really appreciated this pro-tip and customer service. 

The line tends to always be stupid long so come before 7pm if you're one to get hangry and you didn't pack a Snickers.
author: Greg Y.

description:
Niku Udon - 5/5. Broth was flavorful without being overbearingly so, and noodles were chewy and tender. The broth was also thick enough to stick to the noodles, which is exactly what you want when eating these noodles.

Tempura - 4/5. These are very cleverly placed along the line towards the cashier, and it's very difficult to not take as you walk by them... They ended up being decent but not amazing, I'd consider just getting two bowls of udon next time.

All in all, great udon and I will definitely be back. I also liked what they did with the decor to try to make it feel like a Japanese night market - they did a reasonable job with it since I was reminded a little bit of Japan by it.
author: Nevin L.

description:
This place is really great! I wouldn't wait crazy long for the udon, but it's fantastic if you don't have to wait for more than 30 minutes.

Walking through the line is part of the experience itself. You pick what you want and then you see the Marugame team put it together. Afterwards, you can pick up some tempura before you pay. It's a pretty cool system!

On both visits, I had the Nikutama Udon. The udon is perfect and the broth is delicious, so there isn't much to complain about!

What I love aside from the food experience is the inclusivity of the restaurant. There's two all gender bathrooms with two stalls each. Depending on your comfort level, you can choose to lock the main door behind if you want. Otherwise, someone of the opposite sex may walk in or out of the same bathroom.

Worth a visit!
author: Karen T.

description:
BEST UDON PLACE IVE EVER HAD!!! On vacation from Seattle, I've been to a couple of good udon restaurants, but this is by far my favorite. First of all, the prices are amazing! I ordered a large spicy Thai chicken udon and it was only 7.90! Some of the other bowls were around the same pricing, with only one bowl being more than $10, and that cost 10.90. You also get a lot of food for your money. The spicy Thai chicken bowl I ordered was full of flavor, the chicken was perfectly cooked, and the noodles were soooo soft & chewy. I also tried the tonkotsu udon and would say this one was a little bit too creamy. I also tried the musubi rolls and they were delicious for around $2.

The restaurant itself is very nice, it uses a cafeteria style line where you grab a plate and walk through the options. I think it's very fast & convenient and loved it. The restaurant was pretty busy, waited about 20-25 mins on a Saturday evening to get in the restaurant and order, and once we got our food, there were no seats available besides outside! (It was too cold) but luckily people are always finishing up quick and leaving so you can find seating pretty easily. 

Overall Marugame Udon ranks as one of my favorite restaurants, and I'll be sure to stop by every time I come to San Fran
author: David H.

description:
Marugame Udon is fantastic. I would recommend this place to anybody in the San Francisco area who is a fan of Japanese cuisine. 

The curry udon is my favorite. I haven't tried anything else because this is the dish I constantly crave. It's literally mouth watering and I even took my parents here to try it. Sometimes the line appears to be long outside, but don't let this deceive you. It's only long because you order right in the front and they serve the soup in front of you. They're very quick with getting the food out. Their tempura selection is also yummy and I'm glad they have a variety of options available. I'd recommend getting a couple pieces of any tempura along with whatever udon you order. The toppings bar is also a nice touch. I appreciate being able to customize my udon order in this restaurant. It gives me a very personal experience.

The last time I came here I remember they also played K-pop, which I enjoyed even though it's not a Korean restaurant. It was still fun nonetheless. Another thing I like about eating here is that when I bus my tray, the Japanese man who collects it behind the counter always says "Arigato!" and it makes me very cheerful. Shoutout to that guy for being him.
author: Nicole U.

description:
This place is delicious! Came here on a Friday afternoon and there was no wait. 

We ordered:
- #5: Beef Udon (Sweet Flavored Beef in their signature Kake soup)- This was delicious! The noodles were soft and chewy, the meat was tasty and sweet, and the broth was good!

- #8: Nikutama Udon (Sweet Flavored Beef, Soft Boiled Egg, and Kake sauce)- This was good as well, but a little on the sweet side because of the sweet beef and sauce. It was also kind of dry since there was no broth, just some sauce. So if you're looking for a dish with some broth, I suggest getting something else. 

- Vegetable Tempura: Meh, it was okay. I think it's sweet potatoes, carrots, and onions mixed together, but all I tasted was onions.

- Zucchini Tempura: Didn't try this, but my dad did and he liked it.

Overall, the food was delicious and the employees were nice and helpful! I'll be back!
author: Elise F.

description:
I wanna give this place a 3 but then it's not that I really disliked it... so I'll just give it a 4. I came here on a Friday evening and the wait was about 30 mins. Don't let the full house intimidate you because once you've finished ordering, seats will magically appear. Also refrain from grabbing everything that looks delicious because that's how you rack up the bill (trust me, I've been there).

I liked how their assembly line works. Pretty simple, just tell them what you want and move along. If you want a to-go order, do it while you're in line. I grabbed a couple of items along the way. A snow crab onigiri, fish cake tempura, and karaage. After you grab everything, you pay and put whatever toppings: green onions, ginger, tempura flakes etc. The snow crab onigiri was a rip off LOL. It had a very minimal amount of crab in it and the whole thing just didn't really taste astounding.The fish cake and karaage were pretty standard. I had the Nikutama Udon. I kind of wished they put more broth, personal preference. The broth itself was tasty. I loved the flavor. Same with the beef. It was tender and easy to eat. 

Overall flavor of food is good, it just gets expensive and the wait is usually a bummer.
author: Benita M.

description:
I like the cafeteria style setup of this place. The first time I had this was in Hawaii and this is very comparable. We went on opening day and there was a huge wait. This became our default dinner place several times. The line can be long and is bifurcated. The wait can range from 20m to 40m from the times we've been there. Despite the line/crowd, we've never failed to find a table. For the pale of heart, Chipotle is just next door lol.

I usually get the large nikutama. The flavor has been inconsistent. Sometimes the sweetness is overpowering or it's too salty. Lol the best part after getting your bowl is all the extra side items you can get... And I usually lose myself here. Maybe skip the onigiri. They are cheap for a reason; they barely have any meat/stuffing.
author: James N.

description:
There's something to be said for an establishment that almost always has a long line outside. Finally took the leap of faith and chose to brave the SF wind while waiting in line for this place--and it did not disappoint! First off, albeit the line may seem long, it moves fairly fast. The staff at Marugame Udon has definitely upped their efficiency. They operate in an assembly line fashion. You choose the order you want (they have several menus outside, with #1-12 different types of udon to pick from). The options range from tonkotsu udon, to beef udon, thai spicy chicken, curry udon, etc. You let the staff member up front know whether you want a regular or large size, whether you want hot or cold noodles, and which type (#1-12) of udon you would like. 

They then prepare your noodles the way you like, add the sauce, then the meat/eggs (if included in your order). You collect your order on a wooden tray, then slide down to the next part, where you can choose to add tempura, croquette, or various types of musubi for extra money. All in all, a very fast way to receive your meal while ensuring that it is made on the spot. The last step is to add complementary toppings and sauces on the side, which include green onions, ground sesame, chili flakes, etc. 

I opted for a hot, regular sized #8 nikutama udon. It was absolutely delicious. The beef was tender and well flavored. The noodles were very chewy and had a soft texture that went well with the broth. The egg yolk was cooked perfectly, very runny, and out of this world. My added toppings--tempura crumbs, chili flakes, and green onions, added a nice burst of flavor to each bite. I loved the customization aspect of this place. My only complaint is that I feel like there's too little beef and too much noodles. The ratio felt off, but otherwise the taste was on point. Worth the hype and I would definitely come back!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I really like the fun causal atmosphere of this build your own fresh udon restaurant.  When we visited for dinner in the middle of the week , I was surprised at the line out the door and the full house inside . The wait wasn't terrible , and we had some time to look at photos and reviews to figure what what we wanted to order.  It's kind of like cafeteria style ordering , where you grab a tray and walk down the assembly line before paying for your food and grabbing a table. 
 
We ordered one beef udon and one nikutama udon .  We also helped ourselves to a bunch of tempura . The beef udon was definitely wayyy better then the nikutama. The nikutama udon was too sweet and heavy in flavor...plus there wasn't much soup  and the egg was too cold.. I didn't care for it it much. The beef udon has a more clear and pure flavor and was served piping hot. 

Overall not bad . But nothing too extraordinary about the food itself . It's more the novelty of a build your own udon that makes it a memorable experience.
author: Brenda B.

description:
Is it really Marukame? Man, I thought it was Marugame this whole time.

My first thought was - is this the same as Marugame Monzo in LA which I LOVE?? Well, no. It is however the same as the one in Hawaii.

The line is cafeteria style so there is no putting your name down and coming back sort of thing. That kind of blows in my opinion since the line can be kind of long.

I came here too much that I almost got sick of it. Then I waited a while and came back to try their tonkotsu broth udon which is pretty much your typical ramen with udon noodles instead. Love it. The other one I get is the beef. The beef can be a little too sweet for my liking sometimes. Love the tempura and the green onion bar.
author: Sophia L.

description: This restaurant has been on my list to visit for awhile now due to all the love it has received on instagram and social media. Sadly to sum it up, my visit to MARUGAME was a let down. The restaurant functioned kinda like a food court place where your go down the line then pay and sit anywhere you would like. The line actually moves quickly and diners sit and eat and bus their own dishes to the cleaning rack.  We had the tonkotsu udon which was supposed to be spicy( it was not). Broth was flavorful but a bit too oily for our tastes. We also got a few tempura items which I would pass on. Best to get tempura fresh instead of having them sit under a lamp for who knows how long. If you see them restocking then that would be the best time. Overall, it was just ok, more hype than anything.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I was really excited to try this place because it's the same as the one in Honolulu, Hawaii. The restaurant is cafeteria style so you order the udon you want first and then you add toppings such as tempura before you pay. I came on a Thursday for lunch and the wait was not long.

I'm rating this location 3 stars because my udon and shrimp tempura were barely warm by the time I sat down to eat it. Not sure why my soup was already cold cause I didn't wait in line that long. I ordered the tonkatsu udon which came with chasu and a soft boiled egg. The soup was supposed to be spicy but it didn't taste like it was. I also thought the soup would be more flavorful since it's tonkatsu. The only good thing was that my udon noodles were perfectly cooked. I'll be back when I'm in the area to give this location another chance. If you've been to the one in Hawaii be prepared to be disappointed.
author: Ashley C.

description:
Definitely worth the wait! Will come back

The udon at this place is amazing. It's just like the udon in the sister shop in hawaii. There is always a long line in the front, because it's popular. The line is because of the slow speed at which they can produce and serve udon--there is actually always lots of empty seats inside.

The udon is fresh, and very soft. I got the bucket udon, which is served warm and directly from the pot. Even in clear soup, the udon tastes great!

The tempura choices are nice. I have tried most of the items, even the tempura egg and cucumber. The shell is very soft, and warm. The tempura squid is amazing, as is the tempura fish cake.

The staff there are nice and friendly. The yell in japanese everytime you order the bucket udon :)

Have already been back. Will go back again.
author: Henry L.

description:
Like any popular restaurant, expect a wait when you come during peak hours. Why are you complaining about waiting if you choose to come here at 6 pm on a weekend evening? Okay, the point is, expect to wait during peak hours, or come early to avoid the wait! Now on to the food!!

The place isn't a typical waiter seats you and takes your order kind of restaurant. It's a walk-in, grab a tray, cafeteria style place. As you progress in line, you order what Udon you want, and then after you get it, you can move on to get whatever tempuras and onigiris you want as well. Then at the end, the cashier rings you up and then you can go sit down and eat.

I would highly recommend trying the Bukkake Udon (hot), Tonkotsu Udon, or the Curry Udon. Out of the three, my personal favorite is the Bukkake Udon (hot), large size. For $5.50, I get a big steaming bowl of noodles and delicious broth. Add a piece of delicious chicken and squid tempura, and a fresh salmon flake onigiri, and you have a meal fit for a king for around $12~! WOW! Where in SF can I enjoy a quality meal AND be super full for $12? MARAGUME is where! 

If you have never tried this place, what are you waiting for? Pigs to fly? Go. Now.
author: Golden H.

description: Loveeee this place! I was obsessed with the location in Oahu and I was so excited to see one opening in the bay area. Nothing is better than fresh udon! I usually get the plain udon which is the Kake udon but I've also tried the Beef udon and the beef is so tender and tasty.
author: Brenna L.

description:
Oh man. This place just hits the right spot when it comes to comfort food. I don't know about you but I love me some slurpy carbs all day everyday. And for like 6 bucks? Sign me up. Add some soft poached egg and some beef? Yea, sign me up for that too. 

This place is straight up evil too. You think you're coming in here for cheap noodles. Then they tell you to grab a plate and stare at all these tempura items and rice balls. You wanna try this, try that. Now you're at the cashier.... Your less than $10 super good deal meal is now closer to $20 and 1000 calories over what you had planned to eat. Evil. But so tasty. My favorite add-ons are mentaiko rice balls and tamago tempura. 

Anyway, the place is not worth it if there's a line. Yes, the line does move quickly, but it's not like a 3-part line worthy. You can always order take out if you're having a hard time finding a seat. Lots of communal tables, if you're cool with sharing, it's pretty easy to find a spot.
author: Connie C.

description:
Nani!!!!!!!! Got here at 8:45pm when the note said closed at 9pm. I stood outside and an aggressive employee came out and told me and my friends to leave. He said, "these meetings are important and for all we know you guys could just be eating crap," even though there still was a line and no meeting was yet held. 

What he said about, "eating crap" and being aggressive to me and my friends was totally uncalled for. I and my friends have worked in hospitality for years and all the companies that we have worked for have never turned down customers before closing time. This was false advertising and this employee disrespected us and Magurame Udon, whom he represents.

I have always had nothing but pleasant experiences from this restaurant. However, with great food, great service should always be provided. 

This put my review down to 2 because of the guy. But food is 5 Star.
author: Jray M.

description:
The udon here is well cooked and the soup is very tasty. But......

I was looking very forward to Mintaiko udon as I had it before in Asia locations. Deeply disappointed when I saw the sign of Mintaiko udon being sold out. Oh well, it is what it is..  I proceeded to order whatever else is the next best thing.. Then,  I found out they have "Mintaiko mitsubi"!!!
I was like how can you run out of Mintaiko udon but have Mintaiko mitsubi?!? Itz like you go Chinese restaurant and ask for a bowl of steamed rice, get rejected. But they offer you to choose fried rice instead.... 
So not happy when they do this...
Not so sure if they tell the truth when they say they run out of Mintaiko udon.....
author: Rukawa J.

description:
Delicious udon! To clarify, this is nothing like the one in LA with the same name and same owner (so if you're looking for their uni udon, they don't serve it here.) It's exactly like MARUKAME in Honolulu, HI, with the same menu. 

When you arrive, you'll probably see a long line, but don't let that deter you. Since it's cafeteria-style, the line goes pretty fast. For reference, the line is split into 2 sections before even getting inside. The line was all the way back into the second section, and I only waited 25 minutes, and this was at 11:45 AM on a Saturday. 

Now, the food. I recommend the beef udon, regular size. The regular size is more than enough! You can add an egg if you'd like, but I don't think it's necessary. After you get your udon, you can choose all types of tempura and even onigiri on the side. I tried the potato croquette and the shishito pepper tempura. Then you pay at the register and seat yourself. There's a condiment bar where you can add green onions and tempura flakes to your udon. The highlight of the meal is definitely the udon noodles - they are thick and fresh. I'd love to go back and try more of their menu.
author: Josephine M.

description:
Is Marugame Udon worth waiting in line for an hour? No. But is it absolutely delicious? Definitely.

After waiting in the cold, the inside of Marugame Udon is wonderfully warm. I got the Nikutama udon (sweet beef, egg), and my boyfriend got the tonkotsu udon. We got a few tempura to share as well.

The difference in the amount of broth was stunning - my noodles were barely coated, and my boyfriend's bowl was overflowing. I don't think the egg added very much. Mine was very cold. But my udon was absolutely delicious, and my boyfriend ate nearly all of his before I could ask him for a bite.

Skip the tempura - the pieces we ordered were cold. Otherwise, I would definitely give Marugame Udon a chance, and hopefully they speed up their assembly line!
author: Christina S.

description:
Feels like I'm back in Hawaii again! I love marugame udon, since the noodles are pretty cheap, although it can get pricy when you start to add a lot of their tempura items. Udon is soft and chewy.

I tried their mentai udon, which was good, but a bit too salty for me (from the mentai). I also got their tamago tempura, a seasonal item. The egg was sweet and fluffy- a nice try! And, if you like shishito peppers, they have shishito tempura! Their veggie ball tempuras and chicken tempura are always classic items you can't go wrong with! 

I don't know why, but I thought that SF location tasted better than the OG Honolulu location. Maybe it's been too long, and my cravings were satisfied extra well when I came.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
UDON!!!!  I love udon so much.  My friend and I came here on a Tuesday evening at about 8 o'clock and I was surprised at how long the line was.  

I would say we waited about 30 mins in line.  Then when it was finally our turn I ordered the niku udon and my friend ordered the tonkatsu udon.  I like how they have the tempura station where you can choose what you want!  I got tamago, chicken, sweet potato, and a potato croquette.  My friend got a tamago and a salmon rice ball.  

The niku udon was a little too sweet and salty for me.  The tonkatsu udon was good, a little spicy.  Next time I'm definitely going to get the tonkatsu one.  My fav from the deep fried stuff would have to be the sweet potato!!!!  I would definitely come back to this place if I'm in the area.   

I also like how it's in the mall so I can do some shopping after.  Hehe~ too bad it was closed after we finished.... :(
author: Irene M.

description:
Admittedly, I'm really susceptible to hype. And every time I walked by that mile long line at the Stonestown mall for Marugame, I fantasized about what it would be like. Are the udon noodles made of hair from the gods? Is the broth made of unicorn spit?? Do they give you a free cookie at the end of your meal????

Then I got there and realized that it's just semi-customizable udon bowls. And we got there at 9 (they close at 10) so they were out of mostly everything in terms of sides. I got the curry broth, which was pretty good and had tasty bits of beef in it. The noodles were good, but honestly not any better than the udon packages that you can get at Hmart. 

I'd be much more impressed with Marugame if they added more drink options. Their soda fountain just has a couple of sodas and you can also get canned green tea, which isn't very appealing to me. Also, it might be more exciting if there were more options for customization. It feels like they're trying to make the selling point that you can customize the bowl but really you can just pick 1 of like 7 options and get some tempura or musubi on the side. 

I will say that the staff are exceptionally friendly and helpful, and they themselves definitely deserve 5 stars.
author: Claire C.

description:
One of my favorite places. The noodles taste amazing and the sides are also a huge plus. Parking isn't terrible as there's so much parking in stonestown. The price isn't too much especially for the amount of food you get. I honestly don't think there's a huge difference between the amount of noodles you get between a regular versus large bowl. I've personally found myself spending at most $15 here.  That's amazing!!!!! Also the tempura crumbs is a huge plus since you can just chow down on some tempura!!!! Yayaya. 

The vibe is definitely cool and the workers are chill. They even take your tray after you finish your meal when you're bringing up your bowl. At the end of all this, the affordable nature, good vibes and filling nature of the food are all reasons to His this place up. Again, I guarantee that you'll get super full here. Your belly gonna explode baby.
author: Janan D.

description:
Had a couple of recommendations to check out this spot in Stonestown which makes your udon right in front of you.  Absolutely LOVED the concept.  You see everything that's happening right before your eyes.  Luckily, we didn't have much of a line to stand in today although they are definitely prepared for a huge rush.

So you pick the corresponding number to the udon you want, regular or large, hot or cold.  

I ordered the nikutama which came with beef and a soft boiled egg.  We also picked up #1...tonkatsu.  As you walk down the line, you can drop some tempura or misubis onto your tray also.  I picked ebi, tamago, and ika.  I also decided to try the masago misubi.

Sadly, the udon was overcooked and I wasn't crazy about the beef.  It was way too sweet in comparison to similar ones that I've had.  The egg was great though.  Don't forget to take your bowl over to the self service bar and add green onions, tempura bits, and cilantro.  

As for the tempura, not so great either.  They were cold, chewy, and the batter was way too thick.  The misubi was probably my favorite part of the meal.  

3 stars is as far as I'd go...not sure if I'd come back again unless I had a hankering for some udon while shopping at stonestown.
author: Jen W.

description:
It's good, and cheap but I wouldn't say it's worth the wait. This cafeteria style udon place is definitely overhyped. Always a line even during non rush hour on a week day. I got the beef udon, broth was flavorful and udon was cooked perfectly but I felt very thirsty for the whole day. I love the unlimited tempura flakes and green onions that u can get. 

I would skip on the tempura and onigiri because the tempura isn't even hot, and barely any meat. The onigiri is mostly rice. And they do add up quickly when you want to try everything.
author: Debbie D.

description:
We love the ramen and udon shops in Japan but were in willing to stand in line when this place first opened. At 10:35 AM we saw no one in line and haphazardly decided to start a line since we were first. 2 other customers talked to us in line.  One had tried it before and said it was OK. A retired dentist who lives in the South Bay was visiting friends and liked the food here. 

I tried a small tonkotsu udon. The broth is really nice but the pork slices are small. I liked how the noodles are cooked all dente. You can ask to skip the chili oil if you don't like it spicy. Service is nice and polite. Hubby had the soy broth. I had a tast if the broth and thought it was sweet and lacked complex flavors. Within 30 or more minutes, there was a line but seems to move fairly well.  

By the time we added additional items, tempura shrimp, asparagus, fried potato patty, the meal cane to $35 for both of us and we only had water to drink. I'd definitely come back to try other udon dishes but will skip the tempura items.  They were not so great.
author: Ry T.

description:
It's depended. I like their cold udon and dry udon.
It's the best in the bay and great value.
But their soup udon is far more oil.
The oil make my throat uncomfortable.

I mean I'm a skillful ramen and udon lover
The soup should be clean and little like 10-20 oil feeling.
Another tip is never put green onion in a reman or udon, it will destroy the feeling
author: Mr.Gong X.

description:
Bukkake Udon gets the job done for your basic udon cravings. Thick udon noodles are well balanced with a light and clear broth. 

As for comfort meals, get the Curry Udon. When it's time to choose tempura, be sure to pick up chicken karaage and dunk it into your Curry Udon. Ahh so warm as it settles in your belly. Great flavor.

-It still stands that Tonkatsu should stick with Ramen--not Udon. 
-Wish they had Japanese soda (specifically Ramune) as a refreshment alongside the no sugar Green Tea ew.
-Not a fan of their tempura. 
-Don't sprinkle too many tempura flakes, cilantro, and other condiments. Udon is fine the way it is.

Line goes by fast. 

Note to self: I'm not sure if it's just me and my man but our bellies often feel unsettled after eating the udon noodles. Maybe it has to do with udon primarily being made from wheat flour which contains gluten? We don't usually have any problems with gluten food so idk. Damn. :/
author: Rebecca B.

description:
3 things udon has in common with good whiskey.
1. Goes down smooth when you sip or slorpe it
2. Bad for your health
3. But so good

You can watch them make the udon here!
And it's darn good udon.
Here is the ugly.

Tonkatsu was cold.
Small tiny slivers portions of meat.
Add one was also old and replenished

Broth was meh
author: David H.

description:
I had my first handlebar bike ride yesterday, G rode us here to meet up my friends Cassandra, Jeff, & Tracy for lunch.

It was pretty good. I got the curry udon.

^Pretty good. The soup isn't super heavy or thick in consistency. It's not a spicy soup at all. 

And a sweet potato croquette on the side.

^Super delicious by the way.
author: Lilian L.

description:
So is Marugame Udon here in SF really affiliated/related to the awesome Marukame Udon in Oahu?  Some similar menu items, but many different..like who wants edamame salsa udon?  Also, while both have lines, Marukame has more fluid and quicker service.  

We arrived on a Thursday a few minutes after 5.  The line was out the door but a lot shorter than expected.  It still took about 20 minutes to get just place an order.  And by the time they plated my noodles, walked to the tempura station and got rung up, I'd say it was closer to 30 minutes.  

We both got the Nikatuma Udon - his was large ($9.50) and mine was regular ($8.50).  With added sides of two shrimp tempura, a sweet potato tempura, and a zucchini tempura the total was $26.  I didn't see that the spoons were by the tempura bits/green onion station and had to ask an employee who came around to wipe down the table.  We were only able to get a seat at the communal table, but that was fine as we needed to eat quick to pick up our son before 6.  

We added fried tempura bits and green onions at the topping bar.  And tried both their sweet and regular tempura sauces.  The Nikatuma came with lots of beef pieces, a perfectly yolky barely poached egg, and the light sweet salty sauce.  The noodles were cooked perfectly.  The egg was wonderful though I felt it even could have been cooked a little more to form a tad more of a bind.  I chose to get mine hot but they didn't put much broth in it at all.  The sauce could have used more flavor, but possibly could have not been as pronounced due to the broth.  Beef was plentiful and well seasoned.  Tempura was obviously batch fried ahead of time, but the zucchini was so soggy.  It was not enjoyable.  Shrimp was better but again would've been better more fresh.  Unlike the Hawaii Marukame, they don't have spam musubi here.  

I hope they improve their service as time goes on since Marukame in Hawaii has a lot longer of a line but is a well oiled machine to get people in and out quicker.  Prices here are a little more given the area, but the menu has more items too.  I'd come back when the udon craving hits, but only with no or very short wait.  30 minutes is a bit much in my opinion. 3ish stars for now.
author: Cat C.

description:
Marugame udon has made its way to SF! From Hawaii to LA to now SF, there's a good reason why there's always a line here. Cafeteria style udon of good quality at a very affordable price makes for a great meal. 

Since it's still relatively new, the line moves slowly but you'll never have to wait more than 30 minutes in line. Usually.
