You grab a tray and a plate for your tempura, order, receive your udon, grab all the tempura, and pay. They have a self serve section where I drown my udon in green onion and tempura flakes. 

There are many options from kake (plain udon) to nikutama (sweet beef and egg udon) so what you order is based solely on what you're feeling that day. Everything is pretty good so you can't really go wrong with your order. There's a fairly wide assortment of tempura from vegetable karage to squid tempura. They also finally have onigiri which tend to be mostly rice with sparse amounts of meat. Just be careful not to get too much as the sides add up really quickly.
author: Derek T.

description:
Really long line out the door! The line was so long that they made a separate line for the line!  My friends got there early to wait. I headed to Stonestown after I got off work. I got to them right as they got to the door. It actually moves pretty fast. 

When you order, you select the size of bowl you want, and broth. Then toppings and sides. You can customize it! They sell tempura by the piece, so you can get as little or as much as you want, but it can get expensive quick if you want a variety. 

I got the curry udon. It was so tasty with thin sliced pork in the curry. I couldn't drink the broth though because it was super salty. 

I remember the one in Hawaii being better, but it's nice to have an option nearby without having to fly to Hawaii. Not sure it's worth waiting through the long lines though. I hope the hype dies down so I can try it again.
author: Edward N.

description:
This is a good place for Udon, not too expensive per se.

If you're ordering a regular or large and I think the differential is only $1 or so, I'd recommend you get the large, as it's the better value and the portion is right sized for any appetite.

The a la carte fried dishes you can pick are an assortment of deep fried tempura items like fish cake, potato, shrimp, zucchini, etc.   Those will run you, I think $1.50 to $2.50 per piece, so does add up on your dining bill if you're not aware of what you're taking and committing to.

The lines are long because it's an assembly line and they prepare your dish for you in a counter service format, so it takes a little longer to process and prepare as well as pay for orders.

The lines do go faster than you think, and I'd speculate the bigger challenge when you see a long line is the potential for a lack of customer seating for dining in.

This is in Stonestown Mall, so it's easy to find and parking is generally not too bad.

I'd recommend this place and it's worth checking out.  I'd not wait longer than 30 minutes, personally, as my time is a valued asset, but if you come and see there's not much of a line, it's worth coming to.
author: Rick S.

description:
Amazed that there was no line at MARUGAME this afternoon. Came here around 11:30 and we already walked right through the front door. I always wanted to come here, but reading reviews saying the wait was long, I never came. But today was the day! 
They have enough variety of udons. Once you order a bowl of your choice, there's fresh tempura waiting for you! You can choose what tempura you want for your side (price ranging from $1.50-1.80). They also make rice balls. 
The udon is pretty good. Its not too soft and it has the right chewiness. They don't add green onions for you, but they have a booth where you can add your green onions. 
The tables and floors were clean. On top of that, there was always someone ready to wipe the tables. After you're done eating, remember to bring your tray to the back. 
I would definitely come back, but only on days where I don't have to wait in line for hours.
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
I live all the way in Santa Clara, but have been here at least twice because the udon is to die for. Here's what you do when you get there. 

1. Stand in line.
2. Order the type of udon you want.
3. Pick up udon.
4. Pick any tempura.
5. Pay
6. Pick a seat.
7. Eat! 

It's like a cafeteria line, so it runs pretty smoothly.

PROS: 
--- Fresh udon. (Really makes a difference, yo)
--- Extremely nice staff. 
--- Little bar with additional add ons for your udon & tempura.

CONS:
--- NADA.
author: Kaitlyn M.

description: I still like it here! But if you take tempura and you don't put the metal pincher utensil back in its holder, the guy behind the counter will get huffy!
author: Maile N.

description:
I went here on a Saturday late afternoon (around 4 pm) with a big group of people (about 20 people). We called ahead thinking we needed reservations for a table, but it's basically first come first serve. There wasn't an entirely long line when we got there; we waited about 20 minutes in line before we got to the counter to order. Tables were also consistently kept clean, making it a little easier to get seats.

The way this eatery works is basically like a cafeteria. You start off by grabbing a tray and ordering your udon noodles. Once you get your udon at the end of the line, you continue down the tempura bar. There was a bunch of options and what I liked most is that they constantly replenished the supply of all the different types of tempura. My total came out to be about $15 so I definitely think it was a bang for your buck. After you're done paying there's a sauce bar/topping bar across from the soda machines. I added a little more tempura flakes and some chili on top of my soup, and the tempura sauce. 

I got the regular sized egg drop chicken udon soup as well as the potato croquette, sweet potato tempura, and fish cake tempura. The regular size was pretty filling, even for some of my pals who are hefty eaters lol. The potato croquette was really good and didn't really need the sauce imo. The sweet potato tempura and the fish cake tempura were also both really good, but tasted even better with the tempura sauce.

Overall, my whole group was completely satisfied with their meals here, and would come back again!
author: Cass V.

description:
Been coming here quite often since they used to close at 11 pm but now they close at 10 pm. Did they get tired of people walking in pretty late and having to close later? I'm sorry some people are just hungry after working late and craving some udon. How unfortunate, but it's cool I'm not trippin. 

Udon, udon, udon... fresh? yes, you can literally see them when you walk inside. Although whenever I now see the workers handling those noodles with their bare hands, i start to think of the negative part of it.. i just look away before i get cringy ha ha maybe that's how it's supposed to be done? i don't know, i'm not an expert. I've tired most of their menu besides the new ones like their tofu salad, i think it was. anywho, they're not too bad just not a fan of their spicy chicken thai udon (i don't remember something like that) it wasn't spicy for me and it tasted a bit watered down. but I mainly crave their curry udon. I love love LOVE curry any to be exact with udon? even better! order that if it's your first time or have yet to try and make sure to add an egg, and lots of scallions + tempura flakes. if you're into that. mix everything and voila, you get perfection. or maybe a trip to the couch from being so bloated. I always have to get the inari too! like literally! every time i'm here it's a must. dip that into the curry sauce, YUM! 

Very affordable, especially for students.. they picked the perfect location in Stonestown, where SF state, CCSF and high school students is nearby. prepare yourself with sworming high school kids throughout the day when school is over and they come here to eat. they're just everywhere in Stonestown running around. lol at least the line isn't as long as dinner gets. pfeww, not coming here during those hours esp if you're very hungry although they are fast. i got hangry once waiting in the second line (yup, they have two separate lines).. 

The workers are always so nice, from what i've notice when i'm here often. they would greet you when you come in and so polite.. some workers even took our tray when my friend and i were on our way to put them into the dirty plate station. how nice of those two gentlemen. they deserve tips in this place. then again it's a fast food japanese resto. 

Def. would come back when obvi I crave more curry udon and inari! I can literally live off Inari's. okay i'm totally kidding.
author: Deneb T.

description:
Came here on a Monday at around 12:30 so the wait wasn't more than 15min to get inside. 

Food 4/5

The noodles were amazing and the texture was perfect. You can tell that they were made fresh to order. The soup bases however were a hit or miss. We got both the nikutama and the tonkatsu and the nikutama was definitely way better than the tonkatsu, which was lacking in flavor. Also both the hot udons turned out to be very lukewarm which isn't what we expected. The tempura we got was also was just okay. Some of the tempura definitely tasted fresher than others. 

Service 5/5

Once you get inside it's assembly line style but everyone is very nice and helpful.

Overall, I think that I would come back here again if the line wasn't ridiculously long to try maybe their zaru udon, but if I'm waiting for more than 30-45 minutes, I'd pass.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I thought the furor had died down a bit, so I pitched this place for a first date. Once we arrived and saw the horrendous line though, we both agreed that we should try something else. Anyways, the date was meh, so to salvage my afternoon, I circled back and hopped in the (now shorter) line so that my whole Sunday wouldn't be a wash. 

Rating Breakdown:

2/2 Stars for Taste --
While I was waiting in line, I heard someone say "The nikutame is really the only thing worth getting". I had already decided that was what I wanted, but it's always nice to get some validation. Let's start with the star of the show -- the udon. You can watch them making it fresh at the front of the line. Chewy, almost succulently plump, long noodles. I would eat these noodles plain, that's how satisfying the texture is. The sweet/savory broth was the perfect accompaniment. I love sweet beef because it reminds me of the Yoshinoya excursions of my childhood. Also, the soft-boiled egg was surprisingly delicious. They cracked it straight from the shell into my bowl -- HOW? An engineering marvel. It was served cold, a perfect contrast to the hot soup, almost like an umami custard. Also, let's not forget the complimentary toppings bar. I tried not to overdo it with the green onions and fried crispies...but it was a damn near thing. I didn't try any tempura or onigiri this time around because I'm not the biggest fan of fried things or rice (I'm a bad Asian), but maybe next time if I bring friends!

1/1 Stars for Value --
I thought I would be hungry after ordering the regular, but there is a surprisingly quantity of noodles hidden in that bowl! The noodles absorb the soup fast, so it almost feels like a race to finish before all the soup disappears. I'm someone who prefers a higher broth to noodle ratio, so I almost wish they gave me a bit more soup, but I imagine it would be sodium overload. I think the complimentary toppings bar with green onions, cilantro, fried crispies, and a myriad of dipping sauces is a nice touch. I mean, the tempura sauce comes in a coffee dispenser. Magical. All this for less than $10? Life-changing.

1/1 Stars for Customer Service --
The line is broken up into three segments so as not to block up the sidewalk. When I got in line, I was at the end of the second segment, and it took me about 30 minutes to place my order. Once you order though, everything moves real quick -- you pick up your bowl of noodles, select the various accoutrements (onigiri, tempura), then pay for the mountain of food you've inevitably accumulated. The free soda with Yelp check-in is dope too.

Bonus star because I've already promised my parents that I'll take them...maybe during a weekday when the line isn't as insane.

TL;DR -- CHEWY DELICIOUS NOODLES. Try the nikutame! Expect to wait at least 30-45 minutes during busy times.
author: Abby W.

description:
I love this place on a religious level! First lets start with the portions. Large is actually LARGE! And its not that much more expensive than a regular, so why not?! Also the pricing is very reasonable. I dont quite remember but the range is around 10-12 for a large depending on what type of udon you get. Second, the quality of the udon is phenomenal. If you've only had udon in a generic sushi restaurant, I definitely recommend giving this place a try as it is definitely something different. The place also has fantastic tempura. However, some tempura is more expensive than others, such as the shrimp. Regardless I believe all the tempura is fantastic so I usually i just get the cheaper ones such as the cod, chicken, etc. The also have rice balls which are neatly wrapped in a to-go fashion. I've had some friends say the rice balls have too much rice and not enough meat, but hey, I'm a lover of carbs and seaweed so I don't really mind. I recommend getting the crab meat rice ball. In the end, i usually end up with a large udon, around 4 pieces of tempura, and 2 riceballs. If I remember correctly, I only paid around 18 dollars with that, which, in my opinion, is a STEAL considering the quality you are getting. There's also a complimentary condiment(?) section where you can get panko flakes and green onions to put on your udon. 

Despite a long line at any given time, the line actually moves at an efficient pace. The restaurant is set as a cafeteria style, so you get your food, pay for it, and then sit down. Despite constantly having a line, I've never had trouble finding a table after I pay. I dont know why, but I guess the system works. The decor is also nice and waiters usually clean up after people leave, so there's rarely ever a mess after a party is done. All in all, I definitely recommend this place. I take every opportunity to come here every time I'm in the area.
author: Tim W.

description:
Why drive to closest Marugame when I can drive 400 miles to the next closest one?  I've avoided going to the Los Angeles location because the long line and wait scared me.  This San Francisco location and its reviews didn't help with with my fear of waiting.  But, with a daughter who loves eating udon and with us not being too hungry, we decided that we needed to try it.  We made it to the Stonestown location and to our surprise, there was no wait at all!  Sure there were only 2 people ahead of us at 4PM.  

Udon is in their name, and that is what we ordered.  We ordered curry udon, nikutama Udon and a kake udon the for the child.  Each bowl of udon was unique in its own way.  The bowl of noodles were tasty and cheap.  It is a great place for the nearby college students.  We weren't too hungry because our hotel kept us well fed so we ordered the small sized udon.  The musubi was nice and fresh.  It was still warm when we picked ours up.  

It's a good place to visit for a cheap meal.  I'm still have not visited the one closest to me because the wait scares me.  I'll be back when I go back to the Bay Area for work.
author: Phil Y.

description:
I really like this place! I love that they make the noodles fresh and in house.

The line can get really long but it moves fast! The sides are kinda pricey but really filling.

I usually get a small with two sides max and I am really stuffed.

I like that they have a greens toppings bar with tempura crumbs. Really great spot, I love it.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Do NOT come during prime time unless you want to wait 2+ hours! But.. come during random times and have the best udon :)

Parking--I didn't have any trouble finding parking the times I've been here. It's a mall shopping center parking lot. 

I came here twice within a weekend because I was so hooked. There's not really any customer service, but not much was needed. The food is AMAZING, from the fresh udon and broth/sauce to the tempura... SO good. They also let you add your own toppings.. as much as you want!

The small bowls are all pretty cheap (for SF standards), and the large bowls cost a dollar or so more. Definitely worth every dollar.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Was so excited to find out this was opening in the Bay Area! I believe this is the same as the famous Marukame Udon in Waikiki in Hawaii. 

The wait was not as long as I expected. I had read reviews before going here, saying the wait would be an hour, at least. We actually only waited about 30 min. It was a Sunday in the late afternoon and we saw that the line wasn't long, so we took our chance and waited, which worked out great! However, when we had our food and looked out the window, the line had gotten way longer, so we definitely got lucky. 

I ordered the Nikutama Udon hot. I also got the chicken karage and a salmon rice ball on the side. There was ample seating, so we were able to get a table right away. 

The Nikutama Udon came with beef and a poached egg. I thought they would ask me if I wanted to add green onion, but they never did. We had to go to the another table after we paid to get the green onion and other toppings (like crunchy tempura bits). The green onion wasn't sliced very thin. It was actually very chunky, which is different to what is pictured on the menu. There were a lot of pieces of green onion that weren't sliced at all, just a large chunk of green onion. I ended up not adding any green onion and only added the tempura bits. 

The udon itself was good. The broth was nice, and the udon noodles were chewy and definitely tasty. The beef was flavorful as well. The thinly sliced green onion would have definitely made the udon more enjoyable.

Chicken karage was lukewarm and the batter wasn't crunchy anymore. It was most likely an older piece of karage. The chicken still tasted okay, though. And the salmon rice ball was just alright. Salmon was really salty, but it tasted okay with the seaweed and rice. 

To be fair, I have very high expectations, having just tried the Marakuma Udon in Waikiki, which was such an awesome experience. This place was okay, and I think it's worth trying once, especially if you've never been to the one in Waikiki.
author: Nikki P.

description:
Yes! They have tonkotsu! 
I've tried the nikutama, curry, and tonkatsu. They are all tasty and have flavorful broths, but tonkatsu is by far my favorite. The udon noodles are well made and very filling. 
I wish the onigiri was a bit better, but it's cheap. The line is very long, even at off times there at least a 20 minutes wait, but it's well worth it!p
author: Erica C.

description:
Uhhh, no lie, udon noodles here were better than my last visit to Marukame in Honolulu back in January! I was super hesitant to try this spot out bc of that experience, but finally gave in. 

Similar to Marukame, the line is long af. But fear not, it moves quick. And the dining space is pretty large! Came here on a Thursday night around 9pm, and there was still quite a bit of a line. From a quick glance at the crowd, seems like a ton of SFSU students who lives in the area. But who can blame them? Legit noodle bowls for cheap cheap.

My only qualm was that the sign made for a more difficult understanding of what was vegetarian and what was not. The sauces and soups weren't that easy to quickly glance thru. My order ended up being the mentai kamatama udon. It pretty much looked soupless, which was a bit deceiving, bc there was a bunch under the pile of noodles. Bc I didn't see the soup sauce sitch, I pumped some additional sauce at the condiments counter afterwards. This made for a VERY salty meal. The noodles were amazing, but the sauce made it impossible to eat towards the end. So, be warned! Don't make the same mistake. 

Would def come back on another occasion. Won't be adding more sauce to my noodle soup. Udon game was def on point. 4 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I think I understand what theyre trying to do...the bowls of udon you order initially lacks much meat. Instead, you can add a vatiety of tempura of your choice (charged per piece) and add that into your udon, to spice it up/make yourself full. 

You can add as much tempura batter pieces, cilantro, green onion and sauces (ketchup, soy sauce, tempura sauce, sweet sauce, chili powder, sesame seeds) after you choose your udon and pay. 

Wait time is still about half an hour, easy to find a seat, kind of interesting to watch them use the machines to make udon.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
The line went pretty quickly for a Sunday early afternoon. Got the curry udon which was extremely tasty. If you get any of the tempura with it, seems
tempura sauce isn't needed as you could dip your tempura in your curry broth since it is already quite flavorful. My kids got the simple #2 and #4.
I believe and they were very content, just noodles and soup/sauce. The udon is cooked perfectly. My only gripe is that the trays to carry your udon bowls and additional tempura/add-on dishes, are kinda small so if you have to carry two bowls of udon cuz you have little ones who can't do it themselves you have to go back and forth from seating area to the cash register to get your other bowl on another tray, the good thing is servers also volunteer to help you to your seat if you have multiple bowls with multiple tempura. I was the weird one with like 3 plates of an extreme variety of tempura along with 4 bows of udon. Hey we gotta try it right? I would go again, noodles are amazing, flavors are so balanced. Also Large to me is really Large so if you have room in your belly for lots of noodles get the Large it is NOODLE-LOADED.
author: Evangelyn Sacha J.

description:
Pro tip, the small bowls aren't that small, so if you think you can order multiple bowls and try the difference in flavor bases you will be drowning in noodles like I was! 

Noodles have just the right texture and super slurptastic

Favorite broth base was the Kama age udon followed by kake then bukke. Kama held the broth and noodles warm the entire time and in fact was hotter from the beginning which was lacking in the other hot dishes such as the tonkotsu udon

Overall thoughts 

Freshly made udon in a flavorful broth, nothing else needs to be said or added
author: Eddie W.

description:
After many attempts to come here, I finally endured the wait with a friend for a post-hike meal. At 2pm on a Saturday, we waited about half an hour until we reached the assembly line. The wait was not too bad, but having to wait outside in the cold and wind was not fun.

Once you make it inside, the process is cafeteria-styled and quite streamlined: You grab a tray, choose from a selection of hot or cold udon preparations in regular or large, and then add on as many rice balls and pieces of batter-fried tempura as you care to have on the side. The basic Kake Udon starts off at only $5.50 for a bowl, but with the additional beef and soft-boiled egg; this bowl has become the Nikatama Udon at $8.50. I picked the latter as I need my meat and I'm a sucker for a soft-boiled egg. It was really cool to watch them make the udon as the bowl made it onto my tray though.

The part that really eats your money is the additional sides. With the tempura ranging from $1-2, be careful as it does add up. I added a fishcake tempura ($1.70), sweet potato tempura ($1.30), and salmon musubi ($1.60) that left me with a $15 meal --not so cheap anymore. And to be frank, the tempura was a-okay and lacked much flavor. Even the musubi was quite disappointing with minimal meat. If you're looking for a plain riceball, that's what you're getting here.

After paying the cashier, there's a condiment bar to add on some extra free toppings: green onions, cilantro, grated ginger, shoyu, hot sauce, and tempura sauce. For the tempura sauce, definitely go for their sweet version --it's thicker and more flavored almost like a unagi sauce. Finally, you find yourself a seat to enjoy your meal before dropping off your dirty dishes at the counter.

I have to say that the udon was incredibly fresh, silky, and delicious! I especially loved how the soft-boiled egg mixed into my udon for a creamy flavor while the thinly sliced beef gave the perfect contrast to the udon. Next time, I'd definitely opt out of all the batter-fried goods and riceballs though. Also tried some of my friend's curry udon, which was tasty as well. It's more of a soupy consistency for the udon, which was suitable as a broth. Overall, good and cheap udon spot if you're willing to wait.

Tip: For double your noodles, just go for a large at only $1 more!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
#8 Nikutama udon had the perfect creamy soup with flavorful beef. 

#5 beef udon was perfect for slurping on a cold sf afternoon. 

Topping - potato croquette had a crunchy outer with a mighty sweet potato. The fish cake changes the flavor when dipping it into the udon soup. 

Service - there was a line out the door but it was organized well by a worker outside guiding customers. Once you enter, you are greeted by many workers and they were all welcoming and kind. My experience for coming here the first time was very enjoyable.
author: Instafamishe D.

description:
At the moment of writing this review, I've been to Marukame Udon both in Hawaii and in S.F. In my opinion, the one in Hawaii is better because it felt more authentic and was cheaper. 

But now moving on to the S.F. location, this place satisfied my strong craving for udon. I would highly recommend trying the cold niku udon, one of my personal favorites :) This is my favorite by far because the flavor dramatically changed for me, from the hot niku udon. The cold offered a sharper taste and was perfect to accompany a sunny day. Another favorite of this bowl would the difference of noodle texture. The cold noodles are bouncier and chewier, which picked up more of the sauce. 

The tempura was decent, but was not as good as the Hawaii location. The batter felt heavier and the price was a bit higher. But if you're me and craved a fried fish cake, it did the job.
author: William K.

description:
Hand-crafted, homey, authentic Udon in a spacious, engaging, cozy space w/ a designated parking lot!

- Came here first-time to fulfill a late-night curry-craving. Great place for late-night grabs & group hangouts. 

- Overall ambiance is warm, social, casual, & comfortable. First thing impressive is the open view for udon-prep. You see the staff pulling the udon out of water into your bowl! yum!!! almost increases the appetite....

- Ordered Curry udon, Salmon masubi, & Asparagus tempura. Curry udon is tasty, but literally had 4 thin, pinky-nail-sized beef. The rest of the bowl contains a large volume of udon (noodles) & curry sauce/ soup. 

Salmon masubi is a bit salty. Asparagus tempura tastes just as expected- yum! Delicious regardless of the little flaws here & there.

- I believe this brand is an international chain. Been to the one in Japan & Taiwan, and they carry a consistent identity, which is very refreshing!

- Staff is very friendly, welcoming, and attentive to your preferences & needs. Great customer service.

- Overall a happy experience and satisfied my late night cravings!
author: Jess W.

description:
I came here for dinner today with my boyfriend and we were both really impressed with Marugame! This place has cheap food with quality ingredients and it is very fun!!

Our wait was about 20 minutes at 5pm on Sunday. You have to line-up upside so be prepared to be in the cold during your wait! However, once you are able to step inside, the process is pretty quick. You order your soup base, then you pick and choose your own tempura for your bowl and add any musubis. Once you pay, go to the topping and sauce self serve station and then seat yourself!

I ordered the Curry Udon and my boyfriend ordered Nikutama Udon. The Curry was very flavorful especially after adding green onions and cilantro from the self serve station. The udon was thick, fresh, and very filling. I enjoyed dipping my tempura in my curry more than the tempura sauce. I enjoyed the broth for my boyfriend's Nikutama Udon but I wish they gave more broth for that! The musubis were simple, yet good.

I enjoyed watching the noodle chefs make the noodles and putting them in poritions while waiting in line. It was entertaining. The Japanese music they play in the background was very energetic and you just can't have a bad time here.

I will come back for sure only if I know the wait wouldn't be long!
author: Allie Y.

description:
Came here on the noon hour with a friend. He was telling me how often this place has a very long line...we waited about 15 minutes. Not too bad. They were conscious in the sense of placing what they offered on their menu along the line. I can only imagine that this makes placing your order easier and boost the efficiency of service.

They offer a handful of options in terms of broth and fixings. Unfortunately, the only vegetarian option they offer is a cold udon with edamame salsa. I'm glad I asked about the broths...I can only assume that they're fish, maybe chicken, based. The edamame udon was good...very saucy, maybe too saucy, but I typically enjoy food extra hot. *My fault* for ordering a cold dish, but it was the only one available to me.  In addition to the udon, I contemplated getting a potato croquette and some veggie tempura. I opted for the Inari instead when I saw the potato croquettes stacked with the breaded seafood. I didn't like seeing the veg items mingling with the meat items. They were likely fried together. Speaking with family and friends about this place, they all have the same suggestion...that the broth is not hot enough. Perhaps it's a safety issue? There are indeed, careless customers that are at risk of burning themselves. 

I think as a vegetarian/vegan, this place does not really make sense. I can appreciate the value, and the crowds that it can bring, but it falls short when it comes to dietary preferences. Maybe I can give it another try if/when there is a vegetarian broth.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I pride myself on avoiding long wait times. Ya girl has done it again *pats myself on back*. Coachella weekend, soooo bye bye young people, sfsu students, etc. 25 minutes wait time at around 6:40pm compared to the horrendous hour wait times I hear about. 

.:: Food ::.
#2 Nikutama Udon Regular-$8.50: beef udon in a flavorful soup base paired with soft broiled egg. Agreeing with most of the other review that the soup was a little toooo lukewarm and I prefer hot soup at least. BUT, if that's their style then you do you boo. I LOVE udon. So uh, these were so bouncy it made me bounce like a basketball (get the reference? LOL)

#3 Curry Udon Regular- $6.90: very flavorful with beef as well. No egg though in this one.

Shrimp tempura $1.90: Loved!!! Super crispy batter. Loved the dipping sauce. 

.:: Service/Ambiance/Parking ::.
Cafeteria style, get in line, grab a tray, order what you want, they prep in front of you, move on to the tempura/onigiri section and grab what you want, then end up at the cashier where you pay. Look for seating which we quickly found. There is a station where the green onion and cilantro, sauces are. 
Customer service is pretty friendly. No complaints. Restrooms are filthy though. 
Parking is not bad since it's at stonestown and theres a huge parking lot.
author: Chena N.

description:
This place was a good fast udon place.  There was a line outside, but it moved fast.  When you get to the counter you order what you want and then you can add on any tempura you want (of course with extra charge). We ordered the Tonkotsu Udon, Kaikitama Udon, and Nikutama Udon.
The Tonkotsu Udon was okay, the broth was nothing special, but the vegetable tempura was good.  The Nikutama Udon was surprisingly sweet in both broth and meat.  The meat reminded me of bulgogi.  The egg that came with it was cooked nice and soft and runny.  If you like things more on the sweet side than this is perfect for you.  The Tonkotsu Udon's broth had a nice pork flavoring, but I have tasted better.
author: Arianna C.

description:
Came to this place mainly bc of the hype and the good experience I had at the MARUGAME Udon in Hawaii 

I ordered the same udon- the curry which was very salty and over flavorful. I had to rinse my mouth multiple times to water the aftertaste down.  

Pro:  the long line moves faster than you would imagine. I came in on a Saturday near 3pm so the wait was not as miserable.  The udon is freshly made. Ordering is quick and easy. Reasonable price which makes it more tempting to come back! 

Con: the line.  Curry udon too salty. Hard to find a table inside if you come with a group of friends.
author: Shuyi L.

description: The restaurant is located in the Stonestown Galleria right between Chipotle and Olive Garden in a beautiful, spacious area and the line goes quickly since it is cafeteria style like, just like the location in Honolulu.  Only this restaurant is very spacious.  I ordered the #1 Tonkatsu with asparagus and shrimp tempura while Dude ordered #8 with fish cake, veggie and zucchini tempura.  Food was comforting and tasty and I love the atmosphere here plus they have air conditioning which the Honolulu location does not.  An enjoyable experience all around.
author: Karen W.

description:
A sister restaurant of the legendary Marukame from waikiki, this opened with hype and I was happy to join the flock. Now a little more mellow, but still has all the reason to flock.

FOOD:
Almost identical to the style of the original Hawaii version. Hand pulled and perfect udon noodles, made right in front of your very eyes while you wait to order, cafeteria style.

Mentai udon. One of the orders that probably doesn't get enough hype, but I think this is my favorite of the lot. Not soupy, but the eggs are delicious and creamy with the egg yolk. Heavy with green onions and the side of sauce that available, I think this is the most balanced and delicious thing on the menu here.

Curry udon was always a favorite of mine. Light curry, but pretty salty. Not your usual udon flavor but I like it with the tempura chips they offer.

Nikutama udon. Clearly a fan favorite for a good reason. The sweet beef is tender and delicious. The broth is lightly salt to coat the udon and give everything that you want in a bowl of noodles. The udon here is chewy and done right. You can't go wrong with this order.

Objectively a very good udon place. Cheap food, with good tempura. The wait has died down to maybe 25 minute wait for a weekday dinner. Much better than the 2 hour wait when it first opened. The only caveat that I have is that they don't have the soft boiled egg tempura from the original, which was a game changer. Despite that, this place is great and I will be frequenting it.
author: Bryant C.

description:
First time dining in. Another popular noodle place in San Francisco. Noodles were fresh to order. Broth was flavorful. 

Ordered #1 large and spicy  
With side of tempura onion, squid, zucchini and shrimp 

Price was fair and service was great. Expect a long line! But there's employee outside that manages the line. 

Pretty cool experience. I would highly recommend giving this business a try! You'll be back for more! I know I'll return.
author: Kent B.

description:
met my daughter here for lunch.

good place for lunch..good place to get some tasty udon.

u walk in...line up...peep the scene...scope their menu options...grab ur bowl of noods...pick and add ur 'extras' to add in your bowl...move down the line...possibly add side likes...pay at the register(drink is optional)...find a seat!
author: Omar N.

description:
Udon lovers like me? Check this place out! I've been here twice, and I can say from the second time, Marugame udon hit the spot sooo good. I always wait until my second visit to make a review if I know there are things to work on. 

Line was a bit out the door - don't be scared or think it's too long. We didn't wait more than 10 minutes!! It's cafeteria style so line moves pretty fast. 

I ordered 8 regular. I was a little spectacle because there wasn't much broth but I wasn't complaining.
Ordered a bunch of onigiris ( my faaaav ) and some tempura. 

Okay, the udon was piping HOT. I remember before that it wasn't that hot so I could easily eaten it, and I love my soups hot. This was SUCH A PLUS. Yay A+ for temperature! The flavor was SOO good. The beef was so tender and full of flavor, I can see why there was no need for a lot of broth. I love how the egg doesn't spread or fall apart.

This is the closest to me I can get to amazing udon and I will always come here whenever I go to SF! 

I do want to try the tonkatsu udon but dang, I love my beef!
author: Ashley S.

description:
Summary: If this is your Marugame Udon experience, i think you'll love it and don't let the rating discourage you. Eat it for yourself, you'll enjoy it! The line looks long but, it goes by really fast. If you've had their other locations first, i don't think it compares.

Let me start this review by saying I'm not an advent lover of udon and most i've had wasn't really that good. My partner Swore by Marukame Udon in Hawaii and trying that version for the first time, it blew my mind and made this fast food style my favorite. Every time we came in to the Marukame udon and trying the different style dishes they offered was like a new experience, everytime. Hearing that they opened a location in the city, I had to try it. My review for Marugame Udon.

The good:
The location is settled in Stonestown Galleria, a mall with plenty of parking. The line looks really long but, like the Waikiki location zooms by really fast. Price is the same as the hawaii location and along with the set up of the establishment. so, what gives? why the 3 star rating (more like 3.5) why not a 4 star rating? Well, it just didn't give me the wow factor my taste buds were yearning for.

The food:

I ordered the Cold Nikutama Udon. I must have not said cold loud enough because I got the hot version (that's my fault). The udon noodles are made in house and you can see them taking a block out, kneading it, resting it, cook it, and cool it right in front of your eyes as you wait in line. The broth is flavorful but, a little on the salty side but, luckily the sweetness of the beef evened it out. The sou vide egg was perfect. 

The broth was served luke warm but probably from the cooling of the udon noodles. The quality of the toppings didn't seem up to par and if you've eaten in the hawaii's location you can instantly tell the difference in quality. The green onions were cut semi-thick and were dried up and sitting out (Waikiki's green onion looked fresh and cut so thinly that it looked shaved), the tempura have been sitting out and the oils collected on the bottom.

For the sides, I enjoyed the Inari and Musubi. I didn't really care for the squid, Tempura shrimp (too much batter), and the potato croquette (tasted too mushy).

End food review

The udon is still better than most out there. If this is your first time trying Marukame/Marugame Udon, you'll love it. But, if you have tried the other locations i don't think it compares.
author: Alex T.

description:
I've been here three times since they've opened even though I don't live anywhere near here, oops.  All of the bowls I've had so far is delicious. 

Their classic hot Bukkake Udon is simple and a relatively inexpensive meal. Just add a piece or two of tempura/onigiri and you easily have a filling meal that's less than $10. 

The Thai Spicy Chicken Udon is also tasty. It's a sour spicy, so if that's not your thing I wouldn't recommend this. 

The sides (tempura and onigiri) are okay. The onigiris could use a little more filling. After a bite, you're left with a bunch of rice. These are also pretty dangerous. The first time I went, I went overboard and ended getting way more than I could finish.
author: Christine F.

description:
Delicious place to get fresh udon, fresh tempura, and fresh riceballs.

Stopped by around 3 on a Friday and there was suprisingly no line. For ordering it is basically a line where you tell them which udon bowl you like, then tempura and rice balls are self serve. This place also offers a lot of seating which is nice.

Staff was friendly and fast. Prices are cheap and reasonable.

My order was Curry Udon, Nikatame Udon, Inari, and Fish Cake tempura. My boyfriend was very impressed on how fresh the udon tasted and he also really liked their Inari. Curry was very yummy as well, not too salty. Tempura was ok, not as crunchy as I would prefer.
author: Michele G.

description:
Omg, I am so excited that this place opened up. Ever since I visited the Honolulu location (multiple times during my trip) I have wanted udon to become big here in the bay. So happy they have opened a location! I'm bummed it's a little far from me, but at least it's in a mall so there's parking. I visited on a Friday so we didn't have to wait too long. What is great about this location is that it greatly improves upon the Honolulu location. It's a big space, and since it's cafeteria style, it's easy to customize your meal. Scallions, cilantro and tempura flakes can be added after you pay. There are many communal tables and even outdoor seating. My personal favorite is the cold udon with beef and soft boiled egg. Next time I will try the mentaiko udon, that looked delicious! They also have onigiri and I got the mentaiko which was super yummy.

If you plan on getting tempura sides stick to a regular size for your udon. We tend to order with our eyes and get more then we actually can eat (my leftovers kept pretty well so, that worked for me)

The udon here is so good, cooked perfectly and slightly chewier then what I've had here in America. The broth is super good, the price is decent (under $9 for a meal!) and I didn't have to fly to Honolulu to get it!
author: Samantha D.

description:
4.5 stars! I have never craved udon until I've had Marugame! The wait is inevitable, so prepare for the wait and come with a good company. 

Parking is always reasonable. You will find a table despite the long line of customers. 

In terms of food: you can see the fresh udon in the making. I don't think you can go wrong with any of the menu items, but my personal favorites are the curry udon (#3) and beef udon with egg (#2). The egg and the udon noodles are cooked to perfection - Yum! And you get to pile up as many toppings as you want! 4.5 instead of 5 stars because the udon dishes can get quite salty and leave you quite thirsty. 

As for the sides, the potato croquettes and salmon musubi are the bomb. I always order large udon AND get too many sides, and leave looking like a 6 month pregnant woman. 

Recommended? Absolutely! Pile on those sides and regret it each time like me :P
author: Solongo B.

description: Curry flavored udon taste really bad. Curry doesn't taste like curry. Udon was too rubbery. Pork flavored (Kachu)udon was ok good. 4stars subtracts 1 star=3 stars.
author: Heather K.

description:
We had a good lunch here, though I wasn't as impressed as I was with the Hawaii location.  Good food, fast service at the counter, and a spacious setting (unfortunately, not very baby-friendly, as there was no changing table in either restroom).

My husband and I each got the curry udon, which was good, but a bit on the sweet side.  The potato croquette and zucchini tempura were okay.

The setting is such that you wait in a long but quickly moving line, get your food cafeteria style, and then seat yourself.  It's mainly self-service.

The location is modern and quite spacious, with both indoor and outdoor seating.  There are two large bathrooms, but neither has a changing table, which we found disappointing, since we came with our baby.  There is plenty of room in each bathroom for a changing table - I hope they will consider adding them.

Overall, a good spot.  Given the crazy long lines, I'm afraid we got the wrong things - we'll have to get different udon dishes next time we come.
author: Barnali D.

description:
This place gets super packed. Tried it for the first time as we came on a Saturday night. The line was long.... maybe too long. The restaurant is pretty trendy. Its all self serve. Pretty much order as you go. No tip is required. Parking can be a bit hard to find since the restaurant is located inside the mall. 

I ordered the beed udon. It was pretty good, but it was a bit too salty for my taste. Maybe too much MSG? 
Overall, maybe I was expecting a lot more from this place as I had heard a lot of good reviews about this place. 
I might give it another chance next time i am around the city and try something else. Until next time!
author: Chul L.

description:
Honestly, with the long line and so many good reviews, I expected this place to be a lot better. The main highlight is obviously the udon noodles, they're quite fresh, but even then the noodles could have been cooked better to give a nicer, more chewy and pleasant texture and taste.

I had the Nikutama, which came with beef and a raw egg. The dish was at best lukewarm by the time I had it, and they could have definitely kept it hotter for longer. The sauce was a bit strong and concentrated, which is fine but this sauce was really one dimensional, tasting pretty much exclusively of soy and dashi.

The meat also wasn't all that good, and the green onions they gave us looked poorly chopped and not all that nice (it is available in a self serve area in a giant ugly pile).

The tempura was also not really up to par, even though they fry it in front of you while in line, it tasted like it had been sitting around for a while.
author: Tyler T.

description:
Trick is to come on an earlier weekday closer to closing time! The line actually moves at a decent rate, probably came at 9:30 and only waited maybe 15-20 min. The nikutama udon is quite solid. Really hits the spot. The handpulled noodles are delicious- the meat is tasty and the broth super flavorful and lots of depth! Lives up to the hype! The tempura on the other hand was horrible! Maybe it was an off-night? But the batter was really bad- not crispy- super stale and flat, like it was sitting out all day. 

Would definitely return for the udon!
author: Vivian D.

description:
I am definitely one of those people that cringe at the thought of waiting in line. However, I also been longing to go to Marugame for months. So I sucked it up and decided to wait. The udon gods must be on my side because I only waited for about 30 mins which isn't terrible considering how I heard people waited for much longer. 

I think it's pretty cool how it's cafeteria style and you move along a line. I got the regular beef udon and also grabbed a seafood tempura and potato croquette. The regular sized beef udon is more than enough if you want to enjoy tempuras and their other offerings. I would suggest not getting too greedy as the price adds up quickly per tempura (I think it was almost $2 per tempura). 

The broth for the beef udon was good. Light and flavorful- perfect for a foggy SF day. However, their udon was a bit soft for my liking. Not sure if it's suppose to be like that or I waited too long to eat it. The beef was flavorful too, but they weren't that generous (even though it looked it in the photo). 

Seafood tempura was good and I liked the sweet tempura sauce you can get at the station. I was honestly disappointed at the potato croquette- wasn't that flavorful and kinda bland. 

Tip: make sure to stop by the self-serve station and fill up on green onions, cilantro, and tempura bits for your udon.
author: Eva L.

description:
Came here on Sunday at 5:30pm and the wait was only about 10-15 minutes. Definitely wasn't expecting it to be that quick but glad it moved that fast. I would say there was probably about 30 people ahead of us. I didn't know until I got inside that it's like a cafeteria style restaurant. You start by telling them which udon bowl you want and the rest of the line up until the cashier you can pick and choose what tempuras you want. I got the shrimp, fish cake and fish. All decent. There's also some freshly made onigiris at the end that you can grab. After you pay for the food, there's a condiments bar where you can get your green onions, cilantro, grated ginger, tempura sauce and tempura flakes. This is awesome, I really liked this. After assembling your tray, it can be a challenge finding a place to sit. I can see finding a seat being really annoying during the lunch and dinner rushes. 

After getting seating, I of course had to take a sip of the broth to gauge the flavor. It's a very light soy saucy kind of broth. It was a bit sweet but that's probably because I got the beef. I threw a buttload of green onions into the bowl and got a lot of the ginger on the side. The noodles are amazing and super fresh. When you order your bowl you can see them make and cook the noodles in front of you. The tempura were all decently good. As I was picking what I wanted they ran out of some vegetables so I was little disappointed there. I ended up getting a bunch of seafood. The shrimp tempura was good. Tasted like any other shrimp tempura really. The fish tempura I thought was awesome. You can see the little fish tail at the end, nice and crispy. The fish cake I thought was all right but I only got it because there wasn't any fried asparagus available. 

When you finish, you need to bus the trays yourself which is located behind the condiments bar. Overall, this was a great place to get udon. Just wish they kept the tempura trays constantly stocked. Would 100% come back but I am not sure if I would wait any longer than 30 minutes for this.
author: Andrew T.

description:
First time here, and I truly wish they had a location in the East Bay.

I had seen these during my trips to Japan, but never thought twice about going inside. Udon wasn't exactly on the top of my list of Japanese foods to try.
But that has all changed.

I had the Nikutama Udon, Large.

Great Portions!
The broth was absolutely amazing. After one taste, Ithought I was back in Japan. No ramen in The Bay, nor any other Japanese food gave me the feelings of being back in Japan. Outstanding Broth. About as authentic as you can get.

The noodles are freshly made, and it shows. The absolute best udon noodles I've ever had.
The half boiled egg was perfect. Loved mixing the yolk with my noodles.

The tempura, croquette, and onigiri were overpriced and underwhelming. I've had better at Japan's conbini. These were the only things that dropped my review to 4 stars.

I love the atmosphere. Every employee shouting "Irasshai!" or "Irasshai-masé!". This is a truly Japanese atmosphere. The best I have ever experienced here in the USA. 

I'll be back for sure. I'll just be skipping the tempura and onigiri.
You should too.
author: Ron Z.

description:
Amazing udon at good prices! The first thing to note is that this isn't a place to write your name/party down and wander around; you'll need to stand in line and wait. Our party of three came on a Saturday night and it took about 45 minutes until we were able to order. The line can run out the door, and is sectioned off in two parts outside to avoid blocking the walkway. Once you get inside, the place functions as a cafeteria and being able to watch them make the udon noodles as you continue down the line makes for a pretty cool experience!

We ordered the Tonkotsu, Nikutama, and Mentai Kamatama Udon and loved all of them - each had its own distinct flavor and the noodles were perfectly chewy. The Mentai can be a bit salty, so we poured in only half of the sauce that came with it. We were starving, and the regular size was pretty filling! Also loved their tempura, especially the potato croquette and the zucchini options - yum. Don't forget about the self-serve station for green onions, cilantro, tempura flakes, and sauce as well.

Located at Stonestown, so parking is plenty, and staff is friendly!
author: Winnie N.

description:
Cafeteria style where you place your order and watch the magic happen. Udon is made fresh in front of you and your dish is assembled as you order. 

I got the egg drop udon noodles soup which came light on broth but full of flavor. Broth was thick and coated the noodles well. Full of egg and chicken. Noodle quality itself was quite good. Has that sink in your teeth feel with chewy texture. 

To accompany your udon, there's self serve tempura. Tempura was delicious. Crispy, lightly battered. Highlights were the shrimp tempura. Delicious!
author: Michelle C.

description:
For us, worth the wait (perhaps because we were hungry)!  Came 8pm on a Sunday night, the second attempt at this- still a half hour wait since there was a long line.

How it works: it basically works as an assembly line, where you pick up a tray, tell the workers what you want, pick up your finished udon, pick up tempura and / or onigiri, and then pay.  There is also a spot to put condiments on your udon.  Large portion is almost 2x the size of the regular in terms of amount of noodles.  

Venue / Service: Very brightly lit inside with light wood accents.  What surprised us the most was the fact that the number of people coming in matched the number of people going out; I never saw anyone with their tray waiting for a seat!  Service-wise, it's hard to tell but they seemed friendly enough.  Only critique was that they seemed a bit inconsistent with how much broth each bowl got- I had a large amount of broth while my date got half a bowl of broth (and we both ordered large sized portions).  

-- Large-sized Beef Udon ($8.90) - large is quite large; think twice before ordering it if you want tempura and such!  Nevertheless, the broth for the beef udon was delicious- light in color and taste but still flavorful!  Noodles were well cooked for me as well.  I highly recommend adding scallions on top for a bit of freshness.  

-- Assorted Tempura ($1.30 for sweet potato and $1.90 for shrimp, per piece) - tempura were all quite tasty!  Also liked how they weren't too oily and such; also appreciated how the sweet potato tempura (my favorite) was given in large slices!

--  Salmon onigiri ($1.60 each) - a bit much if you have a large portion udon but I liked my onigiri.  A bit inconsistent with the filling however; my date noted how his crab onigiri had only crab at the top and the rest was rice while mine had a good amount of salmon throughout it.  Still came out to be a lot of rice, but otherwise was fine.

Worth a try, not sure if I'd wait more than 30 min for this though.  Otherwise was pretty tasty and worth the wait.
author: Audrey H.

description:
While the line seems long is goes by very quickly! I've been to this place three times and I have yet to be disappointed. The broth is tasty and the eggs and meat are so full with flavor, it's great! I always get the potato croquet (who doesn't love potatoes) and I never regret it.

I've read this place isn't as good as ones in Hawaii but if you're in the area try this place out!
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Pulled up at 9pm Friday, waited ~5 minutes outside and trickled into the cafeteria line. Lots of seating but hard to get around some tables. I grabbed meself a black tray and watched noodles get cut through a large dough shredder, plopped into hot water, and shaped into a loose knot before it was served into a warmed-up bowl. 10 noodle options, regular or large, ranging from $5-$9. After receiving my #10 bowl, I slid ze tray down to the tempura and onigiris ($1-$2 ea.). Paid some money and hoarded half a cup of cilantro/green onion, a dollop of tempura crumbs, and a swab of crushed ginger (spicy). Didn't get sauces. Found meself a set, itadakimasu, and chomped. 

Chicken was so tender, soup was slightly viscous, noodles broke a bit easily but still had a good QQ texture. Potato croquet was slightly garlicy and so soft yum. Inari was a bit too sweet. Tempuras were good--steamed veggies and light batter. the #2 with beef was sweet but flavorful. So much food! 

Yummo!
author: Lydia Z.

description:
Yes! I'm so happy MARUGAME UDON came to the Bay Area.

I went around 5pm on a Sunday and was seated within 25 minutes. Not too bad. I actually thought it'd be a lot longer based on everyones' reviews. Note: I probably wouldn't wait more than 30 minutes for this place, so I'd recommend coming off hours. Parking sucks, but hey, it's Stonetown.

I ordered their #2 Nikuyama Udon w/ beef (R). The noodles were deliciously cooked right in front of us. I could have ordered a (L) for a dollar more, but I wanted to splurge the calories on the shrimp tempura add-on, which was fresh and hot. The add-ons are a tad bit expensive for sure. The included egg was also yummy and added to the thick, flavorful texture of the sauce.

Overall, I'm excited about this location and the place was extremely clean, presentable and had a great line control. I would totally come here again and would recommend it. I spent around $14 bucks, which is definitely more on the conservative side here.
author: Chinsin S.

description:
Did the hype just totally fly over my head and forget to hit me in this face?

My mom and I came here on a Tuesday around 6pm thinking that it wasn't gonna be that bad of a wait and even though the line was out the door it did seem to move at a steady pace so I can't really complain too much. Probably a 20 min wait honestly. 

Their menu is posted outside and at the door so you're able to really figure out what you want before you reach the counter. All dishes are udon. There is no other option which sort of sucks because my boyfriend isn't a big soup person so I can't really see myself bringing him here but between my mom and I, I got a regular #1 which was the udon in the wooden bowl and my mom opted for their beef udon. 

The process is pretty cool, I suppose. You grab your tray and a side dish and then you can watch the person make the udon by hand as you're ordering. Put your tray up on the mat and the person will place your bowl of udon on top of it then you grab your tray and continue down the line to all their tempura and musubi options. Be wary and keep your eyes peeled. Everything is by the piece so don't go too wild unless you can afford to then why listen to me at all. 

6pm on a Tuesday night and they're out of curry. I wanted to bring home a large curry udon to my dad, but they were out. Asked if I could order it later, maybe when they make more? Girl taking the orders said, "we won't have any." 6pm on a Tuesday. When you're opened till 11. Really? Ooookay. 

After you're done grabbing your side dishes you pay and from there you can bring it to the little stand that's off to the side to sprinkle your tempura flakes and green onion into your udon. Tempura sauce and utensils are also located on the same stand. Eat and once you're done you clean up after yourself and place your trays and bowls in the designated area. A little confused on how this is done as there were workers helping when I was eating and when it came time to clean up, no worker assisted and I was stuck with a group of people who were all trying to figure out what piece of trash went into which bin. 

Also at one point there was just a giant gap in the line which I could see why the line would take a while to move now as at one point they were scrambling to make more udon leaving people to wait. 

Overall, it's a pass. My friend raved about how good this place was the day prior to me and I wish he was right but I felt no joy in eating the food. The broth for #1 was legit water and even though they added a sauce to the side there was not much to rave about. I didn't eat the tempura, but my mom did and she said it wasn't worth it at almost $2 a piece.
author: Venus L.

description:
Marugame Udon has finally opened in the Bay! That means I don't have to book a flight to Hawaii anymore just to get my Marugame fix!!! 

Just to warn you, the line is usually out the door, especially during prime lunch and dinner hours. If you're lucky, you'll spend the majority of your time waiting in the sun. But when Karl the Fog rolls into SF, a jacket is necessary to survive the cold outside- so think ahead and bring a light jacket! I went on a late Thursday evening an hour before closing. Even though it was 10 pm, there was still a line with about 10 people in front of me and I still had to stand outside in the cold- good thing I wore a coat that night. To cut down the wait time, I would recommend coming here right before closing. But if you decide to go during the busy hours, don't worry too much since the line moves fairly quickly. 

The "cafeteria style" makes the whole ordering process a little more efficient. When you're standing in line by the door, you'll notice the chefs preparing udon from scratch. Once you get to the ordering window, simply tell them which udon combo you want and they'll make it fresh to order. After you receive the bowl of udon from the window, pick up a couples pieces of tempura and/or onigiri. There's variety of tempura to choose from including squid, sweet potato, zucchini, vegetable croquette, and more. After, don't forget to head over to the complimentary station bar to upgrade your bowl of udon with green onions, cilantro, crunchy tempura flakes. 

During my first visit, my friend and I both ordered a hot bowl of plain Bukkake udon. I grabbed few pieces of tempura (sweet potato, squid, vegetable croquette) and a salmon onigiri on the side. In my opinion, the tempura was alright, nothing too special. I prefer my tempura to be super hot and fresh out of the frier, not warm under the heat lamp. The batter was a little too thick for my liking, and it lost some of its crunchy texture since it was only warm. Out of the tempuras I had selected, I liked the vegetable croquette the best. If you like onions, this one is for you since it contains mostly onions and shredded carrots! My favorite part of the meal was, of course, the udon! I was able to taste the high-quality ingredients and freshness in the udon. The udon noodles were smooth, soft, and had the perfect chew to it. It was delicious!     

What's not to love about Marugame Udon? The prices are very reasonable and the food is super fresh and delicious! The only downside is the long line, but if you have some time to spare, wait it out so you can have a taste of the udon!
author: Michelle F.

description:
Affordable udon that is fresh. I was eager to try this location because my first experience at Marugame Udon was in Hawaii two months ago. In Hawaii, there was a long line as well, and I devoured that bowl of udon. It was mouthwatering and overall, the best meal I had in Hawaii. So setting my standards quite high, I was looking forward to this location.

It's easy to find with ample mall parking. Located next to a Chipotle. I came here on Easter night and the rest of the mall was closed, but to my surprise, the restaurant was not, thankfully. The line wrapped around a few times, but I waited no more than 30 mins like I did in Hawaii. You order in a single file line as you see the staff create orders right in front of you. Once you actually make your way into the restaurant, the rest of line goes by quickly. 

It was a bit difficult to find seating for two. I managed to find one somewhat quickly after clearing the table myself. I saw this group of 4 making a dispute and almost forcing this table to hurry up and leave. As for actual food, I was underwhelmed. It was salty and the flavors I expected weren't there. Even after a long day, I found myself struggling to finish my bowl. I'd come back here again because it's cheap and affordable. But I'm sad I have to lower my standards.
author: Janet S.

description:
This hits the spot when it comes to my udon cravings.  If only the line were shorter, I'd maybe give it an extra half star.  

Egg is a must get.  The creamy custardy egg is perfect with the ramen.  I wish the beef was less fatty, but fat = flavor!  If you want a combo with both egg and beef, order #2 is where it's at.  The regular is quite filling as it expands in your stomach!

I got here at 11:30 and waited maybe 40 minutes in line.  They didn't have all the tempura options available.  Got the tempura zucchini only because I craved a little bit of veggies. I also tried the salmon onigiri.  It lacked salmon and was mostly rice, so I'd pass next time as the noodles were already filling.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I've never heard of Marugame before and noticed that the lines are always extremely long so I wasn't sure if it would be worth it. Needless to say it was.

I've been to this udon shop twice now. First time I ordered the Tonkotsu Udon and second I ordered the Nikutama Udon. Both were amazing. From past experiences I never had much of an opinion on udon because it was generally pretty flavorless. The broth here was packed with flavour and it's thoroughly mixed with the noodles, so you can taste it with every bite. 

I did  not have much of an opinion on the tempura, but the Musubi was also amazing. They have a time stamp on them so you know it's fresh, and also the filling in the middle is not too concentrated - so it's not overall salty and compliments the rice well. Gonna keep coming back till I try everything on this menu haha.
author: Galen W.

description:
We often have days where we crave a noodle soup but aren't in the mood for ramen or pho, and udon fits the bill perfectly!

When they first opened up earlier this year, we found ourselves waiting an hour or two. Now that the hype has died down, the wait is significantly shorter especially if you go mid-week. The line moves pretty quickly and there is never a wait for a table. They have an outdoor seating area that's fenced in, so we've even brought our dog before.

Our favorites are the Nikutama (a must try!), the curry udon, and the beef udon. I love the Nikutama but I'm going to do my best at trying the other options on the menu starting next time. The tempura is also delicious so we usually each get a couple of those to go with our udon. They have a toppings/sauce bar for you to customize your bowl. 

I've never been to the one in Hawaii, but my fiancée was born in Japan and gives Marugame a 4 out of 5 stars, so that says something!
author: Olivia V.

description:
The udon here is so good!! It's got so much flavor and the free toppings are a plus!! I really love it!!

The only time it gets expensive is when you grab some sides... they can really rack up a bill without you noticing! 

The line to just get in is really long so expect a wait time of 30mins - 1hr+ sometimes!  It's very popular and the udon alone is a lot cheaper compared to most other restaurants in SF.
author: Ashley Marie B.

description:
Firstly, we are loyal fans of Marugame since our first experience in Hawaii. So if it's your first time here, you'll have to know the basics: 
* Expect long waits (come 30 min before opening is what I recommend)
* But also expect fresh udon made to order right in front of you, amazing tempura selection fried to a crisp, and a topping area to decorate your udon bowl. 
* Reasonable prices with each bowl ranging from $7-$9. Two bowls of udon + 7 pieces of tempura added to about $32 for us two. But it was more than enough food. 
* Always super friendly staff who greet you in Japanese. 

Udon here is SOLID. Tempura is even better. Rice balls are underwhelming though. My main complaint is the amount of salt in the udon. The top half of the bowl of udon (mostly without broth) is spot on. The noodles taste fresh- nothing like packaged instant udon. The meat is so soft and tender. The beef was perfectly marinated in a light soy sauce. However, the bottom half of the bowl was extremely salty. My date agreed as well, so naturally we added water to drown out the salt. The "soft boiled egg" was overcooked but my date's egg was perfectly soft boiled. A bit inconsistent on the egg cooking but not a huge deal breaker for me. 

Some of my favorite tempura: Fried squid, potato croquette, and fried fishcake. 
Pass on the chicken karage, shrimp, and aji fry.

Service is excellent! The staff are extremely efficient and keep the line moving. We were the very first customers of the day and we felt so welcomed. 

Interior is really clean and sleek. Not to mention, the short chairs with the cushions are really comfortable. There's booths, tables, as well as limited patio seating. Parking is easy since this location is right outside of a shopping mall. 

Considering the many many great places to eat in SF, I wouldn't say Marugame Udon is a *must* But if  you really like udon and tempura, definitely check this place out. Come for the awesome cafeteria style service and delicious noodles. 

Tip: It is first-come, first-serve. No reservations and no calling ahead!
author: Sandra N.

description:
We went to the one in Hawaii and it sparked a newfound love for Udon.

So glad they opened one in SF! Taste is just as good as zi remembered.
author: Daniel L.

description: This spot is located in Stonestown and there is parking all over but might get busy on the weekends so you would have to search a little bit.  We came here on a Saturday and we waited about a good 30 minutes before we got seated.  The line looked really long but it actually went pretty quick.  You pretty much get your noodles first before you sit down.  I feel as if the one in Honolulu taste a little better than the one here but I'm not sure if they are the same restaurant. Great spot if you are in the mood for some Udon.
author: Ben Z.

description:
Yasss!!! Love. This. Place. 

The udon noodles are fresh AF. Okurrrrrrtttt

I usually get the bukake and add an egg. It has so much flavor bih. Literally. It's so simple but so good. I just add hella toppings later, like the tempura flakes, spicy pepper or wwhatevaa. As for the tempura itself, I like the shrimp, chicken, and the fish. I can't talk enough about how fresh the noodles are tho. Forreal. 

Knocking down one star because their sushi roll/musubi whatever is weak af!! It's just a big ball of rice. We got two of them, forgot which. One of the manager/ owner happened to be next to me while I was eating it and saw that there was only rice inside. So he had a staff make me a new one. Well when I got the new one it was exactly the same  it was all rice with a little bit of crab on top. Wtf! Lol. Save yourself $2 and get another tempura instead. 

Oh yeah it's hella loud inside and you just find a seat where ever. You could be sitting at a table with people you don't know. But it's normal.
author: Jana E.

description:
Marugame has been life-changing. 

Four months ago, I was young and ignorant and had no appreciation for udon. But then I discovered Marukame during my trip to Oahu and I was changed. My family and I loved it so much that we came back two days later. And, I was ecstatic to learn upon my return to SF about their soft opening right in the city!

I love this place because it's fast, affordable, and the quality of food is top notch. It is "self-serve cafeteria-style" meaning you line up, order your udon, select your a la carte tempura sides, pay, then find a seat. It's a very efficient process and I've almost never had a problem finding seats since people rotate out so quickly. 

In the span of a couple months, I had been to Marugame / Marukame four times. I've tried most of the udons on the menu but my all-time favorite is the Nikutama. It comes with sweet beef and a poached egg, which are the perfect additions to the already perfectly flavored broth and perfectly chewy noodles. Also, the udon is made right in front of you so it is super fresh!   

Both times I went to the SF-location was around 9pm on a weekend and the line took a bit over 30 minutes. But I have faith that it will get better with time especially since the restaurant is still so new. (The Hawaii location will always have a special place in my heart because they are crazy efficient, the prices are lower and they are very generous with their broth.) Thank goodness Marugame is not located closer to downtown otherwise I don't think I could stop myself from going every single day.
author: Alice S.

description:
Finally! The Bay Area gets a taste of the magical udon that is Marukame Udon in Honolulu. From my understanding, this is all the same chain and they opened two new spots, one in SF and one in LA. 

This store is located at Stonestown Galleria, an extremely busy shopping center next to SF State. There's tons of parking available, but be prepared to park a little far and walk, especially if you go on the weekend. When you arrive, there's more than likely going to be a line. The line is split into two parts so that people don't block the walkway. There's generally a staff member outside to let you know. Be prepared to wait 45 minutes - 1 hour most days.

What I love about this place is that they make their udon fresh! You can see them make everything as you go through the line. You know what you're getting is as fresh as it can be! The udon is so good and has the perfect texture and firmness.

I've tried both the Nikutama udon and the curry udon. Both are amazing in their own way. The Nikutama comes with their beef, a soft boiled egg and some Kake sauce. This is a very simple dish yet so delicious. The curry udon comes with beef and their curry soup. The soup is a little on the thicker side, but there's so much flavor. 

As you go through the line, you have the option to get some various tempura or musubi on the side. I personally like the potato croquette and the fish cake. After you pay, they have unlimited tempura flakes, cilantro and green onion toppings.

Overall, a great place for udon, arguably the best in the Bay Area in my opinion. You can't get fresh, quality udon for the price anywhere else!
author: Gabriel N.

description:
The udon noodles are pretty good here!

...But the 30-45min line (usually outside) + the kinda too-sweet "broth" makes Marugame just okay.

So the experience goes, you drive and find decent parking. Then you spot the lines outside. No lines? Then you're set to go! I know some people miss this from Hawaii, but seeing how much shorter the lines have become since opening makes me wonder if it's as good as the original.

Once inside, you follow the line cafeteria-style where you make your order and size. They portion the udon and give you your order, where you proceed to stock up on various tempura and savory sides. You pay, then load up on complimentary unlimited green onions, ginger, and sauce.

Finding seating, of course, depends on how busy the place is. It didn't seem too hard to find a seat despite it being crowded, though some seats can be sticky from previous patrons.

As for me, I've gotten the beef udon twice. I remember the items with the largest photos are "the most popular", but they sound too fancy for me haha. In short, the udon is plenty and very delicious - and the broth is a little sweet/salty that tastes really good at first, but then weighs you down as you end your meal. Not the best feeling in the world, and I don't think that feeling is worth it.

Overall, if you're missing the original or are playing the "What should we eat? Oh that place is new and lots of people are in line", Marugame Udon is not a bad place to try.
author: Greg G.

description:
Yaaaas!  It's like i'm in hawaii but less tropical over here in SF.  Everything is pretty much the same as the one in Hi.  Long lines, check.  Fresh made udon, check.  tempura, check. onigiri, check.  What more do you want?  Udon is relatively cheap here, it's the extras that can really make a meal expensive.  I got the spicy chicken udon.  Has just the right amount of spicy, and chicken was tender.  Yummy!

Things move pretty quickly here.  Came on Saturday, at 430pm.  Line was extremely manageable (~15 mins).  I've heard the lines can get absurdly long, so come at odd hours to minimize the wait.

Tip: don't save seats for your party if they're still in line.
author: Roger K.

description: Sometimes it's the simple things that make us happy! I love this place.  Their udon is house made and always super soft.  The broth is also not too heavy so perfect when you're craving something filling yet light.   Ramen udon was also good, though I'd recommend their other classic udons like the mentai if it is your first time.  Their side tempuras are also also quite yummy! I recommend the karaage chicken tempura and the sweet potato!
author: Hailey C.

description:
Like many other eagerly anticipated eateries, this one has quite the line.  Good thing my husband is more than ok to stand somewhere playing on his phone while I shop in the mall :)

Food was good (flavorful broth & good noodle texture) and portions were more generous than I anticipated.  Loved that they had a toppings bar where you can add crispy tempura bits, various sauces, and greens like green onions & cilantro.  Also loved the variety of sides and onigiris available right before you hit the cashier.

The only weird thing is the bathroom situation.  I'm all for the unisex, but the multi-stall set-up have gaps in between the doors making it kind of uncomfortable for both genders to be in there at the same time.  If anyone from Marugame is reading, please invest in those gap privacy strips!
author: Sheila C.

description:
Ughhhhh, Marugame why are you so good?!

There are so many reasons why this place is great if you're an udon fan! Freshly made noodles out front, a variety of tempura, different options of udon i.e. hot or cold, dry, dipping or curry and self-serve toppings!

At lunchtime, the line was out the door but the line moved fast. During my wait, I was able to watch them prepare the udon noodles. Boil, boil, boil the noodles are so plump and pretty! I like that the bowls are prewarmed before it's filled with hot broth to keep your food warmer for longer. I decided to go for the classic Beef Udon; thinly sliced beef, broth, scallions and udon noodles. For tempura, I just grabbed one Shrimp Tempura to try. The Udon broth was pretty good, savory and clean, slightly sweet tasting and not cloyingly oily. The beef was sliced thin, was tender and good flavor, but wish they gave a little bit more beef. The udon is where it's at, I don't know if I was just wowed by watching them prep the udon in the open kitchen but the noodles were amazing. Great texture, nice bite and not mushy at all. The tempura here had great texture, batter wasn't too thick and tasted soo good when dipped in the broth. I thought portion was it made for a great meal and the price is affordable!

The interior space is big, but because it's crowded there is a lot of standing around looking for open spots which can be a bit awkward as you stand there with your tray and your hawk eyes on. Other than that, its a great spot for lunch or dinner. Parking can be a bit of an issue since it's located in Stonestown and the lunch time rush is real ... hungry college students + cheap meals ... you know how that is. Great price for a filling and delicious bowl of udon and they have a good variety to choose from!
author: Janet N.

description: This place is amazing! The line is usually long but totally worth the wait and if you think about it, it's quicker than ordering at your table and waiting for your food. The staff is extremely nice and helpful as well. I got the Spicy tonkatsu udon is was soo good. You can also get sides like tempura veggies, potato croquettes and onigiris.
