I love how you can add your own toppings and customize it to how you like it. What topped it all off for me was their music taste. They played a lot of BTS and LOONA so I got lit while eating. I'll be coming here everyday now.
author: Lexy S.

description:
3.5 Stars. I was excited to try Marugame Udon, especially since I loved their Hawaii location. I came here on a Saturday night and the wait was over one hour in the freezing cold. When I finally got in the door, I was getting more and more excited. I ordered the large Nikutama Udon ($9.50) and then selected shrimp, zucchini, and squid tempura along the self-select stations.

What I like most about Marugame is that their udon noodles are fresh, made right in front of you, and have perfect texture. I also like the taste of their sweet beef and broth. Another plus is that you can choose your own tempuras and other add-ons individually. Their self-serve toppings bar of green onion, cilantro, ginger, and tempura flakes is a fun addition. 

What I did not like about Marugame is that they didn't give much broth with our noodles (I like a lot of broth), the tempura by itself was bland (only tastes decent in tempura dipping sauce), the long wait (obviously), and... when it was time to pay, I saw the cashier's screen which had the correct total. After I gave the cashier my credit card, he quickly added one more piece of zucchini tempura, then slid my card very fast. I called him out on it and then he did refund me the overcharged tempura, but it seemed very shady. If I didn't pay attention, he probably would have gotten away with it. Just make sure to check your receipt. 

Overall, the udon noodles itself are pretty good. The regular size might have a better noodle to broth ratio, but the large bowl is so much more worth it (only one dollar more for almost double the amount of noodles). The broth and beef are great with the udon, but it doesn't have an absolute wow factor. Plus, we want more of it. This would have been closer to a 4-star experience, but rounding down to 3 because of the shady overcharge.
author: Jean S.

description:
After trying the one in Honolulu which was out of this world, I was eager to try the one in Stonestown Mall. Let me preface my review with a few facts: I tried it twice, I lived and worked in Japan for ten years and my partner is a native born Japanese so I have had my fair share of steaming hot udon at restaurants and at home. 

The first time I went, the tempura was cold, the second time I went the udon broth was lukewarm, one of the cooks apologized for serving me what he said was an egg that was unacceptable to his standards, which I did appreciate, and there was no tempura at all that day because the fryer was down.  

Udon has to be served boiling hot and immediately once it is ready, otherwise it won't taste its best; if you don't see the cooks hustling as fast as the ones at the Daly City In-n-Out burger joint, than you are in trouble, because you end up with wait times in line that are too long and food that will never live up to expectations.  This company should pay for one of the Honolulu restaurant managers to be flown to San Francisco to whip the San Francisco staff into shape. 

I don't mind paying more that usual for lunch or dinner if the food quality is excellent, but when it isn't, the prices leave a final and lasting sting to them. I paid over fifty bucks for three people over lunch because we added a normal portion of tempura to our udon.
author: Anthony Z.

description:
We got here 10 minutes before opening on a Sunday and had to wait 40 minutes for our food. The worker suggested coming here from 2-5pm on a weekday to avoid a long wait. We ordered the Nikutama, curry udon and egg, and shrimp tempura.

Nikutama: 5/5. There was a hefty amount of beef and the soft boiled egg was the perfect addition to cut the saltiness of the sauce. Definitely recommend.

Curry udon: 4/5. We've gotten this twice during the soft opening and both times were better than this time. They really skimp on the beef now and the broth was a lot soupier and not thick enough.

Shrimp tempura: 3/5. Nothing special honestly but it's not bad.

Overall, the price was great, but I recommend trying to come here not at peak times.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Marugame Udon is new and full of hype located at Stonestown Mall next to Olive Garden. There is a line out the door when we arrived yesterday night around 645pm. We got inside in less than 15 mins as the line moved quickly. Inside, is a cafeteria style set up in which you grab your tray and your tempura dish. You move along to order your choice of udon in which they place in your tray after they fill it with broth and toppings. There are two sizes: regular and large. You then move right along to the self serve tempura and musubi station where an abundant varieties of vegetable kaklage, sweet potato, zucchini, fish cake, squid, shrimp, musubi and inari, awaits you. After the pay station, there is a additional toppings station where you can add ginger, green onions, cilantro and tempura flakes. 

We ordered 2 regular size Beef Udon and 1 regular size spicy chicken. Unfortunately, the beef was not edible as it was a long chain of fat and tendons. I do have to give props to the freshly tasting noodles. However, broth was lukewarm and salty. The spicy chicken was okay, chicken was lean with no fat. The broth was spicy, sour and salty at the same time. In addition, the broth tasted seafood-y and my boyfriend hates seafood so bad experience for him. I also ordered a sweet potato tempura which was cold and hard as it was sitting on a rack for who knows how long. We were able to get seats with the table just cleaned however, we walked by tables filled with food that needed attention. 

I would recommend Kagawa-Ya Udon instead for udon and get their spicy tomato with roasted shiitake which is bomb!
author: Annie L.

description:
This udon chain originated from Japan, is the same as Marukame in Honolulu, and tastes amazing. Each bowl is less than $10, but the side add ons can pile up. Be prepared for a wait, I waited 25 minutes. 

The system is super efficient. There was a line moderator outside, and inside, you pay first before sitting. They speak Japanese too!

I ordered the #2 Nikutama udon for $8.50. It comes with egg and sweet flavored beef. I grabbed a side of shrimp tempura and chicken karaage which totaled to around $14.

The BEST side is the chicken. It's so juicy inside yet crispy outside. The other things were just okay for me.

I just came back from Japan, and I can verify that it tastes just as good here :)
author: Corinna T.

description: After visiting Japan, I was sooo happy to see a location here in SF!! If you love udon then you have to come here! They make their udon noodles fresh on the spot. You can even see them in action. I love the idea of being able to pick your own toppings and fried vegetables/proteins. It's also so budget friendly and a perfect location to grab a bite after shopping.
author: Elise L.

description:
Okay this review is probably largely influenced by how excited I am that we finally have a good food option in this area, so bear with me.

I've lived near Stonestown all my life. And all my life, my soul has died a little thinking of the mediocre food that's been at this mall (RIP Chevy's, good riddance Blue C Sushi). At this point, I've had Nordstrom Cafe's entire menu and have borderline OD'd on clam chowder from Boudin.

When I heard Marugame Udon opened up--and that it was doing well and was actually really good--I rejoiced. I envisioned myself walking to the mall, casually grabbing a delicious bowl of udon, loving life in Lakeshore.

Well, we're not there yet, but the future is promising. Marugame Udon opens at 11am. On a Monday, my friend and I showed up at 10:30am to line up based on Yelp reviews. There was already a long line of people waiting (how everyone's free at this hour on a weekday is beyond me). They opened right on time and started funneling people in - luckily, we made it in the first wave.

The order process is cafeteria style, with a person behind the counter taking your udon order, making it, then handing it to you. You then move down the line to the tempura and musubi station to pick your "sides." The process is interesting, but definitely has some growing pains right now. The staff is still learning - I'm pretty sure I got asked for my udon order 4 times within the span of a few minutes. I can't help but think there should be a way to automate that process instead of having the person ask a few people's orders, and then forget it right away. I hope they can figure out how to streamline this process so that they don't have a bottleneck right at the entrance.

Onto the food - I got #5 beef udon and added a few toppings. I also got shrimp, fish cake, and zucchini tempura. All were delicious. The noodles are SO good! The perfect texture. The soup is sweet but exactly what I expected. I did find myself feeling really thirsty afterwards, so not sure about the sodium content there... but ah well. The shrimp tempura was so fresh! I was pleasantly surprised to find that the batter was not soggy at all.

Since this place is new and so popular, the line doesn't seem like it'll die down any time soon. I definitely wouldn't wait more than an hour for this place, but if you have the time to spare and can arrive early, it's worth a try. I'm sooo happy this place opened in Stonestown!
author: Alyssa T.

description:
We came on a Tuesday afternoon, around noon time. There was a bit of a line, but it wasn't as bad as I've seen it. Guess that's the benefit of going on a weekday when everyone's at school/work. You can expect to wait a while on weekends or dinner time probably. We only waited for 20 mins or less which wasn't too bad, honestly. The wait was primarily due to the cafeteria-style design of the ordering process. It wasn't because people were waiting on tables to clear up. There were plenty of seats available, even when we were out the door. Udon is pretty easy and quick meal. 

You start off by choosing which type of udon you want and what size. We tried their curry udon and their nikutama udon, both large sizes. They weigh the udon noodles. After you receive your udon bowl, which is made to order, it's pretty much self-serve from there. There are different types of tempuras and musubis to grab and go along the way to the cashier. I tried their shrimp tempura and zucchini tempura. My boyfriend got their fish cake tempura and one of their salmon musubis. After you pay, you can go to the self-serve topping bar for additional toppings like tempura flakes, green onion, tempura sauce, sweet tempura sauce (tasted like katsu sauce to me), etc. 

The curry udon was good. It tasted like what I expected. The noodles were soft and chewy. I think next time I would go with the nikutama udon, just because it's a little lighter in flavor! I could barely finish my udon. After reading some reviews, I found out that they serve the same amount of noodles for both the small/large sizes and the only difference is the amount of soup they give in each bowl. If that's true, I would've totally gotten the small. I don't drink the soup anyways... 

I don't recommend getting the musubis at all. The salmon musubi barely had any salmon (maybe just a pinch on the top) and the rest was all rice. Wasn't worth it.

I don't think they allow you to reserve seats for your party either. You have to have your food already to sit down and eat. It makes sense though.

All in all, it was a good experience. I would only come again if there wasn't a wait, lol.
author: Sydney C.

description:
MARUGAME UDON is a fast paced udon restaurant in Stonestown mall. If you've been to Honolulu, Oahu, you might have been to Marugame's sister restaurant: Marukame. As the name indicates, they sell different types of udon; they also sell a comprehensive variety of tempura. The restaurant is structured like a cafeteria, you grab a tray and move along the line picking your udon, tempura, and extras. I enjoyed Marugame, it has wholesome but simple food, and I would come back to get my udon fix.
 
There is a line here usually, but it moves surprisingly quick; i waited 20minutes. The venue is casual. They don't have any reservations and you just seat yourself.

Ordered:
Egg drop chicken udon -  Egg bits and strings of chicken bolster the broth into a much thicker texture than than the typical udon broth. The chicken + broth weren't super flavorful compared to the sweet beef udon. Would recommend adding extra green onions and crunchy tempura bits.
author: Sean W.

description:
One of the best udon places I've tried so far in bay area!

This place is inside a shopping center so there's tons of parking. When we got there for Sunday lunch, the line was already huge and we ended up waiting about 30 minutes. Definitely worth the wait!

I love that as you go through the line inside, you can see the chefs making the udon from scratch. You pick your udon, then there's an area of self-serve tempura and then self-serve condiments/toppings. 

NIKUTAMA UDON ($8.50): Comes with beef and an egg. This one is sauce based versus the Beef Udon, which is soup based. It has less volume of liquid than the Beef Udon because the sauce base is more concentrated so if you're more of a soup person I'd go for the Beef Udon, otherwise this one is great and has a strong flavor. 

VEGETABLE TEMPURA ($1.70): It's a mix of carrots, onions, and sweet potatoes. I wish the tempura was more fresh because the one I got was very soggy and not crispy at all.

POTATO CROQUETTE ($2.20) : Decent tasting but next time I would probably get something else. It's super filling and dense so with the udon it was definitely way too much food. 

SHRIMP TEMPURA ($1.90) : This is probably the most popular because when I got to it, there was no more so I had one freshly made and super crispy. Best one by far!

I was really impressed with the udon and how fresh it was. The texture and flavor were both great. Best of all everything is super affordable!
author: Angela P.

description:
Hello piece of Hawaii. 
I'm glad you decided to move a part of you to SF. 

I'm one of those people who waited 45 minutes. I knew what I was getting myself into, but I told myself it was going to be worth it. 

I got the Kama-Age Udon which comes with plain udon and dipping sauce. Honestly, that's probably the best way to go. 

The setup for the line is simple, but ineffective. The first step of ordering and getting the noodles was fine, but the toppings and cashier that comes after is a bit ineffective. That's when the line starts to slow and why a line forms. The selection of toppings was also more limited than the Hawaii location. Lastly, the sauce bar was a mess. Things and juices everywhere and it didn't look appealing. 

Not sure what it is, but I didn't have the same WHOA moment as I did my first time at Hawaii. It wasn't the broth or sauce, it was the noodles. The noodles were off. It wasn't as chewy and it felt less "hand-made" even though it was made by a machine. 

Don't get me wrong, Marugame is awesome, and I still think its worth the wait. It still is one of my favorite places to go for UDON as it is a dying style of noodle. So, keep on coming and support the Udon fam.
author: Fiona L.

description:
I'm really really happy with the opening of this amazing udon spot in Stonestown! I stopped by here yesterday with a friend - weekday night about 6pm - the wait was 45 min. and 110% worth it :) 

It's almost a little nostalgic the way this place is organized - like you're walking through a school cafeteria line and picking up food items along the way (except exponentially more delicious and drool worthy!). I really enjoyed it though, as you get front row seats for the full udon making process! Open seating when you're done, again just like cafeteria/food court style and when you're done, just bring your trays up to the front! 

I wouldn't mind waiting for this place at all - the food is inexpensive (you can get a really good - I mean REALLY good bowl of udon for as little as $4.50!). As affordable as that sounds, I wouldn't deprive myself of all the crunchy, fried goodness waiting for me after I order my noodles and continue my meandering along the line! It's a tempura haven after you get your order of udon - tempura sweet potato, chicken, fishcakes, shrimp, squid, vegetable balls, zucchini etc. etc. I checked out the menu beforehand and I was still not prepared for all those options (all around the $1.80ish range). In my excitement I definitely over-grabbed, but rest assured I have no regrets about that! They also sell musubi, which in actuality I would say should be called a riceball not musubi! Grabbed myself a salmon one of course! ;D (Tip: don't forget to use the tongs when grabbing!). 

To get to the nitty-gritty - Nikutama Udon. The #2. It is everything I would want it to be and more. I hope they never raise the prices but this udon was worth so much more than the $8.50 I paid for a regular bowl. Udon cooked EXACTLY right (I'm looking at you, Tsuortontan in NY!) mixed with the most amazing kake sauce, soft boiled egg, and a super healthy portion of sweetened beef. The flavors just mixed so well together - I'm a savory person, but the sweetness level didn't bother me at all and in fact I rather enjoyed it! The regular was really filling and I just can't get over how happy that udon made me feel - warm, soft-chewy, perfection. This place really knows how to do udon. I definitely want to try the rest (eyeing that egg drop chicken udon!) and I would have no problem waiting either - thanks for making my belly feel super happy, Marugame!
author: Deanna S.

description:
After trying Marukame in Hawaii, I was excited to try Marugame in SF.  I really wanted to like it, but unfortunately, it was severely over hyped and didn't live up to my expectations. 

Curry Udon: The broth was like drinking salty curry flavored water.  It was REALLY salty.  I couldn't drink more than 2 spoonfuls of broth, but the udon noodles were perfect.  There is also little to no meat in the broth because they just scoop the premade broth from a large vat. How much meat you get depends on how lucky you are that day. Today, I got 1 very tiny piece of meat...so I was basically eating noodles with salty broth. 

Salmon Rice Balls:  Just skip it. It may look like there's a lot of salmon in it, but they only put salmon on the top of the rice ball to make it look like it's filled to the brim. In reality, there is less than half a teaspoon of salmon in there.  The rice ball is also just plain rice with no sauce or flavors added.  It was super bland. 

Tempura:  At $1.90 a piece, it's super overpriced. For those of you that want an extra kick to your udon, it might be worth it. But you can quickly rack up your bill by adding 3 pieces of tempura. For the price of 3 pieces of tempura, you can basically get another udon. 

All in all, I might come back to try the beef udon. Maybe that'll be less salty. I definitely won't be adding tempura or rice balls (literally, there's only rice in there) to my meal. & I probably won't wait an hour in line and go out of my way for this food again.
author: Destynnie T.

description:
I would rate this place about 3.5 stars.

Honestly, I was not wowed by their food but how freaking long the line got. I came here on opening weekend, Saturday with Amy. T (a fellow yelper as well), we got here 30 minutes before opening. Thankfully, we made it inside when the doors open so it wasn't too bad for us. I would not wait 2 hours for this. 

Once you get inside, you get a tray and choose your udon (flavor). Amy got number 2, regular $8.50 (nikutama udon), serve with sweet flavored beef, soft boiled egg, and kake sauce. I think it's one of their popular items on their menu. I didn't want to get the same thing, so I decided to get their number 3, regular $6.90 (curry udon), served with classic curry soup and beef. We also ordered fish cake tempura, shrimp tempura, and various musubis to try, $1.50 each. Don't forget to swing by to get your toppings like green onions, chilli, cilantro, fried scallions, etc. all FREE!

I got to try Amy's soup, it was tasty but too salty for my liking. My udon on the other hand tasted like paste. The curry was too thick to be soup and beef was too shredded. In my opinion, the curry was too overwhelming. It would have been better over rice. The musubis was a NO,NO, don't get it!  When we cut the musubis in half, it was all rice, barely any meat inside. We used the rice to dip into my curry lol. That was a lot of CARB. We REGRET for getting 4 musubis! The tempura was not bad, but nothing special. 

I would say opt the musubis and go for tempura if you want additional food. The regular size bowl was good enough to keep me full. Overall, I thought it was alright. I would definitely choose something different if I'm here again.
author: Noel K.

description:
Whenever people ask me about Japanese food in the city, I almost always point them to Marugame. My favorite thing to get is the mentai noodle and it is consistently good. There is a lot of udon out there but I think that good, fresh udon is hard to find. Good udon is soft and slippery, doesn't crumble when you pick it up, and springy enough to give you a good chew. That is the kind of udon you get here at marugame.

All the noodles are made fresh - the dough is made overnight, pressed, rolled out, cut, boiled, and stacked with ingredients before your eyes. It is by no means a fancy restaurant but it definitely gives you a good feel of Japan in efficiency, spirit, and freshness. There is also an assortment of onigiri and tempura, which I don't personally like too much - its a bit cold but nonetheless the noodles are worth the trip. Highly recommend.
author: Tinaa W.

description:
I'm a loyal customer since I've tried this for the very first time in Hawaii. Everything is made fresh to order in front of you. 

I was ecstatic when I heard a location was opening in SF! 

I've been here twice already and each time there was a wait. It moves faster than you think. 

I always order the curry udon. Super delicious, but very heavy. Make sure you get a regular size, so you can try some of the yummy tempura. It can get a little too salty, but I like salty. LOL 

Beware of food coma, because it happens every time to me!!
author: Bonnie T.

description:
I'm Japanese living in Tokyo for more than 20 years. I love this place in Japan. My apartment when I was in shinjuku had Marugame in the first floor and my dinner was more than 3 times a week in Marugame. Looove here. I'm really happy to have this place in bayarea.
I like pretty much all the menu but I haven't tried salsa one it's only here I guess. 
I like cold one like bukkake, mentai in summer. Soup one in winter. Also tempura, onigiri are amazing.
My recommendation on tempura is chicken, fish cake and kakiage/veggie. Especially kakiage, you should put kakiage on top of you udon and eat together.
The taste similar to Japan and I'm really glad even I waited more than 1 hour..
author: Nazuki Y.

description:
I think Marugame might just save the mall industry by its sales alone, judging from the wait. The downfall of Stonestown's Macy's store certainly suggests it might be in need of saving.

Its explosion into the Japanese food scene on the edge of San Francisco was curious. How often do you see a place receive over 100 reviews, with no sign bribing for Yelp reviews at the restaurant, within mere weeks of its opening? Marugame is extremely popular in Hawai'i as Marukame, which explains the hype. We arrived at the opening of its dinner hours, and after 45 minutes, finally made it through the doors into warm, soupy heaven.

"FRESH UDON!" came the cry, as we pored over the menu. Yes, the open kitchen concept allows patrons to see every aspect of the cooking process, from workers cranking out udon dough disks, blanching the noodles in light broth, frying fresh tempura veggies and seafood, and wrapping the musubis. It goes udon order - tempura - musubi - point of sale - drinks - free toppings.

I stuck to the classic and ordered the kama-age udon, fresh noodles dipped in a savory dashi broth that epitomizes the umami bomb. At the topping bar, I added a sprinkle of green onions that really flavored the original udon broth. Having just recovered from wisdom tooth extraction, this was the perfect re-introduction into the wonderful, wide world of salty food. I couldn't stop dipping. It really helped that it came in a cool bamboo bowl and only cost $4.50 for a regular bowl.

When my significant other wasn't looking, I swiped a bit of his curry udon ($6.90), which included gyudon. Although we both expected it to be thinner, a la made-from-Vermont-Curry-package soupy curry, we were amazed at how rich the flavor was. Emily T. opted for the bukkake udon ($4.50), consisting of fresh noodles submerged in a bit of dashi broth. Also a really good option.

The tempura is really another stand-out feature of Marugame. It's just evil that they put it right next to the udon serving station, where innocent, hungry bystanders who have no self-control like me are lured in by the promise of fresh, crispy sides. Some of the foods on the tempura menu are shrimp, chicken, squid, sweet potato, a vegetable pancake, and an especially-great potato croquette.

On the flip side, skip the musubis. While it's cool that they hand-make and wrap them (and include an 'eat-by' sticker so you KNOW it's fresh), I found that the sticky rice outweighed the salmon flakes by a ratio of 10:1, so it really felt like I paid for plain ol' rice.

I recommend that the establishment put up larger signs about not saving seats and tray disposal. The directives to go leave your tray with the dishwashers, with no indication of where that is (hidden behind the toppings bar), only appear on one side of the napkin holders.

Can't wait to return and try their full menu!
author: Gwen W.

description:
Go when it rains. Just kidding, kind of - we came around 7:30pm and it was raining steadily. It was nice that they had big umbrellas set up outside. The line wasn't long and we waited a total of 20 minutes until we ordered. I would say we got pretty lucky! 

The interior is cute and clean. I like the "cafeteria-style" of ordering and you can see the udon being prepared as you move down the line. At the end of the line, there are many different choices of tempura and musubi that you can grab ranging from $1-2. My boyfriend and I both ordered the hot Nikutama udon and grabbed shrimp, chicken, and squid tempura to share. I couldn't resist the musubi so I grabbed a mentai mayo musubi as well. You can see that their items are all fresh because they were constantly putting out more tempura and newly wrapped musubi. My total for 2 people came out to be $29, which isn't bad at all! (My boyfriend got a large sized udon) 

There's a station of complimentary toppings where you can add green onion (my fave!), cilantro, tempura flakes, and seasoning/sauces. Here is also where you get the tempura sauce that's served hot. So hot that it literally melted the plastic container that it was in. They need to do something to fix this because it's definitely not safe for people to still use the tempura sauce in melted plastic. I saw some other people in the same situation. We ended up putting the tempura sauce in a paper cup instead. The tempura was okay, the batter was a little too thick for my liking. 

As for the udon, it was good! It didn't necessarily blow me away, but there was a good amount of sweet beef, and the udon noodles were cooked perfectly and tasted very fresh. Towards the end of my my meal, the broth did get a bit too salty for my liking. Consensus: It's worth a try because of the experience and fresh udon, but I wouldn't wait over an hour for this. Hopefully it dies down a little soon so I can come back and try the mentai udon!
author: Cecille W.

description:
Finally! It's only been open for a month & a half, but Marugame Udon might be the most authentic, casual Japanese dining establishment in the Metropolitan City by the Bay! This quick-service noodle specialist boasts reasonable prices that a family or a group of friends can hella afford!
That's because of the setup: it's a cafeteria-style fast-casual restaurant that feels like it's plucked right out of a busy Tokyo block.
Don't let the lines deter you from trying out this place at the always poppin' retail destination called Stonestown Galleria in SF! Weekends have been HELLLLLA crazy, but on a weekday, just a few minutes wait will get you to a heaping, delicious & comforting bowl of hot, fresh Udon!

Their Grand Opening was on Thursday, January 18th, and the expansive eatery offers a slew of udon noodles (prepared by a machine, naturally), via soup or dry, in various sizes and topping formations. Diners then take the bowl, which is prepared to order, as well as fill their plates with various freshly deep-fried tempura. After paying, there's a station to finish off bowls with fried tempura bits, cilantro, or green onions.

Prices are reasonable, starting at just $4.50 for a basic Kama-Age Udon bowl which is served in a wooden bowl with a flat bottom. Curry and spicy chicken udon add a bit more flair while things like the beef, tomato, tonkotsu (fatty broth), and nikutama add even more fun. The nikutama features a sweet beef broth served in a moderate portion and topped with a soft-boiled egg. Tempura pieces might include asparagus, sweet potato, shrimp, chicken, and squid, and they each cost $1.30 to $2.20 per piece, and can be enjoyed on the side or in the udon bowl itself.

So why is Marugame Udon one of the most authentic Japanese experiences in SF? The self service, the cafeteria-style arrangement, the reasonable prices, and even the dining room, which asks customers to bus their own tables afterwards. All of that is indicative of a traditional fast-casual eating experience one might find in a Japanese city.
author: Alvin M.

description:
This place is so delicious!! I wish they had one in the North Bay!
We went during the week around 4:30... and it wasn't busy at all!
author: Jantel D.

description: When I heard this opened, I was shook. Like too good to be true. The whole time I was thinking of the wonderful experience I had in Hawaii. I'm not sure if they're owned by the same people, but it's basically the same thing. So easy to order and everything's just out and for grabs. Everything about this place is efficient. The food is great and the udon selection is short and simple and you can pick anything and it'll be delicious. I love that they also have rice balls so you can have noodles and rice.
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
*I highly suggest you coming during off hours (before 6pm and not on weekends) if you do not want to wait in a 30+ minute line*

Good price, yummy udon, self serve!!

The concept is brilliant, lining up cafeteria style and grabbing your food as you move down the line makes the wait faster. Once you are done grabbing your food, you sit down and eat. (You are never standing there with your food with no place to sit) 

I always get #2 beef nikutama udon, if it's your first time here do not expect this udon to be soupy. It is a sauce based udon bowl. Super flavorful and they always give a generous amount of beef & a soft boiled egg is included. The udon is hand rolled, boiled and served fresh to order. You get to see how the whole bowl is made in line. 

As you move further down the line, you reach the tempura and onigiri section. (All made fresh in front of you) This is where I get excited because you get to pick which tempura, onigiri you want.. hehe 

Lastly, is the island of condiments. You can put however much tempura flakes, chili powder, green onion and/or cilantro on your udon. 

Compared to other handmade udon places in the city, at Marugame you will definitely get a GOOD FRESH TASTY bowl of udon for about $10 compared to $15+ elsewhere!
author: Jenny S.

description:
Thank God it's not another ramen shop. Yes udon and ramen are different. Once you get here, you'll know it's a crazy wait. They have workers separate clusters of ppl waiting, which baffles onlookers as they pass by. Like is it that amazing? I say yes.

I've been here twice in the past weekend. Okay feel free to judge me, but it's good! Both times I waited at 4:50pm (sat) and 5:25pm (sun) for about 1.5 hours from start of waiting to paying for food. Good location, but limited parking because stonestown is already jam packed with cars. If you don't mind the short walk, park by McDonald's.

Getting food is cafeteria style. Directions are simple, 1) order udon, 2) optional: add tempura or rice balls, 3) pay. Additional tempura sauce and toppings are on the side. Seat yourselves.

My favorite is #2, beef with soft boiled egg. Its super delicious. I prefer broth over just sauce in my udon, so #10 didn't vibe with me. The chicken one tasted okay. Will want to try the curry or #1.

Pro tip: 
1) Come in smaller groups so it's easier to find seating.
2) Don't order two orders like my friend did. He ordered a large and a regular and ended up dying (not literally). Could not finish.
author: Kevin S.

description:
This is the same restaurant as the one in Waikiki, Honolulu, with one letter spelled differently. Apparently, they changed that one letter for the mainlanders (us) Why? Would we be all more confused if it was spelled Marukame? 

After hearing about the recent opening in Stonestown, and hearing from friends how good it was, I was curious. Coincidentally, I was in town &  nearby for a business trip so a friend and I came here for lunch on a rainy Friday. 

Shortly after opening at 11, there was a line of about 25 deep. Zig-zagging around the line was only made better by catching up with my friend. Once inside, the system is exactly like the Honolulu location:

1) Go in, grab a tray. Study the menu at a fast pace (unless you already know what you want)
2) Once the line cooks behind the counter asks, tell them what you want. Once prepared, (relatively fast) they will place it on the counter for you to take. 
3) Moving further down the line, you can pick fried sides, like tempura shrimp, fried chicken, potato croquette, vegetable tempura  and a variety of musubi. 
4) Order drinks & pay at the cashier. 
5) Look for a table

Yes, everything is self serve. You're even asked to bus your own table, so I'm not sure why there's an option for tips at the cashier. There are also red chili pepper and fried crispy udon toppings near the drink station. 

Originally, I wanted the spicy chicken. But the picture that hangs above the line shows a plain broth with chili flakes. That turned me off, so I got what my friend got, curry beef. The broth was a tad too salty, the meat was sparse, thinly sliced and had a decent fat ratio (not good). Even worse, my friend's order had only one tiny piece of beef. I'd give this udon a 2/5.

I also got a vegetable tempura because it looked the most interesting, only to find out after one bite that it's an onion blossom with 2 shreds of carrots for color. 2/5. I passed on the musubi because from my experience, when they're shaped like a triangle, the toppings/fillings are little and only on top for show. So in essence, you're buying a rice pyramid for over a buck and a half. 

The friendliness of the staff was present. One guy near the entrance explained about the Grand Opening on 1/18 and offered us coupons, but since I live 400 miles away, I declined. 

The flavor and price point is not as good as Honolulu, the only thing I liked better here is it's a more modern decor, and it's temperature controlled, while Hawaii has open windows and was quite humid. 

I tried it. Curiosity filled. Done. Not in a hurry to wait in line for this again. I don't see the hype. Perhaps many people have only heard of the one in Waikiki and were anxious to try it, or want to justify why they waited an hour in line. A generous 2.5 rounded up to 3 because of the nice staff. 

Notes:
* Line is outside, so check the weather and dress appropriately
* Many menu items are not available until 1/18/18
* Soft opening in the meantime with limited items
* If you also think it's ridiculous to wait for average flavored udon, avoid meal times or line up before opening. At least you'll be guaranteed a table.
* Soft drinks are from fountains, not cans. Some people prefer cans.
author: James L.

description:
Their #1 regular is soon to be a regular of mine, as long as those lines don't get any longer! On my THIRD try, I showed up at 5pm and waited about 15 minutes in line while surrounded by a ton of high schoolers.

Everything on the menu looked super affordable and tasty, and it'll definitely take me quite a few visits to try more items on the menu. My dipping noodles were hot and delicious, a tiny bit too long to dip at once though. The tempura flakes were super fun, and my actual tempura was so-so. Accidentally got overcharged for fish-cake tempura instead of zucchini and the cashier gave me my change back in cash (instead of card). 

The one thing that stood out to me the most was the guy weighing out the regular vs. large size udon up front. The fact that he had no gloves on didn't bother me, but his idgaf attitude and the sloppiness of the noodles flopping about his hands was definitely unappetizing. I'm 99% sure some of those extra long noodles flopped their way against the glass partition--ick. Luckily for me, my noodles were delicious and my appetite came right back!
author: Christine L.

description:
So where do I even begin. This is more of a story than a review if you have time to read. Otherwise just know that i love this place and its a must try!

Tried this as my first meal in Hawaii staying by Waikiki and instantly fell in love. Almost made the mistake of ordering size regular but my hungry ass boyfriend convinced me to go with large, pats his back**. I like the vibe at the Hawaii location better but thats not fair, its Hawaii for god sakes. Lets move on ...

I came here on a Saturday night around 8pm, probably a dumb idea since its soft opening. The line had about 30 people so Im thinking whatevz, not bad, I can handle. I wait in line and the dude working was pointed down about 3 feet away and said thats the SECOND half of the line. Now im looking at about 45 people ahead of us, approx 45-1 hour wait. I wait there and this dude behind me is on the phone "this must just be a hype cause its cheap". I turned around and gave him a death stare and said nonono, this is the real deal. Now he thinks im crazy but stays in line, he is about to experience greatness thanks to me.

Cool thing about waiting in line when you get inside is watching them cook the fresh ass udons. So effing good!!!! 

We waited about 45 mins and decided to order 3 bowls for the two of us so we can try a few flavors. Spicy chicken, beef and curry. My fave was the beef, hands down, curry second, and i did not really like spicy chicken. It was spicy to me and kinda tangy.... anyway, i love this place once again and will be back!

Grand opening starts on 1/18 so youll get the full menu then
author: Samantha T.

description:
The greatest things about this place are the texture of the udon (made fresh, perfectly soft) and the sides/toppings options. 

The not so great things were the wait and the broth (many of us thought it was too salty, and our udon didn't come with enough).

THE WAIT: 1 hour total at 4:10pm. It took 40 minutes just to enter the restaurant, and it was maybe about 15 more before we got our food & paid. We were first in the "overflow" line (yes there are 2 sections of lines outside). Once inside, it's a bit of a crawl to get through the food line (everyone, ourselves included, is indecisive). 

THE COST: Not too bad, about $30 for dinner + sides for two.

* Egg Drop Chicken Udon ($9.90) - 2.5 stars
The broth was not too flavorful. The noodles were great. 

* Beef Udon (regular w/ soft egg, $7.90) - 3 stars
Noodles, beef, & egg were great. However, there was too little broth, and it was too salty.

* Tempura - 3.5 stars
Tempura shell was quite soft, I would have preferred slightly more crisp. The zucchini and sweet potato were good.

* Shiso Musubi - 3.5 stars
Good, the rice was perfectly textured and had just enough light flavor.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Smooth udon.  A little snag at the register meaning the udon is fast getting cold.  #1 Broth was good.  Ran out of eggs.  Who runs out of eggs! To compensate they gave extra beef or chasu.  Loved the green onion and cilantro self serve-bar.  Get your udon and pay and sit and eat and bus your own table, the japanese way.  Nobody is to clean up after you.  You do it in consideration of others.  Place was clean.  There's a guy out front to control the line and bow.  Very japanese.  If you like tempera this is your place.  The guy in front took all the fried chicken.
author: Helen L.

description:
Finally tried this place after seeing the lines outside around the mall. Since my boyfriend and I loved the Marukame in Honolulu so much, we thought we'd give this one a try as well. 

We ordered the nikutama and mentai kamatama udon because they ran out of the main soup base (kake) for the udons. When I asked how much longer the wait for the soup would be they said a long time, which was shocking as a majority of the udons use this soup base. Both udons were surprisingly really salty so it was quite different from the ones we had in Honolulu.

The good thing is that they have a condiments bar where you can add green onions, cilantro, or tempura flakes. Not sure if it's worth the wait but I might come back if the line isn't long.
author: Helen z.

description: This restaurant has the best udon ever. Once you walk in you are greeted with the traditional Japanese welcome. Lines can be long but they move quick. Went there for a job interview the other day. It went swell by the way. Hope I get to work in an environment like that pretty soon.
author: Jeremiah E.

description:
Be prepared to wait in a long line because this place is the newest hype in town! 

A self-serve experience, once you receive your made-to-order bowl, you proceed to fill your 'cafeteria tray' with any fried tempura-battered goodies or any musubi of your choice and then pay for your items. After, you head over to a serving station to top your bowl with green onions, crunchy fried tempura flakes, cilantro, and shichimi spice. 

We ordered large bowls of beef udon. The kake soup from here was much tastier than the one from the Honolulu location. The large size bowl is HUGE--they hook you up with a lot of udon and meat. My husband couldn't even finish his bowl! 

Overall, good food at a great value and friendly and efficient employees. Muy bueno. 

+ Be courteous to other patrons: Don't get your family members to 'reserve' a table before you even get your food 
+Grand opening 1/18/18
author: Merica S.

description:
My boyfriend highly recommended this place after trying it in Hawaii, so we decided to make the trip to SF to try this location. The line might be horrifically long by the time you get here, but don't let that intimidate you! It actually moved faster than what I expected (~30 to 40 min wait).

I like how this place allows you to customize your udon bowl and lets you choose from the large variety of tempura sides! I ordered the curry udon and added the vegetable tempura, sweet potato tempura, and a potato croquette (you can tell my eyes were bigger than my stomach...). The texture of the udon noodles was really soft and chewy! They picked up the flavor of the curry really well, which was more like thick curry sauce rather than soup. I really liked the vegetable tempura, which was a mix of onions, carrots, and some other thinly sliced veggies, since it was so light. On the other hand, the sweet potato was so filling that I didn't even touch my croquette LOL. 

Anyways, there's also a toppings bar, where you can add different things like green onions, tempura flakes, cilantro, etc. to your soup! I really like how personal you can be with your udon hehe. Definitely worth the wait and check it out if you're a fan of udon! :)
author: Christine D.

description:
I LOVE UDON. Something about the perfect chewy texture gets me everytime. This place is awesome because the city has never really had a good udon place until now. The line is A LOT whack tho, not a lil. Service is all right, they only really see you for a split two seconds when you order because it's a cafeteria style eating.

Price is okay, a little on the pricier side, but the food is awesome. I like that you can add unlimited green onions and fried onion, dope. The tempura selection is wide and pretty good.

Definitely come and try this place if you haven't yet!
author: Eva C.

description:
TL;DR very delicious and worth the price, but  30+ minutes wait in the cold outside

As of their grand opening in late December, they've had lines out the door. I heard Marugame is good from many people, but was skeptical about the line because it's about 60-70 people on average. However, I was pleasantly surprised that the line moved pretty quickly. There are a lot of soups and toppings to choose from. 

Once you get in, there is a "how to" make your udon dish. You also get to watch them make the udon fresh, so you know you are getting the real deal. After you go through the udon assembly line, you get to choose extra toppings, which range from $1-2, my favorite was the croquette. Just make sure you don't go during closing hours because they might run out.
author: Sophia L.

description:
My boyfriend and I were craving udon so we braved the line at Marugame (took about a half hour) on a Sunday at 2pm. 

There is a menu sign outside that you can look at as you wait (there's also another inside as well as instructions on how the ordering process works). I forgot the names of our orders but what I can tell you is that the broth is simple yet comforting, the noodles have a nice bite, and never say no to a soft boiled egg. The bowls are also very well-priced for their sizes, with some as low as $4-5 from what I remember. I like that you can choose what tempura and rice balls  you'd like as you move through the line - with that said, some of the tempura will be sitting out longer than others and therefore won't be as crisp. 

Even with the long line there was plenty of seating. 

Overall a good spot to satisfy that udon craving!
author: Janice L.

description:
I am not the biggest fan of udon but MARUGAME changes the game. Handmade noodles made right in front of your eyes and immediately you can tell it's legit. The noodles are not too chewy yet stay intact quite well. I ordered a reg bukakke udon, large curry udon, and tempura. 

Bukakke udon - funny name but serious taste. Very umami with a hint of sweetness to the broth.

Curry udon - I usually don't like curry as a soup base because it tends to be watered down, but this one had a particularly strong curry flavor. Very savory and drinking the broth itself was delicious. 

The sweet potato tempura was the best imo, had a nice texture. Only thing I didn't like about the meal was tempura got cold since it's not made to order. They have these items laying out and you can grab whatever you like as an add-on item. 

There's a topping bar where you can add green onion, cilantro, etc. The wait for this place is rather long if you line up after 11. I waited about an hour but think it's worth it if you have the time. 

Service is good and prices are VERY reasonable. If you just want a large bowl of udon you can get away with less than $10. The tempura and add-on items can add up though.

Definitely would come back because of how good the noodles are.

Food: 4.75/5
Value: 5/5
Service: 4.5/5
Overall: 5/5
author: Brian G.

description:
My girlfriend wanted to try this place, so I took her there. When we first arrived, there was a long line, but because of their amazing customer service, the line went by real fast. 

The selections in this place was very organized, I can conveniently choose what I want. 

I got the beef udon with shrimp tempura and it satisfied my cravings for udon. Everything was delicious. I don't mind coming back here whenever I am in the area.
author: Anthony P.

description:
I love all noodles and udon is no exception. Luckily, I only needed to wait 20 minutes in the cold before placing an order. The menu is straightforward and limited, but still difficult to decided what I wanted to eat for lunch that day. Fortunately I came with my family, so I was able to try the curry udon, spicy chicken udon, and bukkake udon. All three of them were delicious with my favorite being the curry. As you go down the cafeteria line you can add extras to your udon order too. It was a very filling lunch at a decent price. I will definitely be back once the line has died down. 

What I recommend:
-- Curry udon
author: Andrew W.

description:
Let me first just say that Marugame is worth ALL of the hype that you hear. I'm usually very skeptical so as not to get my hopes up, but this place definitely exceeded my expectations!! I waited in line for maybe half an hour, but it was so worth the wait. Even in the cold lol.

I ordered the large Nikutama udon w/ beef and an egg. Once you get inside and order, everything is super quick. You order your udon, you get it, then you can choose any tempura or musubi that you want. I got a ton of tempura, but I kind of wish I hadn't because I enjoyed the udon way more and ended up too full to finish my tempura! Also tip for the tempura: eat it right away while it's still hot, otherwise it just gets cold and kind of gross. That was my mistake. The udon was just toooooo good! The beef was soft and kind of sweet. The noodles were perfectly soft and firm at the same time. The broth/sauce they pour in, is just super delicious. 

Honestly this must have been the best udon I've ever had in my life, and I will definitely be back as soon as I can.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
5 stars for the food and quick service but minus 1 star for the long lines

There has been so much hype around this spot ever since it opened a couple months ago. I had been meaning to check it out, but the mentions of long waits made me cautious. I finally got a chance on a recent Sunday, when my friend asked if I wanted to go for a later lunch around 3:30 pm.

The line was still surprisingly long given that it was 3:30 on a Sunday. It was about 30 minutes from when I got into line to the end when I paid and was ready to eat. The line moves pretty quickly as they usher each patron through their assembly line style process. One person cooks the udon, the next prepares the broth and toppings, and yet another person accepts payment. They have the whole thing pretty streamlined.

I went with the beef udon ($7.90 for the regular size) with a soft boiled egg and some extra tempura sides and toppings that are self serve. The freshly made udon noodles were nice and chewy, the broth was light and refreshing, and the soft boiled egg was so softly boiled it spilled open with a light poke of the chopsticks. For my tempura sides, I got fish, squid, and fish cake. The fish was overpriced and not worth the $2, but both the squid and fish cake were good sides to eat with the udon. If I had to pick one, it'd be the fish cake as it is more flavorful.

The restaurant is large with plenty of seating. It was never full, which was surprising given the number of people in line, but I guess udon is usually a fast meal where you eat and go under 30 minutes. There is also an small outdoor area where you can eat on warmer days.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Wow this place was wonderful. I was helping my sister move in at UCLA and asked her to take me to somewhere yummy and she definitely delivered. Even though there was a long line, the line actually moved very quickly. I don't think I waited for longer than 10 minutes even though when I first got in line, the line was already outside the restaurant and bending alongst the street. 

This place's specialty is udon so don't be surprised to see that they only have udon options on the menu. I opted for the #7 Large Beef Udon. After getting my beef udon, I had the option to choose my own add-ons (I decided to get a shrimp tempura for $1.80). After paying, I added some tempura flakes and green onions to my udon and quickly found a place to sit. The noodles were AMAZING. The noodles were cooked perfectly such that it wasn't too soft but it wasn't too hard either. The broth was also so tasty that I still dream about it today (lmao). Would definitely come back here the next time I visit.

Taste: 5/5
Service: 5/5
Interior: 5/5
author: Timothy H.

description:
First time I was introduced to Marugame Udon was in Oahu, Hawaii. I was pleasantly surprised by how tasty it was and also loved the casual cafeteria serving style and how they make the noodles fresh and right in front of you. I was thrilled when I saw this location pop up and it was just the same as the one in Hawaii. 

I was too excited so I over-ordered:
- Hot Nikutama Udon - this one is my favorite. It's a mix of tender beef and an onsen egg in hot, flavorful broth and chewy udon. I find it a very simple and comforting meal.
- Spicy Tonkatsu Udon - this one is my fiance's favorite. He was a fan of the thick, flavorful soup base, which was more akin to ramen dishes. I also don't think every location serves this dish so it may be special. 
- Edamame Salsa Udon - this is a cold noodle dish with veggie toppings. I liked the concept but I thought they put WAY too much sauce. After you mixed everything together the noodles were just swimming in this sort of mayonnaise sauce (yuck).

We also ordered a bunch of tempura (recommend the tomago tempura) and Onigiri rice balls. After paying, don't forget to go finish your udon at the toppings station which has scallions, cilantro, fried crumbs and tempura sauces.

Overall I love the food and casual atmosphere, but I definitely wouldn't recommend waiting more than 30mins in line for it, so try to go during off-peak hours.
author: Kathy L.

description:
1.3.17 

They are currently in their soft opening stage and offer a limited menu. (See pictures below) It seems like they're releasing a new item each day until their Grand Opening on 1/18. 

What I love about MU is that you get to see everything made in front of you as you move down the assembly line! 

SERVICE: 
The restaurant is organized like catefaria style. Here's a summary of how you order here: 
1) Get in line (there is a wait most of the time - 20mins) You will get to see how they make their udon, and assemble everything. 
2) When you get to the front, grab a tray and tell them which udon and what size and hot or cold you will like 
3) Get udon and move on to tempera section - arranged buffet style with corresponding prices. 
4) Then there is the mini masubi station 
5) Pay for order
6) Find an empty table to claim 
7) Head to topping and utensils station 
8) When finished, they have a drop-off station next to the cashier where they will help you sort out your trash and return your bowl and tray

They also have togo containers for you if you don't finish. 

UDON:
They have a wide selection of udons for you in either regular or large. Most of the udon come in their traditional broth or curry style with limited meat. They offer a tempera station with a wide variety from chicken, potatoes, to many different veggies. And lastly, they have a wide selection of masubis. The udon is very chewy and fresh! Their broth is flavorful without being too salty or oily. 

The only improvement I can suggest is maybe offer non-tempera veggies and meat. I know tempera is traditional served with udon, but for those who like to eat deep fried foods in moderation, a non-tempera selection would be a bonus!  

SERVICE: 
Everyone is super friendly there, like most Japanese restaurants you go to! They try to greet and bid farewell to everyone and is super welcoming.
author: Samantha F.

description: This place is average. My friends and I went in after giving up waiting for marafuku ramen next door. The udon isn't that unique compare to Marugame monzo in LA little Tokyo. The flavors are really ordinary, I can almost replicate it with frozen udon from the market...
author: Kaylee P.

description:
We came here last night and guess what? The line was short and we got our udons within 15 minutes.  The setting is exactly like the Marugame in Hawaii so it was comforting to know that.  We had the beef udon and the spicy chicken udon and between the two, the spicy chicken was my favorite.  The broth reminded me a bit of Vietnamese fish sauce with sriracha.  It was surely spicy to where we needed two cups of water to finish it.  The beef udon was simple with an egg.  It was plain in a good way to where you can taste the true udon and beef flavors.  We had the shrimp tempura on the side and that was crunchy good also.  

I really liked the concept of this cafeteria like set up because it was fast and easy and also to mention, it was an extremely reasonable price for authentic udon.  I would definitely come here again!
author: Kristy L.

description:
Conveniently located at Stonestown mall, parking is always easy! Came during their soft opening, waited about 1 hour in line. There were limited udons during the soft opening :(.

This place is beautiful! It's kind of like a grab your food + then pay. You order your udon and they give it to you immediately. Our group ordered curry udon and the beef udon. They were both DELICIOUS but if I had to choose one it'd be the beef udon!

After you get your udon, you grab whatever side dishes you want (cafeteria style ish). But I think they're kind of expensive, I/e: ~$2 for ONE shrimp tempura. But I guess it was good tempura. LOL. 

Will be back when they have all the different broths available! To me it was worth the wait!
author: Melanie T.

description:
If you see a long line outside you know it's going to be good.. if the line is long enough it is actually separated into two lines so it doesn't block the sidewalk for people trying to pass by!

I came here for dinner just 30 minutes after they opened and the line was huge already! I would suggest if you really want to try and before the line gets long to come a little earlier before their opening time. Their line does move fast though... I was in the second line away from the store but it did take about 45 minutes before I was finally able to order.

The positive side is that you really only have to wait in line till you order your food - and your food is made instant! I had originally ordered #5 which is their regular beef udon but the chef heard me wrong and gave me their curry udon. I didn't mind of course because I do love curry. He seemed very upset that he gave me the wrong order and offered to make me the correct one. I didn't want to trouble him since he was so busy so I let him know that it was totally fine. He did offer me some extra meat though which I greatly appreciated!

After you order your udon, you next have a section of tempura and onigiris! Be careful here because you don't want to get too much tempura and get too full! I got the squid, shrimp, and fishcake. The fishcake was alright but definitely try the shrimp or squid.

After you pay, you can go to the side bar and add on onions etc and get your utensils/tempura dipping sauce. Then it's open seating so sit wherever you like! Just remember to clean up after yourself and to put away your tray.
author: Sherry L.

description:
Came here on a Friday afternoon and line wasn't too bad. Waited about 25 minutes to get our food. I got the curry udon and it was okay for what it is. Friends pretty much over hyped this place for me and it didn't live up to my expectations. Don't get me wrong, the udon noodles were great. Very slippery and chewy. The broth itself was very watered down and didn't have that nice spiced curry kick to it that I like. 

Besides the noodles you can get sides such as tempura and masubis. I don't recommend getting any masubis here. It is literally a ball of rice with seafood with the most frugal amount of topping. I am not even exaggerating here. I took the smaller first bite and all the toppings were gone. I was just left with a rice ball. Disappointing. The shrimp tempura I got here seemed soggy. This is probably because they just leave it out for people to grab as they go through the lines of toppings. 

I say go save yourself a trip and skip this place.
author: Ada H.

description:
Went here during their soft opening. My first attempt was unsuccessful as I was on a time crunch and my spot in line was about 1-1.5 hours wait time. So I planned ahead this time and decided to come back the following day but I arrived at about 4:20 to wait in line. There was about 20 people in front of me already around that time and the line quickly filled after me. By the time it turned 5pm, I think the wait time for the end of the line was about 1 hr or more. 

Since it was still their soft opening, their menu is limited and sadly did not have any eggs! I still got their beef udon, even though the egg would've made it 10x better. My bf got the curry udon. After you get your ramen, you can select from a bunch of tempura items and musubis. I was pretty disappointed in the chicken tempura since I remember the one in hawaii being all dark meat and it was so juicy. They used white meat at this location and it was dry. All the tempuras were pretty disappointing except the shrimp tempura and the potato croquette. I would only stick to that next time. I also got a crab musubi and a salmon flake musubi. I would highly suggest you skip on these as its 90% rice.

After you fill your tray, you go to the toppings station and can load your bowl with tempura flakes, green onion, and cilantro. They also have sauces for your tempura.

Udon is just as good as hawaii. I would definitely be back. Literally the best udon I've had at any establishment.

Can't wait for their full menu offering!
author: Lena V.

description:
After two times of attempting to try this place I finally tried it!

This place is hella good as what everyone else are saying. I ordered #2 which is the beef udon with egg, and oh man it was so good! The broth, the beef and the taste and consistency of the udon was good! The squid tempura and peppers tempura was crispy and good as well especially with their sweet teriyaki sauce.

I will try the curry udon next!
author: Nicole D.

description:
Visited this place to see what the hype was about, as I have not tried the locations in Hawaii or Japan. It was soft opening so they did not have their full menu out. Usually the line is out the door to Olive Garden, but since it was pouring, the line was relatively short.

Their set up is similar to a cafeteria. You choose which broth you want, then you can use tongs to pick up your additional items. After you pay, you can add cilanto, green onion, or tempura flakes to your bowl. I ordered a regular hot Bukkake udon ($4.50), which the broth is made with soy sauce. They give you less broth since the flavor is strong. I don't typically eat udon because it can get too chewy but the udon here is by far the best I ever had. The noodles were perfect and extremely fresh. I also got a piece of fried chicken ($1.80) and a salmon flake masubi ($1.60). I thought the chicken wouldn't be crunchy anymore because it is sitting out, but it was still good. Th salmon flake masubi would be better if it had more salmon through out the masubi but for $1.60, can't really complain.

Their grand opening is on January 18, 2018 so afterwards, I will be back to try the other items on their menu. Stonestown finally put a good establishment that will last in that space.
author: Julian Y.

description:
Marugame is now in soft opening mode until their grand opening on January 18th! Hopefully the lines don't get super long, but on a Friday night, my friend and I waited about 20 mins to get to the front of the line. It could've been worse, so I'm not complaining!

We've both been to Marukame Udon in Hawaii so we knew what to expect. I love the concept of ordering your udon and then going down the tempura/musubi line just picking what you want as you go! We both ordered the beef udon. What's nice about this location is that they have green onions, tempura crunchies, ground sesame, pepper, and sauces at a different station so you can top your udon yourself. I liked the thick sweet tempura sauce and the dashi soy sauce. 

The beef in our udon was a little chewy and pretty fatty.. imo, next time I would just order the plain udon and get extra tempura since the plain udon is only $5! The noodles were perfectly chewy and the broth is just how I remember from Hawaii, however the broth could've been warmer. My fav tempura was definitely the chicken tempura!! Surprisingly, the breast piece was super juicy. Compared to the similarly priced shrimp tempura, the chicken was larger in size and definitely more worth it. 

I will definitely be back! I can't wait to try the curry udon once they are officially open. So glad to have some good udon near my house now, and right next to my gym too! :D
author: Tara A.

description:
So I hate waiting. Let me get that out there. I would rather just not go than to wait. 
I've known about Marugame Udon for several months, but never had the urge to go simply because of the wait. But today was different. As I wandered around looking for another store, I saw the line wasn't too bad. So I decided to give it a go. 
My son and I both got the tonkotsu udon. I must say that the udon itself is excellent. It has a soft, silky and chewy texture, and tasted very fresh. The pork broth was really good, not too salty but still a lot of flavor. The two slices of pork was really tender. 

The soft boiled egg was definitely disappointing. This wasn't a soft boiled egg, it was a poached egg. And it basically disenegrated as soon as I put it in my broth. Making soft boiled eggs is definitely an artform, one that this place hasn't perfected yet.  Also because of their assembly line system, the broth was semi-hot but not steaming hot, which would be my preference. 

I also tried the shrimp, tamagoyaki, and squid tempura. The batter was light and had a bit of saltiness, a bit if nuttiness to it. It tasted good. But again because of their assembly line food production, the tempura were all basically cold. And I really don't like eating cold tempura. If this could be improved upon, I would rate this place through the roof. 
Because of the way you get your own tempura and rice balls, you tend to indulge more than usual. Don't forget that each item is priced separately at about $2 a pop, which quickly adds up. So even though the udon is relatively priced, everything adds up to about $15-20 per person. 
Overall though the udon is the star of this show, and I would definitely recommend this place for their udon. I will be back soon, crossing my fingers that the line isn't too long.
author: Dom L.

description:
We came here during a weekday night and waited in the rain for 30-40 minutes. While the line was long, it moved relatively fast with Chipotle-like efficiency. It was worth the wait but next time we may try to come during a less busy time.

We got the Kake Udon and Nikutama Udon along with side items like shrimp tempura, salmon musubi, and tuna mayo musubi. Many of the items were fresh and made on the spot like the udon and tempura, so that was nice.
author: Minh N.

description:
How long you wait in line depends on the time and day you go. Is it worth the wait? YES! There is no reservations as this restaurant is setup like a cafeteria style. You wait in line and then you tell the counter staff what number noodle you want. I would recommend number 1 or 8. Then you can add additional items to put inside your soup or eat it as a side. 

This place is good but no where as good as Hawaii, so if you are expecting Hawaii quality you will be disappointed.
author: M T.

description:
Marugame Udon is a super popular udon chain in Japan. It's funny how a totally normal place to get quick meals in Japan can drive people crazy (to wait 40 min. - 1 hr.) in the USA. Guess what? I wanted to feel nostalgic and decided to wait as well!

I came at around 2pm - 3pm and waited for 45 min. to get in. There are less than 10 different udon dishes on the menu - much less than the choices you can get in Japan. However, they had the essentials. I was disappointed that they didn't have zaru udon. But bukake udon makes up for that. Bukake udon is like zaru udon except the dipping sauce is poured on the noodles. For my visit, I ordered two dishes: bukake udon and mentai kamatama. Both were not disappointing - very similar to the consistency of Marugame Japan.

The meals here are generally cheap. Everything's less than $10. The only problem's that the store's in Mordor. I live in the south bay so getting here's a long drive. Hopefully in the future they'll open more stores throughout the bay and more around Los Angeles as well!

I'm so happy this store opened. Keep the Japanese chain restaurants coming to the USA! :)
author: Jeanne P.

description:
MARUGAME Udon was definitely an experience that I can't forget. Being able to see the whole process on how they make their udon noodles fresh was definitely eye opening and made me appreciate my food a lot more. In this location, it's like a high school lunch line; first you pick one of the prefixed udon noodles, secondly you can add other appetizers such as tempura, rice balls, and drinks, lastly you pay at the end of the cash register.

The food was definitely an affordable, flavorful, and presentable. It's like noodle bowls from an anime show! The only thing I wished this location can change is the level of saltiness of the soup. It was slightly really salty, but at least it has a lot of taste. The udon looks are very long and chewy, just the way an udon should be, slurp-able. The location is open seating, inside or outside. Occasionally there will be lines, but it's worth the wait! I would definitely come back here, especially if I was waiting for my iPhone to be fixed at the Stonetown's Apple Store.
author: Joey C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night with my family around 5:30 PM. We waited in roughly an hour and 20 minutes. Man was it cold! And even though you're waiting in the cold for so long, it is worth the wait!
The style is like a cafeteria line at: you tell them which number bowl you want, they make it right there and give it to you on your tray, pick your sides and your drinks. Then after paying, you can go to the condiment bar to add more stuff into your Udon like green onions, sauces, so on. It's a cute and quick concept. 
I recommend trying number 5, 10, and 2. The large sizes are huge portions, definitely shareable with another person or just take it home for another meal. 

Pros:
- Very nice and attentive staff
- Huge portions that are extremely delicious
- Clean dining area, where you bus your own table
- Great prices (get a large for a dollar more!)

Cons:
- People tend to hang around inside after they're done eating, and don't give their seat up - which makes it even harder to find seating
- Hyped up wait

Tips:
- Bring cash! If you pay on the card, they include the tip in your payment
- Come early and dress warm!
- If you come around the time the mall closes, they don't leave the doors unlocked. So don't park near Macy's or the garage
- Take a look at the menu at the second section of the line, so you can order quick!
author: Lianne W.

description:
Upon visiting this place, I felt like I traveled to an authentic udon restaurant in Japan, and the price of the "trip" costed me an hour wait in line wanting to get in. Although this may seem daunting and a waste of time, it was surprisingly worth it for the experience. As long as you have a good group of mates to pass the time, it goes by quick. 

There was a selected few options to choose from on the menu and it wasn't overwhelming at all, so if you're indecisive like me, there's little anxiety when picking the one item for you. You just need to choose between 8 different items and the process is super simple. It's a single line that starts the moment you enter. You start off by telling the great employees what item you want, what size, and whether you want it hot and cold. I chose a regular, hot Nikutama as it was filling and warm enough for the cold weather at the time. I definitely loved the extras you could add on such as grabbing a few tempuras and musubis along the way to the register. My favorite part was the toppings table where I piled on a lot of green onions and cilantro! Definitely would recommend putting a little bit of ginger in there too! 

The Nikutama was a bowl of goodness as it knew how to warm up the soul. The udon noodles were very fresh as you can see the noodles life span from exiting the hot water to your bowl and into your mouth. I was sad that I was lacking a bit of soup compared to my friends other bowls but it was mighty tasty regardless and got me wanting more. The tempura was really good! My favorite out of the bunch was the chicken so definitely grab a couple of those to pair with your bowl. The beef was soft and melted in your mouth but it was a little fatty for my liking. And the musubi was an okay snack as the ratio between salmon and rice was off balance for my preference but I could've been eating them the wrong way so who knows. 

Overall, I had a great time at this restaurant and would definitely be coming back to try a little bit of a dish more spicy. Definitely would recommend this to someone who's looking for something with great noodles but would warn them about a long wait. Thank you Marugame Udon for a wonderful time!
author: Jomari G.

description:
I love this place... even though I don't eat carbs anymore this is the one place I will go to "Cheat". The broth is amazing and the portions generous. It seems like they had a bad start when they started off... but now I believe they have ironed out the kinks.

The lines also move pretty fast.
author: Rich C.

description:
Great addition to the mall here! This location is cafeteria style, so everyone gets to wait their turn fairly. (I've seen people try to hop the crowd and demand to be sat immediately because they're eating by themselves)

Came during their soft opening, and boy was their line LONG! We waited 45min-hour but I honestly think it was worth it. Waiting outside it seems like it takes a while, but once you get in it goes a lot quicker.

You order first by letting them know which bowl you want and what size (Only certain bowls are avail during soft opening). You can actually watch the workers make the udon noodles so you know it's fresh! After you get your bowl, you can optionally pick from an assortment of tempura and onigiri to eat with your udon, they're all a la carte.

Once you pay there's a little bar area to add your toppings and get tempura sauce. Once you're done eating you bus your bowl and tray to the designated area
author: Michelle N.

description: Been wanting to come visit since I went to one of these Marugame Udon places in Hawaii. This assembly line does not feel as oiled and smooth as the one I witnessed in Waikiki, but I also understand since this spot is relatively new. The udon noodles still tasted delicious, but the beef udon bowl itself is a tad bit oily for my taste. Not sure if it was the beef topping, or something else. I also don't tend to add too much tempura bits. Nevertheless, I'm still pretty biased for this chain and love udon too much to give them 3 stars. Definitely a fan.
author: Sara T.

description:
What's not to love about fresh udon? SO HAPPY MARUGAME UDON CAME TO SF!
Tastes exactly the same as the famous Marukame Udon in Oahu, Hawaii minus the beautiful beach and vacation vibes. They're owned by the same company. 

We went during the grand opening weekend so the line was long as expected, but the wait was not too bad because it's cafeteria style, so the line keeps moving. 8:30pm on a Sunday night and it was a 40min wait from when we got in line to when we sat down with our food. 

Get in line. 
Take a tray. 
Order your udon. Drool. *
Pick your tempura sides. 
Pay.
ENJOY.

The regular size was filling enough for me since I got several tempura items to accompany my udon. But if you're going for just the UDON (and meat), then the large bowl will have you swimming in your udon dreams. 

We particularly love the curry udon. It comes with beef and a rich flavorful curry broth. The two other beef udon options are great too. It has a lighter broth that's just as tasty. 
*TIP: when the server gives you your udon bowl, you can ask for a soft cooked egg for $1 extra. Do it. 
As for the tempura.. since they're always busy, the tempura is fresh and hot from the fryer. Shrimp, veggie ball, sweet potato, fish cake tempura, they're all great. 

There's plenty of clean table space to seat yourself. Just make sure to turn in your tray/bowls to clean up after yourselves. 

All the workers are friendly and welcoming.
There seriously isn't anything wrong with this place. It's so good, it's worth the wait.
author: Audrey D.

description:
The mall may open at 10am but Marugame Udon opens at 11am. Come early! I lined up 15 minutes before opening and was at the halfway point in line when they opened. Soft opening right now so they just have several udon options: kama-age udon, kake udon, beef udon, bukkake udon. They're rolling out the rest of the menu as time passes.

Ordered my (large) beef udon and proceeded eagerly down the line with my tray. This is where i needed to show some self control... but didn't. I wanted every piece of tempura and all the musubis. I piled what i could onto my tray! There's an island of cilantro, chopped green onions, sriracha, and tempura sauce to top your bowl. Watch out for the tempura sauce in what i normally recognize as a tea dispenser. It shot out a lot more forcefully than expected for my tiny dipping container hah!

Seating is difficult. People are far too antsy and save seats before they even get a tray. It doesn't take long to slurp down a bowl of udon. No need to throw your sweaters and bags on a table so far in advance! I'm judging you if you're one of those people ...

Unfortunately the line is long and can move slowly which cooled my soup down significantly. It is delicious though! Their tempura is perfectly cooked too. The squid was tender and surprisingly my favorite. The (boneless) chicken and shrimp were great too. I'm a huge musubi fan so grabbing just the salmon and crab was conservative for me. I would grab more next time to take to go.

Total time from standing in line to sitting down to eat: ~30 minutes

Feels the same as Marakume Udon in Honolulu... except it's not paradise weather and too cold to sit at the tables outside!
author: Samantha L.

description:
If you're craving a bowl of udon at an affordable price, don't want to bus all the way to Japantown, and have time on your hands, I'd definitely recommend coming here.

-There's been such a long line each time I passed by here, so I'd advise eating here on off hours like either after lunch (2PM-3PM), or before they close (8PM-9PM).

-Although the menu is very limited, I feel like it'll expand in the future. My older brother ordered the large Curry Udon ($7.90), and I ordered the regular Curry Udon ($6.90).
