I can't eat foods that are too spicy, so I was very cautious of ordering the Curry Udon, but after asking a customer who sat down eating it, I felt relief. The Curry Udon was delicious! It is very simple though, just curry, udon, and beef. My little brother ordered the large Spicy Chicken Udon ($7.90), and my mom ordered the large Beef Udon ($8.90). I didn't really like how the chicken in the Spicy Chicken Udon was all chopped up, in a mincy texture. The soup base tasted like a sweet and sour soup. I would steer clear of the musubi because it's mainly 99.9% rice and 0.01% seafood. Besides the Vegetable Kakiage tempura, the potato croquette and other tempura choices were mediocre.

-The system of ordering food is in a cafeteria like order. You tell them which size and type of of udon you want, pass by the tempura and musubi options, and pay. They use Square as a POS system, but they don't have Apple Pay as a payment option.

-On the side adjacent to the cashier is a condiments station where there is a variety of vegetable toppings (onions, cilantro) and sauce options. There are also sauce containers and bags incase you have leftovers. 

When you're at the front of the line, there's a green sticker line on the floor. There's an employee on the side with menus who is in charge of the flow of the line, and who can go order. If there are too many people in udon and musubi station, they make you wait behind the green line, which makes a lot of sense. The Curry Udon and Vegetable Kakiage (mixture of vegetable tempura) were the utmost highlights of my meal. A big mistake customers make is leaving their trash and bowls behind on the table when they're done with their meal. On the napkin dispensers on the table, they have signs that say you have to bring your tray and bowls to the back for the employees to wash them.
author: Erica K.

description:
I was never a big fan of udon. However I have found myself coming back here again and again, changing  my mind drastically on my feelings for it as the flavors they put together gives my tastebuds yearning for more.

Let me start off by saying the wait here is ridiculously long. The first time I had came, I went during their down time so being able to get food and finding a seat quickly is a rarity. It is made up with the fast pace the restaurant does with the upkeep but do expect to wait on average 15~30 minutes before being able to place an order and sitting down. This place can get as busy as to having two separate lines before going in to actually order and grabbing a seat to eat.

They have a wide selection of udon ranging from cold to hot and regular to large sizes; prices depending on what udon you get. Typically an udon bowl will range from $8~12 and others with just the sauce and noodles ranges from $4~6. Bowls are customizable for an extra $1~3 per item depending what tempura/onigiri you decide to grab. Do expect that although the bowls are cheap in price, it can run high. I find myself usually spending an average of $15~20 here because they seem to always put new seasonal items they like to try out.

Seating does get hard to find. When it gets busy here both indoor and outdoor seating is packed like sardines in a can. Seats are usually about a foot away from each other so its important to be mindful of space. If you dine here with a friend it is recommended to have either yourself of your friend grab a seat as they can be free one second and gone the next.

In all the times I have came here, I have only ordered the Nikutama Udon. It is quite a bit of food and the sweet beef is something I could not pass up on eating every time. It pairs well with the sauce they put in the udon and the tempura you decide to grab on the side. Compared to other udon I have tried outside of here, MARUGAME is sweet in flavor. There is a bar filled with sauces, tempura flakes, onion, cilantro toppings and much more. This makes it easy to get exactly what you want and how much you want of it. The only bad thing I can say is the tempura you grab seems to be very oily and at times cold unless pulled right out the fryer. 

Overall MARUGAME UDON gets a 4/5 from me. If they are able to improve on their seating arrangements and tempura I definitely see big things for MARUGAME in the future.
author: Dalina N.

description:
Came here during soft opening on a weeknight around 5:30 (30 minutes after opening). The line didn't look that bad but it still ended up being a 45 minute wait to order. However, once you order, it only takes about 5 minutes to sit down with your food and eat!

My boyfriend and I both got the regular plain Kake udon ($4.50 each) with different types of tempura (~$1.80-$2.20/piece) and he got a musubi ($1.50). Don't let the cheap udon and tempura prices fool you - we ended up spending $24 still! Everything adds up! 

The process is very similar to Marukame Udon in Hawaii if you've ever tried that, although it's a little slower but maybe just because they just opened. Hopefully they'll get the line moving a little faster over time. They have unlimited tempura crunchies and a sauce/toppings bar which is nice. As for the food, the broth tasted a little off to me. Not quite the same as Marukame but still good. Tempura was tempura - nothing too special although I took Tara A's recommendation and tried the chicken tempura - definitely filled me up for about the same price as a shrimp so I'd get that again! 

The place is a decent size, didn't seem like anyone was forced to eat outside on the patio the whole time we were waiting in line or eating so the seating turnaround worked out pretty well. 

Overall, the place is good and is worth trying but for me, I wouldn't wait 45 minutes again. I'd probably wait until they get a little faster and if I'm really craving this type of udon. Kind of interested in trying the Nikutama Udon or the Egg Drop Chicken Udon next time after they debut.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Overall review: YUM!

My favorite hands down is the following:

Beef Udon topped with all the fixings in the fixings bar (green onion, ginger, cilantro and some crunchies)
Squid Tempura
Shrimp Tempura
Fried chicken 

Perfectly cooked noodles swimming In perfectly seasoned soup and a hefty serving of beef on top. The tempura is always good - my favorites are listed above based on substantialness, crunchiness and value :)

The tables seem to clear like clockwork. Been here three times and I've never had trouble finding a spot even though it was packed

Parking is a problem, it's a mall, and they don't have a very big garage.

Don't forget your chocolate mint at checkout 

Minus one star for the wait and messiness:

WHEN the wait dies down, I'll be here quite often. At this time, it's nearly still an hour wait at peak times.

I feel like they're still ironing out the service line- I see noodles all over the floor back there and it's not exactly appetizing to see while ordering my meal (so don't look at the floor)! The return tray area is also a mess, I'm not sure if they can't keep up and I really don't want to spend 5 minutes there figuring out what belongs in the green, blue, and black bins!
author: Karen H.

description:
I came here on a rainy Wednesday evening with a friend and waited for about 40 minutes. The rain didn't stop us! 

I ordered the Kama-Age udon and my friend ordered the beef udon. Both udons were very delicious and fresh. I couldn't tell a big difference from their udon and other places (even if it is frozen). I think the fact that customers can literally see them making it fresh allows us to believe that it tastes better. I'm not complaining here! It's pretty good :) my friend said the beef was very good. Nice, thin, and tender! 

The tempura selection was great. Lots to choose from! I liked the sweet potato. The proportions for the tempura isn't the same... which is something the management needs to fix if they want to guarantee each customer can get the same amount of food! 

The rice balls were disappointing. Nothing special to be honest. I just wanted to try it because i waited for so long in line... i had to! The rice is just plain rice wrapped with seaweed. The toppings were okay and nothing super amazing. 

I can imagine this would be a great place to grab a quick meal (once the lines have died down). Also, its pretty inexpensive! :) just don't add so many things.. haha
author: Joyce S.

description:
Udon is not my go-to when going out to eat because I grew up with my mom making it, so when my friend invited me to try Marugame (a 'fast food' udon spot) I was intrigued at the quality and taste. Show up at 8:30/9 on a weeknight and you'll only wait ~15 min!! 

I got the nikutama udon, comes with beef, slightly less broth and a poached egg on top. The lineup of toppings and rice balls reminded me of a Japanese grocery store's hot food section, and I loved the variety available. The kakiage was mostly onions which was disappointing but pretty fresh and crispy. Udon itself tasted not-factory made at all and reminded me of my childhood. I would not wait more than 15 minutes to eat here but I'm sure the waits will die down over the next few months!
author: Hana S.

description:
My family definitely enjoyed the experience here! It's always fun to select your own combos. The staff are very nice and friendly! Kudos to them because I wouldn't be able to keep a good mood with the rush that they have! Lines out the door every hour!!! 

I ordered the #2 udon nikuyama. You place the fried items on your plate. I ended up getting some shrimp tempura (which they fry on the spot since it's always running out), potato croquet, and sweet potato tempura. Those 3 were just okay. The dish itself, fresh udon? Who can complain? Although, I do wish that they gave you more broth. I did hear someone order half noodles though so good to know that's an option. Also, there's another separate station where you add all of the toppings. Everything is kind of do it yourself here, so don't forget to put your dishes away! 

Overall, pretty decent: I would honestly say that this place's popularity is bumped up by the experience. I'll definitely be back, especially since this is one of the better options to eat at the mall. Just make sure you don't come starving because that line can really be killer at times.
author: Karen B.

description: Haven't been able to go to the one in Hawaii but really wanted to try this place out, so while being in sf it was a must. Came on a Saturday around 2pm and even though there was a line outside it didn't take long for us to get inside and order our food. I got number 8 which is the nikutama udon (beef). You'd think there's not much too it because it's pretty simple but there's so much hidden flavors. It was filled with flavor and it kept me full. I never got tired of every bite I took. Something I looked forward to. I can't wait to try more of their udon!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I don't really get the hype. Maybe because there's no udon place in sf (that I know of?) but there's nothing too special about this place tbh. 

I really like their udon noodles and I think they do a good job on the texture of it. But the broth was okay. I got curry and it was okay. The meat inside the curry was definitely over cooked so it was soggy. Meh. 

It's cool that you can see their assembly line - rolling the noodles, boiling the noodles, portioning the noodles to adding the soup. But not so cool when you see the noodles being served to you touch someone's arm but they still serve it to you...

Pretty gross but my friends and I saw a chick make the portions of noodles and she didn't grab them all so one noodle from her hand was long and dangling so it flew a bit where it wrapped around another worker's forearm then she was like :O then unwrapped it but continued to bunch it in serving noodle pile... Pretty unsanitary but didn't want to potentially have my food be messed up somehow. 

I also feel bad for my friend's order (large) verses mine(regular). I think he ordered a large but only got 1 portion of noodles instead of 2... and just had more broth to compensate. Not sure if the workers were frazzled but they might have not noticed my friend's order was a Large and not Regular. 

I would probably give this place another shot later in the future but I think they have a lot of training to go through with their employees before I return. Also - lined up at 4:30pm and waited in the cold until 6pm... No fun. 


+1 Star for the price though. Definitely affordable and not robbing me!
author: Nicole C.

description: I was really looking forward for a good udon spot close by but was really disappointed when I tried it - tried it twice here now but it just doesn't hit the spot or compare to some of the other udon places around.  I would pass on this.
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
Interesting concept of incorporating food and an assembly line and self service. Chipotle and subway has that but they do not have the booth where you can hand pick what you would like- the tempura/free toppings. 

Got there at 1006am and there was no line. decided to kill 30 min at the mall , came out and the line was already building fast. We were lucky enough to make it into the first line section (at the end). 

Got the niku udon large - wish there was a bit more broth but was flavorful , granted a bit salty , and delicious. noodles were SLIGHTLY cooked a bit more than mugizo so mugizo wins here. Noodles at Marugame are still chewie and delish though.

Tempura to get:
shrimp
asparagus
zucchini
croquette - a bit on the sweeter side. this one is a maybe. 

not to get:
chicken - too dry
squid - too soggy. 

Even though their tempura was coming out fresh, I didn't like that they weren't SUPER crispy as they would when you order it at a restaurant. I feel their batter needs to be improved a bit . 

Also got the mentai mayo rice ball and the kombu onigiri. I liked both but would pick kombu more. 

They should also probably open a couple more registers because they were seriously backed up. 

Can't decide if I like marugame or mugizo more since I like each for individual reasons.
author: Eva L.

description:
Great service and great food! Really good prices and quite a few menu options for udon and tempura. 
Can easily go in and get a quick bite to eat or hang out and socialize for awhile.
author: Sami L.

description:
People waited hours for this...?? I've been waiting to try this place ever since it opened but didn't want to wait in line forever. I was able to come by on a Tuesday around 5pm and the line was just out the door. 
Inside is like a cafeteria style where you get your food and pay then find your own seat. There is plenty of seating and should be enough turnover that there will be empty tables when you get your food.

I ordered #2 which comes with beef and egg. I was pretty hungry so I ordered a large since it was just udon. The udon was fresh but wasn't especially smooth or amazing. The soup they poured was barely even hot?? By the time I sat down, it was barely warm... Large size was also not enough for me... Maybe a large and a regular...

Also picked up a shrimp tempura and mentai cod roe rice ball along the way. I like that they're constantly frying the tempura so it seems fresh. I would not get the rice balls again. 

Overall, it was okay. I would not wait hours for something like this!!
author: Kristie L.

description:
I've had this in Hawaii, and I only thought it was ok... I didn't really care to re line up for the one in sf, but my friend wanted to go.  However, the service in sf versus the one in Hawaii is slower. The employees are very nice, I didn't mind it being slow since it's only their soft opening.

Spicy chicken udon: 3/5 the chicken is chicken breast, and the soup is like a spicy sour type of soup. I didn't really care for this udon dish, it was a little to sour for my taste. Although they perfect the spice level!

Curry udon: 4/5 their curry actually tasted pretty good. It is more on the  creamy side and it pairs well with the noodles 

Tempura: 1/5 they let it sit out, so it's cold when you get it. I wish they could find a way to keep it warm/:

Rice balls: 2/5 I honestly had better elsewhere.  You can make these yourself for better... 

All in all, I don't care for this place, the food is only decent but not worth the wait.
author: Elsa W.

description: came by with bear on a sunday night recently - while the line was long, it moved rather quickly. you can pick up snacks and drinks from 85 degrees next door while you wait.  i got the regular size curry udon with tempura shrimp, katsu shrimp, and fried egg cake. bear got a large udon, a musubi, and a fried sweet potato for me. the noodles were warm and inviting, but i though the toppings were overpriced and underwhelming.  i will pick fewer in the future, but would come back for udon if in the area. no special trips, though.
author: Christina L.

description:
No doubt 5 stars! 

I stopped by Feb 4, 2018 and started lining up at 11:30am. Line was long but I'm glad there was some sort of shade. I do recommend someone lining up and the other find parking... 

Not afraid to say this but I lined up a little over an hour to get in... 

Now onto the udon... very, very delicious. I'm not a fan of udon but I did enjoy this spot. I ordered the Nikutama udon along with the shrimp tempura, veggie tempura and croquette. 

I really like this spot but I would opt out the veggie tempura next time. The star of the show was the udon and definitely didn't disappoint! I would come back to line up all over again!
author: Elaine C.

description:
I never liked the Hawaii location, but if you can't tell from the other thousands of review, I'm definitely an outlier. I do like Marugame in SSF though. Likely because its ridiculously cheap for Bay Area prices, but that comes with a ridiculously long wait. The food is still mediocre at best, but seriously...cheap, just so cheap for the amount of food and handmade quality. I came around 10:30AM on a Saturday (opens at 11), and the line was already some 20 groups deep. 

1) Stand in line (the line breaks into 2 parts, so make sure you're not cutting anyone hangry)
2) Wait..wait... and wait some more until you get to the front door
3) Pick up a tray, and look at the menu. Unless you already stared at the menu for the past 1.5 hour you were waiting. 
4) Let the udon makers know what you want, and voila, a bowl gets handed to you.
5) Pick ALLL the tempura that you want! They're at most $2 each (there may have been one for $2.50). 
6) Get some musubi if you think you're still hungry. 
7) Pay
8) Get water, sauce, any drinks you ordered from the next station
9) Find a seat and enjoy! 

All in all, my favorite is still the Nikutama Udon. Since I love egg. For tempura, my favorites were the fish cake, squid, and sweet potato.
author: Annie L.

description:
Came here for the soft opening and was so glad we did! I never had the chance to visit the one in Honolulu, so I was so excited to hear this one was opening!! One of the chefs from the Hawaii location was there tonight too! The restaurant name change, they said, was only due to the different location.
I had the bukkake udon (yea, yea jokes jokes lol) - so good! All the tempura was so good too! I had "hungry eyes" and got one of every tempura option. Didn't finish but the fiance enjoyed the rest! 
I like how the restaurant is setup: order the ramen of your choice from the team making hand made udon noodles, then pick up goodies from the tempura and sides buffet on the way to the register...so cool!
The team was very welcoming and it was a great experience! Can't wait to come back!!
author: Nicole B.

description:
Waiting in line for 45 minutes freezing my bum off for a steaming hot bowl of udon? Check.

Finally getting inside the restaurant with a sigh of relief? Check.

Looking in amazement at how they make the noodles from scratch? Check.

Getting hangry waiting for said noodles? Check.

Mel N. and I drove SO FAR across town (first world problems) to Marugame for udon. Whilst waiting in line, the guy said that they served 15,000 bowls of udon yesterday. That's a lot of noodles!

After waiting 45 minutes in two different lines, we finally got into the restaurant. The couple before us ordered two bowls and proceeded to order 7 bowls to go, which meant that 8 people (including us) had to wait for a whole new batch to be made. Ugh. 

It's an assembly line for the noodles and the team has it down pat. They were like machines churning out bowls  and bowls of noodles.

I ordered the Nikutama Udon ($8.90) which consisted of a soft boiled egg and sliced beef. After they give you your bowl, you can pick various tempura fried items like shrimp, onion, fish, veggies for around $1.90 each. They also had various musubi for $1.50. This can all add up if you like lots of fried food and musubi. 

There is a separate station for Shichimi chili powder, tempura bits, cilantro, scallions, etc so you can load up on free accompaniments. 

The noodles were perfectly cooked and chewy and the soup, although flavorful, was really salty. The beef and egg were also good too (it was a little on the fatty side but I prevailed).

I would definitely come here again and try different bowls like Curry and Spicy Chicken Udon. Perhaps a later time when the crowds have died down.
author: Nette T.

description:
After a 50min wait in a two-part outdoor line with much-needed chicken nuggets as a line-snack, we made it inside! Ordering was easy: pick your udon by number, hot/cold, regular/large. Then slowly weave your way up the counter, picking up your udon order made fresh to order, any tempuras and musubi, and then paying. Afterwards there's a convenient sidebar of condiments (green onions, cilantro, tempura flakes, sriracha) to add to your udon. There's a surprisingly good amount of indoor and outdoor seating, and their waiting structure (ordering and getting the food before you sit) assures you a spot to sit. The chefs and servers were all very nice and friendly.

We both tried the hot Nikutama udon (#2): sweet beef with soft boiled egg in Kama broth. The texture of the udon was great for me, soft but springy. The large order of udon was perfect for me, a ravenous carbivore. I wasn't as much of a fan of the sweet beef, which was ...v sweet.

Maybe I'll come back to try the curry udon once the line dies down. For now I'll just stick to Udon Miguzo in Japantown.
author: Cindy T.

description:
They've opened one in San Francisco! I am so happy. I went last Wednesday and the line wasn't long so I got to sit and eat my beef udon within a few minutes. I love the experience so much, the staff was so extra (in a positive way) right when I walked in the staff at the door greeted me in Japanese loudly and all the kitchen staff replied back, warmed my heart. I sat down and ate my udon, at some point management came up to me to ask if I needed anything which was very thoughtful. The setting in San Francisco feels much modern than the one in Hawaii, it's so beautiful and bright inside! I am looking forward to the curry udon. Fingers crossed the lines don't get as long as Hawaii. 

Also, something I love about this place is that the udon gets made right in front of you and it only takes a few minutes. This is definitely a fast food place yet healthy and delicious! Nom nom!
author: Yenni H.

description: The line was pretty long at the opening for dinner on Saturday evening. Took about 25 min, but is pretty good udon, and the fact that they handmake the noodles there really shows. Ordered the Tonkatsu bowl large and I almost couldn't finish all of it. Make sure you're really hungry! Tried the shrimp, egg, and shisito tempura- while the flavor was there, they were a bit cold so you'll probably need to dunk them in the hot udon broth to warm them up. The toppings bar was great, adding in all the green onions, cilantro, sauces, chili powder, etc. that you want. You bus your own tray but the employees sort out the trash/compost/recycling.
author: Ally B.

description:
It's almost the like the Kuhio Ave location on Oahu. Down to the long lines of people... I was pleased to hear there was a Marugame located at Stonestown. We made our way there for a Sunday night dinner just as the mall was about to close. It's located outside the entrance to the mall by Olive Garden so you cant miss it. 

Let me tell you about the lines, wow... You wait in a line across the way to get into a line that gets you into another line inside where you finally order. It was packed but we were hungry and it was a cold evening and udon was the answer. We waited about 30-35 mins before we were able to order. That wasnt cool but its popular and inexpensive so you just gotta bring your patience.

Once you get inside, grab a tray. You will need a tray per person with all the additions as you go down the cafeteria style ordering line. You first order the type of udon you want. I went with the #5 like I did in Waikiki. It's the beef udon that has a little bit of sweetness to it. I went with a small bowl ($7.90) because I knew I would go crazy with the tempura options... I added 2 shrimp, one potato, a mixed vegetable tempura and an egg plant. They were all good but the mixed vegetable was a little disappointing as it wasnt like the one in Hawaii. It was more of like a ball of onion rings. Not so much the other stuff. I would probably pass on that next time... The udon itself was just as delicious as I remember. The soup it comes in and the perfect udon noodles topped with the sweet beef was delicious... There is an area for toppings so you can add green onions and tempura shavings. You can also get tempura sauce for dipping and other things.

Was it worth the wait? I guess it was because it hit the spot and was light on the wallet. Was it as good as the one in Honolulu? No, it cant replicate that with the scenery or experience. Would I go again? Yes, but not on the weekends if possible.
author: Chuck D.

description:
Might be my favorite udon spot in the Bay Area now. 

The noodles are super fresh (literally they make it there) and they have a real chewy consistency. Soup is on point too, in fact I drank it all-probably not good for you though. Love the fact there's a station you can add as much green onions, tempura flakes and ginger as you want. 

The tempura was better than I expected too. Each different piece had a good chunk of meat inside, especially the squid. I didn't think it'd be as good because they're just sitting there, but it was fine. 

The onigiri was my least favorite, just way too much rice and not much fish in the salmon one I had. Also just not as much flavor as I would have liked. Probably won't be getting any of this again. 

I went for the soft opening and they only had the beef udon, which was great still. I'll be coming back to try the others.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
I have dreamt about having an amazing bowl of udon noodle soup in the Bay Area ever since I had a bowl at Marukame Udon in Honolulu. Unfortunately, nothing I have had around here has been comparable. I had high hopes for Marugame Udon (basically Marukame with a "g"?? Confusing). Anyways, I came during their soft opening on a Sunday morning 30 minutes before they opened with the intent of being the first wave for lunch. EXTREMELY happy we came at 10:30 am instead of 10:45 am, because those who came at 10:45 am probably were at the start of the second wave of patrons. So sad, especially because it was so cold outside. :(

Boyfriend & I decided to we were unlikely to come back & bare the line or cold again so we got the following (don't judge us please): 

- Spicy Chicken Udon -- threw me off a bit because it felt more like a tom yum broth or something--decently flavored & had a nice kick.
- Curry Udon -- not a huge fan of curry udon because it's a little heavy for my taste, but the bf liked this, although he def compared it to Muracci's.
- Beef Udon -- probably our favorite of the 3 udons, wish they offered the egg during soft opening :(.
- Chicken Tempura -- best tempura!!
- Shrimp Tempura -- second best tempura!
- Sweet Potato Tempura -- meh.
- Potato Croquette -- meh.
- Salmon Flake Musubi -- meh.

My biggest gripe with our meal(s) was the lukewarm temperature of the broth & tempura. I'm not sure what went wrong, maybe it was because we were part of the first wave, but then that's kind of weird, too. Honestly, if the bowl was piping hot, & the tempura were at least warm, I think Marugame would have received 5 stars from me. I hope they work out the kinks for their grand opening this past January 12th. HOT BROTH & TEMPURA GUYS, it's important!

Other than that, I would recommend Marugame Udon as a great place for udon noodle soup in the Bay Area. It seriously is INCREDIBLY well-priced. If the line doesn't keep me away, I'll definitely be going for the Kake or Beef Udon with a soft-boiled egg, along with the chicken & shrimp tempura.
author: Carol N.

description:
Line is long of course. Good, tasty, affordable food always has this problem.

The udon is probably one of the best I've had anywhere. Mind you that I am not much of a udon person at all. Great job Marugame!
author: David T.

description:
We heard of this place because of the one that is located on O'ahu, Hawai'i (where I'm from).  When this place first opened, every time my husband and I tried to go eat here, there was always lines out the door that we weren't willing to wait for.  
There is ample parking spots here as this place is located within the Stonestown Galleria Mall.  If you can't find a spot in the outdoor parking areas, there is always the underground parking garage.  We finally tried this place out on a Wednesday afternoon around 2ish.  There was no line at all!  We were so happy that we walked right in and stood in line (inside) passing the counter where noodles were made.  It was a sight to see on how the noodles were properly cooked and prepared.  
I chose the beef udon and got a couple of the tuna onigiri.  We were quite upset and annoyed that they didn't have the tempura station up and running.  We were told that they've always had issues with their fryers and today was just the wrong day to try this place out but we continued to just try to enjoy the food they had.  The beef udon was delicious; broth was flavorful, meat was tender, and the noodles were good.  The noodles are thick and not particularly not my favorite.  The tuna onigiri was okay... it lacked the ratio of tuna and rice.  Literally... there was more rice than tuna and it was not a pleasant piece of snack.  
The restaurant was decorated in Japanese influenced pieces; good amount of tables and chairs but is a first-come first-served.  The process:  you stand in line (cafeteria-style), you pay, and you go find a seat to sit.  After eating, you bring your tray with the bowls, etc. to the drop-off station.  Great and economical concept.
Overall, I had to give this place three stars.  This place did not live up to the hype!  Maybe if there was the tempura station which would have provided more food choices, I think it may have made a difference.  Will we come here again?  Maybe if we know that their fryers are working and we get lucky again with no lines... we'll give this place another chance.
author: Erna M.

description:
After waiting out and hoping the hype would die down I finally made it here. Hearing the hype and commotion about this place makes me stay away for a reason. The wait time.  So it's been about a month now so I decided to come here after my hike earlier. It's a Friday and it's about 8pm and as I walk up the line looks long but after waiting it was about 35 mins.   

As I wait and get ready to put my order in, I scope out the menu and see what the choice was. Easy and simple menu to choose from with many different flavors and side items to accommodate your bowl of soup. I stuck with the simple number one on the menu "Tonkatsu" with a few pieces of tempura "Shishito Peppers" & "Zucchini". 
My total came to a little over $16. 

The place is setup quite well with plenty of seats.  There is a a condiment Bar with chopped Green Onions and cilantro with a varieties of spices and sauces to ass to your soup.  

Ok. After eating my food I sat there and thought to myself this is good but not great. The flavor was there but something was off, the portions was good, tempura was fried nice and golden. After leaving and while driving home it had hit me. What if the broth was a bit more hotter? As I recall when eating I noticed I was eating it without my usual reaction of "Careful Hot Broth". 

I've been to the Marukame in Hawaii and it was exceptionally tasty.  Maybe it was because I was exhausted and wasn't ready for this? Hhmmm... I guess I'll have to come back again for another try.
author: Kao S.

description:
Have anxiously been waiting for Marugame to open and went straight in line the moment I heard it was open. They are in their soft opening and are slowly debuting parts of the menu until their grand opening. 

I ordered the large beef udon and wow portions are huge, and definitely more than enough food. I also tried several of their tempura and their musubi. Loved the potato croquette. Be careful the price adds up very quickly. The broth was delicious, but felt it was more on the lukewarm side as many other reviewers mentioned. Udon was perfect and the beef was good with a nice caramelized sweetness. Tempura was well battered, it just seemed like it has been sitting there for a while though. I like my tempura hot fresh out the fryer. Unfortunately, they did not deliver on that. 

The musubi was also a huge disappointment. I got the salmon musubi and it was basically 90% rice. But the worst thing was when I was biting into the musubi half way I feel a loud crunch in my mouth that resembled a small black grey rock like. I'm not sure what that was but really turned my experience around. Unfortunately, I took my musubi to go so was unable to ask any of the staff about this issue. 

I think marugame does their udon really well. But the musubi experience definitely changed my opinion about marugame. Might give it another try after their grand opening but we shall see.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Maybe the story between me and Marugame Udon is like a love story.  Sometimes, you don't know why you keep in returning to the same restaurant, sometimes you don't know what keeps on drawing you back again and again. And in the end, you still don't know how your true feelings are about the restaurant.   So let the story begin.

When you first arrive, you'll need to get in line, it usually starts outside.  They have a small menu for you to pick from and there are some items with hot and cold dishes and  you can pick the size you want, either regular or large.  When you get inside, you tell the person the number and the size of your order.  You'll need t grab a tray for the udon and one for tempura if you plan on getting it that is.  You'll go to the next section, where they'll place it on the tray and you can ask them to add an egg or two if you want.  It is 1.00 for an additional egg.  Continue down the line and you can pick our tempura.  There's veggie options, like sweet potato, shrimp, zucchini, tamago, and other tempura options.  If you don't want tempura, you can pick the onigri options in the end.  After you pay in the end, you'll need to find a seat or go to the station to add garnishes like, ginger, onions and so on.  

I've had the tonkotsu udon and the beef one a few times.  I feel the beef one is hit or miss.  Sometimes the beef is good, and sometimes, it's just completely fat.  The tonkotsu one was better, the pork was tender, but the chili oil was a little too spicy for me.  Overall, i don't know why i keep on returning, maybe i'm waiting for them to change the menu and add more items to the list.
author: Belinda C.

description:
I LOVE the udon. 

Udon is often dismissed as "plain" thicker noodle to the oh-so-exotic ramen. I admit I always went for ramen instead of udon on all the dinner menus. However, this place has a fresh take on udon with many different soup bases and customizable tempura/add-ons in a 'build your own' style. 

I visited during the soft opening and got the curry udon. I got a large and proceeded to the tempura section. I helped myself to a kakiage (vegetable tempura) and shrimp tempura. There are also onigiri (rice balls) by the cashier. Once you pay, there's a toppings island (with tempura dipping sauce) and a beverage section. While the line was easily an hour outside, there was plenty of seating.

If I got only udon, I think the large would be perfect...but next time I return, I will get a regular size so I can stack up more on tempura. The self-serve toppings is great so you can shamelessly pour tempura flakes and green onion. 

Once done feasting, you bus your own trays/dishes to the kitchen.

The noodles were the highlight with the chewy freshness. You can see the udon being shaped, cut into strips, boiled, cooled, and placed in each bowl. The curry was really savory, but I don't think I would ever drink it. I loved the kakiage. The shrimp tempura was very good, too, but it was not as crispy as I would have liked it.

I joined the line 20 min before opening, and I highly recommend doing so to be the first batch of customers and not wait for seats to empty out. Prices are reasonable for the udon - the most basic being $4.5 for a regular size. It's the tempura pieces that will get you to $15+.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I've been to the one in LA and loved it so I HAD to check out the SF location when I heard they were opening in the Bay! Went on a Saturday afternoon and waited about an hour and a half in line. Depending on the time and day, wait can vary. Once you get inside, there are instructions on how to order. Choose which bowl/size you want, have it made for you on the spot, then add freshly fried tempura onto a separate plate. Pay and from there, there is a topping bars filled with delicious tempura flakes, cilantro, green onions, etc.

beef udon + soft boiled egg: reminds me exactly of the udon I had in Japan! The soft texture of the udon mixed with the sweet taste of beef was amazing. The soup wasn't bad; although I didn't drink much of it. Wished the portions of beef was bigger but the overall experience was worth it! 

shrimp + fishcake tempura: can't go wrong with either of these! both were so light and crispy. At the toppings bar, make sure to grab a little dish of tempura sauce to compliment your delicious deep fried goodness! my favorite was definitely the fishcake but my boyfriend loved the squid + fishcake one

While this location was good, I still preferred the LA one - tasted more authentic and lesser wait time. The LA one also had more options because I got the Tonkotsu udon last time but didn't see it on the menu here.
author: Vinni C.

description:
I've always passed by marugame udon on my way to the gym and noticed how there are not one but TWO lines to dine in this place. If there are this much people who are willing to wait in line, it must be good! 

Came on Tuesday at 2pm. The line wasn't bad at all, about 5-8 people out the door. 
I love how this is a quick service establishment. First, you order your udon, which is made in front of you. Then you can pick what kind tempura and musubi you'd like, and then you pay. There is also a complimentary toppings bar right pass the register. 

#5 beef udon 
My boyfriend got this one and to me, it was the tastiest amongst both udons we tried that day. The beef is thinly sliced. Think of beef brisket when you go to a hot pot place. The broth was flavorful and complimented the beef well. 10/10 would recommend.

#6 spicy chicken udon 
The only reason why I got this was bc I wanted something spicy. To me, it wasn't spicy at all. The chicken was moist, cut into small bits. Freshly cooked udon had a nice bite to it. 

Shrimp tempura 
Tasted cold but was still good.

Squid tempura 
The squid tempura tasted like it's been sitting there for a good amount of time. Not appealing. Old and rubbery. The tempura batter had left oil residue on my fingers. 

Potato croquette 
Yum! My fave out of all fried foods. Basically a mashed potato ball breaded and deep fried. Slightly sweet. Very good. Reminds me of an Asian version of a Portos potato ball.

Chicken tempura 
I was not amazed by this. Many people have said great things but I was not impressed. Although the chicken was moist and the exterior was crunchy, I felt it was lacking flavors. I tried to sprinkle on some seasoning on it but still wasn't tasty. 

Vegetable kakiage
This definitely has been sitting there. Oily and cold. Tasted heavy of onion and nothing else. 


This place is affordable. I love the fresh topping bar where you can customize your soup to your liking. I recommend coming during lunch hours bc the line is significantly shorter. Definitely try the delicious beef udon & potato croquette.
author: AJ C.

description:
We arrived around 10:35 AM on a Sunday and there was already a line when the restaurant opens at 11. We were on of the last group for the first set of the line. They have a second set of line in the back by olive garden so that it doesn't block the crosswalk. After it opened, we had to wait another 25 min to order. 

The set up is cafeteria style. You get a tray, order your udon, choose the udon or musubi you want, pay, go to the toppings bar to add to your udon and find an open table to eat. I think  the process is pretty organized and efficient. When you're done eating, you bring your trays back yourself. 

We ordered the beef udon, nikutama udon, shrimp, zucchini and asparagus tempura and a musubi. The nikutama udon is a sauce based noodle and you can choose whether to get it hot or cold. I thought the udon in Hawaii tasted better but food was still good!! Udon noodles was super fresh since they make it there and you can watch the process as you're in line. Musubi was good too, the rice was super fresh. I will be back when there are shorter lines!
author: Denise J.

description: Udon noodles are made fresh but broth was mediocre. Do not be supprised if you come here and see people ordering plain udon (no special sauce) and dumping it full with tempera. The tempera here is its saving grace. Tempera was very delicate and fresh. The tempera sauce was also on point. If they didn't have tempera, this place would be a 3 star place. Also many people have already mentioned that wait is ridiculous. If you want to try this place, defibately go during off hours. NOT worth a long wait.
author: Diane Z.

description:
Is this worth the wait? tldr- YES! :D

I came here during their soft opening for a Sunday lunch. We waited for about an hour. I was wondering why there would be periods where the line kept moving gradually, while sometimes we'd just be standing there. It turns out that they kept running out of some of the broths and it was a 15 min wait for those options. I think they will be working on the timing and efficiency during their soft opening, so hopefully the wait won't be too bad in the future (fingers crossed). Staff was polite and friendly. 

None of their udons with egg were available during the soft opening, so I got a large beef udon with squid and chicken tempura on the side. Highly recommend the beef udon, though I'd get a regular next time haha (I was so hungry after running the Hot Chocolate 15k in SF that I was a bit ambitious xD). My husband preferred his bukkake udon, but both were delicious! The noodles were cooked perfectly with the right texture and consistency.

As for the tempura, I'd recommend the squid tempura and the potato croquette- so tasty and perfectly fried! After you pay, you can get free green onions, tempura flakes, ginger, parsley, and pepper at the toppings bar and seat yourself at an open table. Afterwards, you bus your own tray to the tray return area. 

Prices are really reasonable, averaging $5-8 for a bowl of udon including tax and less than $2.5 per piece of tempura or onigiri. 

I want the Nikutama udon (contains beef and egg) when they have their grand opening on January 18th, 2018! 

Arguably the best udon place in the Bay Area even though it is a chain-
definitely come check it out!
author: Jessica Y.

description: I decided to give them another try, but this time around they were not serving tempura because their tempura machine is out of service. Also I ordered their mentaiko mayo and crab onigiri and the waiter came around and asked if I ordered tuna mayo twice. Strike 2...
author: Hoyan L.

description: This is my new noodle spot in San Francisco. I wanted the egg drop chicken udon but I was told it was a Winter seasonal soup. I had the delicious Thai spicy chicken udon. I got carried away with the tempura. I had the chicken, shrimp, and vegetable tempura. Yes I slurp my noodles with pride !
author: Juan V.

description: Omg I am literally obsessed with this udon place. The line is always extremely long but it's totally worth it (just bring a snack). I love how you can build your own bowl. The broth is delicious, it's very savory. The shrimp tempura wasn't that good, it was tiny shrimp overly breaded but the other tempura items were good. I like how you can add your own greens on top. You can also see all the food being made , and the noodles being made too! Great spot in the mall, highly recommend
author: Michelle K.

description:
It's still their soft opening, so they only have a few menu items available right now. There was a guy walking around handing out menus, which also had some coupons printed on them to use once the grand opening happened. There was also a really long line, so it took us about 20-30 minutes to finally order. It gave us enough time to go over the menu to choose what to eat. I decided on the large beef udon, especially since I was hungry. 

You get a tray and then wait to tell the person your order. They will hand you the bowl with the noodles and broth, then you are sent on your way to the topping bar. They have many different types of tempura. The shrimp tempura, zucchini tempura, and potato croquette were calling to me. You then also pass by some masubis, but I wasn't hungry enough to also eat one of those, so I passed on it. I might come back and try one of the crab meat masubis. After the masubis is the cashier where they ring you up for everything you order. Each piece of the tempuras costs money, so choose wisely. Everything I ordered was under $15, so it wasn't too bad. 

The beef was kind of a small portion, but I actually enjoyed the beef. The tempura was really good. I think people don't really choose the vegetable tempuras much because my zucchini tempura was pretty cold. It probably sat there for a while and cooled down since it was in the fryer. The shrimp one had just come from the fryer, so it was nice and hot. The potato croquette was a lil cold, but still tasted good. If you see something come straight from the fryer, i would recommend getting one of those items. 

Having only one cashier does slow down the line a lot, but that might be a good thing since it's getting cold now and no one wants to sit outside. By slowing it down, people are allowed to sit and eat and then empty seats will eventually open up for everyone. Maybe it was meant for the seating arrangement to work out. Who knows. 

Anyways, I really enjoyed the udon and it was nice to eat on a pretty cold day. I can't wait to come back and try some of the other dishes that become available soon.
author: Allyson L.

description: Mom, sister, and I wanted to take my elderly grandmother to lunch. The line didn't look too long for 12pm on a Sunday. As we were trying to squeeze my grandma's wheelchair into the roped line, a staff member came out to take us to a table inside. "How nice," my sister and I thought, "Grams and mom can sit while we go back out and stand in line under the warm sun." (Not exact thoughts, but basic sentiment.) As my sis and I went back out to the line and took a pic of the menu to send back to mom to get their order, the same staff member came out to find us and took our order from the table. My sis and I then went to the tempura section to tell him what we wanted. We then paid at the register and yummy food was delivered promptly to our table. My sister and I were grateful for the table, and were more than willing to go back out and stand in line to order, but the staff's response went above and beyond our expectations. We later saw the staff do the same for another elderly patron. We truly appreciate great service and consideration towards the elderly and disabled. If I could, I'd add an extra star for good music. As I walked in, they were playing BlackPink's "As If It's Your Last" (in Japanese, of course). They also played other Japanese songs from Kpop artists including Got7 and Winner. Would definitely come again!
author: Karina T.

description:
Marugame Udon has finally arrived in the Bay Area! Located in San Francisco, at Stonestown Mall, this place packed a lot of people having two separate lines! Due to this week being their opening week, their menu was very limited, meaning four of the other udons were excluded. However, do not fret! They officially will hold their grand opening on 01/18. Be sure to come that day because they will be having a special promotion for their first 100 customers.

We waited about 50 minutes in line, but the wait was worth it. Marugame serves freshly made handcrafted noodles that will blow you away. We ordered the Curry udon as well as the beef udon which were both very flavorful. The curry udon wasn't too heavy and had just the right amount of saltiness. The beef broth was very satisfying. The texture of their noodles was perfect as they were perfectly cooked. The beef was sweet and thinly sliced which was nice because it was easy to eat. The tempura was fried perfectly and wasn't too overcooked.

I thought their ordering system was wise because it allowed quick service and had the long line moving smoothly. The condiments bar which had a variety of different garnishes was a nice touch as it allowed people to customize their udon just the way they liked it.

Overall, the food was great, quality of the food went beyond my expectations and everyone in my group enjoyed their food. We had a great time.
author: Marc C.

description: Best ramen I've ever had! The line was about a 30 minute wait on Sunday at 2:20. It moved at a decent pace though. It's cafeteria style and seating is first come, first serveI got the #1 Tonkotsu and it was delicious! The prices for the ramen are affordable but the sides seem expensive so it kind of evens itself out. I got the tempura asparagus and the fish roe hand roll as well which altogether was $14. They have indoor and outdoor seating and accept credit cards. They're located right next to Chipotle at the mall. I'll definitely be back!
author: Robby T.

description: I waited about 40minutes! I got curry udon and it was too bland for my taste! My sister got nikutama udon and I loved it! Mentai udon was good too but little salty for me! I got shrimp and veggie tempuras! I liked veggie one over shrimp! To be honest, it is not the best udon I've ever had but it's worth the try! I will visit again when line is short!
author: Clare L.

description:
I'd say good for the value (in SF standard), I added an egg and picked 4 pieces of tempura (shrimp, squid, sweet potato, shishito peppers) to the Bukkake (very suggestive ;) Udon for like $13 after tax. 

Their udon is mildly bouncy, and doesn't have much taste of wheat, can use better flour (I can make bouncier udon with more distinctive taste using Bob's Red Mill flour). Decent soup base. Good execution for the veggie tempuras. Squid was particularly disappointing, flavorless as it's from frozen, also a bit mushy.

Mostly very attentive service (except one person), happy employees. I was served around 11:30 on Sept 9. The lady that put soup into each udon: 1. Always made the order taker repeat his instructions multiple times, 2. Never attended to customers, the two ladies in front of me had some questions and she never noticed, as she never looked at people. The rest of the team did a great job running the show. 

Worth trying but doesn't worth a dedicated trip.
author: Roy C.

description:
Finally came and tried out Marugame today. It is still in its soft opening stages so the full menu is still not available but that didn't matter cause you still have plenty of choices to choose from (5). I opted for the curry udon today and it was a very wise choice I must say. I was gonna try out the spicy chicken but when I saw that it was chicken breasts, I said no bueno..... who eats chicken breasts... that's gross. Dark meat only lol... anyways, the wait wasn't terribly bad at 7:30 and the udon tasted pretty well so it was an overall great first impression. The only thing that I had an issue with was some of the tempura was stale since they've been sitting out too long, but other than that, everything was a-ok!

I will return to get that mentai udon... I love cod roe!
author: Marco M.

description: It's like going to a Udon place in Japan. They make their own broth and Udon. Quick service, assembly line style. It's fun picking out extra pre-fried appetizers and ABC style snacks. The lines can be long so try to go at less popular lunch times and days. The young staff are very friendly.
author: Regina G.

description:
I have been anticipating the opening of marugame for a while now! And I finally got to try it yesterday! I came at around 3:30, and was sad to see the lime was already out the door, waited about 30 minutes from outdoor line until ordering. However, I was not let down, the taste is very similar to the Hawaii marukame, but I feel that the quality is a tiny bit lower, and as of now the line definitely moves slower. I felt that the texture of the udon noodles are a little less chewy, and a bit more on the soft side. They also do not give much broth for the #2 nikutama udon that my boyfriend ordered, while my #5 niku udon has plenty of broth. The broth was still tasty with a perfect sweet and savory combo. The tempura options are also a bit smaller than the Hawaii marukame, I wish they had kabocha (pumpkin) tempura, that's my favorite. 

Environment wise, seating was no issue when we came. Although the line was quite long, people were constantly leaving, so there were many seats throughout our meal. In addition, the little bar of green onion, sauce, ginger, and tempura flakes was very clean and a nice addition. It was great to be able to add as much topping as you like! I will definitely be returning! Although the price is a bit higher than Hawaii's marukame, it is still a good deal for sf pricing and definitely cheaper than other udon spots in the area. So glad marugame is here now!
author: Nina W.

description:
Hello sexy udons!!!!! No, I'm not kidding, and yes you should go at non-peak hours unless you want to wait outside for over an hour... but here's the review. 

I went around 11:45am and I was still 4th in line out the door, so be prepared this isn't a fast spot for a lunch break. The udons are made fresh at the spot, which was amazing. That alone was worth the wait, however it is cafeteria style and the tempura is made ahead of time, so that's why it's only receiving 4 stars. 

Regardless, I went very plane Jane- only because I really wanted to taste the noodle and not everything else on top of it. I ordered hot bukkake udon (and yes, I did add cilantro, tempura bits and green onions to it) plus asparagus, zucchini and shrimp tempura. I will say that the tempura should be warmer than the room temperature it was when I went in, but other than that for the price it was more than okay. 

Now, would I wait over an hour just for a bowl of udons at a mall? No. Look, the place looks very authentic, the prices are incredibly affordable especially for San Francisco, but no it's not worth an hour outside either in fog or sun. That said, you should try it and yeah on a cold late morning a hot soup is amazing.
author: Carolina S.

description:
Went here on a Saturday for the first time and I was super excited because I loved the one in Hawaii! 

My friend headed there first because I was coming from Mountain View and he was waiting in line at 10:30 AM and there was already a long line! I believe people started waiting in line around 10... How crazy! I think it took almost an hour but getting the food was super fast which was nice.

Once you've made it to the front, you get a "cafeteria tray" and you order what udon you want. After they made your bowl, you can pick all the fried tempura you want, as well as musubi's for cheap. Then you pay! After you pay you head over to another station to top your bowl with green onions, crunchy fried tempura flakes, cilantro, and shichimi spice. SO PERF! 

I got the Nikutama Udon which has sweet flavored beef,  soft boiled egg, an kake sauce. It was $8.50 for the regular. Not that bad! 

The tempura... OMG! I can eat this nonstop! The shrimp tempura?! Perfect! Everything tasted so fresh and crunchy! LOVE IT! 

It is definitely worth the price and honestly, I don't mind waiting in line. If you are not a patient person, I say wait it out but who knows when the line will die down.
author: Christina T.

description:
I first had marugame in Honolulu, Hawaii. So glad that we have one in the Bay now! Lines get long but move pretty quickly and efficiently and is worth the wait.

Everything I've tried is delicious--get the plain Udon to fully appreciate the fresh hand-made noodles and warm satisfying broth. Sweet beef is also great. As for tempura my favorite is the vegetable ball which is mostly onion. Make sure to top your udon with green onions, cilantro, and tempura flakes!
author: Megan L.

description:
4.5 but the line was too long for a 5.

We waited for about 1.5 hours and I ordered the #2 (beef udon) with a soft egg. So very yammy after the hangry wait. The soup amount was proportionally small, at least for the small bowl. Loved the egg and beef inside. I had a bite of the curry one but it was not nearly as savory, just tasted like salty Japanese curry imo.

I was super excited for the tempura as I've been craving it all week, but it felt much soggier than I anticipated. We got the shrimp, zucchini, sweet potato and the potato croquet. I think shrimp was my favorite.

I'm still full after 3 hours so it was certainly filling! Remember the joy found in delayed gratification and don't opt in Olive Garden or Chipotle next door!
author: Juliana P.

description:
I'm ecstatic to have a Marugame in driving distance!! I don't care if I have to pay toll to cross the bridge because it is worth it! Besides visiting family, I need to find a new excuse to vacation in hawaii once in awhile. 

My friends and I checked it out during their soft opening. I feel that the location is strange being at stonestown, but it somehow works. We lined up at about 7pm. We waited a good hour until we were able to get thru the doors to order. 

The restaurant size is decent. It's not huge, but not too small either. It could probably seat approximately 50 ppl inside and another 20 outside. Unfortunately, there aren't heaters outside, so I'm not sure if i would even want to sit outside. Maybe only during a summer day because it always seems to be cold in the sunset.

The service is average because it is more like a fast food/self serve place than a sit down and be waited on restaurant. You go in an orderly line, tell them what size and udon you want, choose your tempura, they also have onigiri if you like, then you pay, and lastly you seat yourself. 

Everyone got the curry udon and I got my usual beef udon. I also got the shrimp and fishcake tempura. My boyfriend got the zucchini and asparagus tempura. One of my friends got the mixed veggie tempura.

I love how they have a station where u can add your own onion, cilantro, and TEMPURA FLAKES! They also have sauces for your katsu and tempura. As well as a few spices you might like to add to your udon.

Everything was DELICIOUS!!! The beef udon flavorful and soothing. The udon was soft, but still had a little spring in it. It's exactly what I remembered and what I've been craving for since I last had it in November. I had some of the curry udon, and that too was just as delicious as i remember. It was not too thick, but was slightly rich and flavorful. All of the tempura were perfectly battered and fried to a crisp! I had it when tempura is too soggy or over battered. My mouth is salivating as I write all this. 

I'm already thinking of when I can go back. I've been wanting to go back to hawaii just to eat and beach, but now one of my eateries is HEREEEE!!! I still cant believe it.
author: Lily T.

description:
Hands down the best udon I have ever had! The line is out the door, but the wait is reasonable. 

On my first visit, I had the following: 
- Beef Udon with egg
- Shrimp Tempura
- Vegetable Kakiage Tempura
- Mentaiko Musubi (my absolute favorite!)

On my second visit, I brought my dad because I had been raving about this place. They were so understaffed that they ran out of several items. I wanted the Curry Udon, but they ran out of beef and egg. I ended up ordering: 
- Tonkotsu Udon with no egg
- Shrimp Tempura
- Potato Croquette
- Mentaiko Musubi 

Then I find out that they ran out of tempura sauce! Ugh what a disappointment :( I will probably come back again, but just so hesitant if they stay understaffed.
author: Jessica L.

description:
The atmosphere is very trendy and reminds me of Japan even though I have never been there. The staff are very friendly, they greet you and shout out goodbye when you leave. 

I ordered the the "Chicken Udon" & was pretty disappointed, the udon tasted very fishy and made me feel uncomfortable. 

My girlfriend ordered whatever #1 was & it tasted much better. 

I was also a bit shocked that the tempura was $1.90 a piece, I love tempura, but for $1.90 no thanks. 

Overall I'd say 3/5 stars is a fair judgment of the overall experience. Glad I tried it, but won't be back anytime soon.
author: Yuriy T.

description: Be prepared to WAIT. I want to say our party of 6 waited longer than 30 minutes around 5:00 PM, which isn't terrible since I've seen the line even longer than when we waited to eat here. I always wanted to try this place, since Stonestown isn't too far from where I'm at. There's a good amount of seating area if you count the outside (and hoping it's not too cold outside). It's nice because you can pick your toppings once you choose the type of udon you want. Overall the udon was great and the broth was perfect on a cold day, but I can't justify the wait time for $10 udon noodles.
author: Hannah C.

description:
I honestly do not understand the hype. We waited in line for about half an hour and ordered the beef udon, curry udon and tonkatsu udon. Portion sizes were fairly big even for the regular size so unless you're super hungry no need to upgrade to large. 

I was expecting the broth to be piping hot but once they added the noodles, an egg (expect to pay extra) and picked up some tempura on the side, the broth was lukewarm which was disappointing. 

Consistency of the noodles were good but the beef noodles and tonkatsu broth were way too oily and the curry udon was just okay. 

The tempura was soggy but problem solved once you scraped the batter off. Which is a shame because the restaurant had just opened half an hour ago so what's the deal?!

Overall, not horrible but for the wait time and the price I don't think I'd be back.
author: Eunah T.

description:
I would say it's pretty good! Worth the try. Would come back. 

Went on a Thursday around 12:30 and waited about 20 minutes to get in the door. Lines moved fast but it's a slow process to move this assembly line. Once we got ours and sat down, the line resided fast. 

The assembly line moves slow but everything is fresh fresh fresh. I like how they steam the bowl to help keep your noodles warmer. The staff are not in any rush either. I took it as them preparing and giving each bowl it's special attention and the reason why the lines are slow.

We got #1 (highly recommended, my fave one, love that pork chasu), #8, is drier but that meat is SOOO TENDER, full of flavor, and delicious. #6 is ok. The crushed walnuts (optional) was pretty good because I like the crunch. I think the best combo really is #1 and add the meat from #8. Hella bomb!!  Udon noodles are very soft and fresh. There's a little condiment area to get those fried bits of tempura and sauces and green onions and cilantro (Coriander leaves). 

I recommend you to try it because each bowl had their own unique taste and flavor. 

Very cost affordable. Restaurant was clean, but you seat yourself and clean after yourself. I didn't see anyone wiping the tables down. You return your dishes to this kitchen window place area. 

Staff are very friendly and helpful. 

Def would come back.
author: Suiying S.

description:
I heard so many things about this place and how it's like the one in Hawaii.  

Firstly, the line to order/eat can be insanely long, but once you are in, it moves quickly. After selecting what you kind of udon you want (9 kinds) and the size (reg or lg), slide your tray down for a selection of tempura...from shrimp, fishcake, to choices of veggies, fried potato patty (korokke) & assorted onigiri.  

My udon was okay...I'm not sure what the hype is all about. The tempura was disappointing--nothing like real tempura.  The batter was heavy and the food had a greasy after taste, like it was deep fried in old oil.

You get what you pay for and if you want a cheap bowl of udon, this is the place.  After ordering your noodles and selecting the ala carte tempura/onigiri, you can easily spend $15.  I don't think it was worth the long wait and I am not fond of cafeteria style service.
author: Kathy L.

description: It's simple for a great price and absolutely delicious- Just like the one in Hawaii! I also love how convenient this location is.
author: Emily G.

description:
Came here for the soft opening, and in my opinion, the food here is definitely not worth the hype. Udon was overcooked and lacked the chewy and bouncy texture that I love about freshly made udon (maybe I've been spoiled by Japan). Other restaurants in the Bay offer better udon. As other reviewers mentioned, the tempura is not hot and fresh because they sit on plates for customers to choose from, buffet-style.  However, an employee frying tempura was kind to give me a fresh squid tempura that he just finished frying though (I think the key is to linger and stare.) I also had a sweet potato tempura and a croquette - even though they've been sitting out for a bit, I was happy there was still a yummy crunch. Onigiri had expected filling and rice portions - onigiri is meant to have more rice anyway. 
 
The lines here are long, and the cafeteria-style service and new employees are inefficient in dealing with the huge influx of customers. Likely explains why my udon was overcooked. I would come here again later, when Marugame has more of a handle of everything.
author: Christine L.

description: Not really into Udon more of a Ramen guy but i must DAMN! This place is off the hook from the anticipation while standing in line (moves quick) to watching how they make the noodles. The moment comes when its time to order and i am speechless. There is no way you can go wrong with anything on the menu it all looks amazing. Oh the best part is deciding which and how many Fried Tempura to get. I could go on and on but i will save for my next
author: Marvin E.

description:
It is currently the soft opening so not everything is available on the menu. Every time I have past by it is ALWAYS a long line, especially at dinner time. I went at 1:00pm and waited around 40 minutes on a Thursday. 

Aesthetics: The place is a decent size, with an assembly line for your food. A bit noisy from the workers and the rest of the customers. 

Price: It is decent right now average price around $8. Goes up with you want your sides.

Food: The noodles are very fresh (made in-house, you can see the process in the beginning of the line). It is long and has a nice chew and thickness. I had the beef udon and enjoyed the beef mostly. It had a lot of flavor (sauteed with onions, slightly sweet)! The soup base was slightly sweet and but also tasted like it had msg. You can add various toppings at the topping bar (parsley, green onions, fried tempura crumbs) and various sauces. I don't recommend adding the fried tempura crumbs in the soup as it made my soup oily and leaving my extremely sluggish afterwards. 

Overall, its hyped up right now with a long wait, but do try it once!
author: Sharon L.

description:
This place is great! Great food, great service, great location.

It's located right outside of Stonestown Galleria, you can get there from the muni. My friends and I stumbled upon this location because we were going to Miniso inside the mall. We got there around 5:30PM and there was already a line forming outside. I don't think this place ever goes without a line, but it was totally worth it because they have signs of the menu everywhere (about 10 different variations of udon you can pick). They have an open kitchen so while you wait to get your food, you're standing in line watching them make it. 

I got the Tonkotsu Udon, #1 ($9.90 regular). You order it directly to the chefs and you get the udon on the spot. Then you continue to the tempura station where they have sooooo many different tempura. I got the Shrimp Tempura and Chicken Tempura, but they also have crispy vegetable, regular vegetables, squid, fish, potato, fish cake, and more! They all range from $1.40-$2.00 a piece. And if that wasn't enough there also a musubi rice cake station too! Same prices, I got the imitation crab one (:

The food was soooo good. The broth was so cleansing and not over powering. The noodles were perfectly cooked, not soggy or hard. They also have a station for unlimited toppings of green onions, cilantro, extra crisps, and sauces. 

This place is a must try!! I love the presentation of everything from the open kitchen, the decor, the chairs, and the food. I will definitely go again when I get the chance.

Food: 5 | Ambiance: 5 | Portion: 5 | Service: 5 | Price: 5
author: Jessica C.

description: Fresh Udon made to order? Yes please! I got to this resturant on a busy Saturday afternoon about an hour after they opened, and i had to wait about 45 minutes to get in. This is the concept of Chipotle's assembly line style ordering and paying at the end but with udon and a la carte tempura bar.  Loved both my orders and the chicken tempura, so I will definately be back soon!
author: Sarah T.

description: I had wanted to try this place for a long time, so I was pretty happy to only wait twenty minutes on a Saturday afternoon. We got the Tonkatsu and Curry Udon, a variety of tempura, and two rice triangles. The tempura was so-so, cold and not that special. The udon though, was very fresh and the texture was soft and smooth. And the broth was very tasty and satisfying. Overall a pretty good experience:)
author: Kristine P.

description:
Came here on the last night of their soft opening and waited about 30 minutes in line. I've been to the location in Hawaii years ago and loved it, so I was excited to see they were opening a location down the street from my home in Sf! 

As with the other locations, you can see the noodles and everything else being freshly made. My boyfriend and I both had the beef udon (though I really wanted to try the curry udon, but they were sold out for the night) tempura and musubi. 

I would recommend skipping on the musubi, as it's pretty much a giant rice ball with no meat. Hopefully they work on this ratio...Reason why I removed the star. Everything else had great flavor and I will definitely be a returning customer. 

Great food for the foggy SF weather!
author: Lauren P.

description: It was a long lane although it was not a dinning time ... The bad part was it was super cold ... Fresh made udon was tender but it was not worth for two hour waiting time ... tempura was expensive compare to the quality. Other than those, nothing else to complain ...
author: Silvia L.

description:
Worth - the - hype !!!

We came in on a weekday around 8PM & surprisingly the line only reached the door! From there, it only took around 10 minutes to order, get our food, & sit down. 

FOOD:
- #2: Nikutama Udon +4.5/5
Almost everything about this dish was perfect: the portion (you can choose between regular or large), the seasoning, the tastes, etc.. However, I'm a broth-person & that was the only factor lacking. My dish looked like a dry dish bc that's how little soup base there was. Upon asking for more, I was told that I would be charge extra. -__________-
- After ordering your noodles, you can order a selection of fried foods along with misubis. Out of these, our favorites were: shrimp tempura, sweet potato tempura, & the tamago tempura.

Despite being busy, seats open up & fill up rather quickly. So be patient & spend your time waiting at the condiments station - where you can fill up on green onions, cilantro, garlic, tempura sauce, etc.. 

I c-a-n-n-o-t wait to come back & try the other udons on the menu. #sendnoods
author: Rachel Y.

description: This place is super convenient, and has decent udon. However, there is always a long line and takes forever to actually get your food. Majority of the times, the people who are helping you are frazzled and get your orders wrong. The food comes out salty. All in all, if you want to grab a quick meal, then this could be one option out of many.
author: Jello O.

description:
* updated review : we came here Monday morning for lunch right at 11 am HUGE LINE IN THE RAIN . I'm currently sick and once we got in the door I went to sit down to get warm . I was greeted by the lunch police that we can't save seats . I was already inside and my friend was getting our food so what's the problem? He's finally left me alone and I got up to help my friend carry our food to the table . I asked for to go boxes because I know we won't finish our lunch . I get that we want to use biodegradable  items but don't use them for noodles :( my udon noodles stuck to the paper bowl and my soup ate the paper Togo cup !!!!!! Our food was floating in the Togo bag !!!!! Please change this !! You will have very unhappy people call and yell at you for their orders being ruined !! 


We waited in line for a good hour for dinner at marugame this past Thursday's . In the rain too :(
We been waiting for the right day to come but they've honestly been busy everyday since opening. Not all items are available yet so check what you want first before going ! I choose the beef udon and he picked the curry ! Curry was sold out once we got there but I guess they made more because everyone was requesting it. My beef udon had onions mixed in it , it made my meat sour ! The soup and the fresh udon made it better !! The udon was perfect cooked !! Sooo good and they are big noodles !! The tempura was nothing special everything was cold and soggy when we got to eat :( Hopefully in time things will get better in time !!! Can't wait for them to add eggs to the menu !! 

I'm happy to have a new soup place in our area & it's so close to home!
author: Monica M.

description:
Summary: 
+ Reasonable prices 
+ Freshly made noodles 
+ Friendly staff 

- Long wait time 

I came here on a Saturday night at around 8:20 pm. They closed the line at 8:30 pm, so I was lucky to be one of the last ones able to get an order. I waited about 20ish minutes, which wasn't too bad. The service was pretty efficient for the amount of people that were coming through. I felt that the slow down was due to people not knowing what they wanted as opposed to the staff being inefficient. 

I would come back here when I am craving udon. I appreciate that the noodles are cooked perfectly and have the right amount of chewiness. I ordered the hot bukake udon. The sauce was a little on the saltier side than what I would like, but it was still good. Additionally, they have a sauce bar for you to get sauce for the tempura and you can add chili to your udon if you would like. They also have cilantro and green onion too for you to top your udon if you wanted. I will be coming back again to try other things on their menu during their grand opening! I must say that I am quite impressed.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Decent udon and tempura. Seating atmosphere is good. Tempura bits and green onions are unlimited self serve. Prices are very reasonable around $5-$10 for a udon. Tempura, croquette, and onigiri ranges from $1-$2.50. 

1) Large curry udon - Wouldve been fine with a regular size
2) Regular curry udon - Perfect for normal eaters
3) Spicy chicken udon - Soup was sour tingy like malay.
4) Beef udon - Was very normal. Soup was very aromatic.
5) Potato croquette - average, would skip
6) tempura vegetable kara-age - amazing would get again
7) onigiri - Would pass due to too much rice
author: Wesley K.

description:
Lovely seeing a popular Japanese chain opening up in our neighborhood.  We noticed the long lines during the soft opening and decided to come here after work on a Friday.  We arrived about 5.15 and already there was a line.  We waited 45 mins before we got inside.  Please note that this review is on the soft opening and there were only 5 udon bowls to choose from.  However, the grand opening will be on Jan 18th where more udon bowls will debut.

First you line up with a tray and dish and decide on the Udon.  After a few minutes waiting for your udon to cook in front of you, you place the bowl of udon on your tray and continue along the line.  You then pick up your favorite tempura sides, which ranges from vegetables to chicken which you place on your dish. I was worried there would be no seats but fortunately the turnover is quick and people leave as soon as they're done.  The udon was good and together with the sides provided a really satisfying meal. 

Overall, the variety of tempura is good and reasonably priced, starting from around $1.  There is also a bar, where you can help yourself to spring onions, cilantro, ginger and tempura sauce to compliment your udon. Would be back after the grand opening to check out the other udon bowls.
author: Elaine Y.

description: I think this place has scaling issues. The quality seems to be deteriorating. I have been here twice. The place gets messy on the weekends, the soup is luke warm and the broth is bland. The second time, I found a hair stuck in the middle of the udon. They gave me a refund for the udon but not for the onigiri which I threw away because I was so grossed out.
author: Jina K.

description:
Came during the soft opening. Not as good as the one in Oahu but still pretty good. The fact that this is the only type of "fast food" udon place with a tempura bar in the area makes it a win. Line can tend to get long but since it's set up cafeteria style, it moves rather quickly. Food was tasty and I was satisfied. Did not get a chance to taste all the different broths yet because it was only soft opening, but I will definitely go back. 
Space was decent and interior was clean. People seemed to be enjoying the food. Only thing I would've enjoyed was if the broth/soup was hotter. Oh and no spam musubi . Maybe that's just in Hawaii lol. But I'll definitely be back to try more!
author: Christian N.
