description: Best udon I've ever had! The broth was so flavorful, as well as the meat. Noodles are made fresh and were delicious! As you go through the line, there are different little sides you can get such as tempera everything, veggies, and more. There is also a toppings station for your soup. Pricing is pretty inexpensive for the portions you get!! 100% recommend!
author: Sofia A.

description:
WHOA, am I actually writing a review before the infamous Cherylynn?! Cool that's a first! I always look forward to reading her reviews on new spots in the SF/Peninsula area and I'm shocked I actually got to a soft opening before her lol. She's always super on top of it!

When I saw the coming soon signs for Marugame I freaked out. I remember trying them in Hawaii for the first time and it was honestly the highlight of my trip. I had never tried udon before that and I fell in love. Ever since then I had hoped for an udon only restaurant like that here at home..

Fast forward to a few years later and here it is! I only knew it was open because I was actually looking for ramen for my sick self around Daly City when Marugame popped up. I literally dropped what I was doing (which was really just throwing the blanket off me since I was laying down lol) and said let's go! I was afraid that they might be sold out of things since it was already 8:15 when we left and I was also scared they would cut off the line at 8:30 to make way to close at 9. Neither of those things happened so yay!

It ended up being a 15-20 min wait which wasn't that bad for a soft opening since I remember waiting about that long for udon in Hawaii too. The staff was friendly even though it was the end of the night and I loved watching them freshly make the udon! 

They have the same fixings as they do in all Marugame chains, the tempura crumbs (omg yum!!) And the huge bowl of green onions. I docked a star only because I felt like the udon was a teeny bit over cooked and the furikake and egg rice ball had a weird after taste..

You also have to be careful adding too much tempura because the seemingly cheap $4-8 udon really adds up when u start adding tempura pieces. With 3 pieces, my udon jumped up to $14 which is still not bad but no longer cheap as I was excited for hehe.

Since they are still in soft opening mode, they have a limited menu with 5-6 types of udon I believe then adding a new one each week on Wed, until opening day.

All in all I can't wait to come back and try their Egg drop udon when they have their actual grand opening!
author: Jayne S.

description: It's just ok for me as Japanese. But I see few Udon restaurants in San Francisco, so it reminded me of Japanese taste udon.
author: Keisuke W.

description:
4.5 Stars. The lines for Marugame are so long! I don't think it's worth waiting two hours for. If you come mid day or late night on a weekday, lines are 30 min long. 

Overall, I love the layout of the restaurant. There are little things that take me back to my glorious time in Japan. 

The food itself is pretty good. Not two hours in line good, but 30 min in line good. The broth is super flavorful. Almost too flavorful, because I am never able to finish it. 

The musubis/onigiris are not that great. Stick to the deep fried things and the noodles.




Edit: they came out with tonkotsu udon. It is AMAZING! Updated my review to 5 stars!
author: Kay C.

description:
My bestie loves this place.

Eating here, "simple dishes bring simple pleasures" comes to mind. The key is the udon in all its chewy goodness. The noodles are boiled and then dunked in cold water to stop the cooking process. That little extra step goes a long way (and brings me so much joy).

It's an assembly line here when you order. Grab your tray and then wait in line for your entree. Try the Nikutama udon! It's marinated beef, the texture and flavor comparable to sukiyaki beef (sweet soy sauce marinade), with just a bit of broth to cover some but not all of the noodles. The broth is meant for dipping rather than sipping. The egg was cool (temp wise) and the yolk runny.

After you grab the entree you can select tempura of your choice. You pay for what you choose. The asparagus was delicious albeit pricey (charged per stalk). I also enjoyed the sweet potato. After paying you can customize your dipping sauce for the tempura or obtain additions for the udon (green onion, finely chopped garlic, etc).

It's a family-friendly, relaxing atmosphere here. Come for low key, good udon.
author: Cici T.

description:
Yes, this place is very delicious, but the consistency of this place needs work. I've come here multiple times, and each time, it's been different. As for the noodles of this place, it's consistent with texture, but how you get them is another story. Often, I noticed that they try to give it flavor by making it overtly salty. The fry bar is great, but again with the consistency. 

I've gotten the curry udon, the nikutama udon, the beef udon, bukkake udon, and the mentai kamatama udon. 

Curry Udon: I'm usually a fan of curry flavored things, but the curry here was just awful to me. I did not like it whatsoever. There was something distinct that I did not like about it, that I could not even finish it. It was watery, and it felt like they were using pepper to mask it. 

Nikutama Udon: I liked this one a lot. The broth was very hearty, and flavorful. There were many pieces of meat in there, but they're not so meaty, and have a higher fat content. 

Beef Udon: This is a good safe choice. You can't really go wrong with this, but I like to be a bit more adventurous, so I don't really get this one. There's plenty of beef here too, but again, the fat content is more than the meat. 

Bukkake Udon: LOL. Had to get that out there, but yeah, this one, I thought it would be a simple dish, just sauce and noodles. Thought the sauce would compliment the noodles well, but it just made it extremely salty with not much actual flavor to it. 

Mentai Kamatama Udon: Love this one! My favorite one, but there's not a lot sauce or soup. It's basically a little bit of sauce with cod roe. It's really good since it's flavorful, and not salty.

Pricing for these dishes are quite affordable so I guess I can't really complain. They range from $4.50-$9.90 depending on which dish and size you get. A regular is pretty filling especially if you are planning to get some onigiris or tempura.

The fry bar is fun though! It's basically tempura fried things, and there's a huge variety. Again it's inconsistent. Favorite items of mine are the fishcake stick and the potato croquette. I once had the best potato croquette here. It was fresh, crispy on the outside, warm on the inside, and there was nice peppery taste to it. Another time, it was flavorless and I could tell it was sitting out.

Marugame would be amazing if the consistency was ...consistent. LOL
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The noodles are made fresh. You can see them put the dough through the machine to flatten it and cut into noodles. There are a variety of tempura and musubi to choose from, which you can also watch them make.

We waited about 45 minutes just to get into the restaurant (the Sunset chill didn't make the wait any easier). After we got our food, we had trouble finding seats too. We stood for a few minutes searching and waiting for a table to open up (not so fun when you're holding a tray with soup noodles). There were seats outside but it was too cold for anyone to eat out there. It would be nice if they had heat lamps, especially since the Sunset is always chilly.

Boyfriend had the curry udon - it was good but a little too salty for me. I had the Nikutama udon -the beef was tasty (the flavor and texture is similar to that in a gyudon), the egg is unseasoned and had a runny yolk, also take note that there's not much soup in this dish. The egg tempura was fluffy and sweet (like Chinese sweet steam egg). The meat in the chicken tempura was dry. The squid tempura was meaty and well cooked. The sweet potato tempura was good - nothing special but nothing bad about it.

Overall the food was good but I wouldn't say it was worth the long wait.
author: Carmen C.

description: It was a rainy day so positively perfect because there was no line.  Ordered the beef udon and it was absolutely delicious.  The noodles were soft  and when I added tempura bits it totally added a nice crunch to it.  There were plenty of seats open.   Had asparagus and zucchini tempura on the side, which was ok.  I love their udon here, but not sure if I would come here to wait a few hours.
author: KB B.

description: When I can't decide what to eat and have no cravings, I come here because it somehow always  hits the spot. Ignore the people who stare and laugh and point at the line. Its not that nearly that bad because it moves fast at the counter. And it's almost never busy on weeknights when they stay open til 10 anyway.  But don't come here cause you'll just make the line longer for me anyway
author: Susan A.

description:
This place always has not just one line, but two. Why? Because its so damn good. This is my favorite place to get udon at in the bay area as udon locations are very limited (why?). If I am heading in the direction of SF this is a must stop spot and the wait is worth it. Good food is always better when there is a slight wait. Right outside of the mall so parking is plenty with the garage right there.

As you enter you can enjoy the japanese environment and employees welcome you with enthusiasm. I don't eat udon often, but when I do it is the whole experience that I enjoy. At the beginning of the line is an individual handwashing and cooking udon noodles assuring us that these noodles are fresh.

Moving forward you choose your entree and then proceed towards the tempura items. The variety of tempura always gets my mouth watering as they are never fried too much.

Usually, I would get the curry udon but this time I decided to try the tonkatsu udon. Sprinkle some cilantro and onions on there and you have a delicious soup with firm udon noodles. 

Overall, I am glad they decided to open this recently as it has been quite the search for udon dishes in NorCal. Highly recommended as food and service is A1.
author: Andy N.

description:
As expected, it was not worth the wait. Is the food bad? No, it was pretty flavorful. But it was maybe too salty. I found myself quite thirsty during and after the meal. I got the beef with egg. The egg didn't make a difference in the meal, so skip it. 

Pass on most of the tempura because none of it was very good. The chicken, dry. The squid, just bad. The shrimp, meh. The only one I might get again is the vegetable nest tempura. 

The cafeteria style works well, but it's still rather slow when you're waiting in the cold for 40 minutes. 

It's the kind of place that is hyped up because of the name and reputation. It's worthy of a try and again if there's no line, but I don't see myself going out of my way to eat here. Only if I'm at Stonestown and hungry and there's no line, otherwise I'm going somewhere else.
author: Aaron Y.

description: The best and juiciest noodles in San Francisco. I first tried Marugame in Hawaii and how fresh and delicious the udon was blew my mind. I came to the mall early one day and there was no line (probably around 4:30-5pm). 30 minutes later there was a line wrapping around the line dividers they had put outside. I highly recommend this place if you are a noodle lover like myself. It's a bit like a cafeteria and it is fast food, but its so worth it. I would eat there everyday if I could.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Environment: The environment is very clean and Japanese inspired. They have very unique chairs which was a very nice touch. It's lively and great. I loved watching the udon get made fresh!

Service: Pretty standard! Very polite. It's mostly do it yourself :)

Food: No words for food. Everything was amazing :)  

Definitely worth the wait. Will be back :)
author: Casey Y.

description: If you wonder why there's long line outside Olive Garden? Well it's for fresh udon noodles. Depending on the time you go, the line might not worth waiting. The way you order here is cafeteria style, meaning you order at the counter. At the first station, someone will put together your order of udon noodles. At the second station, you can get pre-made tempura and onigari sides. At the last station, you pay and proceed to sit down anywhere where there's a open seat and table. I tried almost every item on their menu at this pint. My favorite was the Tonkatsu Udon which had a flavorful broth, pork and a raw egg. My least favorite was the Kama Age Udon, which was also the cheapest option on the menu and the most plain. Lets just say it wasn't the most appetizing, since they scooped it directly from the water they used to boil the udon noodles without rinsing it. The service here was good, they try to get everyone's orders done quickly. Well the prices look affordable on the menu, don't get carried away with the sides, since they add up quickly and may result in a $20 meal. Overall a good place to get food that is made with fresh ingredients.
author: Peter C.

description:
This is the #8, beef udon, regular. Comes with sukiyaki beef, and basic udon noods. Taste is pretty good. More beef wouldve be nice. Their toppings are pretty good though, you can add as much panko, green onion, pepper powder as you want.

The line is deceptively long. It progresses pretty fast.

They also sell various tempura, karage, and potato croquet. Theses were pretty good but a little pricy (pay per piece)

Flavor of the udon soup is okay.
author: Arno G.

description:
If you love udon, this is a must-try. I went twice within the span of a week. Eat it slowly, and savor its goodness! If you want to beat the rush on a Saturday, try making it out by 4:45PM. What I like about this place is the texture of the noodles and the flavor of the broth--how vague.

Get the Kama-age if you're not looking for anything too fancy. That way, you can stock up on all the tempura waiting just beyond the udon section :)
author: Donna L.

description:
Never heard of them or tried their other locations. Came here with an open mind twice and I was disappointed...both times. 

1st time: came around 5pm on a Wednesday and the wait in line was about 10mins. I ordered the Nikutama and the ratio of broth to noodle is little to none. By the time I reached a table to sit down to enjoy this, it was lukewarm. Meh..the tempura was cold and oily. Nothing special. 

2nd time: Monday, lunch time and wait was SO long. Waited almost an hour in line. Decided to give something else a try so I ordered the egg drop chicken one. OMG...the chicken tasted like it's been sunbathed and soaked in a saltwater bath for 20yrs. It was inedible. 

I don't think I'm going to go for a 3rd visit. Simply not worth it wait nor money. There's better food out there.
author: Serena F.

description:
So what can I say about this place that no one else has said already? "There is always a long line!" Lol. 
So you would figure after several months of it being opened for business that the line would die down. But nooooo....... the line is still there! Maybe because of the students from sfsu? 

I was lucky a few times when I was able to go here without waiting in a long line. As I enter the place, you are greeted by the staff and immediately see an employee pulling the udon noodles out of the water and twirling it around his fist before putting it into a a small bowl. 
This place is set up like an assembly line.  Basically you pick an item (udon dish) from the menu and move down to the next employee for the broth to be added into your bowl of udon. The good part about this is that before you get to the cashier, you can select many of the tempura they have laid out for you to pick and place on your tray. Usually cost $1.50 and up for each tempura. 

I had the Nikutama beef udon. This is a very flavorful bowl of udon that's very filling and sometimes maybe a little salty. The shrimp tempura are delicious especially with the ponzu sauce. 

Would I come back to this place you ask....? Sure I would if the wait line that comes out of the restaurant is only showing 5 people in it.
author: Lakeen W.

description: It wasn't bad. Nice bite on the noodles. Good soup base. Is the line worth it? Meh...
author: Eric T.

description:
The udon here is incredibly good, and it's made quickly and right in front of you. I love how you can see the whole process from beginning to end. The noodles are well-made and the broth and meat taste great.

The service was average and lagged considering that there was such a long line out the door. We have to wait just for trays to be available, but you'd think that would be the most basic thing to provide given it's the first step when you get in. Additionally, they got my order wrong on the first try. They apologized and got me the right order when I let them know.
author: Mary Tiffany M.

description: There were no quality control or what so ever, those damn green onions range from .5 inch to 2 inches long. Is it really that hard to chop them up correctly as garnish for the noodle soups?
author: Raymond L.

description:
Cafeteria style Ramen with niche!

Imagine an open kitchen with people making noodles before your eyes.  The final product is nothing out of the norm or extra special but the feel they give you is the "IT Factor"

Taste - Not bad.  3 Stars.  They are a bit stingy on the broth. But again it's taste wont offend.  Texture of the noodles are thick and chewy. 

Cleanliness - 4 Stars.  People come around and clean the tables constantly.  They even hire the physically challenged.  I like that!

Ambiance - cafeteria style.  Loud, noisy but very casual. 

Price - I think it's fair.  Not a great deal but acceptable given the area. 

Kid Friendly - yes.  Because of the cafeteria style it's quite ok to bring the kids here. 

If you're looking for fast food style noodles this place will do.  Don't expect a lot of extra frills or ingredients.   

Bare bone basics done well.
author: John S.

description:
I love noodles. I love ramen, I love udon, I love Chinese hand cut noodles. (dao hsiao mien) I haven't been the one in Waikiki to compare, surprisingly. I guess every time I've been there (twice) we've had too many other food options to try too! Hubby decided to take me today for lunch since we had already planned to head to the city for a different reason. We got there around noon on a Wednesday and I saw a line outside and my heart sunk a little. "That doesn't look that bad," my husband said.

So I hopped out to wait in line while he parked..it's in a mall-like plaza and you can't miss it next to Blaze pizza which was also packed today (pi day) for $3.14 pizza. The line did move surprisingly fast and they had menus outside for you to peruse and decide while you waited. It's cafeteria style, so you go in, pick your udon bowl, pick the size, add on tempura, see if you musubis, and then pay before heading over to the condiments bar (green onions, cilantro, crunchy tempura flakes). You can even watch them make the fresh udon while you wait (once the line moves you inside) and it's pretty cool!! 

There's someone outside regulating the line too so the whole process is pretty efficient and painless and you pick a seat after you get your food. I have to say one of the guys adding meat and sauce to the udon seems a little slow and sloppy today but I think maybe he was just new. Our food was prepared well though, but the guy in front of us had some messy to go curry bins.

I ordered the beef udon ($7.90 regular) because I wanted more broth in mine and I read some of the other broths were too little. I considered the curry udon but didn't want something so thick today. In retrospect, I think I should have just gotten the noodles and broth ($4.50 regular) and then added on tempura because I was STUFFED. My husband got the spicy chicken ($6.90 regular) which he didn't like the broth as much. I have to agree it was a little too sour for my taste, plus the cilantro in it which I hate but I'm sure you could ask them to remove it. The large bowls also looked like huge portions for another dollar more but I think the regular was already a lot. 

The noodles were super Q and fresh and chewy! I read some reviews that the broth was too salty but I didn't think so for mine haha..i topped it all off with extra crunchy tempura flakes and green onions. On top of that, I got a shrimp tempura ($1.90), zucchini tempura ($1.30) and a chicken tempura (forgot the price). Shrimp was standard, the chicken was delicious--like chicken karage almost with less thick breeding, and the zucchini was a generous slice that I took home and toasted later on for a snacK because I couldn't finish! The chicken re-heated well too. My husband also got a shrimp and fish cake which was pretty good, actually! I would try the vegetable one next time. It looks like a bundle of fried onions (almost like a blooming onion) but it just looked slightly too oily for my palate on top of the shrimp and chicken that I wanted, so I opted for zucchini. The onion ball smelled heavenly though! 

All in all, I would totally come back. Prices are super reasonable and the food was delicious and fresh! I would try the potato croquette next time too!
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Absolutely Horrible.

Visited in a Sunday afternoon.

Our udon is way overcooked, the sauce is diluted and bland, and they even ran out of green onion!!!

I understand this is just a chain restaurant so I didn't ask for the quality as any udon restaurants in Japan. However, you still need to meet the basic requirements!
author: Chin-Yi C.

description: Line looks long but moves pretty fast. The broth is very flavorful as well as the meat. The only thing is the broth isn't that hot and gets cold fast which makes it not as good after awhile. I'd recommend trying to eat it fast before it gets cold.
author: Paolo S.

description:
The excitement was palpable:  My favorite Hawaiian cheap eats were coming to San Francisco.  

As an annual visitor to Oahu I'm well aware of Marukame Udon, the most well-priced satisfying meal to be found in Waikiki.  It's the place I recommended to my brother, when he mentioned how expensive he was finding Hawaii and it's the place I return to at least twice on each visit.  

Marugame Udon (same owners, slight difference in name) is a similarly satisfying experience even if the menu has been tweaked; new menu items seem more fusion-y than the originals, which I prefer.

The experience at the SF outpost stands on its own but I can't help but compare it to the Hawaii experience and somehow, it comes up a bit short (I consistently award Marukame Udon 5 stars).  A line snakes out the door (but moves along at a good clip, I waited about 20 minutes), the condiment adding area was messy and missing some vital containers, and squeezing into some of the seats is impossible to execute with elegance.  The place feels much closer to fast food than its Hawaiian counterpart.  

Still, I have no complaints for a place like this, where there's free parking, service until 10 p.m., and you can get an excellent and satisfying bowl of perfectly prepared, fresh noodles for well under $10.  I prefer their Hawaii outpost but that's not saying I don't like this one.  I do.  

Welcome to San Francisco, Marugame Udon.  I predict a glowing future.
author: Tracey A.

description:
I'm so excited for Marugame to finally reach the Bay Area!! There could be improvements, but everything is greats far! 

Beef Udon 5/5 - The udon was just like how it was in Hawaii, the broth was amazing!! I love how they have a toppings bar separate, so you could add as much as you like. I prefer more green onions/ tempura flakes, so that was definitely a plus! 

Salmon Musubi 3/5 - It was just okay. I never tried the one in Hawaii, so I can't compare the two, but there was barely any salmon, and way too much rice. It was neither great or horrible, just in between. 

Chicken Karaage 3/5 - It was good, but nothing like Hawaii. Honestly, I was really looking forward to this. The one in Hawaii was huge and juicy, and the tempura batter had so much flavor! This one was half the size, some parts of it were slightly burnt and dry, kind of disappointing. It was still delicious for chicken karaage, but nothing compared to the original. 

Service was great! For being opened for just a few months, it seems that they have everything under control. They keep the lines moving, the tables clean, and the customers happy! I can't wait to come back!
author: Michelle H.

description:
No where near as good as Oahu.

2 hour wait... would be worth it if it were Oahu quality

Got the "new tonkatsu" udon

For $20, I got only 2 thin tiny slices of tonkatsu.

Added an egg: the egg tasted like plastic. I'm hoping I don't get sick

I'd rather buy a plane ticket to Oahu to get udon than wait any amount of time to eat here again
author: Hazel J.

description:
I like that Marugame Udon is big and has a nice feeling and nice smell. All the workers we interacted with very nice, but not all of them were knowledgeable about their food.

As vegetarians, we were disappointed that they didn't have much to offer.

We got their one veg bowl, which is a cold dish, got a side of udon, some tempura sweet potato, and iniri (sushi rice in a tofu skin). We were able to add a little scallion and cilantro, but couldn't add their sauce because it was fishy, but they gave a sauce that wasn't.

The food was fine, but definitely not amazing, and we couldn't get any hot veg food. We have no reason to return, but would go back if we had to.
author: Veg V.

description:
UDONNNNNN. awesome place to grab some good udon and tempura. There's almost always a line but it actually moves a lot faster than you'd expect. I love the cafeteria line set up, everything looked really hot and fresh, and the food was delicious.

I know this store is still relatively new, so I'm hoping with all my heart that they keep up this superb quality and it doesn't get any worse with time.
Definitely swing by, there's almost always a wait, but I truly didn't mind it too much and the food is great at the end of the day!
author: Andrew T.

description: Don't understand the hype. We waited in line for almost an hour to eat here but it wasn't worth the hype. Seems cheap, curry udon $6.90 and you can add on whatever tempera you like, shrimp and squid tempera $1.90. Kiddo likes the plain udon for $4.50 -- I like that you can add your own unlimited green onions, cilantro and tempera bits but for the wait, I would not be coming back. Not worth the hype.
author: Cathrin P C.

description:
Waited about 20 minutes right at 6pm, the udon was great! I got the Nikutama Udon #2 hot with sweet potato tempura and the zucchini tempura. The beef was just a little too salty and I wish they gave more sauce/soup, but I'll definitely ask for more soup next time. 

There's a whole condiments bar where you can get sauces for tempura, green onions, cilantro, and fried tempura crisps. The regular tempura sauce tasted like soap unfortunately and the sweet tempura sauce is just tonkatsu sauce. The sweet tempura sauce goes well with the potato croquette but not really with the vegetables. 

I overall really enjoyed it but wouldn't wait more than 30 minutes for this.
author: Iris H.

description: Fresh made udon noodle shop similar to ones in japan. Grab a tray pick broth quantity of noodles and then its self serve tempura and condiments and find a seat.  DONT be THOSE people that skip the line to hold a table.  And DONT loiter at tables when your done.  Get in get out
author: Elle I.

description:
It's tasty, cheap, and convenient--what's not to love? I went with the Nikutama and 10/10 I would order again. I really enjoyed the bounce and texture of the noodles, the runniness of the soft-boiled egg (and how they crack it onto the bowl!), and the oniony, dashi-sweet flavor of the broth and sliced meat. 

The tempura was GREAT and arguably better than when I had Marukame in Honolulu. Crispy with just the right amount of grease! We ordered the chicken, veggie mix, squid, zucchini, and fish cake. Loved the zucchini and fish cake tempura especially!

The disappointments were the onigiri (expensive and terrible, never again) and overall operations outside of making and serving udon. None of the tempura sauces were filled and they ran out of the mini plates needed to fill up on tempura. Lots of time wasted on waiting. 

Overall, it's definitely worth checking out and dining at if you're in the area but certainly not worth waiting more than 15 minutes for!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Long lines, but they move FAST!  Nice, clean and fresh food.  Great for a quick / simple meal.
author: Hlb C.

description: I finally came here when the line was short so I tried this place out. The udon was already made and they just assembled it for you when you ordered while lining up, then the tempura was optional and paid separately by each piece. It was very fast. I had #2 on the menu and it was good but not a "wow-delicious" type of udon. The regular size is a bit small so I am glad I got some tempura to be filled up. Overall it is a good experience for a fast bowl of udon.
author: Lena H.

description:
A cafeteria style ramen place. The ramen is cooked well and the flavors are there. I like the soft boiled egg addition to the ramen, it gives it a nice creamy texture to it. Overall everything is good. The only knock to it is the policy of how they bring people in. Most people would think it's because the service is slow, it's actually pretty fast. What keeps you from going in is how slow other people eat. Also, sometimes they put more ramen than the soup, or is it the ramen sucks up the soup, I'm not too sure. If you like ramen, this is probably the place to be. If you like soup, then I would ask for more soup, I don't think it'll be bad manners to do so. 

Oh lastly, you can get other "goodies" with your ramen. They're fried items so keeping it in moderation is good. I don't think they serve alcohol but that's ok.

Have fun!
author: Will K.

description: No surprise, there was a long wait on the weekend. Came around 5:30 and waited around 45 minutes. I got the regular size hot Nikutama Udon and the calamari, shrimp, chicken tempura. There's a toppings bar to add to your udon. The udon was good but I don't know if I'd be willing to wait that long for it again. The tempura was just okay and not that warm since it's just sitting under the warmer. The wait outside in the cold isn't really worth it for me, but that's just my opinion.
author: Kim N.

description:
I went on a weekday around 2pm, and there was no line.
The following week I was in stonestown on a Monday at noon, and the line was out the door. 
Be strategic in what time you come if you don't want to wait.

My first experience with Marugame was in Hawaii. The Bay Area marugame was just as good !

The concept is a cafeteria style noodle place with fried items to pick from as well.
The prices are very reasonable, and the food is fresh. I love the open kitchen of marugame, you can see them making the noodles and can see the cleanliness and organization standard. 

I was really surprised when I went up to pay the cashier said "that's a very small piece of chicken, grab another one" 
It's very rare that you find a place that cares their customers get value for the price they are paying.
author: Roxanna G.

description:
Definitely not as good as the Hawaii one, and doesn't justify waiting even 30min in line for. I think a 10min wait is fine. 

However, still a good option for high quality decently priced udon. I just wished that I could add extra meat! (Which I don't think I can...?) correct me if wrong.

I also don't eat fried stuff, so couldn't enjoy any of their tempura selection :(
author: Cynthia X.

description: Update: this time I tried the Curry udon #3 and it's pretty good!! The curry broth is way less salty than the kake broth. I'm gonna have to try the beef udon again just to make sure lol
author: Marny N.

description: Delicious udon made right in front of you make waiting in line to get so worth it. Definitely will come back!
author: Rosa A.

description:
The name here is really confusing if you've been to the Hawaii location since its known as Marukame.  But upon checking out their two websites, they appear to be related or the same since the logo matches up.  Compared to the Hawaii location, I'd say this one does a great job. 

Be warned, this place has lines just like the Hawaii location!  Not nearly as long a wait (30min-1hour+ waits), but still long.  The line is split up as to not congest the walkways so be sure to find the actual end of it.

As for the food, it is fantastic.  Everything is fresh since the place is so busy.  I went with the Kama Age Udon just to try something different (be sure you're good at chopsticks if you go with this option).  For first-timers, I'd probably recommend one of the more ordinary udons like the Kake udon or the bukkake udon (haha, get it out of your system).  Or one of the udons with a topping you'd enjoy.  Be sure to pick up some tempura or onigiris too.  They're also very reasonably priced and very tasty.  

You won't have to worry too much about getting a table.  This place has that down to a science or something.  Since the line only moves so quick, seats seem to free up faster than people are coming in so it really works out well in that sense.  I came in with a party of 9 during peak hours and we were able to snag a table fairly easily.  

Overall, this place is a great chain that I'm happy has made its way to SF.  It's a great addition and there really aren't many options in the Bay for some good udon.  Compared to another similar udon shop near Civic Center, I'd say go to Marugame if you have the time.
author: Bryson L.

description:
I've decided to come here after hearing from many people that have tried it in the Honolulu location and loved it. I guess we got lucky right as we got there because they cut the line off a few people after us for a while ? Also my friend texted me that he was there a few hours earlier and they closed down for a bit because something wasn't working I guess ?
 I like that it was located at a mall because that means plenty of parking spaces! It's so hard to find parking in SF these days haha. We waited about 20 ish minutes before we got to the front so not too bad. I ended up getting the curry udon and my boyfriend got the nikutama udon! I liked his so much better than mine if I'm being honest. Mine wasn't ... bad but it was so salty! It made me drink so much water and get full fast haha. We also got a few fried sides and rice balls which were just decent. The noodles itself were superb! We liked how the employees worked in an assembly line order it was unique.
 There was a lot of seating so we didn't have to worry even though it was packed which is good! I noticed the first two tables I tried sitting at were super wobbly though :( almost made me spill my soup. 
 Prices seemed okay too! Pretty affordable :)
 Overall a good udon place with some pros and cons. Would definitely wanna try the Hawaii location one day !
author: Gabriella T.

description:
Hands down, the best udon I have EVER had! Worth the hype and totally worth the 40 minutes standing outside in 45 degree weather. The prices are unbeatable! Especially for San Francisco. I was literally in awe when i noticed that none of the bowls cost over $10. That's totally unheard of in SF. C'mon!

Anyway, I ordered the original one with beef (can't remember the number) and my boyfriend ordered the spicy chicken. Can't speak for his because it was too spicy for me but mine was DELICIOUS! The broth was SOOO flavorful and the noodles were great. Love how they make them fresh in the restaurant too. We also ordered a couple pieces of tempura: asparagus, chicken, shrimp, and a potato croquette. All of which were amazing and not excessively oily. We also ordered two onigiri, one crab and the other was a fish egg with some type of mayo. Both were amazing also. Overall, the food was epic. I wanted to go back the next day- that's how great I thought it was.
author: Dara S.

description:
My first time eating here and I can say that this place way way too over hyped. Got the tonkatsu regular. Tried the soup before digging into it... And it was just alright. Eh, everything was alright. Even hearing the employees saying "Oishi" and other words, they didn't even seemed enthusiastic. That alone made me think that the place was just over hyped. Then again I think they're tired of saying it. I didn't get any tempura or extra food items. Maybe next time when I have a bigger appetite, I'll try that. My next time will be when someone is treating me. I even won't bring my gf knowing she'll say that it's just average and over hyped.

Japanese restaurant inside the food court is way better and just about the same price!

2 stars because they're worth 2 stars.
author: Jonathan C.

description: The place was worth the hype! The line does get long, but moves pretty decently. The outside seating is nice, but there are birds so be cautious! Inside seating is nice, but can be hard to find a place to sit. The selection is nice and portions are quite filling. I got the large beef udon which was very rich in flavor. Also got a fish cake and zucchini tempura which was pretty good. The topping bar was limited but good. Highly recommend for good udon.
author: Monica D.

description:
A great udon restaurant.  Entertaining where you see how the udon is handmade and prepared.  You select the udon based on the soup stock and toppings.  They also have tempura but at the time we were there the fryer were down, and none were available.  

Loved the tonkatsu soup stock, among the other udon based soups.  A must try.  The musubi was not so good and rather plain and not worth the calories.  

The line may look long, but goes pretty fast.  Worth the wait.
author: Art L.

description:
New Udon Shop near SF State and Daly City...........
Hears Marugame Udon is also in Hawaii............
I decide to check it out during their soft opening. 

My buddy and I decide to try it out and get there at about 6 pm. We wait for about an hour and a half. Soft Opening.... Give them the benefit of the doubt. Fingers and hands aren't use to preparing the noodles , scooping the soup, menu isn't 120% in their heads. First thing I notice is the packs of flour from Japan to make the Udon. The noodles are flattened out and cut by a machine then are immersed in hot water for what seems to be 5 minutes. It is then put in a cold bath and portioned out by hand, waiting to be served. During the soft opening they only had a few items on the menu. I ordered the Bukkake. Udon + Broth. After placing my tray on the mat, the chef promptly put my noodles and I was on my way. 

Next Stop.

Tempura Heaven! I could get the typical, shrimp, potatoes, vegetables. Then it was all of the little triangular hand rolls filled with salmon, cod , imitation crab. I decided not to grab either because I'm trying to be healthier. I then went to the condiments bar and added some cilantro, green onions, spash of dashi, and tempura bits. It was easy to find a table as people just eat and go, its relatively quick besides the wait. I bit into my fresh noodles with some soup and I was satisfied. Udon was very fresh, way better than instant udon. The broth was like no other. Sweet and salty. I left with a smile on my face but my buddy was in disbelief we waited an hour and a half. I think its worth it. Its all about the experience. 

Notes:

Cafeteria Style
Grab Black Tray and small white tray for optional items
1. Pick Item from Menu (Small or Large)
2. Optional: Grab Tempura and or Croquettes and or hand rolls
3. Pay (Prices are relatively fair and cheap)
4. Condiments Bar (Green Onions, Cilantro, Tempura Bits, Dashi, Tempura Sauce, Utensils)
5. Find a table and Enjoy

Repeat once a month :)
author: Brian C.

description: Oh my gosh. SO GOOD. I've never had marugame udon in Hawaii so I can't compare but dang this place is yummy! My boyfriend and I came during soft opening, and the line was super long. We probably waited 45 mins to an hour. Not too bad. The way it works is you grab a tray, order your udon and actually wait till you get it. Then you can choose from a selection of tempura and musubi but it's extra cost. You might as well go all out though. And then when you reach the end, you pay. After that you can go to the station that has complimentary toppings to spice up your udon. I ordered the spicy chicken udon and it was so delicious and flavorful. I also got mentai mayo musubi and zucchini tempura. I loved every single bite of it. I definitely will be back to try more flavors! :)
author: Tiffany T.

description:
After months of seeing a bunch of my friends slowly try this place for the first time, I finally got the chance to check out the hype. The line looked long but it moved pretty quickly - we waited about 45 min in line. I decided to try the Nikutama Udon, which is basically the Beef Udon + a pouched egg. I also got a shrimp tempura, chicken tempura, and sweet potato tempura. First off, the shrimp and chicken tempura were definitely worth trying and I understand why it's rated as #1 and #2 tempuras in the restaurant. The sweet potato tempura wasn't that great for me. Now for the udon, the beef was flavored really well, and the udon noodles were cooked perfectly and tasted really fresh. I didn't care too much for the poached egg since they are pre-cooked so it was cold. The udon broth was really good, but sadly my soup was not hot at all. If anything it was only room temperature, and I was expecting a nice steaming bowl of udon. I'm not sure if it's because all the ingredients were cold to begin with, and mixed in with the hot soup cooled the soup down, or if the soup just wasn't that hot to begin with. Regardless, the temperature of the soup was really disappointing for me. That's pretty much the only complaint I had here, but everything else was amazing and I would definitely come back here again! 

Also, there's a station after you get your food where you can add as much green onions, ginger, and tempura flakes to your udon as you want!
author: Shannon H.

description: I love this place! The line may be long but the atmosphere and udon noodles is Nippon! That k you for opening! Open more locations so the lines won't be so long. I recommend the #4 cold with shrimp and asparagus tempura! So good!
author: Alexis M.

description:
After missing out in LA, I was kinda excited when I heard there was going to be one opening in NorCal. But of course the line was gonna be crazy, so I waited a few months before visiting. 

We ordered the #2 Nikutama Udon (hot) and #6 Spicy Chicken Udon. In addition, we picked up some tempura: fish cake and pumpkin. 

Nikutama Udon: I liked the texture of the udon, but wasn't chewy enough for me and thinner than I'd like. The sweet broth with beef and runny egg was pretty delicious. 

Spicy Chicken Udon: I'm not sure what happened, but this one was so spicy! I can take spice pretty well, but this just felt like they dumped all the chili powder they could find into my bowl. My friend couldn't eat this one so I ate a majority of it, leaving me with a hot and numb mouth :( (pretty sure it was also the reason my stomach didn't feel well either).

Sides: not bad, but definitely pricey for what it is. 

Overall, not super worth the hype. I'll be back with other friends probably though so they can try it (and choose a  not spicy chicken udon).
author: Fiona H.

description:
They make a pretty good bowl of noodles here. It's a good amount of food at a good price. I've tried the beef udon, curry udon, egg drop udon, and the mentai udon. All of which were all pretty good, but sometimes the beef can be a little fatty. My favorite is the curry udon and mentai udon with the cod roe. Curry udon can be a little salty at times,  which can be fixed if you eat it with the side tempura. The squid tempura and the shrimp tempura are my favorites to get with the udon. 

Only reason for the 3 stars is because the place isn't really ADA accessible. Brought my brother here who was recovering from Knee surgery and had a difficult time of waiting in line and getting to a table. The line leads into the entrance and the entrance is also the exit, so there is always a crowd there. Also once you get through the doors you have to maneuver your way around since the line feeds right into the ordering line. 

I hear the best time to go, if you want to avoid the line, is around 3-5pm. Also weekends are typically busy all day.
author: Lily S.

description:
To be perfectly honest, I am a very picky eater (even if I eat almost everything). I know what I like, and I definitely can tell you that I enjoy Marugame Udon.

It was awesome to see a new restaurant at Stonestown since I usually do not stop by the mall often to eat in San Francisco. Decided to wait in a decently long line (30 minutes) for my very first time eating at Marugame. Eventually we get to the front and I see the choices on the menu. I decided to go with the Nikutama Udon (cold) since I particularly like my udon to be refreshing, and boy was it refreshing! The soft boiled egg and beef look so delicious the moment they graced the bowl. Garnished with cilantro, green onions, ginger, and tempura bits, it was beautiful.

Something clicked in my brain and I was off to the races. I was on a mission to try every single menu item, tempura, onigiri, etc. Within the first 7 days of visiting the restaurant, I had already eaten there 11 times and consumed the entire menu at least once. Last week I went a full 7 of 7 days eating lunch at Marugame. That week I locked on my usual order, Bukkake Udon (cold), which I ate every single day. I could not get sick of the refreshing feeling eating this dish, and the price was very affordable.

In a way I felt like I started working for Marugame since my days were spent answer questions about menu items to patrons either waiting in line, or on my Instagram when I still posted a lot about it. I enjoy this place so much I am guilty of eating there twice in one day, multiple times. As of currently I have chosen to dine at Marugame 23 times and I plan to still keep bringing my business there!

Personal Favorites:
Nikutama Udon (cold)
Bukkake Udon (cold)
Curry Udon with soft boiled egg

Potato Croquette
Chicken Tempura (when it comes out fresh it is so amazing)
Inari
Kombu (kelp) Onigiri
Mentai (cod roe) Mayo Onigiri
Ume (salted plum) Onigiri
author: Josh M.

description:
Ive been to the one in Oahu a few times during my visit to the island.  When I heard that one opened up near where I worked I had to go as soon as I can.  The noodles are made by hand just like the one on Oahu.  The noodles are perfect.  The broth is tasty.  The sides are good.  The only down fall is the price of the sides.  Quite pricy for just one item.  Since its a treat them it's okay.  I wouldn't pay those prices everyday.  

Over all its good.  I would go back every so often as I can't fly to Oahu on a whim.
author: Guest U.

description:
I am here to encourage those who are standing in the long, dreadful line that yes, the wait is sooooo worth it.

Finally got to try out this spot as I am a HUGE fan of the famous Marukame in Oahu. I love it so much that I dragged my boyfriend there for lunch 3 days in a row while we were on the island. It was almost immediately after we came back and I was still dreaming of their luscious udon that I saw they were opening one in my area. It's almost like my prayers were answered or something???

I came on a Monday night around 6pm and waited about 15-20 minutes. Not bad at all compared to how long I've heard others wait. 

- Cafeteria style
- Pick up a tray and a smaller one for your tempura picks
- Order your udon (highly recommend the Nikutama, Curry or Spicy Chicken)
- Pick up your udon and go down the line of tempura heaven. Snag all your stomach desires
- Pay at the register
- Head over to the toppings bar to finish it off
- Grab an open seat. Or scram for seating if people are saving seats when they're not suppose to (sorry, I'm judging you)

Totally affordable so won't break your wallet and amazingly delicious so will rock your taste buds. Go go go!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Not bad, definitely a long wait but the line moves fairly quickly... So don't go unless you're free for the next hour or so. Everything is made to order, and you get to choose your side of tempuras/ onigiris. A cheap meal depending on what you choose to add! 

Must say I was pretty disappointed with my egg for the Nikutama udon. It was overcooked and did not have any runny consistency at all. Which was the whole reason I ordered it. However the beef flavoring was delicious! Similar to udon in Japan and unlike others in the city. Worth trying! 

Not to mention my friend chose the fish cake tempura and after biting into it, she could see the flour from the undercooked tempura batter :/ 

Overall ok, would only go back if the line was short.
author: Kristen J.

description:
The food is super tasty, but the experience leaves something to be desired.

There is no reason why people should be waiting in line, outside - and sometimes in the cold and rain - for 30+ minutes just to order.  The service inside is super fast, and the tempura is self-serve.....so they clearly just need to come up with a better ordering system.  One idea to improve efficiency would be to have people order on iPads and then pick up by number when their order is ready.  They should also have an option to order ahead online and pick up to go (they are on Postmates for delivery), rather than having to STILL wait in the long line just to turn around and walk back out.  I just think something has to give...

The food is really good though.  Not exactly light or healthy, but a good treat now and then.

The tempura is all perfectly fried and never seems to have been sitting out too long.  I also like the not-sweet dipping sauce that they offer.  

Most of the udons that I've tried are also really delicious.  I wasn't a fan of the spicy chicken udon (pretty bland) and was mixed on the curry udon (a little too thick), but I've very much enjoyed the bukkake udon (cold), the edamame salsa udon (cold), and the nikutama udon (hot).  My favorite by far is the hot nikutama, as it's really more like noodles in a light sauce than it is an actual soup, and the thin sort of shredded beef that they top it with is really yummy (never fatty or grisly.

If they'd just make it easier / faster to eat here, I'd be a more regular customer...
author: Tay H.

description:
This reminds me of the Hanamaru Udon in Japan with it's cafeteria/assembly line style for the udon and then your choice of tempura and onigiri. 

Parking is fine, it's in the large parking lot of the mall but the line! I read reviews about the wait and that coming after 8PM would be a 20-30 minute wait. Well my boyfriend was hungry and couldn't wait so we got there at 7:30PM and it was pretty chilly weekend so we thought no one would be waiting. We were at the end of the first line and we had to move from the first line to the second line out in the middle of the courtyard area. I think we waited 40 minutes which is lots better than an 1+ hours. 

There's 8 different menu items but 3 of them were the base of the other 6. We ordered the Nikutama udon (regular), beef udon (large), and kake udon (regular). The lady preparing the noodles could not remember people's orders and would have to ask the customers 1-3 times in order to repeat the order to next guy doing the broth and toppings. Seemed kinda inefficient. The guy doing the broth and toppings kinda made a mess spilling broth and meat out. Also when he cracked the egg he also cracked the yolk which peeved the lady in front of me probably for picture reasons. The atmosphere also kinda reminded me of the early days of 85 degree bakery when they shouted "FRESH BREAD!" Here they something about fresh tempura and noodles.

The udon was very good and you can definitely tell the difference between fresh noodles and other places. The stewed beef is sweet and the broth was very flavorful. We got some fried goodies after such as croquette (which was plain potato not curry), fish stick, and squid. The fish stick and squid had really salty areas on it but I just dipped it into the tempura sauce and it was okay. 

Would keep coming back when I'm in the area and the line isn't really long.
author: Avita S.

description:
This is my new go-to for udon cravings! Having eaten at the Marukame Udon (I'm pretty sure they are related) in Honolulu, I was happy to find the same familiar items available. Even after traveling back to Japan a few times since leaving it permanently in 2000, the udon quality is similar to the one I found in the popular places in Tokyo or Osaka. The cafeteria-style layout, varied selections of toppings (note: lots of fried items), and even side items like onigiri were also available. I grew up to eating mayonnaise-slathered onigiri filling and when I bit into one from here, my tastebuds were met with sad dryness. The tuna flavor was there, but texture was lacking any moisture. (Minus 1 star)

This place is still relatively new and being that it's adjacent to SFSU, you bet there's gonna be a line during peak lunch and dinner times. However, the line moves relatively quickly (think 30 min from very back to entrance), as the no frills cafeteria-style dining usually rotates tables every 15 min. 

Highly recommended!
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
I was a bit irritated at first by the line because it's was dinner time and I was getting hangry but it wasn't bad at all. We waited approximately 30 minutes at around 6:30 PM. 

The process is pretty efficient:
1. Pick your udon
2. Pick your tempura/musubi
3. Pay
4. Pick your toppings
5. Find a table
6. Take your pictures for Instagram
7. Eat
Optional 8: Complain that you're too full and you should not have gotten so much food. 

I got the Mentai Kamatama Udon and my friend got the Nikutama Udon. Both were delicious. The tempuras were lightly battered, soft and crunchy at the same time.
author: Anny T.

description:
Sooo I was very excited when this opened since we don't have one in San Francisco and I always miss Murakame in Hawaii.

Came during soft opening w/ limited menu items. The Bukake is always a crowd pleaser but they give so little broth that it's completely gone by the time you add the tempura flakes and find a seat. What's disappointing is the lack of soft boiled egg. The masubis barely have any filling or meat, 95% rice. 

Line moves incredible sloooooooow. Not enough indoor seating. Water is self serve but cups are so darned small you end up getting seconds and thirds and fourths to the point where you might as well stand next to the spigot all night. 

Prices are reflective of Bay Area prices.
author: Julie L.

description:
This is more of a 3.5

This place is fast casual, cafeteria style. The menu is straight forward. You pick up a tray, order your udon dish and size, and you can pick out tempura. Pleasantly surprised at how good the tempura was as it is just sitting under heat lamps. Turn around is really fast though, so I guess the tempura is almost always fresh. 

IMO it's mostly hype. There are other spots in SF that make fresh udon just as freaking perfectly cooked and without the insane line. Marugame Udon IS cheaper than most places, so if you're being cheap then stand your ass in the cold ass line. If you're waiting more than 20 minutes for this, you're a fool. I'm not riding their Hawaii-hype-dick, I still think Marugame Monzo in LA is best, and if you're still standing in line at Marugame reading this and it's been over 20 minutes,YOU ARE A FOOL.
author: Susy C.

description: This is my favorite Udon place. I tried this place in Hawaii and accidentally found this in south San Francisco. Hand made iron noodle is absolutely delicious and the broth is awesome. It is a little bit more expensive than the one in Hawaii but definitely worthy
author: Andy P.

description: If you're looking for an udon restaurant in the bay, this place is a must try! I got the nikutama udon (#8) which has sweet beef and an egg. The beef is one of the reasons why I like this place because it's adds a nice twist of flavor. Udon is super thick and delicious. Would come back, even with the super long line :/
author: Demi N.

description:
I have never had udon before and was expecting something similar to ramen, which made the meal very disappointing.

First of all, the line outside was insane. We went on a Sunday afternoon, and the line was broken into two different lines: one a bit far away to avoid the pedestrian walkway to the mall and one right outside the restaurant. It took about an hour, so prepare for that if you go at the same time.

When you get in, it's basically an assembly line where you order each part of the meal. I got the spicy chicken udon with a side of inari. I love inari, so I really enjoyed that, but I did not enjoy the udon. The fishy taste of the broth was a big turn off for me; I was expecting broth similar to ramen. So, if you are a fan of fishy broth, you may like this place. The chicken also didn't taste that great. The noodles, however, were very well done.

Also, the place was pretty dirty. I think they could benefit from having people wipe down the tables periodically, especially if they are expecting large crowds on weekends.

If you're a fan of fishy broth (udon), you'll probably enjoy this place - just be ready to wait if you go on a weekend!
author: Remy B.

description: Delicious, so many options and great price! Long wait time but worth it for the udon bar.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
This place is soooooo good. It has a long wait but moves decently fast. I came here twice within the same month! That's how much I like this place 

I would recommend coming here on a week night instead of the weekends cause of the long lines.

This is an assembly style restaurant where you pick whatever udon and protein you want. Halfway through, you can also pick out fried tempuras, chicken, squid, and etc. I especially like the chicken and squid :) I also love that they have self serving condiments and sauces after you pay. It makes such a big difference! 

Overall, highly recommend! Best udon place I've had in the Bay Area :)
author: Karen K.

description:
At Marugame Udon, the style for the Japanese noodles called Udon is a semi fast food or a cafeteria/casino like at the Stonetown mall.

First- pick your size (regular or large) and hot/ cold udon. 
Second- pick the type of udon- chicken, beef, edamame salsa, etc etc Third- wait for your udon being assemble in front of you. 

Down the line is the self serve various tempura- chicken, shrimp, fish cake, squid, various veges, zucchini, sweet potato, and various musubi -salmon, crab, etc etc.  You will pick what you like.  

Drink, sauces, complimentary toppings with green onion, cilantro, tempura batter crunchies, dashi, ginger at other areas. I like the station which is also equipped with disposable spoons, chopsticks, napkins, bags.

I got the large hot  Nikutama udon (beef + egg).  Disappointing udon bowl for me!   It's not worth the money, the line, and the time.  Meh. 

1.  The line is super long and the wait is purely painful.  45 min to get my bowl of udon is mad.  The service is inconsistent as the line gets stalled and not moving at a steady rate.  

2.  The soup is NOT HOT and the broth is too salty, sweet, greasy!  It's very disappointing to eat oily soup at lukewarm temperature.  

3.  The tempura is good but again, not hot.  I don't like to eat anything deep fried COLD!

4.  The udon noddles are fresh but seem to be over cooked and not chewy as advertised.  

5.  Huge disappointment with the crab and salmon musubi as they are just 99.9% rice!   If you don't like eating  rice balls like me, then skip musubi.  

6.  The sitting area is not comfortable.  Lots of people walking around and bumping into you.  It's annoying to share a table with strangers who were being inconsiderate with their loud conversation.  

One star is for the patient crowd and fun ambiance.  And the second star is for friendly and attentive staff. 

I'm unsure why so many people are willing to wait in such a long line here.  I don't understand the rave about this udon place.  I won't come back.    My bowl of udon was not worth the hype.
author: Ivory B.

description:
I was really looking forward to try this since the lines were always super long. Must mean the food is good right? Nope, just overhyped.

My friend and I came 15 minutes before they opened on a Saturday morning and there was already a line to wait in line. Not really sure when people start coming to line up. 

Once you're inside, you can see the udon and tempura being cooked as you're going through the line. You tell the workers what you want and they scoop it in a bowl for you. Honestly, the line is long just because of this process, not because the place is full. I don't really understand why it takes so long either. They have a bunch of people in the background cooking. Someone is sorting the udon into piles and the meats and broth are already prepared too. The person "making" the udon just grabs a pile of pre-measured udon noodles and gives you a scoop of broth and beef and puts an egg. Everything is sort of prepared and cooked already by all the other workers and the person handling the orders dumps it all together in a bowl. But this is where the hold up is. 

I ended up ordering the hot Nikutama Udon. The udon noodles were smooth with a good chewiness. The beef was really good and sweet. The egg was super cold which was disappointing and I wish the broth was warmer too.  

Definitely not worth the hype for a cold egg and broth.
author: Becky H.

description:
Stepping inside the eatery reminded me of my trip to Japan. The sights, smells, architecture, and cleanliness made me feel like I experienced a sliver of Japan in the large city of San Francisco. 

While the two hour wait was undesirable, the food was delicious. I hope the lines die down more after the opening because that was the longest I've ever waited in line for food. 

The prices are reasonable for the quality of food they serve. Luckily unlike other trendy eateries they don't rack up the prices to $10+ for a dish. Everything is under $10 and ranges from $1.50 - $8.00. 

I'm looking forward to going back but maybe waiting until the hype dies down so I don't have to wait in line for two hours again.
author: Lianna N.

description:
Delicious food, lots of fried goodies, onigiri, noodles/ramen. 

Only con is that you gotta wait a while if it's during peak hours. 

I recommend the miku ramen. You get beef and an egg with your noodles. 

Some fried goodies would be the tempura, Katsu, and the salmon onigiri. 

They have a "bar" to add toppings to your dishes. 

The workers are into their job. Very straight forward, quick, and moves fast in the line.
author: Elijah B.

description:
When reviewing Marugame in Stonestown, there is the dilemma of reviewing it on its own merits or to compare it to its older brother store Maukame in Waikiki.  

On its own, Marugame is a welcome addition to the San Francisco Bay Area as there are few udon restaurants around here.  The restaurant is clean, somewhat efficient, and the food is tasty.  I like the toppings bar where we can add our own green onion and tempura flakes.  Crowd control was a bit disorganized but is better as the initial hype has died down.  Hopefully, this will spark an udon craze around here to compare with the recent popularity of ramen and poke.

Comparing this place to udon restaurants in Southern California, Hawaii,  and Marukame in Waikiki is where Marugame falls short.  The lines tend to move twice as fast at the Waikiki location than at Stonestown.  

What is a continual irritant is that employees at Stonestown tend to yell a few words in Japanese (oishi) every now and then in an attempt to make things feel authentic but it looks and sounds really forced and contrived, as if they were instructed to do yell in Japanese by their management.   There is one particular employee who takes the yelling to a ridiculous extreme and he seems to be more focused on yelling more than at making udon. 

In contrast, the employees at Waikiki are just busy moving and working and processing things along twice as fast as Stonestown without the obligatory shouting in Japanese.  Also, while the broth in Stonestown in good, the broth in Waikiki is magical and more flavorful.  Everyone I've talked with who has been to both Waikiki and Stonestown locations has said the same thing.  Also, most udon establishments offer a greater variety of soups and toppings (sliced braised tofu, for example) so this is another area where Marugame falls short.  I would be much happier with this place if they cut out the yelling in Japanese and focus more on moving the lines.  

I'm not sure if the managers of Stonestown have ever been to Waikiki but I think it would be an eye-opener for them to see how much faster, more efficient, and tastier it can be.  The Waikiki store is like a well oiled machine and I estimate that the line moves about 20% faster than at Stonestown.  If it were like Waikiki, I would go to Stonestown several times a week but I've only been to Stonestown's a couple of times since soft opening.  If I had to grade Marugame based on the high level of the Waikiki store, this is 3 stars.  On its own, its 4 stars. 

Marukame in Waikiki shows up regularly in Top 100 lists.  This one has the potential to do so if they focus less on their yelling semi-random words in Japanese and more on their udon.  The staff should not be the ones yelling "oishi!".  It should be the patrons.
author: Re-pley Z.

description:
After a failed attempt to dine here between their soft opening and their grand opening we were able to finally dine here. Neither one of us has been to the Hawaii location. We arrived about 25 minutes before opening and was able to snag a place waiting by the first waiting area. There is a second area because they don't want the customers blocking the road. 

Basically an assembly line. They make the noodles fresh and the soup base is shipped over. You tell them the number order you want and the size. Then you proceed to the tempura and musubi area. We got some tempura because our udon was a bit bare. We read that the musubis were not worth it so we skipped it. You pay and proceed to the toppings area which comprises of crispy flakes, green onions, and cilantro. You can put as much as you want. 

The dining area is very minimalist but theres plenty of tables and even tables outside. 

I ordered #10 and my husband ordered #2. My soup was overly salty and thick. It felt like those fake egg drop soups you get at a fast food place. My noodles were really good and tasted fresh but they are! Because you see them being made in front of your eyes! 

We most likely won't be coming back. The udon was not amazing especially when the soup is not made fresh. We actually went to a ramen place the other day and spent the same amount of money for all fresh ingredients. 

Plenty of parking.
author: Sarah C.

description: Great concept. Good for quick and affordable food. I actually wouldn't go out of my way to come back but if I'm in the area I would. You can see the machines at work for the noodles and real people in front of you assisting with everything else. Lots of staff which makes the whole purchase quick and easy. Grab a tray, pick a bowl and grab some sides at the end. Cups are also available toward the register for soda. I'm sure this is perfect for people in the area for lunch. I definitely recommend to try once though!
author: Guisela L.

description:
well..... I know Marugame Udon is delicious....because I am Japanese.

but not here...
Marugame Udon is soft and chewy.
not chewy here,,,,
Tthe sauce of Kamatama Udon is too salty...

it is so sad,,,, I want to have real Marugame Udon...
author: Iguanatte S.

description:
To be fair, the udon here was really really really good. I got the spicy chicken udon which comes with udon, shredded chicken breast and some chili flakes. They have a huge topping bar which comes with stuff like ginger puree, shoyu, tempure sause, cilantro, green onion, chili powder, etc. You can really make your broth into so many things depending on your taste, and it's what I really like about this place. 

They also have plenty of types of tempura you can get, along with some musubis. I would say on average a piece of tempura is like $1.75, depending on the type you get. I would also say that on average you don't need the extras in your life. I, like a fool, got spicy chicken udon (large) and two pieces of tempura and I was wayyyy too full. The udon will be enough to satisfy you tbh. If you're really craving tempura though then I'd recommend to perhaps get one of the cheaper bowls of udon, and small.

I really don't think the wait is worth it, though. You have to *stand in line* for 40-45 minutes to order your food in a line, sort of like Chipotle style. They have no option to order ahead or online. It's just like not very convenient, and while I enjoyed the udon, I don't think I'd come here and wait again for it unless it was a special occasion. It's a little bit extra to do so and also a little bit ridiculous tbh.
author: Brian W.

description: I've honestly never heard of this place before and wondered why there was such a long line. One day the line was a bit shorter than I've seen it before, so we went. Ordered the #2 and some sides. Favorite sides were the shrimp tempura and potato croquette. Best. Don't get the mixed veggie tempura. That was basically just fried onions. Once you get all your food, you check out and then there's a complimentary topping bar that includes green onions, cilantro, tempura bits, katsu sauce and more. Overall this place is great and filling. Food is great and the staff is kind. I just want the line to die down already, so that it doesn't take as long to get food.
author: Julie L.

description:
Came by the other day for their soft opening and the wait was about an hour long. They don't have a formal ticketing waitlist system so that means physically standing outside in the cold San Francisco weather for an hour. 

This is a chipotle style udon restaurant with a very basic menu. I decided to go for the spicy chicken udon and it did not disappoint. I also added the vegetable tempura which was so good! The vegetable tempura was basically potatoes and onions shredded into what looks lie a pile of fries, but they were amazing! Highly recommend.

They did not have the full menu available at the time but I am excited to return once they do.
author: Lushi Z.

description:
Definitely a bit overhyped, but still worth eating there since the next closest one is in LA haha.

I don't think you can go wrong with any of the soup bases, but I would recommend getting their nikutama or kake based soups. A lot of their soups do incorporate kake bases and they'll add in lemon juice, and other ingredients, so similar taste across the board. The curry and spicy udon though are different bases, so if you want something different go for those ones. 

The beef make the udon come together, and it's the Japanese sweet beef. I love it so much I could eat it all day. 

The udon noodles are made in house and freshly made, which I think is enough to try it out once. For the price you're paying I think it's more than worth it. Honestly I feel like they might even be losing some money selling their udon for so cheap! 

Another cool thing about this place are the side dishes. You have a variety of tempura (fish cake, shrimp, chicken, mushroom, spam muisibi, salmon muisibi). They're about $1.50-$3.00 a piece. Those aren't made as fresh as they sit under a heat lamp, but I think the shrimp tempura pairs greatly with their nikutama udon. 

TL;DR a bit overhyped but well worth trying! I don't think you'll be disappointed if you don't expect too much out of it. Overall great experience and fairly quick service. Just really crowded because there's only 2 in California, and the next one is in LA.
author: Nikko A.

description:
I believe they open at 11 am and I got here at around 11:30 am on Friday January 19, 2018. There was a zig zag line of three rows outside. There was an employee outside handing out mini menus to everyone in line, but since I was eating by myself, I guess I blended in with the other groups that I didn't receive a menu. A lady behind me in line kindly gave me her menu though. 
I got inside and picked up a tray at 11:55 am, so the wait was about 25 minutes. I ordered #5 Regular hot beef udon (Regular is $7.90 and large is $8.90), with one sweet potato tempura and a coke soda. It was about $11 something. The price was pretty good for good quality food. The employee outside was calling it "high quality cafeteria food". 
After you grab your tray and a plate (if you plan on getting tempura or extras), an employee takes your order for what choice of udon noodles you want. After you get your bowl of udon, you have a choice of choosing your own tempura (around $1.50-$2 ea) and onigiri ($1-$1.60 ea). You then pay for your meal, and then to your left, there is a sauce bar with utensils and the soda machine. 
I was kinda nervous I wouldn't find a seat. Since I'm sitting by myself, I didn't want to take a table with four seats. But after I got my tempura sauce and utensils, someone left at a table for two so I quickly sat down there because I was so hungry. The tables were kinda close together, so I had to kinda squeeze by another table of two to sit down. 
Everything was very delicious and tasted fresh. The sweet potato tempura was a huge circle so I started cutting it with my fork and chopsticks. I guess it looked like I was having difficulty, that I believe it was the manager kindly handed me a knife. After I left, there was still a zig zag line of three rows (see pic). I think I will be back when the line of people slowly dies down (when there is no more lines) because it felt a bit too crowded for me. But I recommend their food! I'll be back to try the onigiri. 
If you are trying to avoid the wait, it's better to go early and on a weekday. I went to Stonestown the next day on Saturday, and I saw they had one full zig zag line of three rows and another full zig zag line of three rows in the back (near benches).
author: Kristin H.

description:
Came here at about 6pm, and the line was just getting long. So make sure you time it well because the line can get really long. The fast food vibe of getting a tray might not be appealing to everyone, but trust me the food is worth it. 

Ordered the Nikutama Udon and the Curry Udon, both regular sizes because we wanted to try the other stuff. The egg drop chicken udon looked interesting and I kinda wanted to try that too. After getting the udon, we proceeded to pick up a potato croquette, fishcake tempura, sweet potato tempura, and shrimp tempura. Everything looked so good, i should have picked up a musubi too. 

The udon was amazing, it was cooked perfectly and it was bouncey. It was basically the al dente of udon. I loved the soft boiled egg and the beef. I think the soup could be a little hotter. The curry udon was super flavorful, kind of the the Japanese curry but in soup form. It also came with beef. All the tempura were crispy but it could be warmer.
author: Jeffrey T.

description: The service is good. The line is always out the door but moves rather quickly. This place is very clean and I like to watch how they prepare the udon while waiting to order my food. The udon is very good. My favorite ones are Kama-age Udon and Beef Udon. The fried foods, tempura and mushubi are ok, not too impressed. I like the side foods from marukame in Honolulu more.
author: Julie L.

description:
Another day, another hype restaurant arrives in the bay! Sorry small mom and pop businesses, but it looks like the trend of famous places opening up is in full drive. 

Marugame is the same Marugame from LA and the same Marukame from Hawaii. They all taste the same, have similar food selection, and long lines. 

As for udon, I've heard it tastes much like the ones in Japan for what that is worth. If you like udon than you'll probably like Marugame. The noodles are well cooked, and the broth is tasty and flavorful. 

Their tempura selection is good too but man what I really miss is the spam musubi like the one they have in hawaii. 

Wait is going to be long at certain times. That is the biggest downside to this place.
author: Christopher L.

description:
Fast-food style udon! The chain offers a range of cold/hot udon options and an appetizer bar filled with tempura and musubis. Once you order from the menu, the udon is prepared and served right in front of you. You also get the option to customize your order by requesting add-ons and choosing different appetizers as you move down the line. After you pay, you arrive at the unlimited self-serve toppings bar where you get to decorate and fill your udon with different sauces and toppings like tempura flakes, onions, and cilantro. 

My boyfriend and I went on a Saturday morning (before it even opened!) and waited in line for about 20 minutes. 

We ordered: 
1. Nikutama Udon (MUST GET!) 
2. Spicy Chicken Udon (Okay.)
3. Potato Croquette  (MUST GET!)
4. Tuna Mayo Musubi (WASTE OF MONEY!)
5. Salmon Flake Musubi (WASTE OF MONEY!)

Udon was slightly cold and more on the saltier side. With that said, I still enjoyed the Nikutama Udon because of the noodles and the broth flavor. The Spicy Chicken Udon is spicy and overpowers the taste of the actual broth; it's enjoyable for a few bites then it gets overwhelming. One thing I really want to highlight is that the musubis are a WASTE OF MONEY! It is 98% rice and one bite of tuna/salmon. Disappointing! 

Tips:
- LONG WAITS!! Go before opening or odd hours.
- Take advantage of the self-serve toppings bar! Tempura flakes are DELICIOUS in udon. 
- Make sure your add-ons are actually added on. I added an egg in my Spicy Chicken Udon and didn't get one, so I had to go back to the register and request another one.

TL;DR:
Great concept
Good service
Moderately priced udon
LONG wait

Overall, I would go back again if I'm around the area, but I don't think it's worth the wait. The location in Hawaii is so much better!
author: Michelle L.

description: You can usually tell how great a restaurant is by their line and this one is always packed to the Olive Garden next door. Awesome food, be sure to season your udon with fried onions and green onions.
author: Usman P.

description:
Waited in line for 35 mins. When we got in, they said there is no tempura serving for today. The employees should let the people know when they line up instead found it out by yourself after the 35 mins wait.

Broth is very very very salty ....
author: Steve Y.

description:
I'm from Hawaii and I've tried MaruKame Udon in Waikiki. The first time I tried MaruKame Udon in Waikiki, it was clearly love at first sight - fresh udon, plethora of crispy, fried goodness (aka: tempura), and the atmosphere was organized chaos (so many people, but somehow the engineering of the seating was perfect - no one was without a seat, even though it was buzzing).
