The first time I tried MaruGame Udon in Stonestown, it wasn't exactly love at first sight. Maybe it was because I came during the soft opening and (maybe?) they were still getting in the groove of their systems? Probably. Why it wasn't love at first sight? The udon broth tasted salty as compared to the more complex flavors of what I've grown to love from their MargKame Udon counterpart. The line was crazy (Waikiki's MaruKame Udon moved WAYYYY faster)... but I guess it was expected since it was open for nearly only a month and everyone was still flocking to this new place. Also, I purchased a soft drink, but they were out of ice (a bummer for me because I like to counter the hot soup with a super cold drink). Nevertheless, my first visit was GOOD - very reasonable prices for SF, crispy tempura, and LOTS of free add-ons (including parsley). 

However, I recently went back for a THIRD time... and I was surprisingly pleased at the improvements since my first initial (and second) visit. 
1) Line moved way faster. Less than 15 minutes in line. 
2) The broth of the Kake was less salty and more dynamic in taste. 
3) The curry udon was amazing and had a lot of beef pieces in the curry broth. 
4) Tempura and musubi bar was plentiful and loaded with all the choices - nothing missing.
5) No problems with no ice for fountain drinks. :) 
6) **Only issue was that they ran out of regular (not extra sweet) tempura sauce AND baskets of tempura flakes were all out. Both were not refilled for maybe 10 minutes... but that was ok, since the food was perfect without either. 

Overall, I will definitely be back. For the price and quality you receive... you cannot go wrong.
author: Enne Mae G.

description: Very simple but delicious and fresh. My kids ate all their udon. This places is super kids friendly and everyone is very polite. This is my 6th time eating udon here. We will definitely come back again. I don't mind the long wait.
author: Mila N.

description: We've been watching the line at this place for awhile. And finally decided to give a try! The wait was actually shorter than I expected for Monday night. We waited about 20 minutes or so. The greeter was very friendly. The place looks clean and organized. The texture of the udon is good however both broth were on the salty side! The tempura taste too doughy!
author: Jaylene L.

description: Part of Stonestown mall. Came here around ~5:15pm on a Saturday and waited about an hour in line (we considered giving up and going to Olive Garden or Chipotle many times). I got #2 (beef udon with egg) and sweet potato tempura, and it was just okay... The soup was okay... The noodles were okay... Egg was a great add... sweet potato tempura was yum. The prices are great, but I don't think I'll wait 1hr+ again for udon. Tables inside are first come first serve.
author: Annie S.

description: Talked to a bunch of people that said this place was good. So I decided to give it a try today. I got to this location around 11:20 am. There was a short line. I ordered the "new" tongkatsu because I am a ramen fan. I'm expecting the big thick noodles and I asked for the spicy version. I notice a scoop of ground pork and chashu come with my order. Everyone gets their own serving tray so you can take your order down to the register. Along the way to the register you can pick up different kinds of tempuras, you have your choice of veggie ones and shrimp ones. Then there is an option to pick up some different rice balls if you want, I did not get one of those. I did pick up a shrimp tempura, sweet potato tempura and the tempura that looks like a blossom which is just essential an onion blossom. My tongkatsu was tasty but I just can't get passed the thick noodles, I had asked for spicy which it was not. Someone else in my party ordered the same thing that I did and their's wasn't spicy either. Now the concerning part is all the tempura was cold. Now I believe this place opened at 11 so this was not a concern for me. I'm used to my tempura being hot. I have to honestly say that if I could give this a 3.5 star rating then that's what I want for my review but since it's a place that I probably won't visit again then it's going to have to be where it's at for me.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Don't be put off by the long line! It actually moves pretty quick!

It's a small price to pay for fresh udon. It's fun to see them make it right in front of you! I recommend getting the regular size. My friend said that the large size had the same amount of noodles - just more soup. That being said, I thought my regular size had a very small noodles-to-broth ratio, so I might have liked more soup... hm...

Although the base price is incredible, you'll bring it up with the buffet of choose-your-own tempura! They ran out of tempura veggies on the day I was there :( But everything was so good, I'm definitely going back to try some! I was surprised that the tempura fishcake is a Korean-style fishcake instead of the traditional kamaboko or even naruto. Still tasty though!

People had complained that the "musubi" (onigiri) was lacking in meat. The salmon was definitely mostly rice, but the crab salad was pretty good and the inari, I think, was worth it! At the last toppings bar, you can put as much green onion, cilantro, and tempura flakes as you want! Just beware the tempura sauce vs the "sweet tempura sauce." I wanted to try both. The sweet tempura sauce is literally just tonkatsu sauce.

Either way, super tasty and good price! I will be coming back!
author: Carrie M.

description:
Udon't want to miss out on this!
If you like udon and self serve spots, Marugame is the place for you. 

My first time trying out Marugame was in LA and I loved it, so I was excited to try it out again in SF. My friends and I came here for lunch during their grand opening and we only waited in line for about 30 minutes until we got our food.

The staff is very friendly, greeting you from start to finish of your experience at the restaurant. It was interesting to see the staff members make the food as you grabbed your trays and self served your add ons. I got a regular Bukkake Udon with a shrimp tempura and a salmon flake musubi for about $9. I liked how the noodles were soft and the soup wasn't too salty. There is also a separate self serve station where you can add on toppings like green onions, cilantro, and different sauces for your udon too.

The overall ambiance and experience was great, I would definitely be come here again if I'm in the SF area.
author: Tracy C.

description: OMG! Noodles are one of our favorite foods and we have pretty high standards. Marugame Udon usually has long lines at dinner and lunch times, but most other hours are pretty short. Lines although go pretty quick. Service is really nice especially for a restaurant that isn't table service. Prices are reasonable and lower than expected and portions are filling. We would recommend a large bowl over a regular bowl because it's basically double the noodles for $1 more. We have gone multiple times and won't stop coming. We love just the regular Kake Udon and the Beef Udon. Soup/broth tastes so good, but can be a little salty and times. Although, the beef is sweet and tasty balancing the soup making it a perfect meal especially with friends. We love the free condiments with the tempura batter, green onion, cilantro, and ginger. We like to put the tempura bits on the side to avoid getting soggy to give the noodles a crunchy and chewy texture. Adding ginger in the soup also gives it a bit nice warm, sweet, and spicy bite to the tongue. All in all, great noodles, affordable, good service, and just great atmosphere! We would recommend people to go and we would go again in the future!
author: Ben And Conna ..

description:
Love this place! I really like the concept and of course, who doesn't love good noods. One thing that really irritated me though was that on my last visit, the various tempuras and musubis were in the wrong spots. I picked up a zucchini from the fishcake tempura area, and I bought a mushroom (?) musubi when it was labeled mental mayo. Was pretty bummed to eat my musubi the next day cause I hate that kind of mushroom :( 

But otherwise, service here is fantastic and the workers are so insanely friendly even towards closing. How it works is that you get in line, take a tray and tell them what # you want, and if you want it hot or cold (if possible). Then you go down the line cafeteria style and just pick up whatever tempuras and musubis catch your eye and pay at the end. You can see the entire udon making process and it's amazing how meticulous they are, weighing it down to the last gram. 

I've tried the mentai udon and the #1, both of which were pretty good but I loved the mentai a lot more. Can you tell that I like fish roe yet? Lol. The soft boiled egg was also spot on. There's also a self serve area where you can get sauces, tempura flakes, water, and so on
author: Nicolette E.

description:
Although it was a Saturday night, it was sprinkling so I only had to wait 15 minutes in line. The layout mirrors the Marukame Udon in Honolulu, where you purchase your udon and fried items before finding a table. My meal ended up being less than $12! The tempura is where they get you though...$2 for one asparagus?? I'll pass on that.

The udon noodles were absolutely delicious; however, I do wish the curry broth had more than a few specks of meat to it. I like that they have a toppings bar where you can load up on green onions and other goodies.

Overall a great place to stop by if it isn't during prime hours.
author: Vans C.

description:
LOVE this place!

I've been here twice (first time was their soft opening and the second time was their grand opening). If you don't want to wait for more than an hour and a half, come here at 10:30 am (30 mins before they open) for lunch. I did that for the soft opening and only waited 10 minutes when the doors opened since there were about 25 people ahead of me. 

You basically:
1) line up
2) grab a tray
3) select your choice of udon
4) pick tempura side or musubi 
5) pay
6) garnish with onions and tempura flakes
7) find a seat and eat!

Both times I came here, I got the CURRY UDON in large. I love the fact the flavor was light but yet very flavorful at the same time. Every worker was very tentative, welcoming and friendly. 

If you decide to come here for dinner, be prepared to wait in the cold. The sweet workers passed out warm tea as we were in line so I guess it made it somewhat better :)
author: Anny W.

description:
Don't let the line deceive you, this place is overrated AF. I heard that this place is originally from Hawaii and that the lines are just as crazy over there. People say it's amazing and I guess I was expecting for my mind to be blown.

Got there around 4:40 and there were 20 people in front of us already! That's pretty insane...but the line got even longer throughout my entire stay there. By the time I left, there were 40+ people in line..?! Crazy what hype can do!

I ordered a beef udon and got a couple pieces of tempura to go with it. It's not super expensive which was nice and it was cool to see your noodles being made in front of your eyes. When I tried the udon, it tasted like every other udon, nothing spectacular. I liked how they had a garnish station, that was a big plus for me. I've never seen that for an udon place before. I asked one of the employees what their opinion of the place was and even he said it was all right... don't believe the hype!
author: Nicholas H.

description:
Incredibly fresh Udon and Tempura at a very reasonable price.

My friends and I always find parking in the Stonestown lot. When we have had to wait in line, we have not yet waited more than 20 minutes at most.  Everything here is prepared FRESH right before your eyes.  Like a cafeteria, take a trey and work your way around the counters, order your Udon and pick up add-ons like Tempura and such. Then, pay for your selections and at the near by bar, spruce up your soup with cilantro, onion and other fixin's then find a seat and enjoy. 

At $6.90 for regular or $7.90 for the large, the #6 Spicy Chicken Udon (has walnuts) seemed just a bit shy with its chicken yet was very satisfying. Note the #2 Nikutama Udon hot or cold at $8.50 or $9.50 Im told is the most popular here. (See my attached images). 

At $1.50 we enjoyed the Shishito Tempura (3 pieces), the $1.70 vegetable Kakiage and the $1.80 succulent chicken tempura.

I don't have enough Udon experience to know if this is as good as it gets yet, for the price, quality and service, this will be tuff to beat, kudo's to everyone!
author: Caesar A.

description:
If you don't like cafeteria style, this place isn't for you. It's a typical Japanese style restaurant where you grab a tray, get your order, pay them look for a table. 

Been here a few times already and I think their udon is actually good, but not consistent with their serving portion. But overall quality is good. I always order the niku udon with soft boiled egg or the kake udon with soft boiled egg. Can't go wrong with those classic bowls and it fills you up. 

Definitely a perfect spot to grab a quick lunch or dinner at stonestown.
author: Toni Rose M.

description: Udon noodles are freshly made.   Crowded,  hard to find a seat when you have a tray from self service looking around for said seats.
author: John S.

description:
Who would have thought a simple Udon shop in a shopping mall can be this tasty? While visiting the galleria, I was curious at a line forming infront of Marigame Udon. So I decided to follow the crowd and have lunch here. The line moved quickly. 

Marugame is a self-serve restaurant that we get to order the food in an assembly chain. First, we picked up the tray and headed to the noodle station. The menu was very basic, with only 5 or 6 types of udon to choose from. Once we picked our bowl, the employee would prepare it infront of us in a matter of minutes! Next, we followed the line to the tempura station to take any fried food we like: there were a range of options from seafood to meat to vegetables. All around $2/each. I had the squid and sweet potato - they were lukewarm and tasted standard. After that, we paid our meal immediately at the cashier and headed to the condiment station to add scallions, add soy sauce and flakes etc depend on our preference. 

The reason why I gave Marugame 5 stars is because of its Udon noodle. I chose the #1 on the menu which had beef and poached egg. The beef was marinated well and tasted so delicious. The broth was the best I've ever had. It's mildy sweet and was NOT salty at all. My bowl had little amount of broth - I think this is the way the restaurant prepares this bowl but I'd love to have more cuz I'm the person who sips the last spoon of broth when eating noodles! The udon was chewy, which made me prefer this over ramen. At $8.95, this bowl was such a steal! My boyfriend had the curry udon and the broth was heavy but delicious too! The udon curry had the same meat as mine. 

I'd love the see Marugame expands its menu but am satisfied with what it offers atm.
author: Nhi D.

description:
I was so underwhelmed by the food. It was OK. Just OK. Nothing special about their udon or tempura. I waited 45 minutes on a Friday at about 11:00am. I expected to wait but would I come back to wait that long for udon? Probably not. 

The noodles had a nice chew to it and the broth was tasty as well but seemed to be just like any other udon you would get at any Japanese restaurant. I got the vegetable tempura which was majority of onions. Shrimp and asparagus tempura were good. It's tempura. Again, it's as though you would get it anywhere else. 

I sat in the back corner of the restaurant and noticed one thing: the hold up of the long line is the cashier. The food comes out instantly, there are tons of open tables, tempura and drinks you get as you move down the line. They definitely need more cashiers. If they had at least one more, I guarantee you the line would move exponentially faster. 

They also need to pick up on their service. They were out of utensils and tempura sauces. I waited at least 15 minutes for them to bring some out after asking multiple times. At one point I saw people just opening the bottom drawer and getting things themselves in the bins. 

For me this was a one time thing. I'm not going to wait 1-2 hours for udon where I can get at any mediocre Japanese restaurant.
author: Marie N.

description: the line outside is worth it! all the udon and tempura options are great it tastes so good!
author: Sabrina O.

description:
Meh. Debating between 3.5 and 4 stars. It's not bad at all but I don't understand what the hype is around this. I'm a fan of all types of noodles and having spent a good amount of time in Asia, this was just really underwhelming for me. Especially with the wait. (Insert Jackie Chan WTF meme). 

I honestly think it's probably because of the location and price point that people are going ga-ga over this place. There are udon places around the city with literally the EXACT same set up. Have you been to Kagawa Ya? Fresh made udon and tempura station...what?! 

I don't know...They play you on the rice balls here too -- all rice and tiny bit of filling.

I wouldn't go out of my way to come eat here again, nor would I ever wait 30+ minutes for this place. 

Maybe I'll give this place another go when their full menu is released but so far, I'm unimpressed.
author: Nadeen H.

description: Good ramen! This is right next SF State University at Stonestown Mall. If you want to eat here for dinner come early around 5 or later after 6-7 because people will be lining up out the door and you'll have to wait, plus the seating is limited. Once seating fills up, you may have to sit outside and it gets cold in SF. For the udon, it was good! I had the Nikutama Udon and my friend had the curry one. Both tasted delicious and were filling with the Regular size bowls. I just wish they put more broth next time. They also have sides such as tempura fries veggies and shrimp which were nice and crispy. Price is reasonable as well.
author: Kelly I.

description:
I love this udon place. Love it to the point where it's freezing cold, pouring rain, and you will still catch me standing in line with my eskimo parka, hiding under my smart-brella. 

Udon: Fresh, chewy, bouncy. broth is flavorful. meat is tender. Free unlimited supply of tempura flakes, green onions, cilantro, and ginger. Really, what more can you ask for in a perfect bowl of noodz? 

Tempura: Light and crispy. YUM! I highly recommend the shrimp tempura, potato croquette, and the fishcake. 

TIP: If you don't want to stand in line for 30-an hour, come between 3-5pm.
author: Maggie L.

description: This was very yummy. Very long wait (45 min from the outside post) but worth it. Don't go if you're in a hurry though, that's for sure! This place is best enjoyed when you're all signed up and ready for the full experience :) Have a nice chat with a friend,  bring a book, and if it's winter an umbrella cus you'll be outside for a bit! I enjoyed the udon and the staff were all very friendly and helpful. It tasted very fresh and everything was stocked. I would suggest that they have someone monitor the seating but actually instruct people where to sit. Assigned seating would help cut down own the wait time and awkwardly asking if seats available (you're not supposed to save seats but people did anyway). Besides that, a relatively affordable and authentic treat!
author: Abigail S.

description: The feel is sweet tomato's udon. You wait in a long line which did not get short until 8pm. Probably waited in total 40 minutes for food. The udon noodles were really good, as for the tempura it was cold so it was whatever. I like how they had a lot of options for tempura though. It was extremely filling food and I was only able to eat about four bites of my udon and had to take the rest to go. Only reason I won't be back any time soon is because I don't want to wait in the line.
author: Kaitlyn S.

description:
My sister and I hurried to stand in line on a Saturday at 2:30pm. The wait wasn't bad at all since it was constantly moving and although we were told it would be an estimated 30 minute wait I think we waited less than that. Although when we went inside the restaurant and I looked behind me I was shocked that the line grow like crazy since it was an odd time to eat lunch. 

I've been to the Marugame Monzo in LA which is a traditional sit down and order from a menu type of restaurant. Their more extensive selections are more tasty than this particular Marugame Udon however that isn't to say this location's dishes weren't good.

My sister and I both enjoyed the Mentai Kamatama the most. Mentai is savory cod roe (fish eggs) and mixed with the udon brings a creamy dish that taste of the sea. 

The other two that we tried was the Beef Udon and the Egg Drop Chicken Udon. The beef udon is okay; just wasn't as good as Marugame Monzo in LA. The Egg Drop Chicken Udon was good at first because the sauce was thick however it becomes more watery as you eat it and we got kinda sick of it. Both of us wished it was just Egg Drop soup by itself, minus the udon since it's just a bit too much. 

We also got the Kombu, Tuna Mayo, Salmon Flake, Mentai and Inari Onigiri rice balls. They're all great though they are more heavy on the rice side. The stand out one was the Mentai Fish Eggs rice ball. 

Unfortunately, this place just doesn't stack with their Marugame Monzo location in LA however it's a great fix for people who are craving fresh udon since we do lack in that department in the Bay Area. It's worth giving a try if you enjoy noodles however, I wouldn't personally wait more than 30 minutes since their dishes didn't blow my palate as the ones in LA did.
author: Rainar W.

description:
This has to be one of the best Udon places in the Bay Area. It is made fresh and the Curry broth that I ordered had all of the flavors. It was also thick and perfect for the cold weather we have been experiencing lately. 

I got a regular and they give a very generous amount. I like the concept of picking your tempura as you make you way down the line but I notice a that a couple of pieces I grabbed were a bit stale. They were also out of squid by the time I got around to it and replenished right after I paid. 

There is a small bar where you can add unlimited toppings to your Udon. I'm a huge fan of tempura flakes and green onion and I definitely helped myself without the judgement of a server asking me if I've had enough. 

I normally take pictures of my food but after the long wait I was so hungry that I forgot what a phone was.
author: Denise I.

description:
The day has finally come! A decent udon spot near the city :) It's been love at first bite since I tried marukame udon in Honolulu. 

Currently its the soft opening. Curry udon was finally released December 27 and the spicy chicken udon debuts on January 3rd. I came with my friends exactly at 5 pm and the line was already long! We waited about 15 minutes to finally reach the doors.

When you first enter, you see the employees making fresh udon noodles. The setup of the restaurant is cafeteria style. You wait in line, grab a tray, and go.

First, you tell the worker what you're order is and he/she gives you your bowl of udon with broth. I was slightly disappointed that they do not serve eggs yet :( they said that eggs will be served after the soft opening is done. Next, you can choose from a variety of tempura and musubi inari. Then you're all set! It's that simple. 

After you pay, there is a condiments bar with fresh green onions, cilantro, tempura crumbs, etc to top off your udon. They have hot tempura sauce that's in dispenser but be careful! My friend almost burned her hand because the tempura sauce was so hot. Hahah there's other seasonings you can add as well. 

Surprisingly, for how packed it was it was not difficult to find a seat. They have seating inside and a couple tables outside by the line. It was freezing so I preferred to sit inside. 

I got beef udon, my friends got curry udon and bukkake udon and all I can say is that all our stomachs were pleased. The udon comes in regular or large and the regular is already filling especially if you get tempura or musubi on the side. 

It's safe to say I will probably be here every week. I'm so happy this opened up :)
author: Mariah V.

description:
This newly opened spot is a new favorite for me and comes at a good price point for the amount of food given. However the line is long af, be prepared to wait an hour even if you're there as it is just opening. 
We ordered the large curry udon and large nikutame udon and I thought that they were both pretty good. Curry udon was a bit thicker in soup base and has some pieces of beef but not enough. Nikutame udon has a good portion of beef. Overall, this soup base was better and I would return for it but I wouldn't want to wait that long again.

We also tried tempura squid, shrimp, fish cake, asparagus, and the vegetable one as well. Tempura shrimp was well made but I didn't care too much for the others. I love that they have a tempura flake and green onion garnish bar! It's such a good idea!
author: Nick H.

description:
It's soft opening right now so not all menu items are available. The wait was a bit more than an hour for lunch so go during off times or until it dies down. 

I had the beef udon, the beef and the broth was really good however it didn't come out hot enough so the green onion and cilantro toppings didn't cook and was still raw. The udon is thick and stiffer than what I'm used to. Not that it's bad, it was just different. 

I like the format where everything is fresh and made from scratch. It's cafeteria style where you grab a tray and go down the line. 

Really happy they picked Stonestown to open a location at. I can see it being much more successful than Blue C. I just hope they fix the temperature issue and find a way to move the line faster.
author: Andy W.

description: Probably my favorite go to place for some of my udon cravings. The wait used to be super long but it's not as bad now and the lines moves pretty fast.
author: Emily H.

description:
This place is OK. Affiliated to Marukame Udon in Waikiki. Same concept: order udon, grab all that fried stuff, pay and find a table. 

Waited in line for an hour! My SIL wanted to try this place since its new to Stonestown. Nothing spectacular. Its more of a "fast-udon" spot. My wife and I didn't really like Marukame in Waikiki, and we still feel the same after trying this place out. The people behind us in line drove all the way from Livermore to eat dinner here. WTF for? Its just a hype.
author: Pam P.

description:
Went today on Sunday and got there five minutes before they opened and there was already a LONG line! Even one of the workers said that it was the longest he has seen it. We waited a hour and an half, and to be honest for the experience and the food it was worth the wait, BUT the next time I eat there will for sure be when they die down! I really loved how you could see what they were doing and just the whole set up made me feel like I was in Japan. 
My boyfriend got the beef udon and he really liked it but when I tried it I thought the broth was a little sweet but still good! I got the kake udon and it was so good and for only around five dollars!? Yesssss!!! And all the condiments!? Amazingggggg! 
We also got the little onigiri and at first I thought omg this is such a deal, but you do pay for what you get... It's mostly just rice and seaweed and very little of whatever ingredient you ordered. 
Overall, I loved the atmosphere and the food! Plus the employees were nice and I love how they were making sure tables were cleaned!
author: Linda N.

description: Really crowded I got curry udon and really enjoyed it. Food was really good. I don't think i would wait more than 10 min in line for it tbh
author: Louis F.

description:
Broth isn't hot; green onion chopped too big (about 1/4" long), the noodle isn't soft and and rather hard, the fried stuff taste like left over oil, and overall the vibe just isn't there.  

We also ordered a niku and there's virtually no beef, just fat.  It's soft opening but if you're not ready to push out your products, then dont do it.  I've been to Marukame in Waikiki, Tokyo, Hong Kong at Taikoo, Vietnam and other places and by far this is not good at all.

My suggestion is to set the bar higher and don't just grab workers off the street that probably have never taste a good bowl of udon before.

Truly need improvements
author: Marco W.

description:
This place has risen my udon standards and converted my ramen-loving bf to an udon lover! I really make the drive from San Jose to SF just for a bowl of gooood fresh udon and I have no regrets every time!!! Disclaimer: I have yet to try Marukame in Hawaii but I heard this was just as good. 

BRACE YOURSELVES! The line is usually out the door during lunch and dinner, and weekends. However, once you're in, it's pretty fast & cafeteria styled; grab your tray, tell them which udon you want, then choose any add ons (tempura, onigiri, croquet, etc) before heading to pay. My only complaint here is that there's only one person ringing people up, but I think the line gets held up when actually ordering and making of your udon. Seating is also self-serve, and cleaning up after yourself is your responsibility, which I think is neat. 

I've tried the curry, bukkake, nikutama, kakitama, and beef udon.... all SO GOOD T_T !!!!!
author: Gretchen S.

description:
You may have strolled pass Stonestown recently and thought to yourself, "is that a line forming in front of Olive Garden?"

No, sorry, it's not, it's no longer the 80's and 90's where we went crazy for unlimited soups, salad and breadsticks, it's this somewhat new udon place that has taken off in places like LA and Hawaii that has people forming lines an hour before this place even opens.

We got there like 20 minutes early and we were probably customer #25 or #30.

The concept is basically udon down an assembly line. So think Chipotle, but udon and also sweet tomatoes where you can tong in all the tempura you want priced a la carte. In theory, the lines should be super fast because all there is to it is someone ladling in your bowl of udon and handling you the bowl, then you go off to scoop your sides onto your tray.

The menu is limited It's soft opening and will continue to be soft opening until roughly 1/18/2018, which is what the sticker on their menu says, anyways.

We got the #5 which is beef udon, partly because our friend said he got the curry udon (which was another available one at this SF location's soft opening) in Hawaii and that he said it sucks. I'm a stickler with Japanese curry, so I took his word on it and passed on the curry udon.

Now, I'm going to leave somewhat of a different review here, and say that in the grand scheme of things, the udon tasted ALL RIGHT. The udon noodle was nice, chewy yet firm and the broth was good. The tempura was excellent.

The critique is this: The udon is too damn sweet. From the broth, to the beef, it's like they cooked and simmered it in an army of vidalia onions. You ever had a french onion soup where it was just too sugary? I got the same feeling here. There's a deleted scene in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory where Marugame's udon is in the movie and the kids swim in it and says its their favorite Jolly Rancher flavor. Too dang sweet, man. After finishing my bowl, I felt hella sugared out. A milktea afterwards would've been too gratuitous at that point, pastries at Tartine? Forget about it. Most palettes would enjoy this, and rightly so.

Another thing is, Marugame should handle seating a little better before they let it loose to the public. When doors opened on the dot, there were people in way back of the line, who probably weren't even going to see a bowl of udon on their trays for another 30 minutes, starting to walk in and save seats already, while people who were the first dozen in line were still ordering. What gives, guys???? Seriously. I thought it was rude and a jerk move.

Also, lots of parents who brought their kids were letting their kids just  roam around, while many people who just finished purchasing their udon, were trying to walk back to their tables carrying said udon (which is stupid hot). There was literally one kid who walked up to my knee, and if I didn't see him earlier before he disappeared under my tray, I would've tripped over the kid, probably landed on the kid, spilled all the udon on the kid and the kid would've probably have been bludgeoned and burned to the first or second degree. Parents, you don't want your kids to be hurt over some $10 bowl of udon, please handle your kids.

I'd come back, possibly after the grand opening to check out some of their signature udon that was held back during this soft opening.
author: Tom S.

description: Recommended but be warned if you are on any kind of diet! This location brings be back to Waikiki Hawaii where I had something like this for the first time. As you enter you'll pick a bowl of udon ($6-10) and before you know it you are in line grabbing a few fried Tempra goodies. And a triangle rice roll to eat later. And you realize your total bill just went over $20. Head over to the condiments area and load up on cilantro and green onions. The food is definitely delicious and very satisfying. I'm going back soon for sure.
author: Shane C.

description:
Wow, soft opening has already won me over so imagine when they finally release their full menu for their grand opening! Udon noodles are freshly made in front of you as you watch the dough go through the noodle maker and come out in beautiful strands before going into the water. The set-up to order reminds me of buffet style except you have to pay for each item you grab. Or I imagine this is what it is like in a Japanese school cafeteria. After you get your udon bowl, you can also grab musubi (I don't know why they call it musubi since there is no spam musubi and it looks like onigiri [rice balls]) or tempura to add on to your meal. Most of the snacks add-ons are around $1.50 or so. The first time I had the onigiri, there was very little filling throughout so it was a bit plain but the second time has improved. The cod one is pretty good! You might have to wait a bit if they run out as they are continually making them behind the counter. 

You pay at the end of the counter as they ring up your order on the iPad. The receipt doesn't show your individual items pricing and just the total paid. Water is self-serve at the water spout by the soda machine. 

Don't forget to check out the toppings bar behind the soda machine. You can add in green onions, cilantro, ginger, tempura flakes, tempura sauce, sesame powder, chili powder, etc to complete your meal. Your udon looks really plain if you don't. You're literally wondering why it doesn't match the photo on the wall until you reach the toppings bar at the end.

BEEF UDON
Beef is soft and delicious. Broth was a bit salty at the end so I couldn't drink it on its own when I ate all my udon

KAKE UDON
Lighter tasting broth and I really enjoyed it. I was afraid it would be too plain but it makes a difference after adding all the tempura flakes, green onions, and several dashes of chili powder.

Pick up chopsticks/fork and a plastic spoon and find a seat. They have indoor and outdoor seating. After you're done eating, you bring your tray over to the back (like in the dining commons at college) and you can throw away your trash and leave the dishes on the shelf so that they can wash it. 

For soft opening, the line is long and stretches out and it looks daunting but the line moves pretty quickly. I say it takes about a minute per person so we only waited for about 20-30 minutes.
author: Diana C.

description: Thai Spicy Udon was a bomb! Although the line was long, but the udon was fresh, hot and yummy.
author: Lily L.

description:
Marugame is an American-ized version of Japanese udon. I personally do not think it's amazing but it is delicious considering it's a fast food udon. I've gone a few times and had to wait in line for at least 15-20 minutes. If I have to wait any longer than that, it's not worth it. I get the hot, regular sized Nikutama Udon ($8.50). The beef has always been tender, the egg is cooked perfectly, and the noodles are delicious. The only request I would have is to have a little more broth. They also offer different types of self-serve tempura (i.e. shrimp, zucchini, potato, sweet egg, etc.) about $1.80 each, depending on what you get. I usually get the shrimp tempura and when it's fresh, it's delicious! The batter isn't too think and cooked perfectly. 

One of my favorite parts about Marugame is the free self-serve cilantro, green onions, ginger, and fried tempura batter bits station. As a lover of cilantro, green onions, and ginger, I appreciate being able to add as much as I would like. Overall, I would recommend this restaurant to anyone looking to have relatively cheap, fast, and good udon.
author: Victoria H.

description:
When you want a little variety in your hot noodle soup life this place does not disappoint. I'm more of a ramen and pho person but the udon here was good that I'll add it to my rotation of spots. 
The place is super casual and has an assembly line set up which makes for fast service. The noodles are prepared to order and you can watch them do it. It's very much a diy/cafeteria style set up, get a tray, order noodles, pick up noodles, add sides/tempura, drinks then pay. The lines here can get long but with their set up it moves fast. 
Got the nikutama udon and was plenty happy. The soup was tasty, the noodles the right amount of chewy, and the soft boiled egg and beef were delish. Also got some tempura pieces, it's nice here because they make it right in front of you instead of just sitting out. The seating here is very much like a food court, open and first come first serve but plenty of space. The service here was friendly and efficient. IMO a solid place for udon for when you want to switch up your hot noodle soup needs
author: Peter P.

description: Usually long lines but they do move fast. I got there on Sunday when it opened and there was already a line out the door. Total time spent there was and hour including the time it took for us to eat. They are like cafeteria style where you get you udon and side then pay at the register before finding a seats. Ordered a Nikutama udon ( beef and egg) and tonkatsu udon. Both were delicious. Nikutama is in a sweet light broth. Tonkatsu had a heavier heartier broth with some chili oil in it. I love their eggs, they are extra soft boiled. For sides, they have a variety of tempuras amd onigiris. I highly recommend this place. There is a dog friendly patio here as well.
author: Angelina N.

description:
Very RICH broth, I got the #1 which is the typical Tonkatsu ramen and it was only about 9 bucks! I would say their "medium spicy" isn't even mild. Price was cheap to start but adding the sides/toppings (the orders don't really come with much toppings)  really blew up the price!

My friend tells me this how authentic ramen is "suppose" to be. It's a fun experience getting to walk down the trays of sides and then picking all your toppings. 

The omelette thing was incredible! Make sure you grab it! I wish I took a picture but it was gone before I thought of it. Can't wait to come back.

Note: the line moves pretty fast.
author: Frank C.

description: I love this place! It's a fast, classy noodle restaurant. I came on a Sunday, arrived at 5:25PM and waited for about an hour till I got inside. I am in love with their beef udon and it's a delightful treat. Broth is simple and tasty, noodles are always freshly made. Their side tempura variation is not a lot, and they tasted warm, but I liked their shrimp tempura out of all of them. Good dining experience!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Came here during the soft opening and got in line at 4:30PM and we were maybe the 10th party to be served.  They opened the doors at exactly 5PM and the lines went comfortably quicker than expected! At the entrance, you'll see a giant menu to choose from as well as steps on how to order.  It is cafeteria style so you grab your own tray, say your order to the worker and they will prep up your udon bowl in front of you within seconds.  After receiving your bowl of udon, you are then able to choose your tempura sides which are priced between $1-$3 per piece as well as a choice of numerous different musubis! The cashier will then ring you up for all your items and then you take your bowl to the toppings bar with choices of green onion, cilantro, and tempura flakes!  There's also several different tempura dippings sauces, soy sauce, sriracha, and chili flake powder (I don't remember the exact names) but for those who like spicy soup, you can definitely make your udon to your spicy preference.

I had a large Beef Udon and it was delicious! I would say that this was quite similar to a pho broth, and the beef that they put in your soup is a little on the 'greasy' side, and you can definitely see the fat layer on top of your soup, just a heads up.  The portion size was enormous for me, so I took my leftovers home and ate the rest the next day!

Other people with me tried the Curry Udon bowl and I was able to try their broth as well.  It's definitely on the extreme savory side but nevertheless, it was delicious as well.  

Out of all the tempuras that I tried, my favorite was the shrimp tempura!  The shrimp on the inside was so tender, almost reminded me of shrimp cocktail consistency, but the outer breading of the tempura was a crispy perfection :')

For those of you wondering if this is like Hawaii's Marukame Udon located in Honolulu, it's exactly like that.  And if you've been craving your bowl of udon from Hawaii, this will not disappoint and will definitely satisfy you.   I will definitely be back here once I go back to school at SFSU, this place is worth it and the price matches the portion sizing which is something that's hard to find in San Francisco!
author: Rochelle A.

description:
I love their beef. I even order extra beef. 
Average price, I considered cheap. I came around 13:30-14:00. No waiting time.
author: Jessie W.

description:
My boyfriend and I arrived around 1130am on a Sunday and of course there was already a line out the door. A host approached us and walked us through the menu - he was very informative. He gave us a few recommendations and we decided on the beef udon and the tonkatsu udon. We each ordered a large beef udon. And large tonkatsu not realizing how much food it was. 

We finally approached the door where you can literally see the udon dough being rolled out and put into a machine to make the noodles. Then they're freshly put into hot water and ready to serve. I loved this place this much because you were able to see how fresh the noodles are. Someone then takes your order and it literally make to order. There's an option where you can get different types of tempura. We settled for the chicken, shrimp, squid, zucchini and asparagus. Mind you, they're like tempura on steroids so it's totally shareable. 

Bill came out to less than $50 for 3 large bowls of udon along with probably 9 pieces of tempura. Totally worth it! They also have an area where you can add condiments such as - tempura bits, green onions and cilantro.

I recommend this place to anyone who loves a great, cheap, fresh experience with food!!! Definitely coming back
author: Charlene B.

description:
I really do not understand the hype of this place, especially after reading positive reviews and constantly seeing a long line outside their business. 

We came here on a Saturday afternoon. Thank goodness the line was not too bad and waited about 15 minutes before getting into the building to order. The system is essentially similar to Chipotle. You pick up your tray, order your udon, grab any extra tempura or onigiris, pay and add your toppings. 

I ordered the regular nikutama (#8), which was honestly very disappointing. At the very least the udon was the highlight of this lunch; chewy and "bouncy" noodles. However, every other aspect was just unimpressive. They give you a very small ladle of room temperature broth that barely covered the noodles. The beef closely reminded me of bulgolgi, except worse and overly sweet. The soft-boiled egg was very soft and essentially thickened the broth since yolk was very runny as well. Adding ginger and other condiments helped offset some of the strong sweet flavors, but the whole experience was not the best. 

I also grabbed myself some shrimp and fishcake tempura. Cold, too much panko, greasy, flavorless tempura. Do not recommend at all. I'd save those $4 for boba to wash this meal down. 

Overall, expensive and didn't taste the best either.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I was excited to try this place since my friends had it in Hawaii and said it was pretty good. 

It's cafeteria style and it was pretty cool to see them make the udon right in front of you. I ordered the regular size hot nikutama udon which comes with beef and a soft boiled egg. I also got shrimp tempura, inari, imitation crab onigiri, and salmon flake onigiri. The egg in the udon was a littleee more raw than I'd like it to be, but it was still good. Also, I felt like the udon soup wasn't as hot as I wanted it to be or maybe it just got cold really fast?? I'd say the price is pretty fair for the udon (~$9), but the onigiri wasn't really worth. It was around $1.50 for an onigiri, but only the very top had the meat and the rest was rice so it was literally only one bite of meat... 

I like how there's a self serve station for green onions and cilantro so you can customize your bowl. The tempura sauce is also self serve, but it's a little salty so don't dip too much. 

Also, don't be intimidated by the line because it goes by super quick!
author: Selina H.

description:
BEST UDON I EVER HAD.
So I usually don't buy udon outside, knowing that I can make udon at home for a few bucks, but honestly this was worth the money and wait. We probably waited about 2 hours. Honestly, I don't understand why the wait took so long. There's plenty of seating inside, it's fast food style so technically the wait shouldn't be as bad, but I think they're still working on their operations (since it recently opened) and hopefully make it more efficient.
They were out of several ingredients so I was bummed about that, but nonetheless, it was delicious. I love watching food being made, since i know it's fresh (and it makes me feel healthier). Absolutely worth the wait!!
author: Alex C.

description:
With all things hype: the wait is going to be at least half an hour, but it's worth it. It's not as efficient as it could be, but given I went on grand opening day, it makes sense. They had a lot of staff to try to make it run as smooth as possible.

Basic gist is this: 1) Pick your udon (I suggest getting a L size since it's not that much bigger anyway); 2) Pick your tempura or side dishes (incl rice balls); 3) Unlimited toppings and side sauces bar!!! 

I recommend the beef udon as a base, and then build it up with tempura (I actually liked the chicken tempura) and grab a rice ball while you're at it. Beef udon feels light due to the soup base, but packs a punch. I really liked the chicken tempura, as well as the squid tempura. The mentaiko cream musubi is EXCELLENT too, by the way. My bf got the curry udon and liked it, but I would recommend that if you're into something heavier. You could easily get away with a dinner under $10-15 if you are wise enough, but I'd say it's worth the wait. I'm hoping the hype dies down soon since I work nearby and I'd like to start coming here for lunch!
author: Christa Lei S.

description:
I went for the soft opening and got a Beef Udon. I've never got to try the location in Hawaii so I didn't really have any expectations. Even though I had no expectations, I was blown away.

I waited 40 minutes in line with my friend who has tried the one in Hawaii and Japan, it wasn't too bad, I was expecting worse. I heard the Grand Opening today had a crazy wait though. With this line it feels like it's kinda constantly moving at least, so you're not just sitting there waiting for your party of 2 to be called or whatever. 

I got chicken breast tempura, vegetable kakiage (not even going to try to spell it right), shrimp, and zucchini. I definitely over ordered. The chicken breast was pretty meaty, vegetable had too many onions, nothing wrong with the shrimp, and the zucchini was maybe a little too moist.

One thing my friend loves about this place is that there is a tempura flakes bar, so you can add as maaaaaaany tempura flakes, green onions, and cilantro as you want, which is awesome because I love all 3.

I'll definitely be back, probably towards their closing times so that we don't have to deal with traffic. I want to try everything here. Surprisingly I was never really into Udon, and then I tried some kind of recently and I hadn't realized how good toppings can make Udon taste.
author: Kenny N.

description:
I waited for one hour to get the food but I think it's not what I expected, the Curry Udon was too salty but I like the Udon,  after eating I had to drink lots of water. 
Also the shrimp tempura was good but the Salmon Rice Balls only a little salmon, rice has no flavor.

I don't think I'll go back and wait in line to get seat again.
author: Lily L.

description:
I finally made it here and the lines are loooooooooooooooooooooooong. On a Sat night around 6pm, expected wait is 1-1 1/2 hrs. Yikes. Crowds don't lie so are they telling me this is worth the wait? 
MARUGAME specialize in handmade noodles specifically, Sanuki noodles that are square shape with flat edges. The soup stock is a kelp dashi, a Japanese kelp base with various dried fish and soy sauce additions. Along with Udon, MARUGAME also features fresh tempura and handmade Musubi. The goal is a custom noodle meal.
With all that said, this was totally worth the wait. The udon noodles had a great texture, they stayed sturdy the entire duration of our meal. The broth was flavorful and it had a lot of depth. There was a large selection of tempura items and each one was visually appealing, but most of all they were light and crispy with lots of flavor. Lastly, there was hand made musubi & inari which was freshly made on the spot so the rice was warm. Overall,  
please go here because you won't regret it!
author: David H.

description:
We came on one of the soft opening days when the menu was still limited to only 4 udon bowls. There were at least 30 people waiting in line ahead of us around 11 but it did have pretty steady movement every few minutes. They have a good amount of seating and you order first then find seats. We got the beef udon (L) and Kama-Age udon (L). They're pretty generous with the amount of udon in each order so a regular size probably would have been enough because two large bowls was super filling. We also got shrimp tempura and squid tempura. There were many other tempura options and some onigiri too. They have a toppings bar with tempura flakes, green onion, cilantro, ginger, and sauces. 
The beef in the beef udon was like beef don (sweet with onions). I felt like it would've gone better on dry udon or rice rather than udon. I did like the kake soup though. It was flavorful without being salty. The Kama-Age udon comes with kake sauce which is a lot stronger than kake soup. I think if you added the kake sauce to the kama water that the kama-age udon comes in, you would just get kake soup. So the biggest difference would be the beef and what your udon is soaking in longer. They both tasted great but for the price, I would be ok without the beef and would just go for the kama-age and load up on toppings for more flavor. The dipping does get tedious for the kama-age but getting that brief burst of flavor is actually preferable. Also the soup you would be drinking would just be kama water and your toppings, which seems healthier.
I would skip the squid tempura (at least if it wasn't recently fried) and just get the shrimp. The batter wasn't oily and was a nice fluffy crisp. It's kind of a lottery to see if you arrive in line at the right time to catch tempura being fried fresh.
author: Christine L.

description:
I've been to the one in Hawaii so you can only imagine my excitement when I found out they were opening one so close to my home ^___^Y

Still the soft opening so not everything on the menu is available quite yet. We arrived before they opened at 11am and there was already a line down the block!!!! Waited in the cold for about 20-30ish minutes but the table turnover is quick and you order somewhat cafeteria style so before we knew it we were inside.

Got the large beef udon (which was MORE THAN ENOUGH) and had a chicken tempura, shrimp tempura, and croquette on the side. The sides are where the price adds up, with each being about 2 bucks per additional piece. I paid about 18 bucks for a large bowl with those 3 additional sides. 

Service, in addition, was spectacular. Someone came over and gave us sauces that he recommended we use for each of our sides. There's a self-serve sauce bar but he took the liberty of bringing some to us directly! On top of that the cleanup crew was just.. so nice.

Great way to warm up on a winter day (minus waiting outside in line)~
author: Genevieve M.

description:
Well I was tricked. I didn't realize the spelling was different from the Waikiki one until after I ate.  It's not the same chain, but don't get me wrong it is still good, just not as good as Waikiki. 

This review will be based on comparison.  The restaurant layout, the line, the ordering system is a carbon copy of Waikiki's. But it ends there.  The menu has less options, the soup proportion isn't very generous, the overall taste is lacking some sweetness, no spam masubi and the cart return is quite abandoned. 

With that said, I will say that it is one of the best udon places in San Francisco, though my experience is just mostly downtown and Japantown, I have yet to try the Sunset/Richmond ones. Finding a table also isn't very hard as there are plenty of seating.

Overall would I come back? Well yes.  It's still closer than Hawaii, but I probably wouldn't want to wait 20 minutes in line again.  Maybe in a few months the line will die down once others too realize it's not the same chain.
author: James R.

description:
I came here at 5 pm expecting to wait a long time, but it actually wasn't that long! I think I waited 15 minutes. Once inside, it was like I was transported back to Japan. I went to a place like this in Kyoto at a food court mall, and the set-up was the same!! I love that you can see the whole process. Everything is so fresh.

I decided to try a regular sized nikutama udon, and it was a big portion! I could not finish it, and they really load it with the beef. :) I also tried some tempura items - the chicken, zucchini, and potato croquette. Everything was tasty. :) 

After you get your food, there is a station with condiments (ginger, cilantro, green onions, etc.) that you can doctor your bowl with. 

Everything is really organized here, and I would definitely come back once the lines aren't so long.
author: Rachel H.

description:
I loved this place so much in Waikiki, that I went twice during my trip! So I was so excited that they were opening a location her in the Bay Area. I came to Stonestown over the weekend, but the line was waaaay too long. I got a day off from work today, and decided that today would be the perfect day to try again. 
I'm not surprised that other helpers waited in 45+ minutes, which I wasn't trying to do, so after reading several reviews, it sounded like around 2-3 PM would be the best time to avoid long lines. 
I got in line around 2:45, and paid at around 2:55PM. So I got lucky! The restaurant was busy and there were a lot of people inside, but I was able to find a seat almost right away. 
I ordered a regular #5 beef udon. It is a cafeteria style restaurant where you grab a tray, and after getting your udon, there are several sides to choose from, self-serve. I got the tempura chicken, sweet potato tempura, and a potato croquette. The total came out to be around $15. 
One thing that I love about this place that I wish the Waikiki location had would be the self-serve tempura flakes and green onion for the soup. I piled that ishhhh on lol. 
The tempura chicken was good, just a little salty for my taste, but anything fried is going to be salty. The sweet potato was good, but was a little harder than I'd like it to be. The croquette was a little bland but that didn't stop me from eating half of it lol. 

Overall, I would say that I prefer the Waikiki location over this one. While the food was good here, I felt like the broth was missing something that the Waikiki location has. With that said, I'll still come back here when I'm craving some udon. I'll give it a solid 3.5, rounding up for service and atmosphere.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
There was no wait. The Beef Udon was  bland, the asparagus tempura was bland. The chicken tempura was ok. Thankfully I "beefed up" my Udon with lots of green onions, tempura flakes, ground sesame seeds and grated ginger. I see other reviews mentioning waits of 15 minutes up to an hour(!). If I had to wait I would expect something much better. 
We stopped here because the Food Court in the mall had already closed. 
Not at all impressed.
author: Michael C.

description: Lunch for Two ....Did we over order ? Lol  . Now what do I think of this place? Well.... it's ok nothing wow.. the udon in LA is better and Japan of course. I do love their tempura but not the chicken ( it's a bit salty). A customer told me their Hawaii location is better. Maybe in time it will improve. I do love their set up and service is awesome. Oh they also have all the condiments and plastic bag for you to help yourself to. I actually enjoy their tempura more than the udon but if I had to choose I'll pick the beef. My girlfriend likes the curry.  The one complaint was the Togo container can be better. I wish they had uni udon like in LA. Overall I'll give 3.5 star but since the staff was really nice plus price is good I'll say 4 star.
author: Christy V.

description:
Went to the grand opening in San Francisco. First time hearing about this place and didn't know what to expect, but my experience was great!

Location is at a mall, so there's plenty of parking but was a pretty crowded area in the afternoon. We were welcomed by a grand opening with balloons, photo backdrops, and cheery staff. Line wasn't too bad around 3pm, we had maybe a 15 minute wait. The dining experience is a unique one with energetic workers (when a worker shouts thank you to a customer leaving, the rest of the crew repeats). The dining process is getting in line, picking up a tray (and plate if you want sides), picking your bowl of udon, watch them make it in front of you, and pick your own sides of tempura, musubi, and more-- buffet style. After you pay, there's a condiment/topping bar right behind the cash register, where you can add tempera flakes, green onions, or sauces to your tray. 

I had their curry udon and some tempura, and both were delicious. The udon noodles were really soft, some the best tasting udon I've experienced by far. The curry was also great, especially on a rainy day. For the tempura, I got a zucchini, shrimp, fish, and sweet potato. All fried pretty well with good texture and tasted great with the tempura sauce they have at the condiment bar. 

I'd definitely recommend this place! The udon selection has a lot of good options with ranging prices, and you control how much extra you want by picking your sides laying right in front of you (with price tags). Employees were cool, energetic people. If their enthusiasm remains consistent to be like their grand opening, I'd love to come back whenever visiting San Francisco!
author: Andrew P.

description: I've had a lot of udon in the city and I was really excited to try this place. The location is clutch because they will always have the student crowd but for the wait, the food was good but great. I appreciate the cleanliness and service but when you're hungry you don't want to wait long. I'm glad I tried it but think it's overhyped and attest that the best beef udon is still at Sakesan in the Inner Richmond.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I went here for a late lunch on a Friday around 1:30pm. The wait wasn't too bad, about 20/30 min. I started lining up at the beginning of the 2nd line. 

Ordered #2, Beef Udon with Egg. Udon noodles were really fresh with good chewy texture. They are stingy with their kake sauce but I guess I can see why since it was extremely salty. We were hella thirsty for hours after the meal. 

The tempura was disappointing because it was cold and very greasy. I tried the vegetable, squid and fish cake. 

I really liked the mentai cod roe musubi. Good flavor and the rice was very fluffy. But like everyone says, it's really 90% rice.
author: Cathy M.

description:
I have been searching and craving a good udon spot in the bay area! My prayers have been answered now that Marugame Udon has opened!! I heard of the name from friends who have eaten at their location in Hawaii and swear by it, so I had high hopes and waited over 30 mins in line (be prepared to wait!) during a weekday lunch during their soft opening.

You wait in the lengthy line and then you tell them the number of the menu selection you want and they cook the udon noodles on the spot. You grab a tray and as you walk down, they'll hand you your bowl of udon and continue down and can choose what pieces of tempura you want. You pay at the cashier and then there is a separate station for your udon toppings and tempura sauce after.

I got the beef udon (regular), chicken tempura and I forgot what it was called but it was this tempura ball of onions and some other vegetables. The tempura was average to me, it wasn't anything special and I have had better. The udon was amazing though, the broth has so much flavor. I would say the beef could have been slightly better if it were softer/more tender. But this is the best udon place in the area so I give it 5 stars! It is also conveniently located at Stonestown. I was pretty full from just the regular size udon so next time I would skip the tempura and just get the delicious udon. I can't wait to go back once they have their official grand opening with the full menu and hours!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
I've been to this establishment twice so far: once during soft opening and another on day2 of grand opening. The food is pretty good! I ordered the Nikutama and the lady ordered a curry udon. Both of them had good flavor and depth. I like how you can choose a large portion or a regular portion and everyone there serves with a smile. 

Moving down the line, you'll have your many selection of tempuras and onigiris/musubis. They do add up in cost since one piece could run you close to $2. If you're in the market for a smaller meal, I believe you can go in just for the musubis, they are about $2 each as well. 

The one complaint/comment I have, and I subtracted a star for, is the management of the line. The manager (I believe) was passing out menus and engaging but I've seen a few people wait in line for their friends and later let 2-3 of them in which is highly unfair to the rest of the line. I also saw some phlegm on the "line starts here" sign and turned it away so nobody swipes it with their elbow... didn't wanna make a scene since it was only day2. 

Would recommend for some quality Udon, but maybe wait until lines start to diminish :).
author: Tyler D.

description: YESSSSS! Ever since i came back from Hawaii I've been craving udon and when my brother told me that they opened one in Daly City i was so excited! I came here on a Thursday afternoon with my friend the wait was maybe 10-15 minutes? Which wasn't too bad! Since it was their soft opening their whole menu wasn't available. I had the beef udon! It was so satisfying i can't wait for their grand opening! It's a little more pricey than the location in Hawaii but definitely worth it! Don't get too carried away with the tempura bar! I like how they have a toppings bar you can add as much green onions as you'd like  don't add too much tempura flakes or else you won't have any broth left since it soaks it up!
author: Tina H.

description: Best udon I've had so far. I came 10 minutes before opening and had to wait ~20 minutes to get my order. It's NOT restaurant style, you order at the counter. I ordered the beef udon with a side of shrimp and chicken tempura. The noodles are freshly made and the beef is soft and flavorful. The broth is also really good but it can be salty for some people (I like my broth on the salty side). The tempura was just the right amount of crispy and soft. Don't forget to try both the savory tempura sauce AND the sweet tempura sauce, they are both great! I'll definitely be coming back and showing tons of people this place!
author: Violet N.

description:
Not worth of money and time at all !!!
Udon itself is very good BUT the broth and other ingredients have ruin it!!
Broth is so call WARM only. I ate #2, 6, 8, 10. NONE of them can be consider good. I would call them worse.... and disgusting. They all taste salty. #6 is spicy chicken udon which is little spicy and SOUR!!! 
Unexpected and unbelievable!!!!
Tempura are oily and not crispy at all. Very low and bad quality. It taste so BAD that we go with empty stomach but still have no appetite to finish our bowl. I just wait 30mins but I Never go again and not worth for the wait.
author: G P.

description:
I'm one of the few people who hasn't tried the Hawaii location apparently. While that makes me a little sad, I can set that as a goal to try when I do visit the islands. I was worried that this would be yet another long line waiting experience ending in disappointment but I actually enjoyed my time here. Once I got in line, an employee quickly greeted me, handed me a menu and told me what items were available during their soft opening. I think I waited around 15-20 minutes to get inside where there was a sign explaining the process. You could see udon being made right when you walked in. After placing my kake udon order, I was excited to see the tempura selection that you can pick yourself!  Wow, I was not expecting that! Me being hungry over did it by getting chicken, shrimp, sweet potato and fish cake, along with a crab musubi which really looks like onagiri to me. After paying, there's a topping bar for the udon and a tempura sauce dispenser. The udon was perfect al dente, though I probably could have put a little spice into the broth. Most of the tempura was good, but I probably should only get one or two pieces next time. They fill you up pretty quick. 

I'm looking forward to going back when they have the full menu. Service was very friendly and the place was packed but wasn't so crowded that you couldn't find a place to sit. I think they will be a good option for those cold nights in SF.
author: Maria S.

description: I had both hot and cold udon from this place and I will say its pretty good for a mall setting udon parlor. The Udon noodles are very fresh and not over cooked when served plus they have a good selection of different tempura without breaking the bank in your pocket; prices of each items are very affordable but did not sacrifice the quality of the food they served. This place will definitely satisfy anyone's udon craving I suggest for all the udon lover to try the cold udon  !!!!!!!oh by the way this is a self service udon parlor if you're a seat-in type person that enjoys the food to be serve at your table this place is not for you
author: Allan A.

description: After stopping by and got turned off by the lines of ppl. I finally bite the bullet and decided to go in this udon hype cafeteria. I had the bukkake udon cause... you know.  And it was alright, but my highlight was really the assorted tempuras. Needless to say, I won't go back because of the long wait
author: Jack L.

description:
Food:
The kameage udon and beef udon were good but honestly just as good as any other udon place. The plus side is that it's cheap as shit which is awesome! Noodles were springy and not too chewy and the portions were large. I HIGHLY recommend the mentai mayo onigiri, it was so freaking delicious I think about it at night sometimes. I didn't like the tuna mayo one at all though and I like tuna usually! The potato croquette was so creamy and delicious I wish I got 3 of them. 

Soft opening wait: 
Okay so we waited about 1 hour to get into the restaurant which I would never ever wait for again. Next time I go will be after the wait is over. I think it's worth a 15 minute wait. Lol.

Parking:
So the location is in stones town mall, aka shitty parking almost all the time, usually have to at least circle once.

I'd definitely come again and next time I'm gonna try the edamame salsa udon during the grand opening!!
author: Justine L.

description:
HQ people from Japan went home already. At least it feels like it.
Their tempura is good, onigiris are good, but their Udon noodle sucks. What is the point of opening up a such a flagship Udon store, when your main item sucks? I see that they imported flour from Japan but their noodles are overcooked and missing noodle's "KOSHI". 

Marugame Seimen (noodle factory) franchises in Japan are known for fast-serving food, But this SF location is backed up with 30-45 minutes. This is unreal (in a bad way). It turns out the noodle-cooking are all done by $15 Americans and cooks are slow. The workers don't keep enough udon noodles ready, and they often have to repeat customers orders, since they don't seem confident. 

In Marugame shops in Japan, by the time you are ready to order, the udon noodles comes instantly from their table along with the soup. Here, it takes 2-3 minutes after you place an order - creating unnecessary back-up all the way outside of the store.  Long lines doesn't necessarily mean it's that good. This is an example.

I think their serving can be improved vastly - they just need to bring back the HQ people and improve on the customer flow. As a hourly worker from SF, you'll have no idea how to make the line flow any better.

The soup is too salty, even by high-blood-pressure Asian standards. 

By the way, I have no idea how they pass city ADA regulations. The interior has less than 2ft to go through between chairs and it will be impossible for wheelchair patrons to go in/out. I wouldn't be surprised if they get reported.
author: Another R.

description:
If you love udon this is the place for you. 
Like their concept and the way to serve make the line move really fast. Recommend one regular size udon and with two sides and that is perfect portion already. No2 is my favorite. Bussiness hours are good 11:00am to 11:00pm, around  3:00pm no line( off rush hours).
author: San J.

description:
Don't wait in line... wait a few weeks once newness dies down.  They also do side tempura and sushi rice. The price is average for SF. $30 for two people with sides.  
I ordered the large #2 Nikutama udon. Shredded beef egg and udon noodles. The udon is fresh and delicious. I also order shrimp tempura and potato croquette. The shrimp tempura was average same with potato croquette. The reason for a 4 Star is I wish there was more broth. I like the toppings bar is self service. My brother ordered the edamame salsa udon - (thumbs down on that one ) Not bad but not worth the wait in line. Wait a few weeks once the hoopla calms down...
author: Hazel H.

description:
Wow This place is off the charts!  First, this place met my first criteria, long lines = good food.  Had to wait an hour on a Saturday night.  Prices are reasonable, $7.90 medium bowl and $8.90 for a large bowl of udon.  The Noodles are FRESH!  Waiting in line you can watch them make it from a pizza size dough ball.  Then as you are going through the line the person adds whatever broth and meat to your udon.  I had the large curry beef and she covered my fresh noodles with two huge scoops of thick meat broth.  Then you if you want, you can pick freshly deep fried tempura.  You can pick your choice from a wide variety of different types of tempura in front of you.  This is helpful for me because I am not a tempura connoisseur.   They were all less that $2 apiece.  Then to top it all off, there is a topping bar with green onions, cilantro, sauce, and deep fried crunchy tempura batter.  So, in summary, if you want to experience a different dining without breaking the bank, this is the place for you. 
 (Hurry, before they figure out that the prices are too low and raise them!)
author: Shauna f.

description: Be prepared to wait!!! The line is already super long even before they open. My tip is to come about 15 minutes before they open just so you can be part of the first crowd. This is the only downside. Other than that, the udon is super fresh, chewy, al dente and the broth is ammmmmazing!!!!! The price is cheap and the food is served quick. This is the same udon place as the popular on in Oahu Hawaii. So good!!!
author: Rainbow W.

description:
The wait wasn't so bad, you can get inside in roughly about 30min. Along where the line is at, you can actually see how the udon is being made. Pretty fascinating. 
The udon itself was pretty good but it does become too heavy after a few bites. You will start to feel like all you are eating is only udon and no other toppings (Lots of udon and little meat). The more you eat it, the saltier it becomes. The tempura/fried stuff were pretty good actually. Would love to eat them again. 
I don't think it lives up to its hype but it's definitely worth a try. Not bad but it's just not amazing.
author: Ching C.

description:
I love the way the place looks. 
I love the atmosphere.
But oh gosh hope that it doesn't rain. I was waiting outside for about 30 minutes in the rain. I loved the restarant's food and staff
author: Remy T.

description:
Just tried this place for the first time earlier for dinner.  My bf and I tried it and both agreed that this place was simple, tasty and best  of all, a great price for freshly made udon.  Upon entering, you order first and pay, seat yourself and eat-and-go.
Once you enter, you can clearly see the udon being made and cooked from scratch and put together in an assembly line way through the glass.  

I got the curry udon and my boyfriend got the spicy chicken udon. The curry udon was really good in flavor and texture. The soup was slightly thick being that it was curry but not overbearingly saucy or anything.  The curry had pieces of beef in it, however, I surprisingly found myself not really caring much for it.  
The spicy chicken udon, on the other hand, was also tasty.  The soup was a lot different from what I got. Compared to the curry udon, it wasn't as noticeably thick, but still had a lot of flavor. The flavor itself was spicy, sour and sweet.  Although it was a strange combo of flavors that I'm not quite used to, it was still pretty good. 
Aside from the soups, the noodles itself were great in texture and flavor. 

Along with udon, this place also serves fried tempura meats and vegetables.  Of the side dishes, we tried chicken tempura, tempura fish cake, potato croquette, salmon onigiri and the shiso one.  

The tempura foods, aside from the non crispy/crunchy fish cake tempura, were pretty good in the crunch factor and tasty when dipped in sauce.  All the sides were basically under heat lamps so they weren't as warm and good. 
Also the onigiris we got were not very good at all!!!, I recommend skipping them completely being that they had little to no flavor and were tiny for what you pay for. 

Overall, this place was pretty fresh and a good price.  Definitely recommend trying this place for lunch
author: Daisy S.

description:
I loved the location in Oahu; and this one is nearly identical. I love the freshly made noodles, so chewy! I love the simplicity of the udon options, I love the selection of the tempura (note to self: try not to overdo it, 1-2 pieces per person is enough oil. :P) and I don't even usually LIKE udon!

So why would some people write negative reviews? Certainly, it is their own personal experience, they are well within their rights to; I would never say they're wrong. What I can tell you is how to temper your own expectations and hopefully have a better time. 

First, the line is ridiculous. The line was ridiculous in Hawaii too, so either be prepared to wait around 45 minutes (bring a book or a friend), or come right about closing time. or really in between lunch and dinner. I'd say when we left around 2pm, there was still a line, but maybe it was a 30 min line. When we came at 9 pm, still a 45 min wait. So maybe we just have to deal. Keep in mind, this is right next to a college campus, so students will come WHENEVER. 

Second, understand the product. 
- The udon options are very simple. Some have more broth, some have less broth. [Nikutama is one that inadvertently tricks you, there is less broth in that one.] Some are cold (noodles will be chewier), some are hot. They're all super simple and straightforward. The ones with meat will be slightly oilier than the ones without. The curry one is spicy, and potentially salty. Get the soft-boiled egg! I love egg yolk, and it adds so much to the udon. 
- With the tempura, you have your standard shrimp- then a bunch of different options. (I like the squid, but haven't had it here yet.) With veggies, the sticks of zucchini have the largest vegetable to batter ratio (potentially most healthy). I personally love the sweet potato. They are expensive add-ons. I would try to stick to just 1-2 pieces per person. 
- Then you have your rice products: know they are mostly rice, don't go in expecting there to be much filling. Don't get it if you expect there to be any filling, that way if you have a tiny bit- you're ecstatic! 
- Have fun with the complimentary toppings! I always add a ton of green onion and tempura flakes. They also have spicy toppings and dipping sauce for tempura. 

Third, this is fast food. I know. I know. It's crazy (because of the line and the hype), but this is essentially fast food. Don't go in expecting it to be a Michelin rated restaurant where the staff tell you where all the ingredients are sourced and how frequently they forage for mushrooms. It's literally cafeteria style fast food. Of course it makes sense that you should be able to get better udon at a sit-down restaurant. Don't go in thinking you're going to get super wowed. There is hype, and a long line, but it is still fast food.
author: Tiffany W.

description: This place was amazingly delicious! The noodles had just the right bite to it. Not mushy, not gummy.... the selection of tempura was awesome. It was cafeteria style set up. Thankfully the line or wait wasn't too long. I will certainly return the next time im in the area. They could have given a bit more broth, but the portion sizes were really filling!
author: Michelle P.
