description: If you are in the city, can't pass this place.  Super yummy and great service.  I arrived with three friends almost at closed time 10pm.  Ate fast cuz we were so hungry, and order to go.  Will come back again and highly recommended.
author: Holly K.

description:
I was so excited to see that Marugame made it to the Bay Area. I saw this in IG from one of my friends and I dropped everything and went with my husband. We went on Monday night around 8 pm and it wasn't busy at all but had a steady flow of people.  We ordered 2 large Tonkatsu Udon and A large curry udon, because I was a greedy hAngry woman. We got onion/sweet potato, shrimp and squid tempura and one potato croquette. 

My eyes were definitely bigger than my stomach. I really enjoyed the curry udon. You get to add your own toppings- green onions, cilantro and or tempura sprinkles. Since this is a far treck for us, we will frequent this place if we are in SF or the peninsula.
author: Melinda R.

description:
super great place! low price, good taste
Although it's not as good as the Marugame udon in Asia ..., still worth it to have one.
#9 is better than what I expect XD (great choose for cold noodle)
author: Wi T.

description:
I love noodles, so I didn't mind driving about 45 minutes to try their fresh udon. 

Wait time: Went on a Tuesday and waited in line for about 20-25 minutes, which wasn't too bad. 

Pricing: Paid under $30 for our meal and got a bunch of food, which I was happy about. 

Thankfully it was a sunny day, because all of the tables were taken inside. The staff was very friendly and helped me and my friend carry our trays outside. I ordered the beef udon and my friend ordered the curry udon. The portions were perfect and they didn't skimp out on the meat, but We were a little disappointed because The beef udon was too sweet and the curry udon's broth was too thick. 
The shrimp tempura was mediocre. 

Even though we didn't enjoy the flavors of our bowls we both agreed that you can taste the difference in the fresh noodles vs other udon places we have tried. I would only go back to try other flavors if I happen to be in the area and when the line isn't so long.
author: Jen O.

description:
I'd give this place 3.5 stars. Definitely need to return to try other items. 

We visited yesterday and arrived at 10:45am. There was a very long line already so highly recommend coming 30-45 minutes earlier than 11am, unless maybe they are less busy in the afternoon. We waited for about an hour. I've tried the one is Waikiki years ago but was not fond of it that time.

Food: I ordered a large beef udon with an egg. First off, a large is A LOT to finish, so I would definitely stick to a regular the next time. The broth was flavorful and the fresh udon was really good. I sprinkled a lot of their "spicy" condiment but it didn't make it spicy for me so I wish there was an option of a spicy paste, but not sriracha. The beef is a little sweet and I don't like sweet meat, but I didn't mind the beef. 

Shrimp tempura-it was not warm and crispy. Of course I should have expected that when it sits out for a while. Definitely try to pick a fresh one. 

Potato croquette-I didn't like how it's mushy inside. I've had it at other Japanese ramen restaurants and it's chunkier inside so it had more texture. Pass on this. 

I like how they have the bar of condiments because I like to pack on the greens. 

Service: Everyone was really polite and it moved as fast at it could in the line. There were a couple of employees that stood near the condiment island to assist customers. 

Price: Definitely is cheap for a bowl of udon but if you start adding in the sides, of course it will be more costly. My large udon with an egg, shrimp tempura, potato croquette and regular soda was $17. Pricey but I mean had to splurge if I'm not here often.
author: Jeanice S.

description: Oh my goodness. Reminded me of Japan!!!!  I have missed this food style since we went to Japan. Finding this place was amazing. The line was quicker then it looked. Everyone was nice and helpful. It is busy and seating is hit or miss but still, this place was great. You go in line and station to station let them know how you want your udon and if you want tempura sides. They have onigiri too. It was good. We went two nights in a row.
author: Ashley R.

description:
If it weren't for the following...
-deep fryer down (so no tempura)
-eggshell and hair found in soup bowl
-long ass line

Then marugame would be a 4. Udon/broths were really good and staff was overall friendly.  Just need to minimize the sloppiness and be ready for a long line of hungry people who expect to eat tempura with their udon!
author: Janet L.

description: Had the spicy pork  ramen. Wasnt too impressed. The food wansnt as good as I thought it could. Be. The broth soup was too salty. The ramen was not chewy enough. I think I could've gotten better ramen elsewhere. And less wait.
author: Selby C.

description:
We came to try this new place out during their soft opening and waited about an hour before we finally got to order. It's pretty amazing to be able to see your food being made in front of you, and then getting to order it right away. 

You wait in this line and basically order what you want with the guys making the udon, receive your bowl, and as you move down the assembly line, you can pick up a variety of tempura if you want. (I will say $1.90 for ONE shrimp tempura is quite hefty of a price considering it wasn't anything spectacular. It was just a good regular shrimp tempura.) Once you've finished picking all the things you want to devour, you pay for your food at the end of this assembly line and move your way onto the island of toppings. They've got green onions, cilantro, ginger, spices, and sauces for you to top your delicious hot bowl of noodle heaven. 

Since it's just a soft opening, they didn't have everything on the menu available just yet. There were about 4 of their dishes that wouldn't be available until their grand opening on Jan 18. I did order the beef udon and I will say, it was prettyyyy damn good. The thinly sliced beef was marinated in this beautiful sweet sauce, garnished with some thinly sliced onions...MMMMMMM so tender and juicy and .. you just have to try it yourself. The broth was rich in flavor yet light enough to drink the whole bowl. However, the biggest disappointment was the noodles. Now I've had freshly made udon before, and the texture is a big difference. Even though you can watch the gentlemen making the udon in front of your eyes, somehow, something tasted different. Don't get me wrong, the udon was chewy and bouncy and delicious - it just wasn't what I was expecting. Honestly, it had the same texture and look as the frozen packs of udon you get at the grocery store. Except these were exceptionally longer strands of noodz. 

I'd definitely come back though - I can't wait to try the rest of their menu!!
author: Ava F.

description: Their soup is so cold and tempura is not fresh and oily. I dont know why many ppl wait long line to eat these. I am not gonna eat udon here again. TERRIBLE
author: Esther P.

description:
Pros: Cheap meal, parking at the mall. 
Great for college students, which is the main clientele here. 

Cons: I had the Nikutama Udon with Asparagus tempura and shrimp tempura. 
The udon broth was salty, not much depth or complexity to it. 
The beef was too minced and a little reminiscent of dog food. 
Line, even at 4:30pm.

If I were in college nearby, I'd probably be there all the time. But alas, I'm 20 years out from that stage in my life and will happily pay more for superior quality food. 
Lots of young (nothing wrong with that!) lively assembly line workers here who do one thing repetitively... the result is a mass produced bowl of noodles which filled me up for like $14 total.

I much preferred the broth, beef, and noodles at Kagawa-Ya udon place in SF and Japantown SF.
author: alice a.

description: Awesome. Broth is killer, udon is killer, tempura is killer. Legit as good as most of the udon I had in Japan. Also their iced green tea is canned, but it is also super good.
author: Brett P.

description: I love foodie experiences and this is worth the trip (and the wait). You need to give it a go at least once. It's simple where you just get noods and then pick your tempura/toppings. It can get expensive (think $12+/bowl) but it's not too bad considering that I know all you azns spend $$$ on other foodie things. Don't lie to me.
author: Joshua F.

description: Beware of the long line an hour prior to opening time! Got here 30 min prior to opening and there were about 25ish people ahead of us. Before 5pm, about 100 people! The staff are friendly, love how you can pick your own sides. During soft opening, they don't have all the udon options. They make the udon in house, as fresh as it can get! But to me this place didn't blow my mind, it is comparable to Udon Mugizo in Japantown.
author: Annie Y.

description: Good! BUT where are the descriptions of the choices? The menu is so unclear and undescriptive. I didn't recognize some of the ingredients? (Marugame,Kama-age,Kake, Bukake)??? Some of us don't know what this is? I asked what type of broth choices they had and chose the pork broth which then automatically became the number 1, which I didn't want....she just made it without telling me. It had spicy sauce and half raw egg. I didn't want either of these. I just wanted a simple soup, chicken, beef, or pork broth with noodles and couldn't get anyone to help me navigate the menu. I believe most of the broths are fish based??? Couldn't really get answers as it was all so rushed...Disappointed that they just assume everyone knows what this is???
author: Halina Y.

description:
I went on a Friday at about 10 minutes before it opened and there was only a handful of people waiting.  It's cafeteria style, so we waited a few minutes for the people in front of us to order and get their food.  Got the number 1, then selected a few tempura from their selection.  
The noodles and broth were good.  The noodles were soft and chewy and the broth had a lot of flavor.  The chasu was also delicious.  The downside was the noodles and broth were not very hot though, more like a bit above room temperature.  
The tempura was not very good and also not very hot.  The batter did not have much flavor and was a bit on the thick side.  I peeled all the batter off and ate the inside.  I have had better tempura.  
If I had to wait in the long line they often have, it totally would not have been worth it.
author: Christina C.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! I always see a longgg line out the door here, so one day at 10pm I decided to go for it and hope there wasn't a long line. Success! The line moves quickly and you order a type of udon from the menu, either large or regular. The price is extremely reasonable, and you get a good amount of delicious food. I'm definitely coming back for udon, and don't even like udon that much. There's also onigiri and tempura here.
author: Olivia C.

description:
I'm...flabbergasted at how/why there is so much hype about this place. My tonkotsu udon came lukewarm and not very flavorful; it almost seemed as if the noodles and broth were taken out of the pot too soon in order to cater to all the customers in line. The egg hadn't even solidified because the broth was so cold. 

The wait was a little less than an hour long, so I was expecting a lot more from this restaurant. Giving them 2 stars for aesthetic and creative concept but I'm not coming back!
author: Shannon H.

description:
I'm so happy Marugame Udon finally has a store in San Francisco :D 

I came with my friend around 1PM on Thursday afternoon during the soft opening, man, the line was long! I convinced my friend to stay in the line and turned out it was a good wait. We waited for about 1 hour haha not bad (almost like waiting for brunch spots in SF anyway).

It's easy to order, basically, you pick a basic set up (cold/hot udon and broth), then you pick tempura as you make your way to the cashier. Then you will see an island with chopped green onions, tempura crumbles, cilantro, tempura sauce, and seasoning. Add as you like! 

Since it's soft opening, they only had 3-4 broth you can pick :( I really wanted to get the egg udon. We got Curry Udon and Beef Udon, pretty basic but it's GOOD. I'm glad we only got regular because we were too greedy when getting the tempuras haha. Be aware not to take too much tempura :P  We left with happy stomachs. Lots of opening seating which is a plus! 

2017040
author: Leslie C.

description: We waited 1.25 hours last night in two separate lines and then enjoyed our udon and sides. We ordered 3 nikutama and one egg drop. It tasted the same as I remembered in Hawaii which is great. The egg drop was surprisingly good too. The tempuras were ok, more batter than I want but I liked the musubi's. Glad they opened up a location here in the city!!
author: Minh H.

description:
3 stars for the food, +1 star for the price (of the udon only) because wow that is cheap, affordable udon. Yay!

* FOOD *

~ Udon
This review is based on the beef udon. I think their curry udon is probably a lot better. I would come back again to try that.

It was just... okay. It wasn't bad, and I guess you could say it was good, but I think this place is over-hyped. It's definitely not amazing, must-have udon. The texture of the udon is really good though, and it's not overly chewy. I wish there was more meat with the udon. The beef broth was sweet (I think it was from the onions) which was pretty interesting, and not what I expected. It nice and clear and had a refreshingly, light taste to it.

- Tempura
Too much batter, and it was cold. Imo overpriced, and not worth it for mediocre tempura.

- Musubi
Lol it's like all rice and barely any filling/topping. I got the salmon musubi ($1.60) and honestly, you can get much better onigiri from the stand in Japantown for only 65 more cents---plus there's actually some salmon in them!

* ENVIRONMENT *

tl;dr-- it's a self-serve cafeteria style place. The other reviews do a good job of describing the process.

Waited about 30 minutes in line for lunch on a weekday, which moved a lot quicker than I expected.

I did notice there was an awkward moment where there weren't any seats available for some people who just got their food. I felt kinda bad for them, but they didn't have to hover for too long.

It's not too loud and the conversations just become background noise. Hardly noticeable.
author: Melody Y.

description: This place deserves 5-stars for the quality & price. You can find the same udon soup in Japan town, but for double or even triple the price. I highly recommend the Curry Udon and smothering it with cilantro and green onions, which you can find at the condiments table.
author: Charissa S.

description:
The wait was about 20mins at around 1pm on a Saturday

I got the tonkotsu udon with fishcake and shishito pepper tempura

Once you get inside the restaurant the process is pretty fast

I'm not a big fan of udon and I prefer ramen but I thought the food here was good not amazing tho

For a 20min wait it's worth a try. 1 hour wait doesn't seem worth it to me

I likely would only come back if I happened to be in the area
author: Will Y.

description:
went for the soft opening.  it was not bad--good in a fix, but ...

(and i hate it when other people write this in their reviews)

... not as good as the other branch in hawaii.  :p

the two restaurants in hawaii taste amazingly top notch--including the variety of fried food.  

i'm hoping that the stonestown version improves and the fried foods have a great crackle and the udon tastes less soggy/weak.  i'll gladly go back to try it again because the world deserves cheap, great udon and i'm glad it's finally here in SF.
author: Philip L.

description: Very good freshly made Udon! Perfect for cold weather, but cold noodle option is even better for hot days! Good prices and very filling!! Always a line out of the door that moves by fast! Clean restaurant with toppings bar for your meal! Will be coming here often
author: Alyssa V.

description:
Yes! They finally made it to San Francisco!!!

I am obsessed with going to the one in Hawaii, so when  I heard it was coming to SF I freaked out! 

Right now it is a soft opening and the full menu is not out yet. They reserved the special broths for the grand opening. 

The LINE is LONG! It does not matter what time you go you will be waiting 45min-1 hour. It is worth all the wait!!!! 

Food! I got the beef broth and my sister got the curry. You cannot go wrong with any udon! It all tastes delicious. Most broths you can choose S or L. I usually get the L and share with those I am with. They have a toppings station where they have cilantro, green onions, extra fried tempura pieces and tempura sauces. 

I cannot wait to go back!!!!
author: Doris C.

description:
this place is great.

but less stars for getting rid of the spicy chicken udon.

the most unique, flavorful, makes-you-like-sour-spicy-sweet combo udon known to man, and they get rid of it.

it's probably the only reason i go there, and will be going less/looking less forward to going.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Ordered a large Nikutama Udon hot (#8). This place hits the spot when it comes to udon. The noodles are delicious and taste fresh, the beef is sweet and tender, the soft poached egg came out correctly, and the broth is also a little sweet. I also added some green onion and tempura flakes. All combined it creates a dish that left me satisfied and full.

First time I tried this was in LA and when I heard it came to the Bay I had go. The side dishes are over priced and average which I don't recommend. This place is worth it if you don't have to wait too long to get in. Will come back again when the cravings come.
author: Michael C.

description:
I had suddenly heard so many people speaking about this amazing new udon place where you had to wait 2 hrs for your bowl. I was so curious but wasn't willing to wait a whole 2 hrs... so I randomly decided to check this place out on a Monday at 5pm. Thankfully, the line wasn't too bad! It extended outside and wrapped around a bit but it only ended up being a 20-30 min wait. Pretty fast! 

I wasn't sure on what to order so I looked through yelp and decided on the nikutama udon while my husband ordered the curry udon. The nikutama looked like the perfect combo of light broth, good amount of meat, and a perfectly poached egg.  I was excited. We also got an assortment of tempura.. sweet potato, shrimp, veggie, and fish. All of this totaled to be $31... I was surprised at how the cost added up but I thought, hey, why not just try it all to see what it's all about. 

They had actually run out of the nikutama broth but they offered to give us a number and have it brought over to our table when it was ready. But when they brought my udon over, there was absolutely NO broth... I knew that the udon was going to have a little broth but my bowl had absolutely no broth. I thought maybe the noodles had already absorbed it... but when I tasted it, there was no broth flavor... so I asked one of the servers and they offered to bring some extra broth. Once I added the broth, it was perfect! The noodles were an excellent consistency. I love my noodles slightly chewy. The curry udon was good as well. But to be honest, while I loved the noodles, the overall taste of the udon was decent. I can't say that it was anything spectacular... but it was a good experience. My husband and I both agreed that the nikutama was better than the curry. The tempura was the same as any typical Japanese restaurant. But just a little pricier.. but we enjoyed the self serve sauce and topping station. 

I would honestly never wait more than 20 min for a bowl here. But it was a good experience so I would definitely recommend it to others.
author: Janice H.

description:
Soft opening right now with only 4 udon's to choose from and a hella long line but let this not deter you from coming here it's hella worth it! Why? Let's get started! 

What I ordered: 

Beef Udon 3x
2 vegetable nest tempura
1 squid tempura 
1 shrimp tempura

The beef udon brought me back to Jimbocho station when I was at Tokyo eating udon for the first time. Same set up and great customer service. It's can never be an exact replica of the udon at Japan but this comes close!! The broth was sooo flavorful and paired nicely with the beef that had a sweet caramelized onion flavor. Yum! It's really nice watching how your food is prepared and seeing the cooks make the dough, have the dough rise, cut the dough, and then cook it. It really makes you appreciate the udon you will be eating. The wait time is around 20-25 minutes but it's honestly so worth it!!!! I can't wait to come back on the 27 when the menu expands more!! The day I went, the tempura was nicely done. Not over battered, and nicely fried and not oily at all! After ordering your udon, getting some tempura to pair it off, that is when you pay. The squid and vegetable nest looking tempura are really good and highly suggest getting it! Now on the side is a sauce bar with all your fixings to ump the level of the already tasty udon! Their is fried tempura bits for the crunch factor, green onion, cilantro, dashi sauce, hot tempura sauce, and a cold sweet tempura sauce. The cold sweet tempura sauce pairs nicely with the chicken kaarage they have! I can't wait to review it when it fully opens. But for now, happy eating! Totally worth it!
author: Roseanne V.

description: It has been nearly two months since my best friend and I drove down from Seattle and ate here, and I'm still thinking about it. The atmosphere is nice, the prices are fair, and the udon is so amazing. We actually feel ruined for any other udon place we'll try in the future. Nothing else will ever measure up. The broths aren't too salty, the noodles are just slightly firm, and all of the tempura was crispy and delicious. Sometimes I consider driving down again just to have it.
author: Charlotte S.

description: This was my first dedicated Udon restaurant and I have to say, it was delicious!! I like how it is fresh and cooked to order, and the tempura/onigiri side bar was right after as well. The toppings bar was really helpful too, as I love being able to control how much green onion or even tempura flakes I add to my bowl. Restaurant was pretty spacious as well, with more than enough tables to accommodate. I really enjoyed the #8 hot, the sweet beef was delicious. Adding the tempura flakes with green onions and the poached egg over it all made it really enjoyable to eat. The only problem I had with my food was that the tempura chicken was nothing special. It just tasted really bland, although given it was just boneless fried chicken. Other than that, I definitely would go here again!
author: Christian P.

description:
Sigh.  Came back because family visiting from out of town insisted on trying try it.  (They were well aware of our food poisoning saga during the soft launch).  Surprisingly we were able to get in before the dinner rush and there really was not a long line at all.

This time we ordered a mix of tempura, the Tonkotsu Udon, the Thai Spicy Chicken udon, and Curry Udon.  The Tonkotsu udon was the leader of the pack.  The large bowl had two small slices of pork (which represented less meat than the photo).  The broth was good once the ginger, fried onion, and green onions were added.  The other two were overly salty.  Tempura was lukewarm but still tasty. 

Customer service from the female cashier was great, but when we asked for a cup of hot water to heat up some milk for our baby, the male kitchen staff refused to provide us with any hot water.  (Shrug). The Peet's Coffee next door was more generous.

No one got food poisoned this time and at least one of the employees was trying to provide valuable customer service.  For that, I have bumped the score up to 2.
author: Alan D.

description:
Gahhhttt dammm!!  This was some good udon.  I feel like this chain is the in-n-out of udon.  Good quality for a decent price assuming you didn't get another meal's worth of fixins.  I've been to the branches in Japan and it really felt like being back in Japan.  Is it the best udon i've ever had? Definitely not but it's definitely worth the trip if the wait time happened to be less than 30 minutes.  

I did have a caveat with the onigiri nazis yelling at me for accidentally not using tongs to grab the onigiri.  It was a mistake - no need to take my head off.  It's already wrapped in clingwrap and honestly completely unnecessary for there to be tongs to pick up onigiri.  

Other than that, people should definitely come here.  Grab yourself a bowl of udon and maybe grab a hand-warmer while you're waiting outside because it does get nipply.
author: Tony H.

description: Not crazy about the wait, came on a Thursday night around 6 pm and still waited about 45 minutes by the food made up for it! Got curry udon and my buddy got the spicy chicken one, and for the price it was such a good deal! went during soft opening so options were still limited but it's cafeteria style where you go in the line, tell them what you want, then using tongs get additional sides like the tempura. I was so full afterwards! Grand opening January 18!
author: Wendy L.

description: I had the beef udon Not that impressed. I felt like there was MSG in it! Which I haven't had in a long time. But I can still remember what it feels like ! Not bad for a quick bite to eat. I would not wait an hour in line though. Too many other options in the city
author: Heather F.

description:
Came here on a random weekday for lunch and was shocked that the line was twisting and turning everywhere! Overall, we waited about an hour... but I should have known better since it was the Soft Opening. 

I decided to go with the Beef Udon based on recommendations from friends and so happy I did. It was really tasty + the udon was chewy and delicious. 

A few downsides, that they may be working through because they're still new is that the soup is not hot enough... its barely even warm so by the time i choose my tempura, pay, and add toppings, it cooled down significantly... another, is their tempura. I was super stoked to see all the options they have, but they're all (again) cold, and not crunchy. The only one I really did enjoy was the chicken. 

Although I didn't have the best first experience, the hype got me and I'm itching to go back to try their spicy & curry.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Went during the soft opening lunch, around 1PM, this past Friday (Dec 29) and it's pretty much on par with the Hawaii branch.

Waited about half an hour in line (it goes by faster than it looks) and ordered the bukkake, regular/hot, plus 3 pieces of tempura (disappointed they didn't have mushroom ones like the Hawaii branch). It's cafeteria style with plenty of seating.

I felt at the end of my bowl that there wasn't enough soup and wish I had asked for more soup while in line. I enjoyed the shrimp and zucchini tempura but didn't really like the squid tempura. I also really like the green onion/cilantro/deep fried flakes bar, so you can put in as much as you like.

It's the kind of place where you bus the tables yourself except that there's a person who's standing by the window that you give it to and they separate everything out for you.

Given that it's a soft opening, I definitely want to try this place again especially once the full menu is available!
author: Mimi T.

description:
I honestly don't see what all the OMG was about this place. I had a few friends as me if I had come here since I work near by but, I hadn't since I usually don't leave my office fo lunch. 
I came with a friend to finally try this place which always has a line. To be honest it was ok, not worth the line or trying to fight to get a table. It's not worth all the hype. It is cheap, if you Don't get a lot of tempura which cost $1 per piece. 

I felt that the tempura was cold, when you went to eat it, it kinda fell apart. The noodles were very delicious and that's probably one of the best parts of it. If you go for the noodles I can see how everyone else enjoys it. I can say I tried it but won't be coming back.
author: Veronica V.

description: The udon is really really good. There udon is so tender and juicy along with the broth.  I don't mind waiting in line for really good udon. Heads up if you go there and there is a line, there are two separate lines. I was standing in what I i thought was the line along with 6 other people. Me and my husband were standing there for at least 5 minutes. There has been a staff member guarding the line, but she tells us after we have been waiting in front of the 1st line to go to the other line which is about 20 steps away. So meanwhile we are walking over there the 6 other people run over there and of course they are able to get there first. We lose our place in line and at that point are very disappointed that these people cut in front of us. If your going to have a staff member outside to guard the lines, make sure they are doing there job by telling people up front that there is a separate line after the 1st line. 5 stars for there food, but 2 stars for there lack of customer service and laziness to communicate with customers.
author: Judy M.

description:
The hype is real! Walking into Marugame really felt like I was walking into an udon shop in Japan because that's how I remember them when I was in Japan a couple years back. 

The soup is light but flavourful enough and the udon is the perfect mix of bouncy and chewy. Also really liked the fact that I could add all the tempura and green onion bits that I wanted! 

The option to add sides to your udon such as fried chicken or tempura is great, but it really adds up! Will definitely visit to try the other udon options!
author: Ashley L.

description: Very delicious curry udon. They have nice portion sizes and a nice selection of tempura.
author: Steven C.

description:
Went around 11am (the time it opened) on a Monday with my sister. There was already a line forming and wait time was around 30 minutes. Since it is a fairly new restaurant, I kind of expected that. It is set up like a cafeteria style. I ordered the Nikutama udon and my sister got the curry udon. Also, a side of chicken tempura. We added cilantro and tempura batter in the udon noodles.  Both were good. I personally would get the curry udon next time. The noodles are freshly made. I ate similar concept like this in Waikiki, Hawaii and the broth there was much more flavorful. I do recommend checking it out.
Ps google the word "bukkake" mean on urban dictionary. ;)
author: Ly L.

description: Love the fresh udon! I'm not even a fan of noodles as it's all carbs in my option, but I can finish a whole bowl of udon here. Was a big fan of the Honolulu location and now I'm so glad we have this one in SF!
author: Sharon Z.

description:
Located near Trader Joe's at Stonestown Mall. Visited this place during the soft opening. The line zigzagged out the door but was moving. We waited about 30 minutes before we reached the inside to order. It's just like the Marukame Udon in Waikiki where you order cafeteria style. Some of the options weren't available since it was still soft opening, but I ordered my usual curry udon. It's intriguing how they make the noodles fresh right in front of you! 

Basically, you grab a tray, tell them your order, they prepare it for you, grab any additional sides you want (shrimp or vegetable tempura, onigiris, croquettes, etc), and then pay. They also have a little topping bar where you can add green onion, tempura flakes, tempura sauce, chili flakes, utensils, etc. 

It was just as good as the location in Hawai'i, but my only gripe is that they don't offer the soft boiled egg in the curry udon. :( Definitely worth the trip over the bridge though!
author: Michelle C.

description: I've come here like 5 or 6 more times since my last review. The lines are still long, but less crazy than when it first opened. Even though this place is still great most of the time, it's been inconsistent for me. I sometimes order the Nikutama Udon, and twice it was so salty I couldn't eat that much. I think I'll just stick to the beef udon now and order an egg on the side.
author: Cynthia M.

description: My favorite place after my Monday and Tuesday walk. Big servings and the price is just right.
author: Grace S.

description: Yummy udon! My favorite place to get udon. The udon itself is rather a good price, but once you add on the tempuras you want.... that's when it gets expensive!!
author: Tiffiny C.

description:
The more I eat here the harder for me to understand the long line every day​ in front of this Udon restaurant. 

Anyone with Diabetic and cholesterol​ issue or someone who is receptive to these health issues it's wise to stay away from this place.

Once we lose our health it's hard to recover.​
author: Piano B.

description:
Overall solid but with room for improvement. Yes, I don't think it is as good as Marukame on Oahu. Here's why: quality control.

I've been here twice. First time there was a short line (10 minutes?) and the noodles were better than average dried noodles, but I could tell that they had been sitting in the post-cooking water bath for too long so the texture was a little bit off. Also, the green onions are really thick cut which is not what I expect from a Japanese restaurant and it is also not what is in the menu photos. Lastly, my tempura was cold. I thought maybe I had caught them on an off day so I withheld judgement.

3 weeks later I am back. This time, no line! Noodles were better but the broth was way too hot and I had to wait a long time to let it cook. My bowl also seemed to be overloaded with broth so it was hard to carry. And the onions and tempura were the same story as last time.

So yeah, better than average but not what it could be, either.
author: Katies F.

description: I usually order regular, hot Bukake udon (no.4) with one veggie tempura (FYI: The one I got in the picture is large beef udon, not Bukake). For small eaters like me, I would say regular size udon plus one tempura are good enough. The menus are mostly affordable (less than $10) but be aware that if you add a couple of tempuras, the total would easily exceed $20. The line is not that long, about 10-15 min, compared to when they first opened.
author: Antony L.

description:
If you come here thinking that you are getting good udon, you are wrong. Came here on 5/1/18 @ 7:00PM, and spent the rest of the night trying to get over food poisoning. 

First and last time visiting this place. Just upon my arrival, watching the employees work the line, I knew food safety protocols are not being followed. They are dumping the fresh noodles in to a sitting bath of water that is room temperature at best. That is not the way to properly stall the cooking of udon noodles.

Additionally, handling of the cracking of the eggs and then using the same gloves to touch the noodles and the utensils for the beef and the broth is absolutely unacceptable.

They need a food safety manager to come in and inspect this joint anonymously, because I saw way too many issues with food safety, but I still ate it; and paid the price as well.

Don't think the Hawaii and Los Angeles locations would overlook such food safety issues. This place can/will continue to make people ill.
author: Brent O.

description:
Marugame Udon knows how to manage a large crowd. It's a cafeteria styled udon restaurant. You order, buy, then find your own seating to eat your udon. Marugame offers affordable and delicious udon. I understand the hype and why it's crowded so often. They also offer fried tempera, from shrimp, fish, to egg tempera.

I ordered the number 2, nikutama hot regular. It was not a soup, but more like oil base. It was delicious and flavorful. It was enough to get stuffed. I would definitely come to Marugame again!
author: Kelly L.

description: I been to multiple marugame  in the US and in other countries. For some reason, this place wasn't as good as other locations. They took too long making their udon when they have a lot of staff. The menu was also a little bit different. The day I went their fryers were broken, so they didn't have tempura. Maybe I'll give this location one more shot, since it's the only location in the Bay Area.
author: Carissa M.

description:
First of all: The line may seem long but it moves quickly, about 30-45 min. 
Second of all: In my opinion, the udon is fairly good. I prefer the curry udon over the house special udon because it has more broth, but it is all to preference. The real stars of the show here, however are the side orders (potato croquette and chicken tempura being favorites). Though sides are pricy, if you bring a fair amount of cash you'll have a good time.
author: Simone E.

description:
Because when a new restaurant opens and everyone is posting about it on Facebook, you have to come check it out, right? Came here today for lunch around noon and there was already a long line, wait was about a half hour. It is currently their soft opening, so as of 12/27/17, the udons they are offering are the Kama-Age udon, curry udon, Kake udon, beef udon, and Bukkake udon. I have never been to the one in Hawaii, so I don't have the original to compare it to, but I enjoyed it nevertheless! You order your udon in line and they instantly prepare it for you, then you move down the line and it's self-serve for all the fried goodies (potato croquette, shrimp tempura, chicken tempura, vegetable kakiage, fishcake tempura, squid tempura, etc) and musubis (crab meat, mentai mayo, salmon, tuna mayo). Then you pay for your order and head over to the toppings section, which includes ginger, green onions, cilantro, and tempura crunchies. There is also a variety of sauces - dashi sauce, sweet tempura, original tempura. 

Beef udon ($7.90 regular, $8.90 large) - good udon texture that is bouncy with a great clear flavorful broth, beef was soft and somewhat sweet but not overly so
Curry udon ($6.90 regular, $7.90 large) - same great udon texture with a light pungent curry soup, soft beef that absorbed the curry flavor
Shrimp tempura ($1.90 each) - shrimp was fresh and had a nice crunch upon biting into it. The staff was frying the tempura right as we were going through the line and it was fried beautifully - amazingly light and crispy.
Salmon flake musubi ($1.60 each) - rather disappointing as there was only less than a spoonful of salmon at the top and barely any throughout, so the whole thing lacked flavor. I did like how there was some fish roe in the salmon flakes though.

Now on to service - amazing. Everyone who was working there was very friendly, from the people serving the udon to the ones helping to seat customers. I didn't open my eyes wide enough and couldn't find the cups for water (and of course I failed to look at the area right next to the drink machine, because who would think to look there?? :P), and as I was looking very lost, one of the workers named Mark immediately asked how he could help me. Later on, my 4yo nephew was standing in front of the drink machine and obviously couldn't reach, so Mark asked him what he wanted and helped him get his half Coke Zero/half Sunkist drink concoction. He was very helpful and definitely exhibited what good service looks like!

Great food (minus the musubi), reasonable prices, wonderful service, convenient location - I'll be back after their January 18th grand opening!
author: Nicole M.

description:
I was excited to find out this opened nearby since I had enjoyed the udon I had in Hawaii.

I finally had a chance to try it this week. I came at around 230pm on Monday and waited about 20 min to order. 

It took another 10 min to go down the tempura line, pay for my items and add any complimentary add-ons before sitting down. 

I had the beef udon (Reg $7.90)with 1 piece of shrimp tempura ($1.90). The fresh udon was the perfect texture. There was a good portion of sweet beef. The meal was quite satisfying. 

It is an ideal place for people eating solo or in small groups because of the cafeteria/food court setting.
author: Angela M.

description:
Came around 1 pm and the line had about 30 people in front of me, the line surprisingly moved fast. Had the number 4 beef, the broth was delicious and so were the noodles. The wait was definitely worth it. Everything tasted fresh, the service was excellent as well my meal was under $12 with two added sides. My only "complaint " or suggestion is on the massubi it hardly had any salmon. 
I will definitely be back.
Don't be discouraged by long lines it really moves fast.
author: Imelda G.

description:
Get here early or else you'll be in line for quite awhile.. On the flip side, there's seats available since the line moves slowly.

The large bowl was a good size, I would recommend getting 2-3 tempura addons if you were getting the large bowl. Do not try to fill up the extra plate with tempura thinking that you will finish it.

The udon and tempura both are good but it's hard to eat a lot of it. You will probably get tired of eating the fried tempura midway through the meal. You'll probably start feeling a bit thirsty from the soup and the tempura.. So the food is A-ok. Not extraordinary.
author: Aaron H.

description: The food here is subpar. A good change for students eating campus food. However, if you are looking for authentic Japanese food... you won't find it here. This cafeteria style set up and contemporary environment is uncommon if not rare in Japanese restaurants. Truthfully the food at mitasuwa is better than this. In addition, the tempura is overly battered, and oily. The soup base is very salty and they don't give a lot of soup to mix with the starchy noodles. However, I will say that there was great customer service despite the average food.
author: Patricia T.

description:
Will be back again soon when their full menu is available! They are currently in soft opening until 1/18/18 which I'm glad to see that they are taking the time to make their operation smooth and dining a great experience. Already I can see the attention to detail to the food and service! Please keep it up, it's the little things that matter!

Udon is made fresh in front of you as you wait in line and order and the thickness and texture is on point! We got the beef udon and the broth is perfect, beef is delicious and sweet with caramelized onions. After you order your choice of udon and broth, go down the line and choose the sides you want - a good variety of tempura and musubi options. 

To get a taste of what they have to offer, I tried the tempura fish cake, squid and shrimp. The shrimp surprisingly was not memorable but fish cake and squid are larger than expected portions and pretty tasty! Next time I'll just pick my fav 1-2 because it was pretty filling.

Tried the crab and salmon musubi options too, which were ok. There was a greater rice to fish proportion than I prefer but let's be honest, we're all here for the udon so I'm not mad about that.

Finally, after you've loaded up your tray of food and paid, pick up toppings of green onion and cilantro to your liking (or not) and get tempura sauce. I personally like the lighter one in the hot thermos that you pump out over the thicker squeeze bottle option.

In the end, we were so full and satisfied and forgot that we are merely at Stonestown. Marugame, you have stepped it up and I hope you keep serving us amazing udon and excellent service here in the neighborhood!
author: Holly H.

description: We waited for about 20 minutes to be seated, and all the queues moved fast The noodles are chewy The sauce was tasty not salty The beef has a sweet tang to it but not overpowering or bland At the lunch hour, the tempura was being freshly made so we got the fresh batch. The batter was light, crunchy, just enugh to coat the food and the meat was tender
author: T B.

description: I tried the regular spicy Chicken Udon during one of their soft openings and it was delicious. The portions are decently big or at least for me. I had some tempura sides it was pretty good. The staff were nice and friendly. It was cafeteria style, but I was glad they put directions on how to order. I can't wait for the full menu.
author: Elaine D.

description:
Not enough soup in bowls! 
The noodles are good however I don't like how they give you a small amount of soup so by the time you sit down after waiting for others in front of you to finish picking out toppings and paying, the noodles have already soaked up what little amount of soup there was! MARUGAME please consider giving more soup because there is still a long wait period between getting the noodles and sitting down to eat!
author: Jennifer C.

description: I had the udon with tofu and added an egg. Also, I had fried tamago and shrimp tempura.  My friend had the beef udon and fried potato. We both enjoyed our meal very much. The food was fresh and delicious. While the line can be long, don't be intimidated. I was impressed they were able moved the line pretty quickly. I highly recommend it. The food and customer service was excellent.
author: Viv C.

description:
We made the cut for the soft opening lunch (ends at 3pm). There was a bit of a wait, but it is a cafeteria style, which makes the line/wait go faster. Plus you get to choose the topping tempuras, which is also a fun experience, and very delicious. My favorite was the veggies and the squid :)

I love their noodles! And udon noodles were freshly made right in front of you eyes! So happy there is this location near me, and definitely be coming back!
author: holly n.

description: Ouuuuuu!!! Best udon place EVER!!! Gets busy most of the time. The Udon is very cheap and you can also get a bunch of different appetizers that are a bit pricey but not that much. Depends on you lol. Workers are very nice and the place is really clean. After you get your udon you can add in some stuff they have on the bar. Which has green onions, cilantro, and some fried stuff. Forgot what they were called. But I really recommend coming here very worth it!
author: Kevin L.

description: Great authentic udon in the Stonestown shopping mall! I came here with a friend on a Friday at around 11:30am and there was a line outside, but it went by quickly. This is a cafeteria-style restaurant, meaning you order in a line, and pay at the end, since there's many add-ins/sides that you can get as well! I got the nikutama udon (#2), which comes with udon (freshly made!!), beef, and a soft-boiled egg. My friend got the beef udon, and her portion was definitely bigger (maybe twice my size? even though we both ordered regular sized), and the only main difference between our dishes was the egg and higher price of mine. There's also tempura that you can add on to the side, but I opted for the salmon onigiri, which was a little salty for me. At the end, you can also add toppings (tempura flakes!!) to your dish to spice it up. Overall, the udon was delicious and there's a good amount of sides, but I would definitely want to try another flavor/dish.
author: Lisa C.

description: I enjoyed my visit to Marugame Udon. It's one of few places that were around that still had food. The workers were great and had a pretty good sense of humor. Marugame Udon's udon is perfect late night food. The atmosphere is great for solo eaters or groups. I ordered their fish roe udon. The ingredients were simple, but so yummy.
author: Tabitha H.

description: First time here, and everything was good noodles were great, broth had flavor and the tempura was crispy! They have toppings that you can put into your soup like green onions and cilantro. And you pick which tempura sides you want.
author: Jonathan M.

description: I have been trying to try this place out since it opened but each time I passed by the line was ridiculously long and my husband hates waiting. Finally got to try this place during a weekday after lunch time, there was still a line outside but not as long as the other days I've seen. When you first walk in, you see the employees making fresh udon and washing it out I am guess. The menu was slim pickins but I decided to go for the curry udon and my husband decided to go for the beef udon. As lined up to order, I feel that the udon portions were pretty much the same for a large bowl vs a regular bowl, so your basically paying more for the soup?  That is not the case, since I saw a few large bowls the soup wasnt that much and it didnt look appealing at all. I finally got to where you can get the add-ons and very very disappointed on what they provided. I got a few tempura items, ( shrimp, veggies and mixed veggies). I was very disappointed in the tempura items, the mixed veggies was basically just fried onion, and the rest of the tempura had too much batter and it was luke warm not even hot. Now for the udon part, the curry soup base was too thick for my liking AND it was very very salty, so it seems like the soups there are sitting there all day and they just add new soup on top, and the beef broth at first looked really plain didnt look like beef broth at all, but after trying it, it was VERY salty as well. The only thing I probably liked was the udon.. but I def had  better. All in all this was def overrated and people made this place sound like a must try, I was not impressed and probably wont be coming back because shortly after both my husband and I ended up with stomach aches.  I guess one star for the good customer service, but seriously the food was not great at all.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Fitting, my favorite food as my first review! I took others' advice and went during lunchtime on a weekday, the wait was merely a half hour. As soon as you enter the doorway, you're immediately hit with an irresistible concoction of bubbling udon pots and the savory smell of simmering broth. Being able to watch the cooks make, chill, and measure out udon noodle portions was extremely satisfying while waiting in line to place your order. I was torn between many of the menu selections, but ended up choosing the Kake Udon with an added poached egg. I also couldn't resist and picked out an Inari and Mentai Mayo Musubi.

After adding a criminal amount of green onion, tempura flakes, and ginger to my bowl, I dug in...and was overall really satisfied! The flakes provided great texture, the toppings were fresh and made the broth taste delightfully complex with each mouthful. Although the noodles were nice and chewy when I first started eating, they soon became somewhat soggy, perhaps a bit faster than I expected? The inari was well-balanced- the sweet bean curd covering really complemented the vinegar-y rice inside. I, sadly, could not finish the mentai mayo musubi as the flavor ended up being too strong and fishy for my liking.

Overall, a great addition to the Stonestown area! However, I am not sure if I would wait in line for more than a half hour to get it again.
author: Natalie L.

description:
I have been here a bunch of times since it opened. The line is still pretty long just as when they first opened! Trying coming on an off peak time. During lunch/dinner the lines get pretty long.

I have tried the Nikutama Udon, Beef Udon, and Curry Udon! All of them are very good. They make the noodels fresh right in the front. My favorite now has to be the Nikutama Udon! 

The prices are relatively cheap. Under $10

The tempura and musubi are extra $$ but definitely taste good! I also go for the veggie one and shrimp tempura. Great place for udon with ample seating!
author: Daniel S.

description: Fairly average, I don't get the hype about this place. I got the curry udon which I thought was a bit salty, same with the beef udon my boyfriend got. The only thing I did enjoy was the tempera bar, it's a really creative idea and it was still nice and crispy. The variety was also great. It's not a "you need to try or you'll be missing out" type of place but I guess the experience of having a bowl of udon made right in front of you is kind of cool.
author: Teta C.

description: Just ok. 15 min wait was fine. Any longer would not have been worth it. Honestly there are better udon places in J town but understand the buzz around a well known chain.
author: Patrick Z.

description:
I really can't find the words; this place doesn't need them really!

All I really have to say is Kevin, the assistant manager, deserves all the recognition for our first time. It was a brief moment in meeting him but he made it such a great experience. Oh, and the food is absolutely amazing, just go try it, y'all!
author: Elena C.

description: Delicious udons. Highly recommend beef udon. Musubis are decent. The line moves pretty fast.
author: Elli L.

description:
I absolutely love the flow of the restaurant and how it functions! Upon entering you grab a tray and let the person behind the counter know what type of udon bowl you want (menu number, size, hot/cold), then you slide on down until you get your udon, and cross paths with the (cheap/super affordable) side dishes! There's a good variety to choose from and all less than $3!

I wanted to try everything on the menu, but ultimately decided on the #8 Mentai Kamatama Udon (L) ($6.90) and for my sides I grabbed the Vegetable Kakiage ($1.70), and Crab Meat Musubi ($1.40). It was super filling and delicious!

The udon is made fresh and you can watch them make it when you pass by or walk in. And if you do walk in you're greeted by the person prepping the udon followed by the rest of the staff behind the counter! I appreciate the friendliness of the staff and the great customer service they provide. I'll be coming back to try other items on the menu since!


**PRICING: $ (everything is less than $10!)**
author: Nicole C.

description: cheap, good taste, clean!! this is japanese quaulity!! now i don't have to eat udon everytime back to japan..american udon culture "udon with ciantro( opptional) "should export to japan like california roll!!
author: えりか

description:
The tempura station was down. The employee working outside said there'd be a free gift at the register because there's no tempura, but there wasn't. Sad.

There's a new tonkotsu flavor (#1), but the broth is not spicy as advertised, and it tasted watered down. The char siu was yummy though.

They've gotten faster at food prep, but that's probably because the tempura station was down.
author: Jackie L.

description: This place tastes just like the spot in Hawaii! Been here a couple of times already and it always hits the spot. The only downside is the wait, which is outside, and since it's SF it gets pretty cold so be prepared! Udon is super fresh and deliciousssss. The COLD nikutama is a must try!!!!
author: Tracey N.

description:
Soup was not hot. 
Tempura was delicious. 
Too long line for wait. Took 2 hrs to be seated.
author: Hyemin O.

description: Great place to grab a quick bite but unfortunately that is not the case here is SF since you might wait up to an hour to just get into the door. I am pretty sure all the Japanese is laughing their ass off to see ppl actually line up to eat here... it's like whenever I see ppl waiting outside PF Chang's for Chinese food I ask myself why? There are so many other places serve so much better Chinese food... anyway give it a try when there is no wait.
author: William C.

description:
Full disclosure: My husband and I have been to Japan multiple times and enjoy Japanese noodles often. 

Wow! The rest of the reviewers must have NEVER had udon in Japan or they're just novelty food whores. The tempura alone should have knocked these ratings down. 

My husband and I decided to try this because we had to pick up from the Apple store that evening. We stood in the line and got inside relatively quickly. We ordered two different types of udon, grabbed a few tempura pieces and breezed past the condiment bar with no problem. 

Whew had to clean our own table to sit down but didn't mind. We understand they're busy. 

However, we could not forgive the quality of the food.  The noodles were alright in texture but the broth/dipping sauce was either too sweet or taste less! The beef was full of fat and tendon. The soft boiled egg was the only thing that seemed right in my dish. 

Do not eat the tempura.  I have never had tempura so thickly covered in batter and drenched in oil. Some pieces were cold when we bit into it. Instead of light and crispy, this was doughy and cold. Some pieces were completely batter. Gross!  

Bottom line: If you're a mindless lemming who enjoys long lines and cafeteria style dining, you will enjoy this experience.  If you've ever made your own fresh or instant udon at home or have had udon in Japan, save your self the sever disappointment. 

With all the great Japanese places in the city, I'm honestly shocked at the good reviews people have given. I haven't checked the demographics of the reviewers. Maybe they're all young and naive? In any case ... Beware. Yelp is not always honest.
author: Marie L.

description:
I got the Curry Udon and my bf got the beef udon and I wish I had gotten the beef udon as well because although the curry Udon was delicious the flavors and spices were too strong for me. :) 

As for the musubis overall, flavorful but so full of rice :'(
author: Alison L.

description: The line is long around lunch hours, so expect to have a lot of time in your hands if your going around that time, the expected time of wait is around 45 mins during these hours. The tempura (varieties of tempuras ranging from vegetables, squid, chicken, etc) is around 2$ each if you wanna get it as a side with your choice of udon. Overall, its a good place to eat and a "bang for your buck".
author: Martel B.

description: The Udon is good but not as good as the Honolulu location. The tempura was soggy so if I come can here, is only get the Udon. The prices are also $2 more or bowl than Honolulu :( lines get long here. I came here early so the wait was only 5 minutes. I guess the wait isn't bad considering how the cafeteria service makes everything more efficient.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: So delicious!! The line seems to be endless but goes down pretty quickly. Idk if they make their own noodles there but it was nice and chewy, the broth was flavorful and the tempuras were perfectly fried!! For the price it was definitely worth the wait. I had the beef udon cuz they were out of tonkotsu, I liked it and I will go back to try the tonkotsu!
author: Joanne B.

description:
Very good

When I lived in Korea, I often went to here near Gangnam station. I like this store in San Francisco, too.
author: Seungho B.

description: Fairly cheap for a large bowl of noodles and soup. I was definitely full after eating here. I ordered the Nikutama Udon (beef and egg). The base of the noodles is a sauce, so the dish itself was quite salty. The next time I go here I will probably order the Beef Udon, which is a soup base. Other than the sodium level, the rest of the dish was delicious. The beef was flavorful and paired well with the sweet onions. The udon noodles tasted fresh and were the perfect texture. I really liked how the green onions, cilantro, and tempura flakes were free and unlimited. I used a sauce cup to carry the tempura flakes to prevent them from getting soggy when walking to a table. I also ordered the potato croquette as a topping. The outside batter was light and crunchy. It was great to dip with the sauce in the noodles.
author: Mina T.

description: Union is great and matched the level in their Japan locations. However, The fried items are not as good as their stores in Japan. Also, you have to be ready to wait. We were there around nine pm and still waited for about 30 mins. Overall, because of the fresh iron, we will visit again but probably won't get so many fried items; just larger portion of noodle.
author: Shannon C.

description: Amazing simple udon at a very good price!! I can eat this everyday :) the noodles are handmade and the line moves very quickly. My only complaint is that we can't put our own onions and tempura flakes. In Japan, you can add as much as you like. Here, they are not as generous about it.
author: H T.

description:
It is just a fast-food Udon place. Don't expect too much. Tempura and Udon are all tasty, good lunch option for shoppers in Stones town.
I would prefer to be there again only when the waiting line is shorter.
author: John Z.

description:
My first experience at Marugame was negative! I do not deny that they provided a good service, and the staffs were nice. My mother and I ordered two bowls of udon,  a large Nikutama and a regular curry beef. Also, we grabbed some tempura and two masubi. I was so excited to try all the food. However, the broth was sooooooooo salty, and I have been drinking water for a whole day. Plus, the tempura was cold and too oily.

Some people think that the one in Hawaii is better, and I will probably try it again in Hawaii. Definitely, we will not come back here.
author: Irene F.

description: A coworker suggested this place and wow I love it! It's like udon chipotle style, where you order your main dish with a food tray and pick out the tempura or other side dishes and pay at the end. Initially I was very worried about finding a seat as the line was out the door and there was limited seating indoors. But the line wasn't super fast moving so by the time we cashed out more seats were available. We ordered the curry udon and the beef udon. Both were delicious! The beef udon didn't have a lot of broth so I'd suggest you getting a different type of udon if you want broth
author: Nina Y.

description:
Omg people. If you're just gonna complain that it's not as good as the one in Hawaii then don't come here. just go to the one in Hawaii instead!!!

So grateful that the best udon in the Bay Area has opened here. Everything we ate here was delicious and affordably priced. Definitely worth the wait.

One thing to note is that the broth could be warmer but overall I still left completely satisfied and happy customer.
author: Veronica T.

description: Every time I go to stonestown the line is always out the door for this place. I was eating at blaze pizza the day this place opened and they had Disneyland long lines it was insane. You have to go here early before dinner unless you don't mind waiting an hour or longer. And weekends forget about it. 5 months after opening I finally went here when there was hardly a line and I ordered the beef udon and shrimp tempura. Its cafeteria style where you wait in a line to pick your udon and the size bowl then you grab a tray and pick up any additions that are already cooked like the different kinds of tempura and sushi. They have a separate table for sauces as well. The beef was ok but I would come back here again and probably try the tonkatsu udon. It looks pretty damn delicious. The tempura was really tasty too.
author: Dianne E.

description: I happened to pass by the place after a trip to the mall and saw that there was a line for this restaurant so I decided to give the place a try. Even though the line was out of the store, the wait wasn't too long. The store is like a chipotle style assembly line for udon. The price is pretty cheap ranging from $4.5 to around $8 depending on what you get.   The store inside was fairly clean and has a nice aesthetic. I would definitely come again and recommend to others!
author: Kiki K.

description: We decided to give this place a try since it is near my son's apartment. There is usually a line but it went pretty quick for us. The noodles were handmade in front of us and we found the process fascinating. The bowls are made to order - what type of broth and do you want them hot or cold. The prices are very reasonable even if you decide to add sides to your order. Each of us had a different type of broth and we enjoyed all of them. The udon/noodles are both delicious and filling!
author: Pamela S.

description:
4 stars for the tasty tonkatsu broth, minus 2 stars for the explosive diarrhea 10 minutes afterward. Maybe the bukkake wouldn't have been as bad as it sounds.....

Place is odd, long waiting pen outside like it's some sort of Disneyland ride. Or the way they slaughter cows. There's a menu near the beginning of the line, with no explanation about what they are doing. It's also woefully incomplete. You get INSIDE the door and there's another (incomplete) menu. You walk a ways and there's yet a third incomplete menu, but enough to get your soup order started. Cafeteria trays, they give you soup and maybe a RAW chicken (!) egg (supposed to be "soft boiled," but nope). Afterwards there's a bunch of tempura items that suddenly appear, with a price below them. Mostly around $2, you ask the worker and they say the price is for three pieces. But you get to the register and learn no- it's PER PIECE. Mixed vegetables tempura order could set you back $10-15 easy. There's some rice wraps near the end too. You pay and then there's an island with green onions, cilantro, sauces and a single little can of pepper. Also some plastic tableware. 

 Was it a repeater? Nope. Even without the diarrhea it doesn't measure up to most ramen places around, and you can get some damn good udon all over town. It's cute to see all the Chinese staff yelling out Japanese phrases, maybe that's more Disneyland stuff, but overall I'll visit here about as often as I visit Olive Garden next door, i.e. not ever.
author: T J.

description:
Marugame management,

Please have hot water available to be able to dilute your salty soup. I have never had to do it in Japan, but you're too arrogant to think that this is not necessary here. Both HNL and SFO have this problem. 

The second exit, should be kept shut but employees kept going out of there on a cold day, when my chair was right in front of the door because they try to fit three big tables on the side. When all three tables are occupied, it's impossible to fit all of that without blocking the door. If it's required by the fire code, just get rid of one table. 

---------

I am happy that Marugame came to San Francisco.
author: Jorge T.

description: I like the concept but the meal is overall pretty heavy. You would think the prices are pretty cheap until you keep adding on the sides and then you realize your one bowl of udon costs about $20. This place is good for a quick bite to eat but I don't think it's the best udon ever. I do appreciate seeing the process of the noodles being made but I think the broth lacks in flavor. The soup is quite sweet and they are pretty skimpy with the meat. I would come again if I was in the area but I don't think it's worth the drive over.
author: Serena C.

description:
looking forward to some great udon.  advertised closes at 10PM.
showed up 8:45PM with girlfriend after some birthday shopping at the mall and sign on door reads closing early for staff meeting at 9PM.  
oh great, we made it anyways.  however, we were turned away because they started cleaning up already.   showed them the clock, but they refused service.  
don't think i wanna try this place anymore, nor would i recommend.
author: TIGGER P.

description:
I've got 99 problems but this place ain't one!!!!!!!!!!

This is the same chain as Marukame in Oahu. If you've never been here before, its cafeteria style udon with sides of tempura + musubis!!!!!!!!

If its your first time here and you don't know what to get, the Beef Udon (same Niku Udon from Oahu location)!!!!! Don't forget to add the egg!!!!!!! 

If you can't decide between two- just get both! LOL The line is so long and a regular udon goes for like $5 to $8!! Just YOLO it and get both especially if you waited 1+ hours in line LOL 

The only sad thing is they don't have spam musubis here. Also their musubis aren't so flavorful and has a really high rice to "topping" ratio. You could probably skip out on those unless you love rice lol.
author: Fiona D.

description: Tried the one in Hawaii Waikiki and wanted to give this one a try. Went around 3-4pm-ish and there was no line. Unlike the Waikiki shop where they ask and place for optional toppings for you, there was a little bar for you to place green onions or fried tempura on top of your udon.
author: Diana N.

description:
I actually only ate here because I got out of the gym at 9 pm and literally the dozens of other chain restaurants were closed. I can never get over how early this city is. I would like to say that because it was past 9 pm, there was no wait whatsoever. 

This place is very casual but had traditional wooden/bamboo like decor, which I liked. You pick from an array of udon, tempura, and onigiri (rice balls) and each item is very inexpensive, be careful not to go too ham! 

There are options for vegans and vegetarians which is cool. It was my first time here so I got way too much: a regular bukake (dont giggle, it means splash. Ok i get it even that is lol) udon with a poached egg, some tempura, an onigiri and an inari sushi (its a type of vegetarian sushi made with fried tofu skin and it is amazing). The inari was bomb as it literally always is, because its so unami (savory); the udon was very good udon but the poached egg was almost raw so if that freaks you out then avoid it, the tempura was very standard and the onigiri was also very standard. If you aren't craving tempura or onigiri, I would skip it. But the cool thing is you can see them make everything in front of you, so if you see a freshly fried tempura, you might want to try it. 

Some people just can't see udon as a delicious experience the same way they see ramen or soba. Udon is its own experience, so if you like it, this is a good rendition. This won't change your mind if you are an udon hater.
author: Crystal Y.

description: Came here during around 12:20pm, waited only about 15 minutes in line (since the hype 3 months ago, there is no more waiting like 30+ min in line) Got a hot large number 2, and it was pretty good! The udon was very soft and you can see the workers make them fresh, while you are in line. Before you order, you grab a tray, and a small dish. The smaller dish is where you can self serve pick diff types of tempura, or sushi rolls. I picked a fishcake tempura, which was an extra like 1.80, so total price was $12.15. Pretty affordable! It doesn't end there, because there is another self serve area, where you can pick green onions, cilantro, ginger, and regular tempura sauce, and sweet tempura sauce. Plenty of seating inside, and close to SFSU. Right by stonestown if you need to do shopping as well. Just return your trays when you are finished. Compost and trash bins are right in front of the tray return area.
author: Kyle H.

description:
Finally went here since there was a lot of hype and I wanted to give it a try.

I definitely felt it is a little overhyped, but the food is good and the price decent. The musubi that they had were not the best according to my sister and friend that went with me, but I definitely liked the curry udon that I received. The potato croquette was pretty good as well. The staff are pretty friendly, but this is more cafeteria-style, so there isn't really much interaction or anything. 

If there's a long line, I probably wouldn't wait. The line was too long, but we waited about 15-20min. The seating can be difficult as well since it's free seating, so finding a table for 3 was a little awkward. 

Food: 4/5
Staff: 4/5
Atmosphere: 2/5
Value: 5/5
Overall: 3.75/5
author: Evan K.

description:
Came in at 930pm on a Thursday and waited around 10-15 mins. Gf ordered #2 and they were super stingy on giving extra soup out. I had the curry udon, which I could've sworn came with beef but I literally got one slice while she had a whole sac of beef for hers. Most likely not coming back.

Curry comes with 1 small slice of beef
author: Benson W.

description: Waited almost an hour for dinner on a Saturday around 5:30pm .. was willing to give it a try since I've heard so many great things about this place. The staff is well trained and very polite. The concept of this place is very cool. It's like an assembly line for udon. You pick whatever udon you want, choose additions, and pay at the end! They also have a self serving condiments and utensils area. To my surprise, finding a table after paying wasn't difficult at all. I got the beef udon, and my boyfriend got the curry udon. We both added extra tempura items and rice balls at the end. My beef udon was just ok. The soup was too sweet and salty at the same time. After awhile it got overwhelming for my taste buds, and I had to gulp down a whole cup of water. My boyfriend didn't really like his curry udon either. I stole a bite from his and wasn't impressed. The udon noodles were great though! It was cooked perfectly and had a firm but not hard texture to it. Decent price for a meal at the mall but really not worth the long wait in the cold.
author: Nancy C.

description:
Once you've figured out if you're waiting in a line to ride something at Disneyland, or if you're trying to get some udon, you'll enter into a precise udon machine ready to take your simple but delicious order.

After eating here a few times, nearly everything is always available. Once I heard they didn't have any chicken ready in the middle of the lunch hour. Not sure how they weren't prepared, considering chicken is a go to easy option for people not so easily ready to engage on flavor towns train.

The basic using is dependable, the curry udon is delectable, and the egg drop udon is unsurprisingly delicious if you enjoy such a soup. The accompanied accoutrements are all worth obtaining. I myself go for fried shoestring vegetables, some shrimp, and a hidden gem people may pass by is the octopus. 

Last stop in the human udon machine, Marugame, is the free stuff bar! Who doesn't want free? 
More crispy bits. Free
Some sauce for your finger foods. Free
A little extra herbs and onions. Free

So, stop on by this well oiled machine, but do remember that this isn't a Disneyland ride you're waiting for... Waiting in line should be the only thing you'll be disappointed with, unless that's a life long goal. Enjoy
author: Brandon W.

description: My roommate took me here to eat on my first day moving out here in SF. I was quite surprised to be eating such delicious food, not that I thought it was going to be gross I'm just not as hyped about eating food out here like a lot of people are, if that makes sense? Anyways, I got the number 8 and oh my gosh it was so good! I'd definitely would recommend eating here to anyone who's in the mood for Asian food :)
author: Leslie M.

description:
I tried this place out at 2pm on a Thursday, so luckily, there wasn't much of a line.  And the line moved rather quickly.  

I ordered a large beef udon to share with my toddler, but was given a regular size.  Since I had never tried Marugame before, or the one in Hawaii, I didn't know the difference.  I also sampled one tempura shrimp and one tempura asparagus.  

Honestly, the food itself was good.  The beef was a little fattier than I preferred, but the noodles were nice and chewy.  The broth was sweet, yet savory.  It was the perfect complement...a warm bowl of noodle soup on a chilly day.  The tempura was also light and crispy, which surprised me since I wasn't sure how long it had been sitting out.  I loved the condiments bar as well, where you can top your bowl of noodles with as much cilantro, green onions and tempura bits as you like.
    
What really blew me away was the service!  I was a bit nervous...how was I going to hold my toddler's hand with one hand and my tray full of food with another hand?  But they offered to carry my tray for me!  I wasn't expecting this kind of service from a cafeteria style restaurant.  The cashier also summoned another employee to grab a high chair for me.  I was so thankful and appreciative...I'll be back for sure!!!
author: Stephanie F.

description: Not sure but the curry udon tastes the same or close to the one in Hawaii. Either way I was never disappointed. It's great! It's nice to have the option to have the topping added on your order the way you want it. Tempura chicken isn't the same as the one in Hawaii but it's still enjoyable.
author: Allan P.

description: This place is different for me, and personally I didn't really enjoy it as much. Your opinion may be different though! It was more dry than I thought, but maybe it was because I got the wrong type of udon.. lol anyways it's not a bad place, just not my type of udon that I would eat.
author: Phi V.

description:
I used to live in Hawaii and would always go to MaruKame Udon... yes Kame.... and it was delicious and cheap. Always a line but so worth it. So missing my 2nd hometown, I come to Marugame Udon and boy was I disappointed. 

Came around 9:45pm so there was no line. (They close at 11pm) We ordered the Nikutame Udon. The soup is minimal. I asked the kitchen person if i can have more soup n she said she is only allowed to give one scoop of soup. She says they charge if she scoops additional scoop of soup. The "soup" is barely even touching the udon. 

There wasn't a lot of tempura sides left. We had to order and wait for it to be made. (Usually you're suppose to just grab it.)

Flavor is definitely not as good as Hawaii's Marukame. Their condiment station is dirty as hell and there were no green onions left. Tables had dirty bowls and crap on it. Customers are supposed to return the trays back at the tray stations, newbies. You know how Japanese ppl like to keep things clean. Nope, not this restaurant. You wouldn't find a Japanese restaurant like this in Hawaii. I don't see any Japanese workers here either.

Overall, probably wouldn't come back. Definitely would not line up for this.
author: Tammy F.

description: Utterly ridiculous wait.   Was there early weekday evening around 4:45 so the line was short when I started waiting.  Only about 12 to 14 people ahead of me, which is very short compared to most evenings.  Stood in line not moving at the same spot for more than 30 minutes.  Overall, it took 45 minutes for me to reach the cashier when there was only a dozen people ahead of me.  While we were there standing still for 30 minutes, there were plenty of workers standing around joking with each other ignoring customers.  The workers absolutely didn't care how long customers have to wait.  It was dinner time so what the heck were they thinking when the line grew to more than 50 people by the time I was served.  If you want to stand in line for hours for bad service then this is your place.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I love Marukame udon in Hawaii so I had high hopes for this place to be exactly like it. However, the beef curry udon was a let down. It was still very good but it didn't taste like the one in Hawaii. If you've never had the one in Hawaii then you must give this place a try! It's definitely one of the best udon places on the mainland!

The place is located outside of the mall so parking is insane and impossible to find!  I went a couple days after the grand opening and the lines were wrapped around but it moves pretty quickly!

Definitely give it a try and go when you're not that hungry so that you'll have an appetite by the time you reach the front of the line!
author: Linda T.

description:
