Very good hand pulled udon. Tried the Nikutama (beef with egg) and Mentai kamatama udons. Mentai is my favorite. It's like a japanese carbonara but with roe (at least I think it's roe)! It's dry, no soup.

Good tempura, but can go without. 

Cafeteria style (you pick what you want) with a condiments bar (like a salsa bar.

Nice clean facilities.
author: Jean S.

description:
Decided to check out Marugame for the soft opening. I was a bit disappointed because they weren't serving a few items but understandable since they haven't officially opened. It does make me want to come back and try the other menu items though! 
There was a line out the door but the wait wasn't too long and we were able to find seats. I enjoyed watching the workers prep, boil , and portion the udon. 
I got the Kama-age udon. It comes in a great wooden bowl/vessel with a dipping sauce for you noodles since there's no broth. The self serve sides are great, cheap, and freshly made -- although piling them on can tip the cheap udon into a regularly priced SF meal. I couldn't help though, I mean how could you resist potato croquettes, a variety of tempura, and all kinds of onigiri/musubis???
author: Brian L.

description:
This place is easy a FIVE out of FIVE star restaurant, but I will explain why I took a star off after explaining the amazing-ness of Marugame.

I am posting this review after going to Hawaii and trying the original Marugame. I am so pleased to say that they are close to being exactly the same!

I got the Bukkake Udon which comes with their amazing udon noodles, this sweet beef (along with a beef broth obviously), and a poached egg. Compared to the one in Hawaii, the tempura flakes and toppings in SF are on the side so you can add your own. DELICIOUS DELICIOUS YUM DELICIOUS. I typically have bigger eyes than my stomach, but this was so good, I pushed through to finish it and yummm.

There are sides (which in my opinion are super expensive), but the only one that I enjoyed after trying the tempura, the Inari, Tuna Mayo, and Salmon Flake Musubi, and the Potato Croquette....
The Potato Croquette gets the crown!

Now the reason I knocked off a star. The line moves relatively fast, almost like moving in a cafeteria line, so no worries there. First problem was that since this is located in Stonestown, there clearly needs to be a walkway, so they break their line by ending it and starting it with ropes by Olive Garden. That's fine, but the chick made my friend and I wait by the Olive Garden even though we were the last ones and for a while too. But eh, that could be policy. The other reason I knocked off a star is because since it is in San Francisco, pretty common to have beggars or homeless people, whatever you may call them. One in particular kept coming inside and just scooping tempura flakes, going outside to eat it, and going back inside to refill. I mean...more for the business, yall should watch out for that!

Besides that, my mouth is watering when writing this. Hopefully will go back soon!
author: Shayna P.

description:
Great stuff and the wait is not as bad as it seems but it is about 2x-3x what that udon would cost back in Tokyo. 

Felt like I was back there for sure, though :)
author: David C.

description:
The line could be really long, so avoid normal lunch/dinner hours if you don't want to wait too long.   They are open throughout the day, so try early or late hours for meals.  You may still have to wait but the line moves quickly.

The food was great.  I was happy to have real authentic Japanese udon in SF! 

They also have many several different tempura toppings and rice balls.

I will definitely come back!
author: M Y.

description: If you're looking for a cheap udon spot that still has tons of flavor then this is the place for you. I normally order the #5 and if you like to eat then get a large. Otherwise, the regular size is more than enough food for one person especially if you get tempura on the side. The broth is yummy and the noodles are cooked perfectly. However, the tempura can sometimes be hit or miss. I stay away from the vegetable tempura but I love the shrimp tempura! So far this place still has a bit of a wait so be prepared to stand in the SF cold but you'll definitely be warmed up by the delicious udon.
author: Jennie J.

description: Lines are too long to justify eating here. Quality is just ok. Not enough seats to accommodate guests.
author: Wes L.

description:
It was ok. Probably wouldn't go back again. Line was long but moves pretty quickly. Also a tonna parking so that's nice.

Udon was ok. Tasted kinda weird. Wouldn't eat again. The onigiri was decent though, but I ate it like 2 hours later so maybe it was actually really good.
author: Adrian Y.

description: I wasn't sure if this place would live up to the hype (and incredibly long lines) but it really delivered! Amazingly fresh udon noodles cooked to perfection right in front of you in a cool cafeteria style setting. The broth was delicious and the large size bowl is a generous portion. The tempura was excellent too and the rice rolls were tasty (my toddler gobbled them in!) Definitely worth the wait and I can't wait to go back again.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
large dining room but has long line out the door due to slow assembly line.  the menu here is slightly different than their Waikiki location. the price definitely reflects the high living costs of SF area. 

this location has self-serve garnish station with green onions, cilantro, tempura flakes. 

tried the nikutama which is the beef with udon in their sauce instead of their soup.  we are liking this version better now as it tastes slightly less salty than the niku udon.
author: Amy T.

description:
I still don't get why people would line up for at least half an hour to eat at this place. I walked by Stonestown everyday and there was a line every single time. I thought it must be good because the line was always there no matter what the weather was. So I gave it a try to see what people really like about this place.

Price: It was pretty affordable price for a big portion of udon. (Probably this was the reason??)

Texture: It said aged udon on menu, however, it wasn't aged enough. A good texture of udon should be chewy, but their udon was just soft and easy to break. Obviously, it wasn't AGED enough.

Tempera: Kinda over priced per piece depends on which one you get. Don't forget! The size was just made by the tempera flour.

Broth: Salty and NOT HOT. (It was just warm enough to not to be considered as cold)

Seating: Crowd and uncomfortable. 

Utensils and saucing: Right in front of the drop off area. Simple but you won't miss it. Water was right next to the cashier.

Staff: Good and friendly staff, but why you have to show out your tattoo????   I mean the tattoo was pretty and it won't be a problem if you work in some other industries. But once you are in food industry, at least don't show it out to consumers because it makes people lost appetite. 

So the two stars were from 
1) The staff were non stop doing whatever they were doing.
2) The cashier was almost ran out of voice. Her voice was super low and almost go deaf. I am sorry for her because she needed to talk the same thing over thousands time a day.

I might come back for cheap udon if there wasn't a line or short line. But if I needed to wait for half hour and get this quality of food to fill up stomach, I would rather go to McDonald's. They have better quality of stuff to fill me up with cheaper price-.- 

I would like this udon place if they could improve and maintain their quantity and quality of udon. Other side dishes are just extra.
author: Kalum Z.

description:
My family had high expectations for this place because it always had long lines. TLDR: The food was just okay, but the service was HORRIBLE.

This place is food court style. You get your food, pay at the cashier, and find a seat.

My aunt was responsible for buying all the meals, while my grandparents and my parents looked for a table. My grandma is disabled, so we try to find a place for her to sit as much as possible. A waiter came up to us when we were sitting and waiting for our meals and said we couldn't sit there unless we EACH have a meal in our hands. We told him that my aunt was in line buying all the meals, while we wait here since my grandma couldn't stand for long periods of time. He then threatened to call security because we were waiting for our food and didn't have food at that moment. Apparently the rule here is, if you don't have food or are waiting for food, you can't sit. You must have food in order to take a seat. This is BS. 

Since this place is food court style, it is a do-it-yourself meal. You carry your own food and you clean up after yourself. My family didn't want to tip because of the rude service and the threat of security that they received during their visit, but there wasn't a "NO TIP" option. Even though you do everything by yourself, you are still REQUIRED to give tips. Tips are encouraged, but should remain an option for your customers.
author: Melody L.

description:
I have gone twice, tried 3 menu items and can now write an accurate review. I've had the Kama age udon, beef with egg udon, and spicy chicken udon. The spicy chicken is the worst. It's sour spicy, which is unexpected and makes it taste like Thai food. 

My biggest problem with Marugame is that the noodles, soup, and tempura are all lukewarm. Nowhere near hot enough. Today I went in for the 2nd time and figured out that if you want hot noodles, you need to get the Kama age. But it's not perfect - the dipping sauce can get salty real quick. Tempura was still just warm though. And some pieces had chewy batter, which means it's been sitting out too long.

The rice balls have been consistently good. If I ever come back I'll try the curry udon.
author: L M.

description:
I came here yesterday, 1/8/18, for their soft opening at 5:20pm and the wait was only 15 mins. Keep in mind it was pouring last night so I'm sure thats why the line wasn't that long.

I ordered the beef udon and got a side of the chicken tempura. It taste exactly like the one in Hawaii. The noodles are fresh and the soup has just enough flavor. I would definitely pass on the tempura. It was nothing special. I would recommend trying Marugame only if the line is short. I don't think its worth waiting in line for more than 30 mins.
author: Kelly S.

description: I got the bowl on the bottom (it's the #8, regular size) and it was delicious! The udon and broth (as well as everything else) is a 10/10. The wait may be a little long, but i promise you it's worth it.
author: Meg C.

description: Every time I go by it's always a line. When I finally got a seat I was super hungry. I would say that the udon was decent. I was expecting a bit more. They have a variety of fried side dishes. But I would say that by the time you are eating the udon and then start if the side dishes, it's not as crunchy anymore. It's a bit pricey for the side dishes, I would say if you want to try the side dishes and the udon, eat them about the same time. It's ok to be a pig, take a bite if the tempura then. A bite of udon.. lol that will at least the tempura wount be soggy/less crunchy.
author: Bonnie C.

description: YUM! I didn't have to wait that long since we got there around 15 minutes before they open. But I can see why it would be a nightmare if you come during prime time. Udon was delicious, and I love the all you can grab toppings for your noodles. Would come again if I'm in the area!
author: Sappho C.

description:
The freshness concept is great, but this place missed the mark for me. Service is self serve made to order. 

Food -

Tried the tonkatsu udon and the soup was not up to par. Noodles were ok only, and the poached egg was more on the raw side. Someone else in my party ordered the beef udon and it was better. I don't recommend the tonkatsu since it lacked the milky broth bone taste it is known for.

I must say the tempura was delicious. I don't typically order that but everything was made fresh.

It was nice to try this place but I won't be back.
author: Steph C.

description: This place is actually really cool. It's themes to look just like a traditional Japanese ramen house. Although this is not what they look like in Japan, but I love the attempt at trying to make it totally Japanese looking. My favorite is the tonkatsu ramen at $9! Exquisite! I love to top it off with the various tempura.  Cheap and great!!!
author: Stan V.

description:
Super good big portions Love it!!! 
Noodles taste so soft and fresh 
Love how you see them making the noodles
author: Tasha B.

description: 3 stars because even though the food is good, it's got a cafeteria style feel. It's nice to watch them make the noodles, which are great because they're fresh. The flavors are all good. I added an egg and beef to my Kama-age bowl. We waited 25 minutes, but I wouldn't wait longer than that. After the cafeteria-style line (grab a tray and slide through), you have to find a place to sit, which can be hard depending on how busy the place is - you may have to share a table (not my thing). Lots of little kids at this location, looking super cute slurping their noodles.
author: Florence A.

description: This place is great for that quick fix of udon! I definitely recommend the beef Curry udon! Super rich and delicious, just great comfort food! They also have yummy tempura shrimp and veggies, potato croquettes and a small selection of onigiri/musubis, the musubis are good as well but the filling to rice ratio is a little off but none the less is still good! This place gets super busy during peak hours, but if your willing to wait just a little longer, the food is still pretty good! I occasionally come here every other week at times for my udon fix and it's easy on the pockets as well, pretty good prices!
author: Shiloh T.

description:
This is a great place for good tasting Udon. The Udon noodles are cut and boiled right in front of you. The bowls are warmed in hot water before they serve the hot Udon and pour the tasty Tsuyu (soup) into the bowl. The freshly made Tempura are deliciously displayed for your choosing. The Onigiri (Rice Balls) are also made right in front with fresh ingredients and the rice is hot and fluffy. 
The only drawback is the long wait in line. My first visit when they just opened was about an hour wait, the 2nd time was about 45 min - 1 hour. On the 3rd and 4th visit (10-15min), the line was much shorter maybe due to my going after the lunch rush around 2:30. Another recommendation would be if they can slice the green onions thinner like they displayed it in the pictures. All in all, I would definitely recommend this spot for the Udon fix.
author: B N.

description:
Well, this place is not officially open until 01/18 but they are doing a soft opening at the moment. We just happened to be in the Sunset before going to the airport and we saw the line and hopped right in. My boyfriend loves Murakame from Hawaii (Not the same chain for those of you who know it), so he wanted to see how this place compared. We waited in line for about 30 minutes before opening and then probably another 30 minutes after to get inside since some people were holding up the line.
Anyway, this place is simple. Pick your udon dish. Grab your fried food. Grab a rice ball. Pay. Then garnish your udon and fried food as desired. Simple, right?
Well, right from the start the assembly line was a mess. The guy who took udon orders switched all of a sudden and forgot to finish one person's order so when his bowl was up, they took my order, thought it was the wrong one and threw it out and retook the guy in front of me's order. Then they forgot that I ordered. Messy. They were ready to just forget about me too.
The food itself was...I mean it's freaking udon, people. I thought the udon at Murakame was meh and Marugame is probably only slightly better. I have eaten udon in Japan and to think I have been forced to wait in line at both overhyped restaurants of similar names in the US to eat something as simple as udon is just mind boggling. The fried food tastes like oil and the onigiri is boring.
Long story short: Why are you wasting your time waiting in line for udon?
author: Jenn T.

description: I was super excited to try this place since I loved the one in Hawaii! There is typically a long line but it usually goes by quickly since ordering is similar to an assembly line and seating opens up quickly. The setup and menu is similar to the Waikiki location. However, I felt the food, particularly the broth, was not up to par. It was a consensus with my friends that the broth was too salty. Overall, Marugame was a bit of a disappointment. If I were to return, I would get the plain soup.
author: Lynn T.

description:
~Don't bother if you're vegetarian~

Me: Is your tempura sauce vegetarian?
Staff: Um I think so. 
Me: Okay cos tempura sauce sometimes has dashi. 
Staff: Dashi's only fish flakes. 
Me: Yeah. I'm vegetarian. 
Staff: Oh sorry. [walks off] 

Only one staff member (the lovely woman actually taking my order) could tell me what was vegetarian and what wasn't. No one else knew or offered to find out when asked. 

There's only one vegetarian udon dish and it's cold, which isn't particularly appealing in a cold, foggy part of town after waiting outside for 45 minutes. The vegetarian tempura has been sitting out so it's lukewarm and soggy. I wish they had a vegetarian broth. 

The udon is nice though. My meat-eating partner loved it.
author: Ari W.

description: Delicious restaurant that doesn't mess around with their udon! We had the egg drop udon, 6 pieces of tempura, and 3 onigiri for about $22; quite affordable for SF! Be prepared for a long line. Dining is super casual/informal, don't expect a waiter/waitress! Nice selection of soft drinks.
author: Victor W.

description: Really nice, in my opinion! Cafeteria-style; you line up to pick your udon, followed by choosing other foods like tempura. The udon is good , especially the Tonkotsu and Beef Udon. I've also had the potato hash which was really good, but don't think was worth it for $2. The Curry Udon was delicious at the first few bites, but after that I felt like it has too much curry, as if my every bite was only curry. And I also really like the whole design there, put me in a great mood!
author: Zoe T.

description:
I've been here about half a dozen time. It's cheap, authentic udon. There's always a line. I usually wait about 20 minutes total. The food is good but it's not overflow line good. Those who have been there know what I mean by overflow line. 

My favorite hot Nikutama Udon (#2) or Curry udon (#3). 

Pro tip: The difference between regular and large is 50% more udon. They have full size piles and half size piles of udon. Regular gets one full size pile, large gets 1 full size and 1 half size piles. For $1 more for 50% more udon, I say go for it. But only if you can finish it. Take home udon sucks. 

My only complaint is that the broth is consistently lukewarm. It needs to be streaming hot. I don't want to wait 20 minutes outdoors to come in and drink lukewarm soup. That just ruins the whole experience. 

If you're going to get any of the seaweed wrapped rice balls, make sure you get one right out of their hands immediately after they wrap it. Seaweed touching warm rice gets soggy very fast so avoid those sitting in the tray unless you like rice wrapped in soggy seaweed. 

I come back regularly. It's a great value at Chipotle price. Chipotle next door at Stonestown is definitely taking a beating.
author: Pat Y.

description: I am so sad to be writing this review!!! I honestly had such high standards due to all the previous reviews but I was unfortunately let down when I tried this place. It's still grand opening so the line is pretty ridiculous still. I came here with my boyf on a Friday night around 8:30 and waited around 45-1hr, so come here as early as you can to avoid lines or prepare to wait! My boyf has been to the one in Hawaii so he was expecting the same quality, we even spoke to one of the workers about this and was reassured it was of the same standard so we were super excited! I got the Nikutama and boyf got the curry udon. Sadly, I think because we came near closing time, they ran out of eggs ;( or something about the machine was broken so I just had beef udon. We also got a couple of sides like the potato croquette, sweet potato tempura, salmon,crab, and furikaki rice musubis. The beef was bomb, super tender and flavorful. The broth itself tasted exactly like the beef, it was good at first but after a while it got really repetitive and way too salty. The noodles were honestly okay, it was very mediocre and I tried so hard to enjoy it but I was just meh :/ Boyf said his curry was okay, too salty as well and nothing compared to the Hawaii location. He said at the Hawaii one he came back the next day to order TWO different udons lmao, but that's not the case for this location. I felt like everything was just too salty. The musubis are a rip off ngl, there's barely any meat and it's all rice plus there's no flavor. I'm not giving up on this place though! The prices are really good here and the workers are SO friendly, I think because since they're still new they still have to adjust and work on things. I def will be coming back in a couple months just to see if they've made any changes.
author: Erica L.

description: The line is intimadating but it goes by pretty fast as reflected by the service. Staff is friendly and the service makes sure you get exactly what you want. Last time I ate here, my beef udon was perfect but this time it was barely lukewarm and there was barely and broth. Overall not the best udon but consistently good.
author: Usama K.

description: I really thought this place was just super hyped up, but I finally tried it and I have to say it is so good. I loved it, besides the line. I came around the opening time and I waited for about 20-30 minutes which isn't bad. I got the nikutama udon and wow. The beef was super tender and flavorful and the egg was so soft was runny inside. The noodles were so good, perfectly cooked with good soup. The bowl was super filling and I can't believe that I considered getting a large.  I also got the shrimp tempera, which was amazing and went with the udon perfectly. I also got the vegetable tempera but it was alright, not that great or special. I also got the salmon rice roll, and it was really good!!
author: Lauren L.

description:
In response to some of the reviews I read while waiting in line... 5:30pm arrival on a Saturday - 7:30 finish eating.

They clearly identify hot and cold, not so much sauce and soup. Soup is not sauce and sauce is not soup.

Tempura and panko have good texture.
author: Norman H.

description: It's good. Tonkatsu Udon is pretty good. Line has definitely shrunk down more than when it first opened up, which is good. It's good udon, just not worth waiting more than 20 minutes for.
author: Thomas C.

description: Good Authentic Udon  Noodle on a Cloudy / Overcast Day . A Bit $$ if Your Not Careful on the Tempura Side Dishes .  Definitely Not Everyone's Cup of Tea  ,  But Would  Invite Friends and make a Repeat Visit.
author: Gerry L.

description:
I waited SOOO long to try this place and I finally went today. I came here around 10:20am and there was barely any line by the time I got there. Of course, I had to wait until they were open but the minutes flew by fast!

I got a large beef udon and it was so good. The noodles weren't hard and perfectly cooked! I also got the chicken, asparagus tempura and the crab rice cake. I wish I got more of the chicken because it was delicious. But maybe next time! There's also a separate area for you to add sauces!

Overall, definitely worth the wait and will come back soon!!!
author: Sandy C.

description:
Got to try out this place over the weekend with my parents. We went on a Sunday and luckily we didn't have to wait over an hour. We had an early dinner so we got there around 4:30pm and we got in by 5. (FYI: The best time to go according to the worker there is around 2-3pm). The menu is pretty limited but you can choose from variety of udon on the menu. My mom ordered the kamage udon and my dad and I ordered the nikutama udon. We actually all ordered a large size b/c it seems like the regular had a better portion. (If you're a big eater, get the large and if you're feeling somewhat hungry, get a regular size) I like that you can pick your own toppings/sides to eat with the udon. There were tons of options from sweet potatoes, fried squid, tempura shrimp, fried chicken, and some other toppings. The udon was freshly made in front of you within minutes. After you pay for your udon, you can add cilantros and green onions and some other sauces available by the cashier area.  

In all honesty, I wouldn't wait over an hour though for these udon. It was good but not to the point where I would have to wait over an hour.
author: Monica W.

description: So affordable and definitely worth the trip there. Im from monterey and coming out there is always worth it. They make the prices cheap so it can give u a chance to buy more like the sides of onigiri and tempura. I love every aspect if it and would definitely recommend this to a friend
author: Lyl A.

description: I have never been to Hawaii, so I have never had Marukame before. HOWEVER, the moment I told my bf and his sister that there was a MARUGAME opening in SF, he looked at the photos and said "we have to go". Reason being that he usually doesn't like udon, but he loves MARUGAME. Being a student at SFSU, I know MARUGAME took over a sushi spot and I LOVE what they have done with the interior. It's very cafeteria style where you line up and make your way down the line and let them know what type of udon you want, then once they prepare your bowl you get to pick and choose a bunch of different tempura, then you pay at the end and go pick a seat. The wait wasn't very long at all, and i love how you get to see the udon being made as you stand in line. There's also a little bar island after you pay with green onion, fried tempura bits to add to your udon, etc. Don't be fooled like me, because I got the beef udon (large) and got two pieces of sweet potato and shrimp, and one piece of fish cake and one salmon onigiri. Man oh man was I shtufffffed. My bf got the egg and chicken udon (small) with one piece of shrimp and sweet potato also. I ended up letting him finish half of my beef udon and one sweet potato and one shrimp. It was the freshest and softest udon I have ever had. The broth was so light and refreshing, and the temperature of the udon is also perfect where you won't burn yourself if you dig in, but it's not too cold either. 10/10 would come again.
author: Tram H.

description:
In San Francisco, there aren't many places that serve udon as its main offering. There are even fewer places that serve cold udon in addition to the normal hot udon. A recent addition to San Francisco, Marugame Udon is welcomed among San Francisco's sparse udon offerings. I came here on two separate occasions and I have to say that I wasn't disappointed with the udon, especially with the cold udon here. 

The first time I came here was on a Saturday evening with some friends, and we were waiting in line for at least an hour and a half before we got to the front. Once we got to the front, we got to see the udon being prepared. I ordered the large cold Nikutama Udon because I rarely get to eat cold udon, and watched as they prepared my food. Even though it was freezing outside, I knew I wanted to get the cold udon because I haven't had such high-quality cold udon in such a long time. After my udon was served, I went to the tempura counter and deliberated what I should get. The tempura sides are self-serve, and I got the sweet potato tempura, zucchini tempura, asparagus tempura, squid tempura and the potato croquette. After I paid for the food at the cash register, there is a self-serve station where you can get your garnishes (scallions, tempura flakes, etc.). When I dove into the nikutama udon, I was delighted by the slightly sweet taste of the pork, the cold noodles and the nice cold broth that was filled up half the bowl. I started off with the vegetable tempura, and to be honest, it didn't make much of an impression on me. I moved on to the squid tempura and it tasted very mild, it had a very subtle squid taste. Finally, I went for the potato croquette and was blown away by how soft and fluffy it was. The potato croquette had a very soft crunch on its exterior, very easily broken once contact is made with your teeth. Hands-down, the potato croquette was the best among all the sides that I got, and it more than made up for the mellow taste of the tempura that I got before it. Overall, the highlights of the meal was the nikutama udon and the potato croquette, and it was a very satisfying meal overall. If I had to pick one thing that I didn't like about this particular visit, it would be the plastic spoons! For udon, I would rather have a large real spoon instead of a plastic spoon for ladling the noodles, but other than that, everything else was excellent.

The second time we came here, we went on a weekday evening to try to avoid the weekend rush. Unlike the long line that we encountered the first time, we just strolled to the front of the line with no wait time. This time, I ordered the Curry Udon with a side of potato croquette, fish croquette, and vegetable kakiage. When I went to the self-serve counter to get my garnishes, I noticed that the spoons this time are much larger and they're of the disposable kind, which probably meant that they've noticed the spoons used previously seemed out of place when compared to the rest of the utensils. The curry udon was thick, which was just how I like it since I believe udon taste better when the curry is thicker. There are slight traces of beef scattered throughout the curry, and as I made my way toward the bottom of the bowl, the curry became more liquidy, which was pretty interesting. The vegetable kakiage was tasty, and so was the potato croquette. The fish croquette, on the other hand, had a very mild taste, and I didn't particularly feel anything when I ate it. It could be because of the curry overpowering any taste that the fish croquette had, and I'm willing to chalk it up to that. But like my first time here, I was very happy with the meal, and I couldn't really find any cons this time. 

In my opinion, Marugame Udon is perhaps the best udon establishment in San Francisco, I have to say that price-wise, and especially for San Francisco, the udon itself is very reasonably priced. I'm inclined to believe that they make their money on the tempura, since the tempura is where it starts to get pricey. I honestly didn't mind though, since being able to choose the amount of tempura you want was far better in my opinion than getting multiples of the same tempura. I would highly recommend coming here on a weekday if possible to avoid the long waits during the weekend. One of my friends said that one could easily be satisfied with a regular size udon since you're getting sides to go with it. I'm inclined to agree because I felt extremely bloated after getting a large udon and the tempura sides. The next time I come here, I could see myself getting the edamame salsa udon. My hope that in the near future, Marugame Udon would expand their repertoire of cold udon dishes, but for now, their current offerings is pretty good compared to the rest of the udon places in SF.
author: Nelson X.

description: So happy to found out that they open one in the Bay Area. I fell in love with Udon on my trip to Hawaii and I can say that the quality of noodles and the flavor of the broth and beef is similar to the ones I had in Hawaii. I had the nikutama udon and I feel like you can never go wrong with this choice. Great udon at an unbeatable price, what's not to love about that!
author: Hakim R.

description:
FINALLY!! I dont have to make a special trip to Hawaii just to get my favorite Udon!! 

went on a saturday afternoon around 1pm during the soft opening so they had limited items available on the menu. The wait was about 1 hour which was ok because from the last time I was in hawaii the wait was just as long since the dining area is slightly smaller.

hubby and I both ordered the large bukake  udon, the sides were almost the same, but this location has less offerings. no tempura friend mushrooms which was my favorite from the hawaii location. I do like that the tempura  station and the green onion station were self served so you can put as much or as little as you like. 

the bill was around 35 for 2 bowls, 1 drink, 4 shrimp tempura, 1 potato croquette, 2 salmon onigiri, and 1 tuna onigiri. not bad i think the hawaii one was the same price. 
 our eyes were bigger than our stomach cause we could barely finish our food.  

over all this place is just as good as the hawaii location only downside is its not located on a beautiful island.
author: Dixie N.

description: While the noodles were fresh, I didn't find Marugame to live up to the long line that we had to wait in. We waited for about 30-40mins from 5:40pm on a Saturday. I had the egg drop udon and also snuck a few sips from the beef udon and curry udon. Again, the noodles were fresh and the prices were good, but I didn't find the flavor to be anything out of the ordinary and there wasn't much meat in the soups. I would come back here again, but no way will I wait in that line for this.
author: Makena W.

description:
Was gonna try the one down in SoCal a few months back but didn't get a chance but I was so happy to know that it has arrived up here. 

Came here the other week during soft opening with most likely one of the shortest lines they've had during those two weeks they were open, aka waiting outside for ~30 mins on a Thursday night. It's cool, at least it wasn't raining and they had a employee be outside handing out menus and telling people about the place. 

In terms of price and quality, it's really good for what you get for sure. Got the bukkake udon and topped it with green onions and tempura bits, plus a shrimp tempura and some "musubi" aka really onigiri on the side (I know call me an elitist but I'm right). The noodles definitely tasted fresh, and also the broth is more concentrated which I really like since I think we're all used to seeing regular watery broth in most typical places. But I also wanna say this beats Kagawa-Ya (lol Uber udon) to me, since that was a bit pricier for something like this. Would much rather take the trip over to Stonestown where I can actually park my car too. 

Also tried my boyfriend's niku udon, somehow he managed make his bowl taste like some kinda Japanese fusion pho. Don't take my word for this, it's probably because he added a ton of cilantro and green onion in his. But in all seriousness, that was good too :) 

However, the onigiri was alright. Could use an improvement in preparation with placement of fillings in the rice, and packaging to keep the seaweed from getting soggy with the rice. Not really something worth getting next time around. 

Can't wait to try the other stuff from post-grand opening once I can go again with the least wait time haah. haah. haah. It's gonna be awhile before that happens.
author: Olivia C.

description:
Everything about the place is great it's very similar to the one they have on Hawaii. The inside is spacious with nice decor. 
Food was good, I got something that didn't have in Hawaii. I don't remember the name but, the number (10).
author: Johnson V.

description:
MMMMM UDON! I've had MARUKAME udon in Waikiki Hawaii. Same same, but different. My understanding is they are NOT the same company. Still delicious and very comparable. Udon is made fresh and tempura is still hot off the fryer! I would suggest tempura fish cake, shrimp, and mixed veggie. 

I would pass on the onigiri, it was all rice no meat.

Don't forget to add your toppings! 

 I was lucky to go during their soft opening. Line was about 20 minutes long. I hear the line is MUCH longer.

Although i think the food could be worth the wait, i probably wouldn't wait longer than 30 minutes.
author: L F.

description:
We waited 1 hour at 7pm on a Thursday, so this place is a commitment and a half. The only positive is that they see everyone that got into line before their cut off time. So don't be worried that you won't get your meal.

Once you make it inside, you see a long line of workers. One is making the udon, one is cutting it, and the third is cooking it. Finally you tell them which one you want. I got the beef udon. Then, they have a bunch of tempura and onigiri options. I tried the fishcake, chicken, and shrimp tempura, as well as, the crabmeat onigiri. 

Well, the udon itself is bomb. The portion is also huge (coming from someone who eats a lot) and very affordable. The broth is pretty simple, and the meat inside is of decent quality. But the udon itself really was the selling point. As for the tempura, it was all good. I haven't had fish cake tempura before, and I liked it a lot. The onigiri though I would say you should pass on. There is very little meat in any of them, so skip that. 

I am excited to come back to this place when the hype dies and they bring the beef with egg udon onto the menu (theoretically end of this month).
author: Nikita K.

description: Incredibly good and authentic udon & tempura. Unlike most Japanese places in the bay area, rather than offering every kind of Japanese food imaginable (with none of them being very well-executed), they do two things here but have them down to a science (and still lots of variety in the way you can get your udon and the types of tempura). Amazing flavors and outstanding noodles. Don't miss it!
author: Ian C.

description:
I've been to marugame twice and twice I've gotten sick. And I mean stomach pains, diarrhea, the works. I went with my bf and he got sick the second time and had hives (same other symptoms). 

I'm willing to give this place one more go and avoid all seafood but at this point I don't even know what I should or should not eat. The shrimp was still raw on my second visit when I bit in. The tempura batter was soggy for both the shrimp and squid. The fried onion bunch was leaking oil. Maybe just plain udon and nothing else?!
author: Jessica W.

description: Finally came here! I have been to the Marugame in LA and thought it was the best udon I have ever had, so I had high expectations for this one. I think it is still worth the wait, esp at its price point. I got the beef udon and added a soft boiled egg. I ordered a large (only $1 more) and was able to finish it all, however I think I will just get a regular next time as I was super full. The udon noodles were super good, but the broth could use more flavor. I also got shrimp tempura-that was very good! It is cafeteria style, so pretty much you grab a tray and tell them what you would like. They prepare it then place it on your tray. You continue down the line and get to pick out which tempura pieces you want. After paying, there is a toppings/sauce bar. They have green onions and tempura bits you can add to your udon (highly recommend!) I will definitely come back! The line moves rather quickly, so don't be too intimidated.
author: Kim C.

description: New favorite place! My son loves the Bukake Udon Cold. Also ordered Nikutama Udon and it was delish. So many tempura to choose from and rice musubi. I couldn't decide which tempura to get, it all look so good. I'm glad we finally had a chance to try this place out. They have condiments to add to your bowl. Two types of tempura sauce ( sweet and original). Employees are friendly. Place was clean. Definitely will be back!
author: Esmeralda C.

description:
You can see the noodles being made fresh and the person portioning out the noodles can be entertaining to watch! The staff is friendly and does their best to greet and thank every customer.

I ordered the curry udon and i was not disappointed at all! The cold bukkake udon was also a lot better than I anticipated. I would definitely come back to order a cold udon on a hot day!
author: Marianne L.

description: Worth the wait??  It really depends people have different tolerance, so on a Wednesday night the bf and I only waited about 30mins..granted the weather was border line raining and windy,the udon is made by hand/machine and washed by hand...you just order by number and reg or large size(get large) hot or cold...the tempura and other side snacks can be added before check out, the udon it self had good flavor and the tempura tasted fresh and crunchy...
author: jonathan h.

description: Simple. An udon place that give you versatility on creating additional toppings. There alot of sides you can add towards you order, which is unique for a Japanese Udon.
author: Ernest S.

description:
Went on Sunday at 11:20AM. Total wait time was about an hour and a half. BUT SO WORTH IT. (: My family and I dream about the Marukame Udon in Hawaii, so to have them open up one in SF, I'm so happy! 

What we ordered:
Nikutama Udon
Spicy Chicken Udon
Curry Udon
Lots of tempura

Nikutama Udon - 10/10 worth the wait. By far my favorite udon. Oh my god. I would go in line again for this. Sliced beef with soft egg and lots of green onion/tempura toppings. YUMMMMMM

Spicy Chicken Udon - If you like sweet/sour broth, you might enjoy this a lot. It is spicy so keep that in mind. I didn't particularly enjoy this. Wouldn't order again.

Curry Udon - I've never been a fan of the curry udon, so I knew I wouldn't enjoy this as much. It's delicious, just a bit heavy for me. My dad raves about this dish though!

Tempura - some of the tempura was soggy. The best ones were: potato croquette and fried chicken.
author: Nicole W.

description: SO HUNGRY AND GOOD I FORGOT TO TAKE A PHOTO! It's a must eat place, they have different varieties of Udon I ended up getting the beef udon with egg on top, so good! The broth is so tasteful and well marinated. OH, and don't forget to get shrimp tempura it's to die for!
author: Gabriel T.

description:
Surprisingly, there was a line to get into a line on a Monday afternoon. Fortunately, the line moved fairly quickly. Simple instructions on how to order is posted right when you reach the entrance. 

I had the nikutama udon and my friend had the curry udon. I found both to be really tasty. Udon was cooked well and had a nice chewy texture. My only complaint is that it lacks broth and the curry udon is bit too salty. It's flavorful, but salty. I've never had the one in Hawaii, so I can not compare. Prices are really affordable. It's around $10 or less per bowl. After you choose your udon, there are a variety of tempura you can choose from ranging from $1-3. I chose a few, which included the shishito pepper, sweet potato, croquettes, and zucchini. To be honest, I didn't enjoy them as I prefer a thinner lighter batter. The tempura looks like it has been sitting out and was luke warm. The tempura sauce is self serve and when it was my turn to fill my plastic container, it was either cold or empty.

Tables were dirty and I had to wipe them down myself. After you finish eating, bring your tray to a designated area where you can dispose of your trash. 

Is it worth the hype? I say no as there are better udon shops in the area.
author: Kate W.

description: Exactly like the one in Honolulu but of course, a little more expensive than getting udon there. Came here with my friends on Saturday evening  around 7:30 and waited about 40 minutes before we got to the front of the line. I like the concept of being able to select which udon I want to have, watch them make the noodles fresh, as well as select whatever sides I want. I remember the last time I was in Hawaii, I made a note to self to not get the curry and get the beef udon the next time I was at the restaurant. With that in mind, I got the regular beef udon with a side of the vegetable tempura ball thing. My meal was about $11, which in comparison to what it costs in HI, is a bit more but it was still good. I also liked how there was a lot of seating inside and we didn't have to fight or wait for seats. Definitely will be back again for my udon fix
author: Michelle C.

description:
MARUGAME Udon at sfo
Udon is same as good Marugame at Japan
Waiting line was long
Service is good you should go anyone visit sfo
author: Rei S.

description:
The foods are ok if you  only go there once in a while,  otherwise, you might get bored because all the foods are very much alike.
Bad experience with the cashier who took our order, he intentionally dropped our credit card without apologie because we didn't tip him I think. It was obvious he wasn't happy. 
Tips for self-serve restaurants are bad ideas, because many employees expect tips without service.
author: Sapphire L.

description:
I loved location in Waikiki. So, when I heard there was one here, I had to get a taste of the island here at home.  MARUGAME SF definitely did not disappoint.  Same concept as the other location.  Grab a tray, pick your selection, pile on the sides, pay, add on the toppings, find seating and devour.  I had #2, beef udon with poach egg.  Just as I remember, sweet beef perfectly balanced with well seasoned broth.  No additional flavor required, as with a lot of Japanese dishes.  The only thing I would request is, maybe, a tad bit more broth in my bowl.  But after reviewing others photo, maybe its intended to be served with lesser broth to show case the poach egg? (??)
My husband had the egg drop chicken udon.  I don't believe this one is served at the Waikiki location.  The broth in the egg drop chicken udon was a bit thick to me.  Very similar to Banh canh, maybe even thicker.   My husband enjoyed it since he didn't care too much for the sweet beef.  Me on the other hand, I would of if the broth was on the thinner side.  We also had the shrimp,  squid, and sweet potato tempera.  Everything was light and crispy as it should be.  PERFECTION. 
Overall, was it worth the hour and a half drive and another hour and a half wait?  If in town, definitely.. yes!
author: Fann H.

description:
Visited this place on a wrong day, literally a day after their soft opening was done so had to wait for their grand opening. After their grand opening, rumored their lines were going for hoursssss so I waited 3 months later hoping for the lines to die down. NOPE. That didn't happen. SO, STILL stood in line on a Sunday, waited about 40 minutes to get in. Overall the line moved pretty quickly. Once you get in, it's literally ordering which udon you want and they prepare it on the spot in front of you, kind of like a canteen cafeteria feel except you get to see how the udon's are made so that's kind of cool. 

We tried #2 (Nikutama Udon) and #3 (Curry Udon). We both got the small size since we wanted to leave more room for tempura's and onigilly's. Both udon's were quite nice, one's on the light soupier side and the curry had a thicker sauce/soup. Both came with beef. 

Onto the tempura's and onigilly... DON'T GET VISUALLY DISTRACTED as they charge per piece, price are shown below the food. The tempura had a lighter golden crispy batter almost flaky, done nicely, doesn't feel too heavily patted on. Of course my favorites the shrimp ones! Classic. 

The onigilly's quite standard, if you're having Japan withdrawals and you're missing those easy pickups at the convenient stores, they got you here. 

After you pay, there's a sauce bar nearby where you can grab all those tempura dipping sauce, hot sauce, green onions, and whatever you like to pair your food with. The tempura sauce pump was a little tricky. Can't tell if they ran out of sauce or the pump was just really hard to push down. Not gonna lie, it was very filling, the tempura's were so big we had to get a box and take them home. 

As for the hype.... I mean it's not as blown out of proportions as I thought it would be, it's still satisfying. If compared to Udon Mugizo in Japantown, what differs most is the environment for me. This place feels more like a quick fix here whereas the Japantown one is where you can sit down, relax and take your time.
author: Aly C.

description: I have been looking forward to one of my favorite udon chains in Japan to come to the mainland USA. I believe this is known as Marugame Seimen (what the Japanese characters on the store front reads) in Japan, and maybe Marukame Udon in Hawaii. Anyway, they are all part of the same chain, but the location in SF is a disappointment. The broth used at this location is quite different from the one in Japan (and Japanese udon broth in general!). Udon broth (or tsuyu) is based on dashi from dried bonito fish shavings plus kelp, soy sauce and a  bit of salt. The broth at Marugame Udon seems not to have enough of the dashi taste and is on the sweet side!! The flow of the restaurant is also poor. Most people queue up outside, because there is very little line space inside. The exit is also through the same door, so there is quite a bottleneck most of the time, even if the restaurant isn't that busy. We were one of the first to arrive after they opened, and we waited outside for about 15 minutes before we were able to place our orders. Once we got our food, about half of the tables were empty.The fried toppings are the same as in Japan, but I seem to recall there being more variety in Japan, than just the fried stuff. The edamame salsa is not on the menu in Japan, and just looked weird to me. I did not try it. And maybe it was just the day that I was there, but the self serve areas seemed sloppier than what I was used to seeing in Japan. Sauces spilled, napkins strewn about, floor was sticky in places.
author: 和子

description:
Good fast food place for a UDON! 

Flavorful, basic selection a few tempura and masubi selections.
author: Day D.

description: I was trying to find a day which didn't have a long queue and Tuesday was actually okay. I ordered their Nikutama Udon and you can see the noodles being cooked and the ingredients being made. I can really trust what I'm eating because how fresh it is. The only one complaint I have is the side dishes. (Tempura and Musubi) They are all overpriced like $2.20 for a potato croquette? They should of put everything as a set meal. Overall pretty good. I would come back again.
author: Carrie L.

description:
Its like a Udon chipotle! And exactly the same as in Hawaii! Thank you for coming to the bay!

All of the broths are great! Maybe the curry one is a bit saltier than you may like though.
author: Sean L.

description:
* Don't get frustrated by the long line. It moves fairly quickly, I waited outside for about 30 mins, then another 15 mins inside the restaurant to order and wait for the udon to be prepared. 
* Total 10 various types of udon with different broth and protein. They also have small side orders to compliment the udon. Most of them are deep fried in tempura style. Price range is between $1~$3 I would say. 
* A station for extra goodness: green onion, cilantro, sesame powder, tempura sauce and deep fried tempura flakes. Yummy!
* Plenty of seats inside and outdoor, area is clean and well stocked.
* I tried Egg drop udon (#10), thick consistency and kinda bland for me. I added soy sauce and even tempura dipping sauce hoping for the flavor to kicks in. 
* I left with a good impression. I must say it's the standard you would expect from most restaurant. Nothing much has wow-ed me that I have to make a trip here again anytime soon. If I ever crave for udon, I will head back, I'm more of a Ramen person.
* The staffs worked really hard to accommodate the customers during lunch rush. They deserve 4 stars for this visit!
author: Krystal G.

description: I'm disappointed about the food quality especially when compared to the Marugame Udon in Japan or even the one in Hawaii. We ordered the Kama-age udon, a beef udon, some tempuras and a few musubi. The udon is good, but everything else are poor. I believe that this chain gets their food from the same source as every other Marugame Udon, but I don't think that these cooks know how to process the food. First of all, the broth was luke warm by the time I was seated. Secondly, the tempura was poorly cooked. In fact, one of the squad tempura wasn't fully cooked as it was still in liquid form. The crap meat musubi was tasteless. And whoever cut the green onions need to be fired as they are as thick as my thumbnail.
author: Aaron C.

description:
The answer to your question: Yes, it is like the one in hawaii. 

Limited menu during soft opening. Only diff I can see so far is the chicken is white meat instead of thigh. Thats too bad. Udon is spot on. Quantity might be bigger than oahus location.
author: Brandon N.

description: I visited here I thought I died and and went to heaven! This place reminded me of when I went to Japan. The line has a line on its own but man so worth the 2 hr wait I waited in line. They have udon that is so good, makes you wanna slap yo mama. I got the curry udon and man, it was out of this world. The curry udon is just straight . They had shrimp, sweet and potatoe tempura that was straight up jaw dropping. The salmon tringles, ( thats not really what they are called) so lit. Would drive here from San Jose any day! I'm a changed man. Until we meet again...next week.
author: Edwardson S.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for awhile now but the long line has always scared me away. Came here on a Tuesday for lunch and was pleasantly surprised with how fast the line went-- it was about a 30 min wait. I think the cafeteria style restaurant is a great concept for this place and it is also fun to watch them prepare the udon! I ordered the #2 and added a shrimp and zucchini tempura. The udon has a great texture and is goes well with the sweet flavored beef. One thing I would probably ask for is more broth in the bowl. Pretty big space with lots of seating-- didn't have any trouble finding a table. This is a nice addition to the mall!
author: Mauricia L.

description: Long line but it went fairly quickly. Noodles had some chew to them and didn't soak up the broth quickly, surprisingly good for how they mass made the noodles. Tempura was only OK, fairly pricey but not super fresh and crisp.
author: Kevin T.

description: The food was delicious and I really like the beef noodles really fresh and it had a good texture and the soup was delicious. The lines were long but it was moving fast. I would definitely be back again.
author: Belle D.

description:
The chicken is a must have. Generous portions of udon and many choices of toppings. 
The management might want to review the prices for some of the toppings. $1.50 for 1 strand of asparagus? I know its simple pricing, but an entire chicken thigh shouldn't be priced the same as 1 strand of asparagus.
author: Jerry W.

description:
The best place to have udon noodles in the SF Bay Area.

I visited this place for lunch on a rainy Monday and waited for 5 minutes. I ordered large bukkake udon (cold noodles are best for quality check). It tastes amazing at the same level as in Japan! Their noodles are al dente and the surface is ideally slick.

To achieve this quality, they carry professional noodle maker machines and special flour for udon from Japan. Also they cut udon from dough right before boiling in hot water.

I will definitely come back!
author: Satoshi N.

description: So yummy for price point. I got the large Kake which is sweeter broth. A large is 1.5 noodles of a regular. The udon noodles were soft and tasty. Be prepare to wait in line. You select your bowl and size and then grab the tempura by the piece. I got the onion nest piece which reminds me of a lighter blooming onion. Then you can choose more toppings in the topping station. This a place to go eat and then leave, not to be social. Their grand opening is 1/18 and I can't wait to have a bowl with egg in it.
author: Liana L.

description: Came here in a Thursday afternoon at 2pm and only waited in line for ten minutes!!! How lucky is that?! Parking is easy here since it's Stonestown mall. I've tried the one in Hawaii and this one did not disappoint at all! This place is way bigger and more spacious than the original one in Hawaii. I got the large hot Nikutama udon $9.50. You grab a tray and tell them what udon you want. Pick it up then head to the fried tempura section. Don't get too crazy. Then you go to the cashier and pay. I would say this is pretty much cafeteria style. Friendly staffs and the line moved quickly! I will definitely be coming back whenever I'm craving for some delicious udon!
author: Tina C.

description: .: @marugame_udon at Stonestown near my old College SFSU :. I got the spicy chicken Udon and my Queen got the Beef one. SHE said it reminded her of Yoshinoya beef in Udon (only my Yoshinoya lovers will get that) my chicken was really good the chicken seems to break up easily in the spicy broth. The Udon noodles are machine made FYI but they give you Hella noodles which makes the bowl great till the very end especially on a cold day/night in SF which is pretty much every night. Very clean place where you gotta bus your own tray but the soft opening this week seems to have made me wanna come back once the Egg Drop Chicken Udon is available. GREAT SPOT for people who want Udon that isn't doing too much but wouldn't care waiting 40-60 mins to get ur Udon because everyone likes Ramen in this area. #schmackin #foodporn #udonporn #marugameudon #bestfoodsf #nomnom
author: Charles D.

description: I just love anything noodle....and although I ultimately prefer ramen... this place was pretty awesome.  I just love the choices and uniqueness of the udon presentation here.  Went here for a lunch date with a group of friends.  This place is extraordinary bz...usual normal non bz wait 45min. On weekends and peak lunch hours up to 2 hours.  But the flow is nice.  The line was very organized,  the udon ordering system was new to me. Very smooth, authentic, noodles +  the broth is so flavorful.  The compliments to the udon are perfect! Tempura, and/or rolls, plus a topping bar. I think we all agreed that only a regular size was needed unless you are sharing because it is alot of food.  The thicker noodles are very filling so you really have to be "hungry heavyweight Jack" to completely finish a large udon + tempura + rolls. BTW...the chicken tempura is the best!! And the cold udon is just as awesome as the hot...so take friends and try them all. They are all awesome. So why 4 stars?? They ran out of tempura bowls...it held up an already bz long line 15 minutes.  There probly really should be someone rounding in the dining area.  Tables were dirty.  Ppl were lounging knowing that tables are in high demand.  The toppings bar needed attention more frequently. But definitely worth the wait...
author: Cassandra M.

description:
I LOVE MARUGAME.

Ever since I came back from Hawaii, I was always hoping and dreaming that an udon shop would open closer to me (the bay area). And when Marugame was in the works I couldn't contain my excitement!

Food: SO FRESH! The broth is so tasty, and the noodles are made right in front of you! 

Staff: Hardworking and kind. If I could, I would come here every week. But unfortunately that is quite a lot of carbs! haha!
author: Kiana M.

description:
-best udon in the bay
-super fast service
-as fresh as it gets as they're made right in front of you in line
-not ridiculously priced
author: Derrick W.

description:
Did I miss something? Did the rest of these reviewers somehow get a return coupon for submitting a glowing review?

Udon was fine. Just fine. Nothing special. Broth was ok too. The noodle ninjas were pleasant. The tempura person today may have been a bit too generous on the batter. It was pretty heavy to finally get to the shrimp. Unfortunately, I couldn't taste the shrimp, fish cake, sweet potato past the batter. I agree with the "musubi" reviews. Yikes. I've rolled boogers bigger than these portions. 

As for service - they claim an "upscale cafeteria experience"? Sure, if your lunch lady/seat police constantly hover around, apologetically reminding you to bus your dishes in the back. None of the floor staff knew how to manage a family with a stroller. With no place to stand (I wasn't rolling the stroller in the cafeteria line with hot soup!) and their "strict" no seat-saving policy, I just don't see how this place can call themselves kid-friendly. We were shamed by floor staff into thinking we were in the way. They gave us few options to park our stroller. Then they said we couldn't save seats (we were standing by the stroller) until we paid for our food. Uh. How do you expect three adults and two children to safely obtain this food you speak of?! Yeah - send one adult, the rest hang back. You know what's funny: there was another family of five behind us in line who got no static from the seat police when they placed utensils and napkins on a table - I guess the universal sign for "seat's taken". I overheard one of the seat police speaking to them in their mutual language (not English) and couldn't help but feel his cultural bias.

Lots of kinks to work out. I don't see how they can improve an already shoddy system where you have to wait outside in the elements only to wait in another line for your food...and you're not guaranteed seating. Meals should be enjoyed. This meal was definitely a stressful and demeaning experience. I'm fine with a scale cafeteria experience - at least I know what to expect and I don't get cheated on the meat in my musubi. I'm going to continue to support local noodle heads with a passion for food and service. This place belongs in the family-friendly, ADA-compliant food court. Aaaaaaverage.
author: Juliet P.

description: Not much people in line but Line went pretty slow the day i went (Tuesday around 6pm). Loved the noodle texture. Didnt care for the egg drop soup but totally recommend the curry chicken. The tempuras are okay, nothing special about them. I'd go back and bare the wait, for the curry chicken!
author: Angel L.

description: I've been here 4 times now and have gotten the same thing each time (#2 nikutama udon), but my udon has been different each visit. The first time, everything was delicious: portions were great and noodles were on point. The second time, I felt like the broth was extremely salty and the noodles were undercooked. The third time was good, but I had mostly onions and barely any beef. The fourth time was also good but not as much soup as previous times and my soup was not hot...lukewarm at best. Because of their inconsistencies, I would eat here again if there's no line because it's cheap and decent, but it definitely isn't worth waiting more than 15 minutes.
author: Margaret N.

description: Was told this was a very good place to have fresh udon noodles. It was a little busy when we got there, but the line moved quickly. There are several posters showing you how to order your noodles before you get to place your order. After you get you bowl of noodles served hot or cold, regular or large-sized, and if you want various toppings, you can then move to the wide variety of tempura selections and some rice items. It does add up so be careful. But the price is pretty reasonable. One problem is that depending on how soon they pour your broth onto your noodles and you get to a table, your noodles will have cooled off somewhat. Also the consistency of how much broth each of us received was not good. 2 in my party hardly had any broth in their bowl while 2 others had quite a bit of broth. The tempura items were a little cold too so some of it was a little greasy
author: Carol T.

description: Although self-serve, just their staff deserves 5 stars for their willingness to help and guide through out.  Excellent udon with good quality tempuras.  I love their condiments (fresh green onions, freshly grated ginger - my fave, tempura bits, and tempura sauce - the umami taste of bonito base) all enhanced the udon and tempuras.  Hope MARUGAME can keep up with both the food quality and service and it will be a place I will return again and again.  Good job!
author: Shirley H.

description: I decided to give this another try today. On weekday at 330 pm there was absolutely no line. Still took me 15 min to get my food Togo. Instead of ordering their soup, I ordered the dry version udon number 9. It's shockingly good! so for now on I'll order that n  their tempura.
author: Aniko N.

description:
Excellent udon. The line was long and out the door when my friends and I went, but it didn't take long at all till we got to ordering.
For beginners, go big, go for the popular Tonkatsu Udon; that's what I got. Next time, will get the hot Nikutama Udon; seen good reviews for that.
Best of all, the staff behind the counter are helpful.
author: DJ G.

description: Oh shucks, I can't believe it! After playing line roulette for two hours my coworkers and I got in. Lucky for me, each person in my group ends work at different shifts so we took turns getting in line. If you work in SF or go to SFSU, Marugame is not to miss. I got in just in time with 3 other drivers and talk about a close shave, a few minutes late all of us would have lost our spot. This has to be the best Raman/Udon that I have ever tasted. Even better than the ones in San Jose. I can definitely taste the authenticity like it came straight out of Tokyo, Kyoto or Nagoya. The flavors have a really attractive aroma that will make you want to come back again and again. Service is okay but keep in mind it being a new restaurant it can be slow but who cares it's worth the wait and the "bus ride". Love the price you get a lot more for a little US dollars. SF's hottest Japanese place is here.
author: Michael W.

description:
Made plans with my girlfriends to eat at Olive Garden and as we were walking in we saw the soft opening and the line for it... then Hawaii came back to me and I told my girlfriend that it feels just like the one in Hawaii... well of course we stood in line instead of going to Olive Garden. 

We waited about 20 mins and it was nice that some of the staff came out to hand out menus and it was from them who confirmed that it's the same EXACT restaurant as in the one in Hawaii. They only previewed 4 items on the menu along with all the tempura & musubi except the Inari. 

I had the Beef Udon. It was yummmmy... love the broth and how flavorful it was and I love the topping bar. It reminded me of the islands again and it was nice... 

I also had few of the tempura. So crunchy and good. The furikake musubi wasn't all that great, they could have added a little more flavor to the blandness. 

All in all our experience was wonderful!! Wait wasn't too long, they didn't allow saving seats till you actually got your food which was nice that way people who get their food can actually sit down and eat rather than the ones in line saving seats when they don't even have their food yet. Staff was great and friendly and courteous. Will definitely be coming back now that I know my FAVE Udon place is now close to home.
author: Amara R.

description: I didn't know anything about Marugame except that it is good so I went to check out the hype. It's only the soft opening and this place has crazy long lines. I waited maybe 30-45 mins outside in my soccer uniform and I was freezing my butt off so bring a jacket! When you get inside, there's an ordering station and you walk through and just buy what you want and pay at the end. Surprisingly, there was a lot of open seating. They have a condiments station with the crunchy tempura topping, fresh green onion and cilantro. It's almost like fast food except it's healthier and the line isn't fast. The udon was high quality and was very enjoyable. The price was definitely worth it. I ordered a large beef udon was $7.90. One thing was the portion amount. I was comparing my amount to other customers next to me and we were all given noticeably different portions. I had more than enough to eat, but I found that odd. They also don't given that much soup but other than that it was pretty good. I think it's hyped up mainly because of the pricing. It's a fairly good deal.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: WOW!! The best udon I've had in the Bay Area so far. I went this past Saturday at around 4pm. I'd say the wait for 2 was around 45 mins for us, but it was definitely worth the wait! There always seems to be a never ending line here. Once you get inside, the line moves very quickly. You get to see them make the udon from scratch, which I thought was a nice touch to my experience here! It's sort of like fast food/cafeteria style -- you go in, grab a big tray and a tempura tray, let them know which udon you want, they get it ready quickly right in front of you, you move on to the tempura/onigiri section and add whatever you want to your tray, then pay. Then, you move on to the sauce/toppings section. You can add cilantro, ginger, green onion, etc. to your bowl before grabbing a seat. Everything moves quickly so don't shy away because of the long line! Overall, great experience!
author: Benita L.

description: I braved the long line, had fun people watching, and plenty of time to catch up with my dining companions. We waited in line an hour. Yikes. If it wasn't for the long line, I would eat here once a week. They had a variety of broth choices. I also liked that you could get a regular size or large size. I love choices. For some odd reason I opted for the regular size (strange for me), and it was enough. Why was it enough? Because I added some delicious tempura on the side. Fresh, delicious, udon noodles. Really nice. Welcome to San Francisco Marugame!
author: Jason P.

description:
I know why you're here, you''re trying to see if that lonnnnnngggg wait is worthy of your time. I'm here to tell you it's worth the wait if you want to be one of those people that need to claim they've tried the latest hype. I'm not saying the food is bad; in fact, their udon is pretty good. The line gets broken up into two parts (to avoid obstruction of public foot traffic) so be sure you're in the correct part of the line. As you slowly make your way inside, you'll find yourself in a cafeteria style line where you grab a tray, a side dish plate and keep moving along the counter. Think of which udon # you want, size, cold or hot before you get to the staff cause you'll sound like an old udon patron who knows exactly what he/she's doing (#savvypoints). You can see the udon gets pumped out from the machine behind them, it gets cooked and tossed into cold water by hand and placed into the bowl. They then add the broth and whatever else you ordered into the bowl and move on. After you grab your bowl, you'll see an array of optional tempura side dishes which will cost an additional $ per piece.

I ordered #2 Nikutama, the beef was really flavorful and the broth was tasteful and light. But given this place specializes in the noodle, the star is the udon. It was good, but I'm not going to say this is the only spot for great udons. There's plenty of actual FRESH HANDMADE udon around the bay area and it doesn't fall short in comparison to Marugame. So like I said, if you don't want to brave the cold for the wait, there's many other options for a great bowl of udon. But if you'd like to feed your instagram with the latest foodie hype, then this is the spot to check out.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I'll get the issue out of the way first;
You've probably read in all the other reviews already, the wait.

The wait was 45 minutes for us on a Friday night at around 8:00pm, so we managed to get lucky. But the wait is terribly long. Now let's get to the positives!

I'll start off with the udon. I got number 2) the udon with beef, and it was good, but I think if you do happen to come here, I'd go for the cheap $5 plain udon because the udon really is delicious.

The toppings bar where you can self serve chives and tempura is amazing. I love the tempura, and I'd definitely recommend treating yourself to as much as you can.

So in conclusion, I personally would love to come here as much as I can, but the wait is definitely an issue. But without a wait, I'd go everyday!
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Stood in line for 1 hour for the soft opening. Was it worth it.... not at all! There was a limited menu, which I wish I knew - it sounded like they were unveiling a new dish every few weeks to make it interesting rather than perfecting said dish. I really wanted a soft poached egg in my beef udon, but no no - that will be unveiled in a week. How annoying. Other than that, the prices are much higher than the one in Hawaii without having the same quality. That in my book is already minus so many stars, but whatever. I ordered their beef udon, regular and added 1 piece of fried chicken, 1 piece of fish cake, 1 piece of shrimp tempura. Don't forget to get tempura bits and chili flakes at their sauce bar!! 

To be honest, the only reason why I gave this three stars is because the noodle portion is pretty generous. The noodles are pretty filling and perfectly cooked. However, I was also sad how their fried chicken is DEFINITELY not the same as their Hawaii's location. The breading was very light and had zero flavor. The pieces were really small and thus very dry. If you have been to their Hawaii location, you will know that the only thing to get there is their fried chicken because it's so plump and juicy and drips of juiciness.. (omg salivating as I'm writing this). Anyway, this is not the same. Don't get it. The only addition that's worth getting is their fried fish cake! It's HUGE - definitely enough as the only protein needed for the entire meal (also note I am a petite asian girl that doesn't eat much - if you're a large dude X2). I would go back for some fried fish cake and beef udon + poached egg. Hopefully they learned how to perfect their soups by now!
author: Anh Thu P.

description:
Went during the soft opening. Waited in line but not too long for lunch. 
I enjoyed my meal. I got the Kama age udon, a sweet potato tempura, and the shredded veggie one. My friend got the spicy chicken, shrimp tempura and the calamari tempura. The Kama age udon was definitely the best thing I ate. The noddles are a great texture and really tasty. The sauce that came with the Kama age was prefect. I wasn't crazy about the broth for the spicy chicken udon. I thought it was too acidic and lacked depth. The tempura were all about rubbery and oily. The sweet potato one was the bear and the others I wouldn't get again.  
There is a fair amount of seating and the space is pretty big. The staff is super nice and helpful. 
I would give it three stars, but I give it four now because I would go back again. I'm a bit fan of noddles and I thought the undo itself was great. It's worth a try, but maybe not if you have to wait 45 minutes. Come back another time when the line isn't so long
author: Andrea W.

description: First time here and the service was exceptional. I loved the gyudon was so tasty. I love the different flavors that they offered and will definitely be going back again. The tempura was delicious. The wait is definitely worth it!
author: Vernon B.

description: Interesting take on the common Japanese Udon. You stand in line (when you make it inside) and watch your udon  being make from scratch. As it move down the assembly line, your bowl of udon comes alive. After your udon is done, you can add on some tempura and fried stuff on the side. You paid at the end of the line and can add on green onion and other topping at the self served bar. Line is long usually, but it moves quick.
author: Wayne Z.

description: Great place for happy people. Lots of fun. Super tasty. Kid-approved. Line moves fast... but I wouldn't want to wait more than a few minutes in it. It's good but not life-changing good.
author: Rafe N.

description:
Had my first experience in Waikiki and I went back 3x during my one week stay! However, after hearing that there's one in the Bay I ran. I wanted to give this place a fair review but in comparison to the island one is no where near. 

The noodles are fresh made in front of you, however, the soup base lack of some key ingredients. I came here once and I don't see myself coming here any time soon. If you are going to Hawaii soon, I suggest you to try their original place. 

I can't describe what is missing in their soup but hey now that is open, students bring more business especially when it's affordable.
author: H H.

description: Tasted like a normal bowl of udon. Although it wasn't a big explosion of flavor in my mouth, it still tasted good. I would go here again if the line is shorter.
author: Lisa T.

description: Overhyped, has way too long lines for mediocre food. Not enough seats and too crowded. No service either and people don't clean up properly. Better off eating next door at Blaze because it has shorter lines nowm
author: Kevin R.

description:
Pretty good food, but buying tempura can be risky and drive up your price a lot depending on how much you order. I've had the cold nikutama udon and the hot kakitama udon here; I prefer the cold udon to the hot, as I find that the chewy texture of the udon is far better. My hot udon noodles were a little overcooked, and when I went with my BF he had a similar complaint. The beef is on the sweet side - it didn't bother me too much, but may not be to others' tastes. The mixed vegetable tempura and chicken tempura were good, but the sweet potato was disappointing - the slice of potato was super thin. Flavor-wise in general, though, I have no real complaints.

The line can seem long, but it does move relatively quickly. If you like udon, you'll probably like this place. If it's not, then you'll probably find it just average or unimpressive.
author: Em F.

description:
AMAZING! Such flavorful Udon broth and noodles! 

Arrived on a weekday 30 minutes before they opened for dinner and there was already a line forming.

It's still their Soft Opening so the full menu is not available. Had the #5, Beef Udon. I ordered a Regular and my boyfriend ordered a Large. My Udon came in a smaller bowl but my boyfriend thought it looked like they put the same amount in each. Either way we were both stuffed after.

You order and pay before sitting. After you select and wait for your Udon to cook you get to choose your toppings/sides. So many fried goods I could not contain myself!! I ended up needed a box to take the rest of it home. They have Chicken Tempura, Shrimp Tempura, Asparagus, Zucchini, Fishcake, Vegetable Kakiage (my fave), several types of Musubis and more.

They also have a station with complimentary Tempura flakes (yuuuuum), green onions, ginger, and different sauces. 

Looking forward to coming back after their official opening!
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I have a fairly unhealthy addiction to this place. Have not been able to get anything other than tempura zaru udon in person (cold udon, dipped in dipping sauce served with fried tempura - shrimp and vegetables). 

I recently was able to get this delivered at home and try a sampler - the creamy chicken/mushroom udon, the pork cutlet udon, the cold sesame beef udon. All were very good, the cold udon(s) and cream chicken/mushroom were the standouts.
