I've been lucky enough to have a fair bit of udon in Asia, and while this isn't elite compared to the best I've had there, it is excellent for SF. I hope to try Marugame Seimen SF soon, but it's a bit out of the way (that's a clear favorite).
author: W N.

description:
First timer here! My friend and I wanted to check out what the hype of this place was all about. This place was soooo good, especially if you are a big fan of udon like I am!

I got #5, the beef udon, which was amazing!! I though the broth was perfect, not too salty. I like how they and a little bar where you can get the crunchy flakes, green onions and pepper. I also got the shrimp tempura, chicken tempura, sweet potato tempura and fish cake tempura on the side. All of them were good! My friend loves the fish cake tempura. Out of all the tempuras, the chicken and sweet potato tempura were my favorite! The chicken was super juicy and tender!

I'm so happy this place opened here in the bay! Definitely should come here!
author: Liz L.

description: For those looking for great udon that reminds you of Marukame Udon in Waikiki this place is for you. While they don't have the awesome tempura egg, the udon and broth here is very good and hits the spot. Went while it's still a soft open so the menu was limited. Had the beef udon and a bunch of tempura.  I like how you can put toppings on yourself at a side bar. I wish they would put all the spices at each table though as I like to add to my bowl as I'm eating.  Will definitely be back here. Especially as it's closer to my home then Waikiki is.
author: Joanne T.

description: This is my 4th time visiting and I was disappointed because the Nikutama udon did not have much broth in it. It was also lukewarm and a little too sweet. When I had the Beef Udon last time there was plenty of broth and it was hot! I was craving some hot soup on a cold day, so I only finished half. However, the tempura and salmon musubi were delicious and fairly priced! Staff were very nice.
author: Kelani T.

description: Came here with the family 12:30pm on a Thursday and only waited around 15 minutes, BUT when we sat down the line started to grow. I got the beef udon with sweet beef and it was super flavorful, almost too flavorful for me. My parents got the tonkotsu udon with chili oil 4/5 and my brother got the curry udon which was more unique but still a 4/5. We've been to the location in Hawaii and the tempura here is nothing compared to it, but not absolutely terrible. Overall it's a great place to bring friends and family because of the great ambiance and friendly atmosphere. The workers yell things like "fresh noodles!!" and the phrase is repeated like a domino effect down the chain of employees. The food is good!! But great enough for the 2 hour wait if there is one.
author: Karina T.

description: First time I came the wait was 30 mins at 5PM. Few months later at 5:30PM the wait was only 10 minutes. Not as good as Hawaii, but still hits the spot. My son loves it here. I get the Niku udon and I always have to get some tempera that they have on the side. I like how it is like the one in Los Angeles where they have a toppings bar for you. Unlimited green onion, tempera flakes, cilantro, and sauces. Their rice balls aren't good. All rice and hardly any fillings.
author: Karen H.

description:
I like how the flour is from Japan but the wait is too long at 40 minutes at 5pm on a Friday. 

The broth is generally salty. 

I wouldn't come on a weekend, maybe a weekday for lunch. I really don't like waiting
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I'm about to update this later cause I'm still waiting in line for an hour and haven't eaten yet.  But apparently you have 1 designated person to wait in line while the 3-7 other people go shopping and come back to the front of the line. It's been happening 5 too many times. Hope this branch could find a way to control this, but it's not their fault.

Update: Everything was great like Waikiki (5stars)
Got the Large Beef Udon, added a bit a shoyu sauce, green onion, and tempura flakes with the following tempuras:
-2 shrimps
-1 shredded vegetable
-potato croquette
-1 fishcake
Came out to $20

Mental notes to self for next time:
-go with a regular size cause you had a lot of leftovers
-try the curry udon and the egg drop chicken soups 
-avoid the potato croquette or eat it last if you're worried about getting full too fast.
author: Roderick Xavier D.

description: I was super excited to try Marugame, especially since I loved their Hawaii location. I came on a Sunday during lunch time and waited for approximately an hour in line. This place is designed as if you're walking though a school cafeteria line and picking up food items along the way, which I think is a very great and convenient way to do so. I got a regular beef udon with a soft boiled egg and a side of fish and shrimp tempura. I was very happy and satisfied with every bite I took! So exciting to have an affordable, flavorful and presentable udon place open in the Bay Area. Will definitely come back here soon again!
author: Vivian D.

description: Recently went here for dinner and was excited that the crowd died down. Ordered my usual #5 beef udon with 2 sides of shrimp tempura. Sat down and ready to eat until I looked closely at my soup and tempura toppings and saw small bugs crawling in it. These were very small bugs that only crawls around unsanitary places. Went up to the cashier for a refund and showed him the video of the bugs crawling in my food. He quickly refunded my dinner and apologized but was left with a empty stomach and dissappointed that this restaurant can't maintain a healthy/clean environment.
author: Major C.

description:
Same as the one in Oahu. Delicious. Line was about 15-20 mins last week during soft opening. Limited menu until they officially open mid-January but they got the greatest hits so still worth hitting up. 

Update - just drive by for a late lunch but the line now is 3x as long as the first night they soft opened. Expect parking to suck as usual at Stonestown and a wait if you're planning to get yo udon on.
author: Jesse J.

description:
Decided my husband and I would be insane and come here during peak dinner hours tonight and it was one of the most delicious meals we've ever had!  I would highly recommend the regular size (seems the large size is nothing more except extra soup and the price doesn't seem justified).  We were so stuffed we brought the salmon musubi home and maybe it wasn't a good idea to add all that extra tempura either.  :)

The wait overall was 30 minutes to get into the door to ordering.  Don't be fooled by the lines!  Treat yourself to some good food, I promise you won't regret it.
author: Stephy S.

description: Wowowow. be prepared to wait in a longgggg line, but wait!!! it's so worth it. the restaurant is cafeteria style and actually located in a mall, but no worries. ordering is super fast and THE UDON IS AMAZING! the broth is deep and smoky, the noodles are firm and have great structural integrity, and my fave part was adding as many tempura bits and green onions as i wanted to my bowl! I got their special - the sweet beef and egg - and i was very very happy and full after my meal. will be coming back!!!!
author: Mar S.

description: This place is pretty good and comparable to the location in Hawaii. First time I came here was during the soft opening. I ordered the curry udon, croquette, and deep fried vegetable ball it was delicious. I only waited 15-20 mins for lunch time, but it was sprinkling. The second time I came here was after the grand opening. I ordered Nikutama udon, this time I waited about 1hour 20 mins on a Friday night. The only think I probably skip is the musubi, it doesn't have enough filling it's mainly rice, and the fish row one I got was really fishy. It's not As good as the Hawaii one but it's still beats a lot of places in the bay area for the price and they have a toppings bar with unlimited tempura flakes for the upon. They choose a really good location.
author: Susan K.

description: Very much looking forward to this place. I left with a broken yolk. I meant heart. Cornucopia, I know. So was the food. Very generic I swear. It wasn't good, more on the salty side. Just another ramen shop.
author: Dang D.

description: I am so glad this place finally opened so I can get my udon fix; still working out their kinks.  We had the Bukkake and Curry udon. The flavors are very similar to the Waikiki location. The onigiri's tasted fresh since they continuously make it in front of you. My family and I did not have to wait in very long since we arrived there closer to 9pm and the line moves quickly. Prices are very reasonable considering the location.
author: Valerie P.

description: An impressive broth and ingredients. Very tasty. But its workers could be trained more and better to deal w all kinds of ppl. Stressful music.
author: Tai S.

description:
The udon was very fresh, and it's a really good value! There is a long wait but that's probably because they just opened.  
My kids really loved the kake udon, and they have a variety of fried items and rice balls.
Will definitely come back.
author: Nicole S.

description: It's good! We came on a weekday and close to opening time so it only took us 15 mins to sit down with our food. We got the Tonkatsu udon which was flavorful and yummy. Udon is chewy and smooth. Though I never hate udon ... like the regular supermarket package is plenty delicious. All in all, would definitely come again.
author: Theresa N.

description:
We came for dinner on a Friday night. As everyone mentioned, the wait can be long, depending on time of day. There is a window area towards the front of the line where you can watch them make udon! 

I ordered the Kake ramen (plain) with chicken, veggie, sweet potato tempura. I added the crab musubis on the side. The udon is freshly made and the broth is amazing. Very simple and light. There is a toppings area where you can add tempura flakes, green onion and cilantro. 

Highlights:
Simple menu 
Fresh udon
Tempura is light and crisp. Not heavy or oily. 
Clean
Cafeteria style - ordering and pick up is quick
Service is great

Conclusion: I will be back, but not during prime time lunch/dinner when the wait is ridiculously long.
author: jen c.

description: Fresh pulled noodles for under $15 in the city and parking??? THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!!!! the line moved fast so don't be too turned off by how long it is.  Staff is friendly and plenty of seats.  Best time to go odd not rush hour though
author: Miss J.

description:
I've been to the one in Waikiki so I was super excited to hear about their arrival in SF. Make a smart move & come on a weekday or expect to wait over an hour (bring a jacket). While my friends and I were waiting, an employee made multiple rounds to serve us hot green tea. TYTY. 

I ordered a spicy chicken udon and it was just okay. It tasted like the instant udon noodles you could get at Costco tbh. I also ordered a salmon rice bowl ($1.60) and there were SO much rice and small bits of salmon flakes. 

Summary: Not wait the wait, inexpensive lunch/dinner, and overhyped.
author: Debby L.

description: Finally got to try this place. Line was a little crazy, but worth the wait. Had the #2, shrimp tempura, sweet potato tempura, and the salmon masubi. Their broth was so tasty, the homemade udon had the perfect texture, and the egg was done to perfection! Will definitely be coming back! I just wish they'd open one somewhere on the Peninsula.
author: Karla V.

description:
Base on the elite yelper's review and goods review for the business i was really excited to try this new Udon place. After driving 1 hour to the city just for that, i was super hype to eat but was disappointed right after i took the first bite.
I ordered Beef Udon and Bukkake Udon. Udon noodles are fresh and made right in front of you, boiled and rinsed out with cold water so the warm broth couldn't help it. The noodles taste 7/10, not too hard nor too chewy like many places. The broth tastes 4/10, light on soysauce (some people likes that due on their health benefit) and too sweet. 
Tempura shrimp is ok but  tempura sauce tastes like water, they don't have grind radish to put in the sauce so it doesn't bring the favor neither. Plus, all the deep fried stuffs are pre-made so they are cold when you get them. Good luck to you whom get there right after the fried stuffs just done. 
The atmostphere is good, every staff is nice and welcome. 
There are plenty of seats inside and few outside table.
No sign in sheets, you wait in line till you get in the door (in a busy day). Make sure you know what you want to order because as soon you get to the counter, you order first, they put the noodles in the bowl, another employee poor the warm broth in that then you go straight get the deepfried thingy you want then you pay. There is the bar with green onion, cilantro, deepfried crunchy flour from the tempura and sauces you can get. 
Despite all the good reviews, i am sorry to give this business 2 star.
author: Velvet D.

description:
Got lunch here today finally! 

The line always look long but now I understood why

Anyways go in and pick something from the menu

They make it in front of you

Then add in some side pieces and grab yourself a seat to eat
author: Chiu H.

description: If you had Marugame Udon before please don't come and waste your time! They don't know what they're doing. They need to refigure their SOP, it was a mess! The noodles were too soft, it should use cold water instead to soak it out not warm, the fries are cold and mushy, the worst thing is Musubi, the packaging was horrible... very disappointed!
author: O K.

description:
Line goes by fast with good company. 
Can't tell the difference between the one in Honolulu. 

They ran out of the chicken egg drop when I got there... so I'll be back soon. 

The fish tempura is a hitter.
author: Diane S.

description:
It's probably unfair to write a review after one visit during a soft opening, especially when they had a limited menu but some things need to be mentioned. The udon was very good, fresh and made in-house. The tempura was dreadful, made far ahead of serving and with wheat flour breading - tough, greasy and tasteless. The misubi was OK, although I would have preferred Spam to their bland offerings. 

Sure they'll be a hit, especially at first when they open. Let's hope they get better.
author: William G.

description:
Wait: approx. 30min 
Order: niku udon #2. There was barely any broth in the noodle soup. The niku was a bit too sweet with onions. The food was supposed to be hot but wasn't hot or warm for the matter. I'm used to the Waikiki location where the food is served piping hot as requested. I did like the load your own toppings station. People were getting soda with water cups so someone might hang to guard the drink dispensers. I might drop by here again if there's no other options. I do feel J-town might have better options which reminds me that I haven't been Mifune for a long time.
author: W A.

description: This place lived up to the hype. Definitely worth the 40 minute wait in 45 degree weather!! Definitely recommend #2 Nikutama Udon
author: Ashley B.

description:
There was a line for the line haha
I got the curry udon and Croquette. Overall the food tasted good but for the amount I think it was over priced.
author: Emilene Paula C.

description:
I went before the grand opening. You walk in and there's a bit of a wait as they made your udon. Once they're ready, you order your order and just bring it down the line. It's open "community" style seating. 

All around, pretty good experience. The food was pretty good as well.
author: M C.

description: Heard a lot about this place and have been to the one in Hawaii. We were able to stop by as soon as it opened and there was already a line forming outside. We moved quickly through collecting items cafeteria-style. I chose the Curry Udon and the others with me had the Tonkatsu, Nikutama and Bukkake Udons. All were fantastic and nicely portioned for regular bowls. We also got some tempura and salmon musubi sides which were relatively standard food fare. I personally recommend the any of the above udons as they were flavorful and the noodles had a nice chew. Will def comeback if in the area again.
author: Todd H.

description:
Customer service was excellent (just like their food) 

I didn't understand the hype at first because I thought to myself it was just udon, but then I saw the way it was operated was unique. The prices were by far super affordable and I would 10/10 come again for the price and the flavor. The wait wasn't too long (about 30 minutes) and all employees were very attentive. 

I got the fishcake tempura along with the mentai udon which was enough to satisfy my cravings being a total of $8.75 + tip = $9.01. Can't wait to try #1 at my next visit :)
author: Tricia T.

description: This is my first time coming to this location. I went at around 5:00pm and there was an approx. 30 minute wait from the time in line until paying at the register. I love the wide array of options you can choose as far as musubi and tempura. I ordered the #9 Edamame Salsa Udon. Overall, I really liked the option I ordered. It had a great amount of flavor and the udon was on point. I also got a salmon musubi which was just okay. I will stick to getting only tempura next time. All in all this is a great place with inexpensive udon and many options for sides. It is worth the wait!
author: Joe A.

description: Came here before they even open which is 11am and there were already a long line! It's so crazy, maybe like an hour and 15mins wait. Mmm... delicious fresh udon!!! I got myself the number 10 egg drop udon, flavors was fantastic and the udon was so good! I also got a salmon masubi (the salmon was kind of skimp they make it look like every bite you will have some salmon pieces but no, they piled it on the top of the triangle to visionary that it looks a lot but really it's not, but besides it just being skimpy with the salmon the masubi was delicious!!! Overall experience it was worth the wait and we'll definitely come back and try another flavor of the udon and the toppings!
author: Camille A.

description:
Waited an hour in middle of the afternoon and was very excited to try the egg drop chicken udon. It was verrrrrrry salty and the broth felt almost like a reduction. Noodles were nice enough, liked that we could put our own toppings on and I piled cilantro and onions in particular. The tempura was light overall and they had a good system to get me the items that had not been made when I went by with my tray. I added shrimp, asparagus and kakiyage and it was too much for me, grease wise. Tempura sauce was gross imho, salty and fake tasting. Staff was super nice and working so hard. Glad they serve in ceramic bowls and wish we got ceramic spoons too.

I eat udon in Japantown regularly and this was nothing better than anything I've had there. I will try it again and eat here when I am at Stonestown once a year or so but I didn't find it anything special, unfortunately. I did not finish my food and it felt like a lead weight in my stomach. Will try a different offering next time.
author: Sally R.

description: 1 & half hour waited for just a simple bowl of udon, but it is soooooo delicecious.  I'm their fan in Hawaii and really happy when they open it here.  Very sweet, cute, and polite customer services.  Despite the wait was too long for who are in rush.
author: M P.

description:
Went here with the GF a little after opening and the wait was around 1hr 30min.  As it was the soft opening still, there were a few dishes that were still unavailable, so we both decided on the beef udon.  Portions were huge and they had an assortment of tempura and masubi to choose from.  We tried the squid, chicken, shrimp, and zucchini tempera along with a salmon masubi.  

The udon soup base was very flavorful and had a rich taste to it that blended well with everything else.  The noodles were perfect, but the beef was a little too sweet, but thats personal preference.  I had the large bowl and the portions were huge.  I was barely able to finish and I worked up an appetite waiting in line so long.  As for the tempera, the shrimp and chicken were tasty while the others were just ok.  

Overall, it was a cool experience, being able to watch as the cooks made the udon for you fresh while waiting in line.  Definitely quality udon and probably some of the best I've tasted.  Sucks that the wait is so long but I guess thats to be expected, seeing as this is a new spot and everyone wants to try it.  Will be coming back to try other flavors!
author: Calvin H.

description: My friends were raving about this restaurant, which they first heard about in Hawaii, so I had to try it for myself. The line was out the door, but loved the experience! Noodles were all handmade and you're able to watch the whole process. Ordered the spicy chicken udon; it was delicious. You can also add as many tempura and mususbi as you want (kind of like buffet style), but they're a tad bit pricey. Still delicious though!
author: Grace C.

description: After waiting in the 45 minute line, I was hoping to taste what I did in Hawaii and here's my honest feedback... it definitely wasn't the same in my opinion. I had to drink a ton of water afterwards so I'm guessing there was MSG mixed in the broth? The fried appetizers also were decent but not the quality I had in Honolulu. Overall, it's not something I would want to come back to. Not horrible but nothing great.
author: Jenna C.

description: This has to be one of the best ramen places in town. The owner was also super nice when I met him. I would highly suggest going here!
author: Deborah Y.

description:
Cheap fresh good
No other place serve freshly crafted noodle. Their sweet beef is tender and flavorful
author: Hieu T.

description: Just like oahu. Nice and clean. Good food. However we all had msg dry mouth after. Didnt in oahu. Had some different udon  selections than oahu. But as close as u can get. Service was good.
author: The G.

description: Very yummy udon and best I've had so far in the city, but I don't often eat udon.  However, I still had the runs on my first visit after gorging on two bowls.  Portions are a bit on the smaller side, but the prices seem fair.  The cold bowls make the udon have a different, and in my opinion, much better texture.  The lines outside are wacky sometimes splitting 3 ways because they want people to be able to walk across the sidewalk.  But they move pretty fast due to cafeteria style assembly line system they have going.  Overall I enjoyed the experience and definitely would return during their less busy hours for some food.
author: B F.

description: Went for soft opening, ramen bowls for $5-10, nice and soft ramen, wasn't blown away by the broth or beef, nice fast casual spot on a rainy day!
author: Ryan L.

description:
TLDR: Last call is at 10PM but closing time is 11PM. They should change their closing time to 10PM so people don't waste their time coming after 10PM. What kind of food service establishment does last call 1 hour before closing.

We stayed at a hotel right across from the Hawaii location so we ate at this franchise a lot. Was excited last night to come here and check it out. We checked yelp and they close at 11. So we left the concert early at 10PM to make it here by 1020. Turns out last call was at 10 so we left early for no reason. Was pretty disappointed. Rating is for restaurant hours and not for food as I did not get to try it.
author: Eric N.

description:
This place isn't mind blowing and I also haven't been to the one in Hawaii so I have nothing to compare it to lol.  Anyway I went there today (day after Christmas) with my 3 sibs and 2 nieces.  The concept of fresh udon in a cafeteria style line is great - but why did I wait for 45 minutes? haha!  Yes, definitely be prepared to wait. Glad it was a soft opening because if it was a full menu I'd think the wait would be much, much longer.   

On to the food...

The noodles are amazingly fresh, the broth is a bit too salty for my taste but it was good.  I put fresh ginger (yuuum), green onions and lots of tempura bits.  Broth soaked tempura bites make this soup all the better. We all shared tempura and different types of musubi, all really great!  

One less star because we took 2 soups to go and by the end of our meal it was leaking through the container onto the meal tray.  They were kind enough to replace the broth and double the container.  We were smart to bag it separately and tie it up because by the time we got home after an hour trip to the mall after lunch....half the broth was in the bag (eek!).  Hope they can fix this issue for future to-go orders!

I will return when they have their full menu because I can't wait to have a soft boiled egg in my udon, yum!!!
author: Mary-Anne C.

description: Awesome Udon restaurant. Been to the cousin in Hawaii. Second time here & wasn't disappointed
author: Ashish M.

description: Best udon I've ever had. I work at the mall and I didn't want to eat here at first because everytime I passed by there was always a long ass line. I decided to try it after work one day and stick it out. The wait was about 45 mins but it was so worth it. They prepare your udon infront of you & you take it to your table. When you're done you take the trays back up (cafeteria style) so they can wash the bowls etc. It was so warm and delicious, specially during a cold night, and I now understand why people are willing to stand in line for an hour just for a bowl of udon from this particular place. Well worth it but go on a day where you have a lot of time to spare. It's not a place for you to go to if you're just looking for something quick.
author: Eljay S.

description:
recommend getting the udon w/ cold sauce.  Better texture and resilience in the noodle with cold sauce.  The nitutama udon with hot sauce was not as good.  

Overall good noodles and good sauce.  Had the bukkake, edamame and nikutama udon.  

Had better noodles in Asia and actually Paris.  Worth coming up from the peninsula though but I'd eat here once in a while.
author: John R.

description: they offer good size almost for every thing. for less than 10 dollars, you can definitely fill yourself up with something hot . what i like the most is the all you can take green onions.
author: Terry L.

description:
A friend of mine convinced us to try Marugame after our clinical rotation at the hospital. We get there and the line is WAY out of the door, but it moved pretty quick considering how fast the employees were working.

The inside was neat and clean, even though customers had to clean up their own dishes. I really liked their Japanese layout and design. It was a shame that they were out of eggs at the time I was there, so I decided to go with the Curry Udon. I thought it was really interesting how there was a section where you could choose all of your add ons yourself after you get your udon. There were add ons like fried tempura, zucchini, chicken, etc. There's also an unlimited topping bar near the back!

Finally onto the udon. The curry udon I had was one of the BEST udon I have ever had here in the Bay Area. Not only was it fragrant, it tasted even better than it smelled. I was extremely satisfied with the appearance and flavor of my meal. The curry was not overpowering like many others, I thought that it was just right. Marugame has reasonable prices for their udon so there is no way you can go wrong coming to this establishment.

I HIGHLY recommend this place, I am sure if you are an udon lover you will not be disappointed. Hopefully next time I stop by they have eggs so I could try out their Nikutama Udon. I can't wait to go back, and I'm sure you'll feel the same when you get a taste of their udon!
author: Jason H.

description: I haven't had a better Udon place in the bay than Marugame. Although Oahu location is better than SF when it comes to authenticity, this place met my expectation and I enjoyed every bite of my udon!
author: Kyu O.

description: Been here multiple times. I love how clean the food is and although the lines can get very long due to their popularity, they have a pretty smooth system for the most part. I guess aside from the food, if they could fix some of the wobbly tables that would be nice! The place is usually packed with little to no seats, so it was hard to find a good and enjoyable spot. Of course, that could be a quick fix.
author: Vivian N.

description: I always been this place when I travel to Hawaii. Saw a line everyday when i on the way to home. Finally we got a chance to try here. It taste little bit different than Hawaii. The line is not too bad, around 15-20 mins we got to order. We order 4 different kind of flavor. I don't like the spicy chicken one, it taste like sweat & sour & very spicy. For me it's a little weird. We try the beef udon, curry udon. For me I don't think I'll come back very often.
author: Yueming G.

description:
Come here often, good udon, and probably one of the cheapest meals you can eat in SF.
There's almost always a line but the line moves pretty quickly. My go-to is usually the Kake Udon, a regular on days where I don't want to be overly stuffed, and a large if it's going to be the last meal of my day. Super simple and inexpensive. 
Their Tonkotsu Udon is good, but not worth the price at all, as it comes with the smallest, skimpiest slices of pork, but if you're craving a rich broth, this is the way to go. The chili oil in the broth is pretty mild and not spicy at all.
The Kama-age Udon is a struggleeeeeee to eat and so time consuming, you gotta move the long noodles from the bowl of water into your dipping bowl (which is super small and makes it kind of annoying), and then into your mouth, and it's just so much harder than shoving food directly from a bowl into your mouth. But get this if you're going here for an aesthetic picture for the gram, the snap, or other social media. 
Tempura-wise, I only care for the potato croquette. Fried fish is good too.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Thee best udon, so good! The noodles are different from any other udon place I've tried before n was the best one I've tried
author: Danielle A.

description:
Their fry machine was broken, we didn't get to try any of the tempura **disappointing**

Tonkatsu soup was pretty good
No. 8 (some special beef udon) was pretty flavorful even served cold

However: 
Hot soup was not hot enough
Both salmon and crab meat rice balls had very little salmon or crab meat
The staff prepping the food were not wearing gloves
author: Carmine W.

description: The food is good especially for the price but the wait is entirely too long. It seems as if there is too little staff for the busy-ness level of the place. Ordered the bukkake udon and the spicy chicken Thai udon and both were delicious.
author: Kevin L.

description: You know I drove 40 minutes for this udon, and you know it was worth it. I've never been a huge udon fan, but I can say this is the best udon I've ever had. The noodles were firm and lacked flavor, but the broths and meats really made up for it. We ordered 3 large bowls which were huge, and we had movie tickets so we had to destroy those 3 large bowls in 20 minutes which was quite the adventure. I slurped down noodles so fast I lost my vision, but this only enhanced my eating experience. My favorite udon bowl was the tonkotsu, and I've never had tonkotsu udon, but I've had plenty of tonkotsu ramen. I took a sip of the broth, and the broth was perfect. It was be perfect blend of richness and bold flavor, and the broth was the highlight of my experience. The beef udon was slightly sweet and decently tasty, and we ordered the Thai chicken udon which really lacked depth and flavor. The tonkotsu was the best part of my experience, and even though I drove 40 minutes and waited 30 minutes for this udon I was glad I tried it.
author: Andrew H.

description: Marugame Udon is so good! It was my first time there and I got the Curry Udon. It was very flavorful. A regular size will make you full. It was pretty fast pace once you start getting your food. It's like a subway/chipotle except for Udon. The udon itself is pretty cheap, but it started to get expensive for me when I started to become heavy handed when I saw their choices of tempura which is really good! Because it's so popular it's hard to find seats. The workers are very nice as well. One of the workers told us everything about their menu and some of the difference between the Udon. Cold day, get some Marugame Udon it is very filling.
author: Alaizza F.

description:
Broth taste is what i had in JAPAN! Almost excellent! Kage age is authentic and "toppings" like tempura, veggies are tops! Now why 4 stars? Broth is not that hot, with the winter weather (actually whatever weather it is) it should be steaming hot to soothe the soul and palate so to speak :) The udon is authentic but should be chewy not overcooked. Maybe the time i went there, 'twas "well-done" but they should watch it...chewy done is the right way guys. I would still come back here. I am a ramen person (1/4 nihonggo blood) who live and breathe japanese. So Marugame folks hope you get to read this. You gotta scroll to all reviews to be perfect and hone your craft. Ramen on folks!

Ps: Price is spot on! I wonder why 2$?
author: Archie K S.

description: This was my first time at Marugame Udon and I loved it. I had the Egg Drop Chicken Udon which was delicious. However, plan ahead if you are going because we had to wait in line 45+ minutes on a weekday for lunch.
author: L C.

description:
Super good broth and meat is super tender. 
Tempura is nice and crunchy and soft on the inside. Yum yum yum. Before Hawaii was the closest MARUGAME udon now I'm a daily here
author: B E.

description:
What can I say ...I love this place !

Want to avoid lines?!

I usually go around 3-5 pm on a weekday! 

No line
author: Anna I.

description: Decent and surprisingly not that expensive. I do wish that the broth was less salty, though. The noodles are made fresh in house but it isn't superb, imo. But overall it's a good eating experience. Go hard with the tempura but be careful bc it's easy to go overboard with them ww
author: Kc C.

description: Unlimited toppings. Busy place. Liked the self-service aspect. Sorta like a cafeteria where every customer has his own tray and waits for his requested order then moves on. Add-ons like tempura, and such towards the end of the line, before you get to the cashier. Also there's that one guy in the kitchen who randomly yells phrases in Japanese(i think?). Anyway, I find him entertaining although my friend was annoyed lol. Udon was good. Got the egg drop one, better than the Spicy Chicken imo
author: Aina D.

description: If I could give this a zero I would! It's only popular because of the one in Hawai'i! Noodles are soggy and their fried sides were big in size, but tasteless! Expensive!! Japan Town is where I'm going to continue going too.
author: V. P.

description: When you come here, expect to line up to order and wait for seating. It could be a 10-25 minutes wait depending. Their udon noodles are delicious and you get to see them make it while you wait! I love how you get to choose how much green onions, fried tempura scraps, etc you want at a counter after you receive your udon bowl. The only thing I wish I could change about this place is how expensive one tempura and one onigiri costs. It's kind of a ridiculous price for something you can finish in one minute.
author: Nassa J.

description: Honestly, you will expect the food here must be awesome with this long waiting line. However, it is not as good as u think. Everything here is pretty much a fast Japanese food place with all the food mainly produce from central kitchen. More likely a college cafeteria place to go. Beef were precooked in a really salty broth. It reminds me Yoshinoya in Japan. Tempura with over too heavy breaded flour, it's not good taste either. I wouldn't recommend this place as a real Udon fan. This place was suppose to be a fast food place but with long waiting line these days. It turn out is not as fast as it could be. I will not come back here. It's simply not worth the wait.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I waited for months to try this place since they opened but there's always a long line. Finally on Memorial Day at 5:30p notice there was no line and ran in with my family.  
The udon is freshly made . The broth is tasty. I got the tonkatsu udon but was disappointed with only 2 oieces of tonkatsu for $9. Love the the self serve tempura stations . I will probably come back for the food but not the wait.
author: Roadrunner G.

description: The first time I came here I loved the udon and the tempura. I did have to wait 20 minutes to get inside the restaurant. But I think it's worth it. Butttt the second time I came here I found not only one hair but two... im not so sure if I would come back but I probably will
author: Monique T.

description:
Tempura station still down and signs indicate 'until further notice'.  Texture of noodles have improved since opening month, soup should be hotter imo.  The soft boiled egg is too soft (yolk was cool in my bowl and white was barely whitened) and ends up being a 'sauce' in the soup, it doesn't get cooked any further because the soup is not hot enough.  

They don't have spam musubi for some reason.  Sometimes rice is too hot and when they wrap their other musubi, the packaging forms condensation, making the seaweed chewy.
author: L H.

description: This was some of the best udon I've had! It's so worth the waiting in line! The service was fantastic, and the atmosphere is lovely! Definitely bring all who are willing to try a slurp of heavenly noodles.
author: Peyton G.

description: Very tasty, the number one tonkotsu ramen was delicious and the broth was full of pork flavor. The egg and everything else is all prepped beforehand and done well. The udon has a good amount of elasticity and the meat itself was good. The potato croquette was delicious. There's generally a bit of a wait, but having eaten this in several other countries I will say their consistency in taste and quality is similar to din tai feng.
author: Michael J.

description:
Prepared long waiting line!
Plus, no good area for waiting, the waiting area with no cover during raining.
author: SteveMorris M.

description: I have to say i was hesitant to try marugame udon because I didn't have a good experience at the one in Honolulu Hawaii. However I decided to go because everyone said it was really good. I had low expectations when I went and I have to say this location is a lot bigger and cafeteria style and the servers are extremely friendly! I ordered the #2 but cold because I prefer cold udon over hot. It was really delicious I added some tempura crumbs at the sauce station and I also tried the salmon sushi. My friend tried the egg drop noodle and got it hot and a crab meat sushi and calamari tempura. She said her noodle was too salty but I really liked mine; maybe because it was cold you can't really tell it's salty. She really enjoyed the sushi, so did I! I have to say I would come back to get the sushi and udon! But I don't really like the tempura, I recommend you to skip on that. I would come back most likely on a weekday when it's less crowded.
author: Carissa C.

description:
Finally!! A restaurant that specializes in udon instead of ramen here in SF and it's actually tasty! 

Noodles were tender and broth was light but flavorful and the beef was soooo darn good. Also got the potato croquettes which was awesome. Can't wait to come back and try the other options after the soft opening! 

I'm so glad SF is attracting restaurants like marugame that serves delicious Japanese cuisine. I passed by a Hikari sushi that's under construction earlier today. Things are looking bright for SF people's taste buds.
author: Constance Y.

description: Made me happy. Great broth. Good tempura. Noodles were fantastic and I'm not even an udon fan. The egg wasn't bad either, not sure if it was seasoned at all as it was pretty plain. Sum is easily greater than the parts.
author: Ke L.

description: Love this place and the food is great I will definitely come back sometimes the line and the waiting time it's too long but it's totally worth that :)
author: Roy C.

description: I really liked the flavors of the Udon! My favorite one would have to be the Nikutama Udon as it has a  simple yet flavorful taste, as the curry udon would be my second favorite one. I feel like the prices were pretty worth along with the large being about a dollar more with double the amount of noodles which I find a steal! Great place to just come and eat, but watch out for the lunch or dinner time hours as you would have to wait in line for 15-30 mins. Lucky for me I usually go at the slower hours where the line is at the front door (3pm) and usually wait for 5-10 minutes. Very polite and hard working employees. I have to say the tempuras are eh maybe not worth, but I would still have to get some to satisfy my needs. I also really like the complimentary free water and toppings bar. Be careful when going into the bathroom as they are gender neutral so don't freak out if you see the opposite gender in the bathroom. Came here over 5 times and everything is consistent!
author: Kristofer P.

description: Funny that I didn't like Marukame in Honolulu but Marugame at Stones changed my mind. I've tried this location many times before writing this review. The hype died down before I came for a visit. Wait time now is 15-20 mins on weekdays. Came here on a Sunday too and it was around the same wait time. The only down side is that there is less selection for tempura compared to Hawaii and the green onions are cut way too big. I wish it was much thinner. Other than that the udon and broth are both really good. The beef is very tender and juicy too.
author: Cori N.

description: i had marugame udo in many places including japan, this one at stonetown is a great surprise and worth wait in a long line. The omusibu has bad wrap pack making the crispy seaweed all wet...
author: Ray F.

description: Thought I had to be back in the islands to join this so happily surprised to have it here.  Great portions!  Yummy.
author: Eleanor S.

description: I have ordered the hot Nikutama udon today, the noodles taste good, but the temperature of the noodles and soup is too low not enough hot, also too salty.
author: Yun Z.

description: Having tried this restaurant in Oahu, I had to go try out and see if it lived up to its predecessor. I went on a weekday afternoon, therefore I only waited for about 15 minutes (if you go at any peak time expect the wait time to be 30+ minutes). I ordered the Nikutama Udon and it was quite enjoyable. All the food here is pretty affordable and for the price you're paying it's good quality food. However, the day I went they had no tempura and this definitely affected my experience.
author: Kiana L.

description: The wait wasn't too bad for a weekday lunch. I ordered #2, which was the sweet beef udon. It was delicious. I didn't try the tempura, but did get the tuna musubi. The musubi was average, nothing special. However, the udon was very delicious with the beef. The price is reasonable for a bowl of udon. I will definitely try to come back again.
author: Elaine C.

description: Came here few days ago right after I landed from NY. The line is long! But the udon is good and fresh.
author: Amy L.

description: BEST UDON hands down. Both San Fran and Waikiki locations are fantastic. This is a must try!!!!
author: Sally T.

description:
Marugame Udon is definitely a great addition to the Stonestown shopping mall. I waited a couple of weeks until the hyped died down because the lines were sooooo long. I've been here a couple of times now, and only have good things to say about it. 

The restaurant is cafeteria style so as you go in, you grab a tray, and make your way down the line. They make the udon noodles fresh and you get to see them do that as you are in line. You let the worker know which noodle soup you would like and they put the noodles in the bowl, add the broth/toppings and place it on the tray for you - so getting your udon bowl is pretty quick once you order. I've tried both the beef udon and the spicy chicken udon. They give you a pretty good amount of meat on both the bowls and the flavor of the broths were delicious. The udon noodles tasted fresh, and were so soft and had the perfect consistency to them. 
After you get your udon bowl, you get to the tempura section of the line. They fry the tempura fresh as well, so the tempura are all warm and crispy! Some tempura options include: shrimp, squid, sweet potato, fish, etc. The only con I have about the tempura is the price. It's a little pricey for one piece of tempura- for example, the potato croquette is $2.. which seems a little steep for a palm size piece of fried potato. 
At the end of the cafeteria line, you'll be able to check out with the cashier so the payment process is easy - especially if you go with a group of people, everyone can pay individually rather than having a bill. You make your way over to their topping bar and you can add tempura flakes, green onions, and scallion to your bowl. I recommend adding all three to add a little bit of crunch and freshness! The place has plenty of seating so finding seat was pretty easy all the times I've went. All the workers there are super friendly too. 

All in all, I would 100% recommend going here if you haven't tried it! I found that going before 5pm beats the line so the longest you'd wait is 20 minutes.
author: Lina T.

description: Came in on a monday and there was no line to get in.. menu is pretty basic.. you get a tray, choose what number you like and size and you can add and choose tempura on the side and u pay.. not a big fan of udon ( big noodles) but they make it fresh. I ordered #2 and it was a good. I thought i was gan have more soupy but guess not. Maybe will come back again someday! It got Pricey after getting all those tempuras on the side.. so for 2 adults and 5 year old and $50 bill not worth it
author: Neng A.

description: Long line and wait. No hot tea. Ran out of croquet sauce. Ran out of ice. Fountain drinks not cold. No hot veggie selections.  Dirty tables and floors. Bus your own dishes. Sweet potato tempura not cooked through. Potato croquet mushy. Loud rave music. For the prices and poorquality this was not a good value and experience. Japan located equivalents are on a much higher level on quality, experience and much better value.
author: Benny A.

description:
When Krispy Kreme opened in Japan, there was a long line (1 hour wait). Now, the same thing happens here. Marugame Udon is a fast food and there are about 800 branches in Japan. So, I don't think it's worth to wait for 1 hour.

However, it's fun to see their open kitchen, also, their plain udon is reasonable ($4.50). I understand there is a line.
author: Yuzan K.

description: I am so glad they opened a location in San Francisco. I had been to the one in Honolulu and fell in love with it. The Spicy Chicken Udon (number 6) is one of my favorite meals ever. The tempura is great just make sure you get a hot one. The line can be long but it is worth the wait.
author: Darius A.

description:
What a great way to start a new year with great food. 

The food was remarkably good and flavorful. I got the large beef udon with extra beef and some tempura.

The staff was very friendly and helpful, was assisted bringing my tray to the table as I was pushing a stroller. 

Would come back again after the grand opening to try some of the other dishes.

The problems that I noticed was that the wait was long just to get inside, along with it being fairly sparse on space when it comes to seating if it's busy like it was today.
author: Jeffrey L.

description: I've been here a few times with my boyfriend. It's awesome!!! I love watching the staff make the noodles upon entry in such large quantities. You pick what item you want and size and then hand the bowl of noodles to the employee adding all the goodies aside from the noodles. Then there's a mini bar of tempura you can choose from which is not all that great but I love the option. After passing you're good to head to the garnish station and load up on fried onions and fresh green onions. The staff are great which is my favorite aspect of any restaurant. I'm definitely going to become a regular here when I have an udon craving!
author: Stephanie R.

description: I love this place! The udons dishes are amazing! So tasty and you can get whatever you would like since it's a serve yourself kind of place! The tempuras are kind of expensive in my opinion, otherwise a really nice place!
author: Jae N.

description: Delicious! It's great to have this place since I prefer udon over ramen. The menu is a bit limited but the flavor and quality definitely makes up for lack of variety. The tempura is kinda overpriced but still good if you want your fried food fix. Excellent mall food and although there's usually a big line, once you try it you'll understand.
author: Jade J.

description: Super yummy udon and tempura! The restaurant tastes identical to the one in Waikiki, but definitely seats more comfortably. Hopefully they will open more locations in the near future.
author: Mable C.

description:
so good!!!  
I love this restaurant. It is not that expensive and worth to eat ( even I costed about half an hour to get food )
author: Ye C.

description:
mid Fri afternoon line not too bad.  now a reason to stop by Stonestown.  similar to marukame HI which is toridoll parent company and launched as marugame in CA.  would like a little more broth but overall good for mass production.  tempura decent given high turnover right now.  nikutama sweet.  musubis slightly bulging.
back again, tried tonkotsu with decent pork, this time was out of tempura though due to mechanical issue.  still long lines.
author: Rob C.

description:
The food is great, love the fact that the noodles were being freshly made!!! The staffs are friendly. 

Will difinitely come back here to try the other dishes.
author: Mega Team R.

description: This place is great and it helped me get into loving udon. I think it's reasonably priced, and the servings are a lot more than what you think when they just pour it in the bowl. You can watch them as they make the udon when you're on your way to make your order. I could eat this every week.
author: Emil A.

description: Worth the long wait & soooo yummmm! Great place to go to with friends when everyone is paying their own way. My favorite is the curry udon - if you're really hungry & like egg drop soup, the egg drop chicken udon is really good (it's HUGE). The tempura is probably one of my favorites & I always get an assortment - the tempura is light, crispy & perfectly flakey. I went in when I was 39 weeks pregnant & the host outside, Ewe, was sweet enough to bring me to the front of the line! I've never experienced such considerate service before so 5 stars for him - management at Muragame should be proud!
author: Christina July K.

description: Me and my daughter love eating here! She's super picky BUT will finish her OWN bowl.. she's only 3!
author: Kristen F.

description: Love the price and taste of this place! Easy and convenient with also a bunch of tempura options. Only downfall is that it's always so busy. Otherwise, I love it :).
author: Karla C.

description: Great place! Just like being in Waikiki, Oahu version, without having to travel all the way their. Best udon in the area, and great price. Only bad thing is the wait, but the cafeteria style setup makes it somewhat quick. The service/ table service people are very nice and helpful.
author: Eddy N.

description: This is very close to how an udon place is setup now in Japan. Food is ok but the wait is ridiculous.
author: E C.

description: Came around 8 on Saturday night. I'm patient and was with good company so the wait wasn't so terrible. Finding a table to fit ten people was easy too. I have been to the Honolulu location twice and this one does not disappoint. The only critique I have is that their chicken tempura isn't delicately crispy and moist like it is in Hawaii. But everything else was cool and staff were super friendly. Would definitely eat here again.
author: Dinah V.

description: I would eat here again but just drink lots of water because it's really salty. I even drank my medicine pill beforehand. It helps me eat the food I want but I still had a small allergic reaction where I got hives around my mouth after drinking their soup. It still tasted really good but they put a lot of garlic seasoning or intense flavor to it.
author: Kimberly K.

description: I'm not really fan of Udon. But when bf took me here I can't stop coming back!! Everything is fresh! & taste Great!!
author: Quiachon L.

description: DELICIOUS! The broth was soooo good and flavorful. The udon noodles had the perfect chewy and bouncy texture. It has a hint of sweetness that went so well with the rich umami flavor of the kake sauce. I got the Kama-age udon. It was a huge portion, and at first I thought I needed more Kake sauce, but I didn't realize how flavorful it was! They have a topping bar on the side with extra tempura pieces, green onions, and sesame seeds to add onto your udon. I also tried the Curry Udon, it was really flavorful too! Not like the package curry you buy in asian grocery stores. The udon went perfectly with the curry broth, but it felt a little too dense. We also got the veggie tempura, but it wasn't as crunchy as I liked, which was disappointing. So overall: definitely go for the udon soups and maybe skip on the tempura. Next time, I'll definitely want to try the vegetarian edamame salsa one, it sounds perfect for the summer time.
author: Fei S.

description:
After waiting for one hour in the cold!!, I was super hype to eat this Best Udon per everyone yelps....  Needless to say, I was very disappointed  :(
Granted the Udon was fresh - Hands down!  BUT by the time they cooked the Udon and it sits there in the tray (where it gets COLD), and then they wring out the water, then add the sauce (which the sauce was not HOT), my bowl and everyone in my parties were lukewarm.  This is definitely not the way I was imagining in Hype. Udon is supposed to be eaten hot.  If this is how they serve it, I should have ordered the COLD UDON.
Moving into the TEMPERA...ANOTHER DISAPPOINTMENT.  Ater they fry it, it sits on a wired rack were it get cold.  Imagine, eating  chunks of  grease and having it in your stomach.  Had they had an hot light over the Tempera, it would had been kept warm-hot.  Then this would had been an bomb!.  Moving on to the Musubi.. LOTS OF RICE AND A TOUCH OF CRAB... Unless you love rice... I would pass on this too.  Would I go back... NO.
author: May C.

description: I love this place. Try the tempura shrimp and dip it in the sweet tempura sauce. Omg. Super yum. I get the spicy chicken udon, but I tell them not too spicy. It's delicious. I've been to this place 3 times in the last month, that's how good it is!!!!
author: Cortney P.

description: This was not worth the wait.  I don't understand the hype.. the udon looked like it was cooked fresh but it didn't taste like fresh udon so I think their formula is very commercialized.  It had a very fast food feel, which I guess is fine if the line wasn't so long.  My hubby also got a stomach ache for the next two days after eating their udon...I would not recommend this place!
author: Sally Y.

description: I went here a few weeks ago... I've never actually had udon before, and this place was okay. The wait was surprisingly not that long since I went in the morning. I got the egg drop udon and since I ate breakfast an hour before I went, I didn't finish it. I'd only go back for the lobster musubi
author: Krystle M.

description: Good noods. No reservations. Cafeteria style-ish, in that aside from your Moodle entree the sides are prepared and available to grab.
author: Sebastian V.

description: OMG SO Good. Feels like I was teleported to Japan for some udon and tempura. The rice balls are great too. There's a mayo fish roe rice ball I highly recommend to top off some udon and sweet potato tempura.
author: Kevin M.

description: Probably the best udon in SF. Right off ocean ave and has great service and tasty food!
author: Ricardo H.

description:
Went here last night with the family.  Reminded us of a place in Osaka we went to years ago with freshly made Udon.  Great options, I ordered the Mentai noodle ( #8 I think ) and it was very unique.    Line seemed long, but moved fairly quickly.  Probably about 15 minutes and we were inside the restaurant.  

Food was great, vibe was good ( sort of fast casual type self serve ).   Good pick if you're craving Udon in the city.
author: david t.

description: Stopped by one Sat out of curiosity. There was a line, but it wasn't that bad and it moved fairly quickly. The food was OK, but I was entertained by the setup that you get to watch the noodle making process once you enter the restaurant​. You get to pick different kinds of tempura from a display before you pay. The price of Udon was cheap although tempura (depending on how many you pick) may add up the costs. The noodle was chewy and delicious, but the broth wasn't memorable. Curry Udon was tasty.
author: Jade J.

description: Went on a weekday at lunch and there was only a 25 min wait. The service was quick and the noodles were perfectly cooked. Staff was also friendly and offered to help carry my food to my table when they saw i was alone with my baby.
author: Mel P.

description: I'm so glad we have an udon place by our house, it's so tasty! After some time waiting in line, you pick your choice and keep moving down the line. The fat kid in me loved watching stuff just get deep fried, and prompted me to grab a tempura shrimp along with my bowl. Prices were fair too. Got to dress my bowl with MORE tempura (fat kid was living her best life) sat down and got to enjoy my noodles. One issue is that this place is so insane, it's a mad house trying to find a seat. Kids running around, adults acting like kids... that's a lot and I'm not sure how they fix that issue. Super good though, just take it to go!
author: Emily M.

description:
Marugame udon story 
Been driving at back from work everyday passing the Marugame in Stonestown mall making a menta note to try it ,but the line continueslay turned  me away from trying it . But one night coming backshopping at h&m which I only spended $17 dollars on some suede feel exterior chino with a ocean blue demin shirt . The Time was 15 passed eight , for the first time there wasn't a line it was a  third of it normal size . Normally it looks as as if there was a world famine and there was only on restaurant in town that sells food . But all I have to say it's that it was crazy , like Great Wall of china crazy . Just to say the company started in Japan and their noddle is special because it the only in the world that has a diamond cut . Which makes it evermore delicious. Aaccording to the host I spoke too.At the time I am one person away from the door my mouth is think of the lean Japanese style grilled chicken with bases of spicy chilly style broth and can't forget the diamond cut noddle .  8:32. If you don't want to wait for noddle I would recommend coming on a Tuesday night . I am writing this still in lines ahhh . Just entered theres a  fishing net sit over a pot with running water will. Has noddle cooking facing the streetview has you first walk in. In my head I feeling the warm fuzzy feeling .The employred are wearing English style train conduct caps accompanied by peach cream half aprons all tied together with half sleeve chef coat . They dress real western but it a Japanese company interest? . Just me being curious  but let me tell you it looks dope . I almost thought about asking if they were hire but because the work outfit looks lit . Yeah it lit .  Still in line chewing my gum imagining the taste of the ramen . The noddle is now bedding in rectangular basins the noddle is watch In two different temperatures hot first than cold  then final n hot . Than served in an Asian style bowl  I ordered  number six  .  The guy asked me large or regular . I looked at him o he knew what it was . Just tried it and it nothing special to be honest i would rather wait in line At the dmv than wait for this half ass insta ramen bull shit story "we make fresh noddle from scratch" . Yeah your  right, you make it from scratch but why does it taste like insta ramen   that probably the most exciting thing about the whole wave . First off the broth was so under seasoned  you might aswell serve me green in sweet and low . I would prefer to drink that shit and to drink that half ass chicken pour ramen bull shit that I have to wait 2 hour in line for . Thanks but no thanks I will run my ass to the grocery store and for that eleven dollars that I spent on the bowl would probably buy me instant ramen for a month .  That sounds like a better financial invest to my stomach and pocket than that bull shit y'all are serving people . No yeah I forgot I having secon thought on that job interest . Y'all can keep it . My recommendation ,not worth it 
I give 1/2 a star 
Bull shit  
But I took some nice photos though
y'all check it out
Peace I'm out
author: Bruce S.

description:
I was very excited to eat here after reading the reviews on the udon and tempura. But after the long wait in line outside in the cold, we were quite disappointed with the food. We got the #2 and the #5 and a mix of tempura. The difference between #2 and #5 is sauce vs soup. #2 was too salty for us, and #5 tasted too bland after eating #2. 

Overall, not worth it for the wait or the stress of finding a table
author: Jenny K.

description:
I don't like lines, esp in the cold.
But this lady me seemed bearable for me and somehow all 8 of us managed to sit on one comfortable table together at 7:30 pm.

Servers were really friendly, enthusiastic, and patient. 

Udons were obviously fresh and extremely tasty. 
I was hesitant about getting any tempura, but we did have some and they were amazingly good!

Much better than the one in Hawaii when it comes to the sides (tempura, onigiri).

Very filling n satisfied at a cheap price!!
author: Bon B.

description: So my family and I were in Oahu, and when we were, we literally ate at that ramen place 3 out of the 7 days we were there. Yes, it was that serious and that delicious. So when this opened here at home, I was so excited to try it out. I came during the soft opening, so options were a bit limited, but had the nikutama udon. The broth was very salty and literally tastes like salt water. I had them put the sweet meat on the side which my son loved. I was a bit over zealous and ordered a large for me and the little guy to share,  but it was too much. Def all hype.
author: Linda P.

description: I love this spot but their service sucks. I've been to the one in Honolulu a handful of times and they have their sh** together. This location always has a 25-45 min line but the dining area is NEVER full. It has nothing to do with anything other than the people working their can't seem to get on a fast routine. The udon is great, don't get me wrong, but not good enough to have to stand in line for 45 min EVERY time I come here. They've been open for a few months now and still can't seem to train their employees to be efficient. Must be a disappointment to the owners as well, because they could be turning over way more costumers and make way more money. If I didn't like the udon so much, I'd give this place a 2 stars based on the service alone.
author: Pnut B.

description: First timer and definitely not disappointed! I was wondering what all the "hype" was all about so I decided to come here with my boyfriend and check it out! It was quite a long line, but luckily the line was moving rather quickly. It's a great location in my opinion since it's located at the Stonestown Galleria plaza. You can shop and grab a bite to eat, or hit the gym and grab a bite to eat. What I really liked most about this restaurant is that the noodles are made fresh!! You can see the chefs making the noodles. The environment is great too, I love the ambience, how it kind of feels like you're actually in Japan haha. Even though I loved the experience, I gave this 4 stars because the beef udon broth was way too sweet for my liking, and there aren't a lot of vegetable options. I wish the udon came with more veggie options. The other thing I wanted to mention is that the line was very confusing to me. It doesn't start near the restaurant. Rather, it's kind of far out. The only "greens" that were available is cilantro and green onion. I really wish there was more. But the beef is delicious!! I would definitely come here again!!
author: Annie Y.

description: Very good and affordable noodle & tempura fast food restaurant.   Love the beef udon soup, inari, and zuchinni tempura.  The lines get long, but moves along fairly quickly.   Been to their other locations in honolulu and LA's sawtelle restaurant row.
author: Lawrence L.

description: Got here a little after 5pm with the family as I don't want to wait for a long time.  There is a short line outside and we have waited maybe 15 mins.  We had no. 2 (hardly any broth and it is just meh), no. 5 beef (meh), no. 3 curry (just ok), and no. 1 (my husband likes it).  My boys LOVE musubi.  They each got some.  They think it's alright.  It looks like just plenty rice to me.  Overall, I think their udon is pretty good.  But their broth is kind of weak and their topping is subpar.  Beef is just shredded fat.  The soft boiled egg is way undercooked.  There is no comparison to ramen parlor or Santa ramen in San Mateo.  Probably won't be back again.
author: Y Y.

description: Very good noodles and excellent tempura. The only vegan/vegetarian option is the edamame salsa dish, which is only served cold. After waiting 45 minutes outside on a cool foggy Saturday evening , I wanted something hot, so went adaptatarian and had Dish 4 - broth a touch fishier that I'd hoped. Excellent noodles though. Great prices (~$42 for family of four) and very courteous service once you get inside- but the wait is a significant deterrent.
author: David F.

description: The spicy chicken udon is pretty good. The soup base is not salty and is on point but the soft boiled egg is a disappointment. The egg is watery and needs to be cooked a bit more. This is an consistent problem. The tempura is crispy but can add up in costs. Overall this is good place to get your Udon if you cannot fly to Hawaii or Japan.
author: Victoria L.

description: I went for the first time a couple months ago. I worked at the mall at the time and the line was always so long. The hype for this place was incredibly high with a friend telling me it was super good. After waiting in line for a little while, not too long, we finally got in. The ordering process isn't complicated. You tell them the size and order you want, grab some sides, and then pay. You grab some sauces and seasonings and sit down to enjoy your meal. It's a little pricey and can add up, but it is mall food (technically). The udon was soft, the broth a little above warm but below hot. The meat a little over cooked for my taste and the poached egg was pretty good. All in all, it was good, but it wasn't "super good." I've definitely had better udons. I feel the place was overhyped (once again) but it's definitely better than most of the places inside Stonestown.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: To our surprise, there was no long line so we stopped by on a Friday, right before 5pm. We each ordered the chicken udon, and we were pleasantly surprised! We wouldn't say it was the best ever, but overall, it was a good experience and the price wasn't bad at all. Thanks for the yummy udon! Just what I was craving.
author: Steph L.

description: Honestly..... Idk if I just don't really enjoy udon or if this place just seriously didn't live up to the hype. Thursday at 3pm, the wait was still about half an hour. You wait in line to get the food and then get seats after. It's cool to see the machine make the noodles then goes into hot water to cook and get rinsed before being served to you. I got the beef udon plus egg and honestly.... The broth was no different than buying the bottled soba sauce concentrate and then diluting it out yourself. I would dare say the udon itself is very good and consistently round/slurpable. But... I can't tell much difference between this and a frozen udon pack. The beef was very fatty and stringy, kind of reminded me of the beef bowl they serve at Yoshinoya. I got a tempura shrimp (crunchy good), and fried battered fish (crunchy and very good), and a fried fish cake (not good and it absorbed a lot of the frying oil). I also got a mentai rice ball and it was just super fishy and not good. The rice was HOT so the mayo filling melted and the seaweed wilted. Overall, the place is not bad and price is ok but... I don't think I'll stand in line for this.
author: Susanna C.

description:
Came here for their SOFT OPENING! Of course, just in Oahu they had a line out the door. The menu was limited until their grand opening in late January (so it gives me a reason to come back). 

I ordered the REG beef udon and paired it with some tempura and musubi. That particular day, the chicken tempura was buy 1 get 1 #WINNING but all in all I think the one in Oahu tastes better. MAYBE BECAUSE EVERYTHING IN HAWAII TASTES BETTER!

Lastly, make sure you respect the rule of getting seated after you have gotten your order and have paid OR the nice employees there will excuse you out of your saved seats politely (save yourself some shame)
author: Virginia L.

description: Overrated. Soup was luke warm. Egg was cold. Udon noodles weren't that much better than frozen udon. Broth was decently flavorful. We waited an hour, I wouldn't even wait 20 minutes for it. HYPE.
author: Anson T.

description:
The fast-food of the western Japan finally arrived. In the cafeteria format, where you'd first grab a tray, order your basic noodles-in-a-bowl, then pile all the sides you want yourself, it's an unadulterated, very authentic experience.

The wheat noodles (no gluten-free option!) are made on the premise. They are pre-cooked, then reheated upon ordering, just the way it is done back in Japan. It has the right level of firmness, or "koshi": neither rubbery or mushy. You liberal commies ;) should stay home, because there isn't, shouldn't be, and won't be a vegetarian, vegan, or gluten-free options for you snowflakes. You are less special than this gem, even if it's run by a gigantic corporation in Japan with over 1000 restaurants. They run a carefully designed formula that's been tested over many years.

There are a few gripes, though. The food quality is equal to that back in Japan. After all, this is fast food. The broth is ok, but a little too salty and too dark. The quality of bonito flakes is ok, but not superb. The green onions you can pile on your noodles aren't cut as thinly as they should be. There should be grated ginger instead of blasphemous Sriracha. The noodles and broth should be served hotter, too.

But again, you can get a bowl of authentic noodles for as little as $5. Sure, it costs about the double of what it costs in Japan, but other Japanese noodle joints in the Bay Area cost twice as much again. No more $20 bowls of rāmen, thank-you-very-much.
author: Anonymous M.

description: Buy their frozen packages from supermarket and you will be all set. Same quality and same taste but without the line. I went there before 1130am and waited for 20 mins to get in on a Wednesday. Tempura machines was broken. Don't know what is the hype? Weird...
author: Ricki H.

description: About as good as the food court at Mitsuwa but with the benefit of a 40 minute wait. Broth was lukewarm, the noodles might have well been from the supermarket. Decidedly underwhelming.
author: Tom Y.

description: This place is just as bomb as the one in Hawaii. The line can get long but moves pretty fast. The average wait is probably 30 mins. Service is great and the atmosphere is pleasant. This is definitely now the best udon restaurant in SF and the best thing to hit Stonestown.
author: Julie H.

description: Not expensive and easy udon with choice of tempuras. The line is long since it recently opened so the wait is usually 30mins or so. The beef udon was tasty with good bits of beef. I like how they suck the excess water out of your udon before finishing it with a broth or sauce to prevent dilution. The chicken, shrimp, sweet potato, and fishcake tempura was crunchy and just as expected. It's basically the same as the Hawaii location but with more seating. Wouldn't wait 40mins in a line again but would come again once the hype train dies down. Basic, easy, tasty, and somewhat cheap. If that's not satisfying then you should probably go elsewhere and shorten the line for me. glhf
author: Thomas L.

description: It's good but the wait is not worth it. The amount of food you get for the price is a great deal.
author: Janette W.

description: The wait here is kind of long, but I guess with all trendy new spots you have to wait to play. Overall the udon here was bomb! I got the curry and man, I think I just found my new favorite noodle spot. Being in Stones town, parking is pretty limited on a busy day, but it is definitely worth the experience. 5/5 would come back.
author: Marco K.

description:
Solid 4 stars.   The one in Oahu does taste better, but without having to fly 4-5 hours to go there, this is a solid alternative.  The wait was about 30-40 mins long on a Saturday 5:30pm ish.

Love the Curry udon!
author: Sean K.

description: I'm not usually a big fan of udon but this place as a mind changer. I had the Mentai Kamatama Udon. It was delicious. My wife and I went at about 5:15 pm on a Friday. The wait wasn't that long. I didn't time it but I'd guess about 20 minutes. The environment is more like a cafeteria than a formal restaurant. There is no table service. Overall, I'm giving 5 stars because I simply loved the food.
author: Paul N.

description: Just as good and amazing as I remembered 5 years ago when I first had marugame udon in Honolulu. We waited about 30 min on a Sunday afternoon. The condiments bar is convenient after paying for the meal. I was allowed to eat with my dog on the outside patio, but dogs are not allowed inside when you're getting the food.
author: Diana N.

description: I was so excited to hear that Marugame Udon opened up at stonestown. We visited the Marukame Udon in Hawaii and loved the place as well. The only minor problem we had was that the broth was luke warm rather than HOT. I'm not sure if that was intended or not, but we would have preferred for it to be hotter than how it was served. Other than that, it was a good experience. We will plan on visiting again once the wait times get shorter.
author: Bella D.

description: The line was finally short and got the chance to try it out. I had the curry udon and it was good with added chicken tempura. The only thing I didn't like was that the food was not hot. I don't know if that's their style or not, but the curry was just slightly warm and the chicken tempura was not even warm at all, let alone hot since I believe the tempura has been sitting at the counter for some time. I prefer they fry it when we order it, hot and fresh.
author: John S.

description: This place is conveniently located near a shopping mall. It is a buffet style and I haven't experienced that before. Luckily there were sings posted to help you out and staff members were very courteous as helpful when we asked questions in regards to soups. It does get crowded and we saw a line forming as we exited. We arrive around 3/3:30pm and there was no line until around I want to say 5pm. They have a station where you pick which which items you want for tempura. Some options are asparagus, shrimps, squid among others.  Parking wise, it is easy to find if you arrive earlier than the food rushes of the day. The place itself offers a wide space to eat and dine but tables fill up fast. They have a small area where you can add more tempura if you like and green onions and leaks.
author: Janet B.

description: Came here on a Wednesday night thinking there wouldn't be a crowd, but we were wrong. People love their Udon! MARUGAME Udon is run by the same person as the Marukame Udon in Hawaii, which is just fantastic! The lines are long for a reason, the food is good! You can watch fresh Udon being made constantly. The food was worth waiting in the freezing cold for. Ordered a number 2 large and of course I got tempura. The beef was DELICIOUS! Sweet beef and Udon just goes so nicely together. The egg got lost in the dish but still tasted great. The Udon obviously tasted fantastic. The dish didn't come with too much soup, which I actually prefer. Complementary topping bar with tons of good foods: ginger, green onion, tempura flakes, sauces. The tempura: chicken, shrimp, sweet potato. The only one I loved loved was the shrimp, perfect decadent piece of tempura. I grabbed what I thought was a big piece of chicken, but the cashier told me to get another as well to make it worth the price. How nice! Unfortunately, the chicken was a bit salty and thick for my taste. The sweet potato, was too dry for me. Tasted kind of like egg yolk. Overall, LOVED THE FOOD. Will be back. Oh and also, the food is pretty CHEAP and QUALITY
author: Emily X.

description: Marugame udon has been the spot for me in Hawaii for 2 years. And I'm so happy that SF has a one now. The udon is healthy and soup&sauce is tasty. If the line is quicker, then it will be better. Overall, authentic and authentic. Good quality.
author: Annie Y.

description: Reminds me of the udon in Hawaii. Very delicious.I shall come back and other favors and Musubi.
author: Martin N.

description:
honestly the wait here isn't as bad as you'd expect seeing the long line constantly running out the door. went on a weekday around 11am when they were opening and we were seated with our yummy udon within 10 minutes. Not much selection but the food is delicious! Highly recommend the hot beef udon (#5). Slightly salty but very flavourful and the toppings (tempura flakes, green onion, cilantro) they offer were good too. The add on tempura and onigiri is decent but a bit overpriced. One regular size beef udon without any tempura is perfect for one person (unless you're super hungry!). I practically had to stuff myself with the tempura because I was so full but didn't want to carry it home. But it was gooooood! 

I can't wait to visit again so I can try the other stuff on the menu! This place is so yummy! Definitely make sure to come right around opening on a weekday or at off meal hours!
author: Jessica C.

description: Came on a rainy day and there was no line! Udon was super chewy and bomb, just wished that the soup was a little bit more hotter.
author: Debbie C.

description: This is the worst restaurant I have ever been to and probably will never come back ever again. The udon was cold when it was labeled hot. Weirdly, even the fried food that came out fresh were oily and soggy. Almost all of the food tasted good.
